editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p: ALL THE HISTORIES AND NOVELS Written by the Late Ingenious Mrs. BEHN, Entire in One VOLUME.

VIZ.
I. The Hitory of Oroonoko, or the Royal Slave. Written by the Command of King Charles the Second.
II. The Fair Jilt, or Prince Tarquin.
III. Agnes de Catro, or the Force of Generous Love.
IV. The Lovers Watch, or the Art of making Love; being Rules for Courthip for every Hour of the Day and Night.
V. The Ladies Looking-Glas to dres themelves by, or the whole Art of Charming all Mankind.
VI. The Lucky Mitake.
VII. Memoirs of the Court of the King of Bantam.
VIII. The Nun, or the Perjured Beauty.
IX. The Adventure of the Black Lady.
Thee three lat never before Publihed.

Together with The Hitory of the LIFE and MEMOIRS of Mrs. BEHN. Never before Printed. By one of the Fair Sex. Intermix'd with Pleaant Love-Letters that pas'd betwixt her and Minheer Van Bruin, a Dutch Merchant; with her Character of the Country and Lover: And her Love-Letters to a Gentleman in England.
The Third Edition, with Large Additions.
LONDON, Printed for Samuel Bricoe, in Ruel-treet; at the Corner of Charles-treet, Covent Garden, 1698.

div.head: THE Epitle Dedicatory, TO SIMON SCROOP, Eq Of Danby, in Yorkhire.
div.p:
I Am extreamly pleas'd with this Opportunity of renewing that Acquaintance, which I had the Honour and Happines to begin with you at the College (where you laid the Foundation of that fine Gentleman you ince have prov'd, and where you gave uch early, and certain Promies of your future Merit) and at the ame time of doing Jutice both to the Repect, and Honour I have for you, Sir; and to the Value, and Eteem I ever had for the Peron and Memory of Mrs. Behn, by making you a Preent, that has more than once already met with a publick and general Applaue; and by ecuring thee Admirable and Diverting Hitories from being protituted to a Peron unworthy of the Honour: And were he alive,
he would be infinitely fond of my Choice; in whom he would have found all the admirable Qualifications, that make up the Character of a noble Patron, and a generous Friend, an HEREDITARY HONOR, and a PERSONAL VIRTE; in whom he wou'd have found an ancient Decent dignified with your own particular Honour, Jutice, Sweetnes of Temper, Affability, Generoity, and Sene; in whom he wou'd have found uch a Felicity of Addres, as makes your Dicoure at once convince, and charm; a prightly Wit, and ound Judgment, which are eminent both in your Converation and Conduct, in the Choice and Exercie of your Virtues: In whom he wou'd have found Generoity without Profuenes; a native Propenity to do good to others, without injuring your Poterity; a jut Conideration of the Object of your Bounty, before you betow a Benefit; and then the Favour doubl'd by preventing the Expectation, and aving the Peron oblig'd the Confuion of asking; in whom he wou'd have found Prudence without Cunning, the deliberate Effect of a true Judgment; not the haty and mean Reult of meer Interet and Deign. In whom therefore he wou'd have made no doubt of finding the noble Souls and Principles of Mecenas, Proculeus, Cotta,
Fabius, Lentulus, Gallus, or Meala; a Soul exalted with a generous Ambition of no vulgar Praie; for to be a Protector, and Encourager of the Mues, is an uncommon Glory; the Prerogative of but a few, Quos aequus amavit Jupiter, and more Ages have gone to the producing a Good Patron, than a Good Poet.

Not but that Poetry in every Age, and Nation has pleas'd, and found among the rich and powerful, uch as Juvenal decribes in his time,
—Didicit jam dives avarus
Tantum admirari, tantum laudare diertos
Ut pueri Junonis avem.—
who give an empty Admiration, and a barren Praie, but want Magnificence of Soul enough to reward, or preerve the Author of their Pleaure. They have nothing to pare from their Profuenes in their Trifles; their Follies are too expenive to allow any thing to Learning, Good Sene, and divine Poetry, which like Honety, are only prais'd and tarve.

q.l: Non habet infoelix Numitor quod mittat amico,
Quintillae quod donet habet; nec defuit illi
Unde emeret multâ pacendum carne leonem
Jam domitum; contat leviori bellua umptu
Nimirum, & capiunt plus intetina Poetae.

div.p: Sophocles might get the Government of a Province for writing a good Play: Tyrtaeus the Command of an Army; but that golden Age of Poetry is gone; and at this ditance, looks almot like that fabulous one the Grecian Poets decrib'd. For now (and almot ever ince) no Arts are encouraged, that are not immediately employ'd in the Service, Ornament, or Pleaure of the Body, and thoe that adorn the Mind thrown aide as uperfluous; and as ueles as Ragou's Shirt, which wou'd make one think, if (as our piritual Writers call it) the Body be but the Garment or Habit of the Mind, that the Minds of mot Men are meer Beaux wholly lot in their Dres, and inenible to all that does not either dicompoe, or adjut that.

Hence 'tis evident, That whatever pretence the ret of the World have to complain of the Times, the Poets only have a jut Caue to do it: For let the Times be never o hard, all other Myteries and Faculties thrive, and meet with new Supplies: The Sharper (as numerous as his Tribe is) till finds freh Bubbles; the Knight of the Pot freh-bad Caues; Whores and Bawds freh Cullies; Brawny Fools freh City-Wives, or diappointed Quality; Taylors freh Fahions; Uurers freh Spend-thrifts; Lawyers freh Clients; Courtiers freh
Bribes, freh Projects, and freh Places; Soldiers freh Plunder; and Divines freh Livings; But the Poet carce freh Straw, and now 'tis as of old,
—Utile multis
Pallere, & toto vinum necire Decembri.
I might have made it Anno, but out of Repect to the Vere. Poetry can get no freh Star to hine on it; no freh Patron to encourage it, that it might be fullfill'd, what was long ince written of it by Petronius Arbiter—
Qui pelago credit, magno e foenere tollit;
Qui pugnas, & Catra petit praecingitur Auro;
Vilis Adulator picto jacet ebrius Otro,
Et qui ollicitat nuptas ad praemia peccat:
Sola pruinois horret facundia pannis
At
que inopi lingua, defertas invocat Artes.
'Tis Encouragement that advances all Arts, epecially Poetry; which requires a free, unditurbed and eaie Life, void of all Cares and Sollicitudes, which confound the noble Idea's and Images that hou'd fill a Poet's Mind. If Virgil had mis'd the Patronage of the Prince of the Roman Empire, he had never been the Prince of Poets.

q.l: Nam i Virgilio Puer, & tolerabile deit
Hopitium, caderent omnes à crinibus Hydri, &c.

div.p:
An enlivening Bottle, a pleaing Converation, and an opportune Retreat of hady Groves, Hills, Vales, and purling Streams, are things that give freh Vigour; to the weary'd Pinions of a oaring Mue,
O! quis me gelidis in montibus Aemi
Sitet, & ingenti Ramorum protegat Umbra.

Poetry, the upream Pleaure of the mind, is begot and born in Pleaure, but oppres'd, and kill'd with Pain. So that this Reflection ought to raie our Admiration of Mrs. Behn, whoe Genius was of that force like Homer's, to maintain its Gayety in the midt of Diappointments, which a Woman of her Sene and Merit, ought never to have met with: But he had a great Strength of Mind, and Command of Thought, being able to write in the midt of Company, and yet have her hare of the Converation, which I aw her do in writing Oroonoko, and other parts of the following Volume; in every part of which, Sir, you'll find an eaie Style, and a peculiar Happines of thinking. The Paions, that of Love epecially, he was Mitres of, and gave us uch nice and tender Touches of them, that without her Name we might dicover the Author, as Protogenes did Apelles, by the Stroak of her Pencil.

In this Edition, Sir, are three Novels not Printed before, and coniderable Additions to her Life; from all which, I'm perwaded you will draw a very agreeable Entertainment, which I always wih you in your Converation with the Mues, for we often eek the Company that pleaes us, among which, if I hall hereafter, by the Indulgence of a better Fortune, be able to place any thing worthy your Perual; I hall enjoy a very enible Satisfaction for Principibus placuie viris non ultima laus et. and I cou'd find no readier way to obtain o agreeable an Event, than thus by putting my elf with o powerful a Bribe, as Mrs. Behn's Hitories under your Protection, Sir, where the Malice of my Enemies, or the Malignity of my Misfortunes, will never be able to give any uneaie, at leat anxious Thoughts to,

closer.signed: Your mot Humble, mot Obedient, and Devoted Servant, Charles Gildon.

div.head: Advertiement to the READER.
div.p: THE Stile of the Court of the King of Bantam, being o very different from Mrs. Behn's uual way of Writing, it may perhaps call its being genuine in Quetion; to obviate which Objection, I mut inform the Reader, That it was a Trial of Skill, upon a Wager, to hew that he was able to write in the Style of the Celebrated Scarron, in Imitation of whom 'tis writ, tho' the Story be true. I need not ay any thing of the other Two, they evidently confeing their admirable Author.

div.head: THE HISTORY OF THE LIFE AND MEMOIRS OF Mrs. BEHN.
Written by one of the Fair Sex.
div.p: MY intimate Acquaintance with the admirable Atrea, gave me, naturally, a very great Eteem for her; for it both freed me from that Folly of my Sex, of envying or lighting Excellencies I cou'd not obtain; and inpir'd me with a noble Fire to celebrate that Woman, who was an Honour and Glory to our Sex; and this Reprinting her incomparable Novels, preented me with a lucky Occaion of exerting that Deire into Action.

She was a Gentlewoman, by Birth, of a good Family in the City of Canterbury, in Kent; her paternal Name was Johnon, whoe Relation to the Lord Willoughby, drew him for the advantageous Pot of Lieutenant-General of many Iles, beides the Continent of Surinam, from his quiet Retreat at Canterbury, to run the hazardous Voyage of the Wet-Indies; with him he took his chief Riches, his Wife and Children; and in that Number Afra, his promiing Darling, our future Heroine, and admir'd Atrea; who, ev'n in the firt Bud of Infancy, dicover'd uch early Hopes of her riper Years, that he was equally her Parents Joy and Fears; for they too often mitrut the Los of a Child, whoe Wit and Undertanding outtrip its Years, as too great a Bleing to be long enjoy'd. Whether that Fear proceed from Supertition, or Diffidence of our preent Happines, I hall not determine; but mut purue my Dicoure, with auring you, none had greater Fears of that Nature, or greater Caue for 'em; for, beides the Vivacity and Wit of her Converation, at the firt Ue almot of Reaon in Dicoure, he wou'd write the prettiet, oft-engaging Veres in the World. Thus qualify'd, he accompany'd her Parents in their long Voyage to Surinam, leaving behind her the Sighs and Tears of all her Friends, and breaking Hearts of her Lovers, that igh'd to poes, what was carce yet arriv'd to a Capacity of eaing their Pain, if he had been willing. But as he was Mitres of uncommon Charms of Body, as well as Mind, he gave infinite and raging Deires, before he cou'd know the leat her elf.

Her Father liv'd not to ee that Land flowing with Milk and Honey; that Paradie, which he o admirably decribes in Oroonoko; where you may alo find what Adventures happen'd to her in that Country. The Misfortunes of that Prince had been unknown to us, if the Divine Atrea had not been there, and his Sufferings had wanted that Satisfaction which her Pen has given 'em in the Immortality of his Vertues, and Contancy; the very Memory of which, move a generous Pity in all, and a Contempt of the brutal Actors in that unfortunate Tragedy-Here I can add nothing to what he has given the World already, but a Vindication of her from ome unjut Aperions I find, are ininuated about this Town in Relation to that Prince. I knew her intimately well; and I believe he wou'd not have conceal'd any Love-Affair from me, being one of her own Sex, whoe Friendhip and Secrecy he had experienc'd; which makes me aure the World, there was no Affair between that Prince and Atrea, but what the whole Plantation were Witnees of: A generous Value for his uncommon Vertues, which every one that but hears 'em, finds in himelf; and his Preence gave her no more. Beide, his Heart was too violently et on the everlating Charms of his Imoinda, to be hook with thoe more faint (in his Eye) of a white Beauty; and Atrea's Relations, there preent, had too watchful an Eye over her to permit the Frailty of her Youth, if that had been powerful enough. As this is fale, o are the Conequences of it too; for the Lord, her Father's Friend, that was not then arriv'd, perih'd in a Hurricane,
without having it in his Power to reent it. Nor had his Reentments been any thing to her, who only waited the Arrival of the next Ships, to convey her back to her deir'd England: Where he oon after, to her Satisfaction, arriv'd, and gave King Charles the Second o pleaant and rational an Account of his Affairs there, and particularly of the Misfortunes of Oroonoko, that he deir'd her to deliver them publickly to the World; and atisfy'd of her Abilities in the Management of Buines, and the Fidelity of our Heroine to his Interet: After he was marry'd to Mr. Behn, a Merchant of this City, tho' of Dutch Extraction, he committed to her Secrecy, and Conduct, Affairs of the highet Importance in the Dutch War; which obliging her to tay at Antwerp, preented her with The Adventures of Prince Tarquin, and his fale wicked Fair One Miranda: The full Account of which, you will find admirably writ in the following Volume.
But I mut not omit entirely ome other Adventures, that happen'd to her during this Negotiation, tho' I cannot give o jut and large a Repreentation of them as I willingly wou'd.

I have told you, that as her Mind, o her Body was adorn'd with all the Advantages of our Sex. Wit, Beauty, and Judgment, eldom meet in one, epecially in Woman (you may allow this from a Woman) but in her they were eminent; and this made her turn all the Advantages each gave her to the Interet he had devoted her elf to erve: And whereas the Beauty of the Face is that which generally takes with Mankind, o it gives 'em mot commonly
an Aurance, and Security from Deigns; for they uppoe that a beautiful Woman, as he is made for the Pleaure of others, o chiefly minds her own; and in that they are not much mitaken, for they purue the ame Coure with the ret of the World, Pleaure; but then 'tis as various as their Tempers, and what they generally imagine may have the leat hare in many of them. The Event, I'm ure, hew'd that, in Atrea (at this time at leat) the Pleaures of Love had not the Predominance, when he diverted the Hopes, which the Vanity of a Dutch Merchant of great Interet and Authority in Holland, had entertain'd of a uccesful Paion, to the Service of her Prince, and his own hameful Diappointment.

They are mitaken who imagine that a Dutchman can't love; for tho' they are generally more phlegmatick, than other Men, yet it ometimes happens, that Love does penetrate their Lump, and dipene an enlivening Fire, that detroys its graver, and cooler Coniderations; at leat it once prov'd o on this Spark, whom we mut call by the Name of Vander Albert, of
trecht.

Antwerp is a City of great Opulence and Compas, and before the Separation of the Seven Provinces from the other Ten, the Emporium of Flanders, and is yet a Town of coniderable Trade and Reort; 'tis in the Spanih Netherlands, and yet near Neighbour to the Dominions of the States. For which Reaon, our Atrea choe it for the Place of her abode, where he might with the greater Eae hear from, and meet with Vander Albert; who before
the War, in her Husband's time, had been in love with her in England, and on which he grounded the Succes of her Negotiation. Albert, as oon as he knew of her Arrival at Antwerp, and the publick Pots he was in wou'd give him Leave, made a hort Voyage to meet her, with all the Love his Nature was capable of, (and which by chance was much, and more refin'd than mot of his Countrymen, at leat according to our common Notions of 'em,) and after a Repetition of all his former Profeions for her Service, pres'd her extreamly to let him by ome ignal Means, give undeniable Proofs of the Vehemence and Sincerity of his Paion; for which he wou'd ask no Reward, till he had by long and faithful Services convinc'd her that he deerv'd it.

This Propoal was o reaonable, and o extreamly uitable to her preent Aim in the Service of her Country, that he accepted it; and having the Reward in her own Power, as well as the Judgment of his Deerts, he put him to that ue, which made her very erviceable to the King. I hall only intance one piece of Intelligence, which might have av'd the Nation a great deal of Money and Digrace, had Credit been given to it. The latter end of the Year 1666. Albert ent her Word by a pecial Meenger that he wou'd be with her at a Day appointed, which nothing cou'd have oblig'd him to, but his Engagements to her; but his Affairs requiring his immediate Return into Holland, he had ent that Expres to get her to be alone, and in the way thoe few Minutes he cou'd tay with her.

The time comes: Atrea is punctual to the Appointment, and Albert informs her, that Cornelius de Wit, who with the ret of that Family, had an implacable Hatred to the Englih Nation, and the Houe of Orange, that was o nearly related to it, had with d' Ruyter propos'd to the States, to ail up the River of Thames, and detroy the Englih Ships in their Harbours; ince, by the Propoal of a Peace, the King of England had hewn o little of the Politician, or was o rul'd by evil Counellors, that he never thought of treating with Sword in Hand; but to ave the Expence of fitting out a Fleet, had expos'd o coniderable a part of it to the Reentment of the Enemy. This Propoal of de Wit, concurring with the Advice which the Dutch Partians in England had given 'em, was well receiv'd, and you may depend on it, my Charming Atrea, that it will be put in Execution (aid Albert) for I can further aure you, that we have that good Correpondence with ome Miniters about the King, that being enur'd from all Oppoition, we look on it as a thing of neither Danger nor Difficulty.

When Albert had dicover'd a Secret of this Importance, and with all thoe Marks of a incere Relation of Truth, Atrea cou'd not doubt but he had ufficient Grounds for what he had told her, and carce allow'd that little time that Albert taid to the Civilities due for a Service of that mighty Conequence; and this Interview was no ooner ended, but he got ready her Dipatches for England.

But all the particular Circumtances he gave, nor the Conequence of it, if it hould be effected,
cou'd gain Credit enough to her Intelligence, to make any tolerable Preparations againt it: And all the Encouragement he met with, was to be laugh'd at by the Miniter he wrote to; and her Letter hew'd, by way of Contempt, to ome who ought not to have been let into the Secret, and o bandy'd about, till it came to the Ears of a particular Friend of hers, who gave her an Account of what Reward he was to expect for her Service, ince that was o little valu'd; and deir'd her therefore to lay aide her politick Negotiation, and divert her Friends with ome pleaant Adventures of Antwerp, either as to her Lovers, or thoe of any other Lady of her Acquaintance; that in this he wou'd be more uccesful than in her Pretences of State, ince here he wou'd not fail of pleaing thoe he writ to.

Atrea vex'd at this Letter, and the Treatment he had met with, for a Service the Ancients wou'd have decreed her a Triumph, gave over all ollicitous Thought of Buines, and reolv'd to comply with her Friends Requet in what he wou'd take o much Pleaure in the Narration of. But oon after he had the Satisfaction to ee her incredulous Correpondents ufficiently punihed for neglecting her Advice, and by their Mimanagement, find e'ery particular thing come to pas that he had forewarn'd 'em of. Nay, and ome powerful Men fall under the Cenures of the People for the Misfortunes, their Pride, Folly, or private Deigns had brought upon them. But to return from this hort Excurion, to her Letter.

body.head: LETTER.
body.p: YOur Remarks upon my politick Capacity, tho' they are harp, touch me not, but recoil on thoe that have not made ue of the Advantages they might have drawn from thence; and are doubly to blame. Firt in ending a Peron, in whoe Ability, Sene, and Veracity, they cou'd not confide; and next, not to undertand when a Peron indifferent tells 'em a probable Story, and which if it come to pas, wou'd ufficiently punih their Incredulity; and which if followed, wou'd have put 'em on their Guard againt a vigilant and indutrious Foe, who watch'd e'ery Opportunity of returning the everal Repules, and Damages they had met with of late from them. But I have often oberv'd your buie young Statemen, o very opinionated of their own Deigns, that they are o far from encouraging thoe of another, if good, that they cannot forgive their Propoal, and acrifice a publick Good to their particular Pride.

But I have let thee Idle Reflections (for uch mut all be that regard our wretched Statemen) divert me from a more agreeable Relation: To comply therefore with your Requet, in its full Extent, I hall give you an Account of both my own Adventures, and thoe of a Lady of my Acquaintance; and with her I'll begin, for 'tis but civil to give place to a Stranger. I hall convey her to your Knowledge by the Name of
Lucilla. She is of a gay, airy Dipoition, middle-iz'd, fine black Eyes, long flowing dark Hair. Nature has drawn her Eye-brows, which are dark, much finer than Art uually does thoe of the affected Beauties of our Acquaintance; her Mouth is mall, her Lips plump, ruddy, and freh, I won't ay moit; her Hand mall; Fingers long and taper, and her Shape better than is uual among the Flemih Ladies: To this I mut add, That her Wit is much above the common Rate.

With all thee Accomplihments, you may imagine that he was not without her Admirers; among which Number, none came o near her Heart, as the eldet Son of Ramirez, an old ordid Mier, that loved his Money much above his Sons, or ev'n himelf; which made the Allowance he gave his Two Sons but very mall, and not fit to enable them to make any tolerable Figure in the World. For the real Names of thee two Brothers, I mut give that of Miguel and Lopez, and for the Grace of the Matter, add Don to 'em.

Don Miguel, and Don Lopez, I know not how they came by 'em, had Souls as brave and generous as that of their Fathers was wretched and bae; they with Pain aw their many Advantages of a liberal Education their Fathers Covetounes robb'd 'em of; and by their natural Parts, and winning Behaviour, touched their Relations o nearly, that they long contributed to their Improvement, ev'n till now the Brothers were become two of the mot accomplih'd and gallant Youths of the City; their Quality gave them Admittance
to the bet Families, and their Accomplihments to the Hearts of the fairet Ladies: but few ever pas'd farther than the Confines of theirs; and the lighter touches of an Amoret was all that made them igh, till they aw the incomparable Lucilla, and her fair Couin, of whom not knowing her, I hall ay nothing. Don Miguel, as gay as he was, and as inenible as he fanied himelf, no ooner aw Lucilla, but he found the Difference betwixt the Force of her Eyes, and thoe of the ret of the Ladies of his Acquaintance: And as a Proof of it, he was not ooner touch'd with Love, than Jealouie; for her Couin itting by her, he oberv'd his Brother's Eyes often cat that way, and was very uneaie at it; and that Friendhip that grew up with their Years, and increas'd as they grew, found now a udden Check. I will not, like your Romance-Writers, give you an Account of all his private Reflections on this Occaion, nor the Conflict and Struggling betwixt his old Guet Friendhip, and this new Intruder Love. It is enough to tell you, that aoon as Opportunity erv'd he took Care to put himelf out of Pain, or at leat to give himelf a Certainty, whether his Brother was his Rival or not; and was not a little pleas'd, that Lucilla had only found the way to his Heart, while his Brother aw nothing o fair as her Couin. Don Miguel and Don Lopez, as they were in Love, o they were too accomplih'd to be unuccesful; and there remained no Obtacle to their Happines, but their Father's Avarice, which wou'd never be brought to any Reaon, in allowing them what was fit
for Perons of their Rank. They coming therefore to a Conultation, what Meaures to take to cure their Father of o ungenerous Ditemper of the Mind; and by that Means, accomplih what they both longed for more than Glory.

They found their Father's Avarice had not o engros'd his Soul, as to beat off all Sentiments of Religion; on the contrary, he was extreamly credulous of all the upertitious parts of religion, and particularly of all Narrations of Spectres, Witches, Apparitions, &c. they therefore concluded to attack him on that ide that cou'd make the leat Defence. He contantly pent part of the Morning in telling his Money, and counting his Bags: His Sons therefore having procur'd a Pick-lock to his Cloet, took Care to place in it a Figure that was very dreadful, o that the old Gentleman hou'd find him counting his Bags and Money when he came in; which happen'd accordingly. He was not a little frighted, and hatily retir'd, nor came thither again in three or four Days, but on his next coming, he was extreamly urpriz'd, to find the Number of his Bags increas'd, which for ome time had been leen'd e'ery Morning, o that he concluded it was a Reward of his Abtinence from a Sight that pleas'd him too much: Yet was o well pleas'd with this Increae, that he repeated his Viits for three or four Mornings together, and found his Bags decreae on that. He was very much troubled in Mind, and conulting his Confeour on all that had happen'd, he aur'd him it cou'd be none but the Devil he had een; and that he was
to fear the Conequence of taking Poeion of any of the Money o left there by that evil Spirit, and it was much to be doubted whether he had not exchang'd the whole. So concluding with ome wholome Advice againt Avarice, he dimis'd his Penitent, who again for ome time forbore his Cloet; and on his next Viit, finding all he had ever los'd returned, and abundance more added, a Fit of Avarice coming on him, he reolv'd to try if he cou'd out-wit the Devil; and by removing it from that Place, which he uppos'd taken Poeion of by the foul Fiend, ecure both the Money and his own Peace of Mind. Accordingly in the Night he digs a hole in the Garden, and conveys all the Bags into it, and covers them afely up. His Sons the next Day, coming to the Cloet, and finding all removed, were not a little diappointed and troubl'd, to think how they hou'd at leat recover that Money which was lent 'em by their Friends to carry on this Deign. All the Difficulty lay in dicovering where their Father had hid it, and to do that nothing occurr'd that wou'd hold Water, till Don Lopez concluded to make once more the Experiment of his Fear of Apparitions, againt the next Night; therefore they prepared the Chamber for their Deign, and invited ome of their Friends, on purpoe to make the old Gentleman drunk; which having effected, he was carefully carried to Bed, and three or four Statues, out of the Garden, convey'd up into his Room, and placed on each ide and corner of his Bed, with People behind 'em to flah and make lightning, to dicover to
him thee imaginary Spectres. All things being in this Order, a Matiff Dog, with a great Iron Chain, was let into the Room, the ratling of which, in a little time, waken'd the old Gentleman, who began to pray very heartily; but Fear till prevailing, as in Depair, made him think to get out of the Room, when he heard the Noie on the other ide of the Room, the mot ditant from the Door. On his firt Motion to rie, the Peron behind the Image flah'd with his Lightning, and dicover'd a white pale Ghot to the frighted Mier: So he tarted back into his Bed again, and thus he was erv'd on each ide till in Depair, and ready to die with Fear, he cou'd carce utter o much as one Prayer. Then he heard a Voice with a thouand Terrours and Threats, demand him, he having taken the price of his Soul in the Money he had removed: The old Man replied, with a thouand Croes to guard himelf, That the Money was in uch a place, and that he wou'd urrender not only that, but his own too, to be at eae. When they had thus got the Knowledge of the place where the Treaure was hid, they eaily, in the Fear he was in, convey'd away the Statues, and left all things in Order, as if nothing had happen'd; and repairing to the Garden, found the Money, but took no more thence but what they had before put there.

The next Day, the old Gentleman ends for them to his Chamber, ill with the Fright, and lets 'em know, That he had thus long been in an Errour, in etting his Mind on hoarded Bags, which ought to be plac'd in Heav'n at his
Years; but having had various Warnings againt it, he now reolv'd a new Life, and in order to that, wou'd immediately ettle his Affairs. So he divided his Etate equally betwixt them; and having found his own Sum of Money left, as he thought by the Devil, he gave a third part to charitable ues, and divided the other betwixt his Sons, and retir'd to a Monatery, where he oon made a very Religious End.

The Sons having, by thee means, gain'd their Point, did not long deferr the Happines for which they undertook this; and thus was my Friend Lucilla, and her Couin, made the mot fortunate of our Sex, if Love and Money cou'd make 'em o.
But I have been too long in this to add ome pleaant Adventures of my own, which I mut defer till the next Opportunity, having only room enough left to ubcribe my elf your Friend and Servant,

body.head: LETTER.
body.p:
THO' our Courtiers will not allow me to do any great Matters with my Politicks, I'm ure you mut grant, that I have done o with my Eyes, when I hall tell you I have made two Dutch-men in Love with me. Dutch-men, do you mind me; that have no Soul for any thing but Gain; that have no Pleaure,
but Interet or the Bottle; but in Affairs of Love, go to the mot acred part of it more brutally than the mot ordid of their four-footed Brethren; nay, they are o far from the Warmth of Love, that through their Flegmatick Mas there is not Fire enough to give 'em a vigorous Appetite, o far are they from the finenes of a vehement Paion. Yet I, Sir, this very numerical Peron your Friend, and humble Servant, have et two of 'em into a Blaze. Two of very different Ages (I was going to ay Degrees too, but I remember there are no Degrees in Holland) Vander Albert, is about Thirty Two, of a hail Contitution, omething more prightly than the ret of his Country-men, and tho' infinitely fond of his Interet, and an irreconcilable Enemy to Monarchy, has by the Force of Love been oblig'd to let me into ome Secrets that might have done our King, and if not our Court, our Country no mall Service. But I hall ay no more of this Lover, till I ee you, for ome particular Reaons which you hall then likewie know. My other is about twice his Age, nay, and Bulk too, tho' Albert be not the mot barbary Shape you have een. You mut know him by the Name of Van Bruin, and was introduc'd to me by Albert his Kinman, and oblig'd by him to furnih me in his Abence with what Money, or other things I hou'd pleae to command, or have Occaion for, as long as he taid at Antwerp, where he was like to continue ome time, about a Law Suit then depending. He had not viited me often, before I began to be enible of the Influence of my Eyes, on this
old piece of worm-eaten Touch-wood: but he had not the Confidence (and that's much) to tell me he lov'd me, and Modety, you know, is no common Fault of his Country-men: Tho' I rather impute it to a Love of himelf, that he wou'd not run the Hazard of being turn'd into ridicule on o diproportion'd a Declaration; he often ininuated, that he knew a Man of Wealth and Subtance, tho' tricken indeed in Years, and on that Account not o agreeable as a younger Man, that was paionately in love with me: Deir'd to know whether my Heart was o far engag'd, that his Friend hou'd not entertain any hopes. I reply'd, That I was urpriz'd to hear a Friend of Albert's, making an Interet in me for another, that if Love were a Paion I was any way enible of, it cou'd never be for an old Man, and much to that purpoe. But all this wou'd not do, in a Day or Two I receiv'd this Eloquent Epitle from him; for he had heard Albert praie my Wit, and he thought, that what he writ to one o qualify'd, mut be in an extraordinary Style, which I hall give you as near as I can, in our Language; and which I indeed was indebted to an Interpreter my elf for, tho' 'twas writ in French, which I have ome Knowledge of.

body.head: LETTER.
body.p:
I Have trove often to tell you the Tempets of my Heart, and with my own Mouth cale the Walls of your Affections, but terrified with the Strength of your Fortifications, I concluded to make more regular Approaches, and firt attack you at a farther Ditance, and try firt what a Bombardment of Letters wou'd do; whether thee Carcaes of Love, thrown into the Sconces of your Eyes, wou'd break into the midt of your Breat, beat down the Court of Guard of your Averion, and blow up the Magazine of your Cruelty, that you might be brought to a Capitulation, and yield upon reaonable Terms. Believe me, I love thee more than Money; for indeed thou art more beautiful, than the Oar of Guinea, and I had rather dicover thy terra incognita, than all the Southern incognita of America: Oh! thou art beautiful in every part, as a goodly Ship under ail from the Indies. Thy Hair is like her flowing Pennons as he enters the Harbour, and thy Forehead bold and fair as her Prow; thy Eyes bright and terrible as her Guns, thy Noe like her Rudder, that teers my Deires, thy Mouth the well-wrought Mortar, whence the Granado's of thy Tongue are hot into the Gun-room of my Heart, and hatter it to pieces; thy Teeth are the grappling Irons that faten me to my Ruin, and of which I wou'd get clear in vain; thy Neck is curious and mall, like the
very Top-mat Head, beneath which thy lovely Boom preads it elf like the Main-ail before the Wind; thy Middle's taper as the Bolt-prit, and thy Shape as lender and upright as the Main-mat; thy Back-parts like the gilded carv'd Stern, that jets over the Waters, and thy Belly, with the Perquiites thereunto belonging, the Hold of the Veel, where all the rich Cargo lies under Hatches; thy Thighs, Legs, and Feet, the teady Keel that is ever under Water. Oh! that I cou'd once ee thy Keel above Water! And is it not pity that o pruce a Ship hou'd be unman'd, hou'd lie in the Harbour for want of her Complement, for want of her Crew! Ah, let me be the Pilot to teer her by the Cape of good Hood, for the Indies of Love. But Oh! Fair Englih Woman! Thou art rather a Firehip gilded, and umptuous without, and driven before the Wind to et me on Fire; for thy Eyes indeed are like that, detructive, tho', like Brandy, bewitching; Alas! they have grappl'd my Heart, my Fore-catle's on fire, my Sails and Tackling are caught, my upper Decks are conum'd, and nothing but the Water of Depair keeps the very Hulk from the Combution, o you have left it only in my Choice, to drown or burn. O! for Pity's ake, take ome Pity, for thy Compaion is more deireable, than a trong Gale when we are got to the Wind-ward of a Sally-Man; your Eyes I ay again, and again, like a Chain-hot, have brought the Main-mat of my Reolution by the Board, • ut all the Rigging of my Dicretion and Interet, blown up the Powder-Room of my Affections, and
hatter'd all the Hulk of my Boom, o that without the Planks of your Pity, I mut inevitably ink to the Bottom. This is the deplorable Condition, Trancendent Beauty, of your

div.p: To this I return'd this following ridiculous Anwer, which I inert, to give you a better Picture of my Lovers Intellects.

body.head: LETTER.
body.p:
I Receiv'd your Extraordinary Epitle, which has had extraordinary Effects, I aure you, and was not read without an extraordinary Pleaure. I never doubted the Zeal of your Country-men, in making new Dicoveries; in fixing new Trades; in upplanting their Neighbours; and in engroing the wealth and Traffick of both the Indies; but I confes, I never expected o wie a Nation hou'd at lat et out for the Iland of Love; I thought that had been a Terra del Fuego in all their Charts, and avoided like Rocks and Quick-ands; nay, I hou'd aoon have upected them guilty of becoming Apotles to the Samaoids, and of preaching the Gopel to the Laplanders, where there is nothing to be got, and for which Reaon the
very Jeuits deny 'em Baptim; as of etting out for o unprofitable a Voyage as Love. Hark ye, good Sir, have you throughly conider' •
what you have done? Have you reflected on the ad Conequences of declaring your elf a Lover; nay, and an old Lover too to a young Woman! To a Woman that wou'd expect all the Duties of Gallantry, ev'n from a young Servant; but great, and terrible Works of Super-erogation from an antiquated Admirer. Have you enough examin'd what Degrees of Generoity Love necearily inpires? that Foe to Interet; that hereditary Enemy of your Country? Nay, have you thought whether by holding this Correpondence with Love, you may not be declar'd a Rebel, an Enemy to your Country, and be brought into Supicion of greater Intelligence with the French, by entertaining their Gallantry and Love, than de Wit, by all his Intrigues with that Monarch? I confes I tremble for you. Alas! alas! How deplorable a Spectacle wou'd it be to thee Eyes, to ee that agreeable Bulk dimember'd by the enrag'd Rabble, and Scollops of your Fleh old by Fih-wives for Gelders and Duckatoons! have you maturely conider'd the evil Example you et your Neighbours, who may be influenc'd by a Peron of your Port and Figure: And hou'd the Evil by this Means pread Holland, we're undone, for then there were ome Danger of Honety's preading, and then goodnight the bet Card in all your Hands for the winning the Game and Money of Europe! Lord, Sir, think, what a dreadful thing it is to be the Ruine of ones Country! but if publick Evils
don't affect you, have you et before the Eyes of your Undertanding, the Charge of fitting out uch a Veel (as you have made me) for the Indies of Love; and I fear the Profits will never anwer the Expence of the Voyage.

There are Ribbonds and Hoods for my Pennons; Diamond Rings, Lockets, and Pear-Necklaces for my Guns of Offence and Defence; Silks, Holland, Lawn, Cambrick, &c. for Rigging; Gold and Silver Laces, Imbroideries and Fringes fore and aft for my Stern and for my Prow; rich Perfumes, Paint and Powder, for my Ammunition; Treats, rich Wines, expenive Collations, Gaming Money, Pin-Money, with a long Et caetera for my Cargo; and Balls, Masks, Plays, Walks, Airing in the Country, and a Coach and Six for my fair Wind.

You may ee by my Concern for your Interet, and Peron, that the Approaches you have made, have not been a little uccesful, and if you are but as furious a Warriour when you come to torm, as you are at a Bombardment, the Lord have Mercy upon me.

But to deal ingeniouly with you, I doubt your Prowes in two or three particular Retrenchments, which I fear you'll hardly be able to gain. There is firt your Age, a formidable Bation you'll carce carry; then your mighty Bulk will with the lat Difficulties, be brought to treat with my Love; but what is yet more dreadful, your Treachery to Vander Albert, is a Fort that mut prove impregnable; if any thing can be o to uch a Pen and uch a Head. But if you carry the Town by dint of Valour, I hope you'll allow me Quarter, and be as
merciful to me as you are tout, and then I hall not fail of being, Extraordinary Sir,

body.head: LETTER.
body.p:
I Have receiv'd your Packet in anwer to my Epitolary Advice-boat, which did lately and honetly remontrate my preent State. You give me hopes, that out of your Imperial Bounty, you will have me tugg'd home to the Harbour of your Good-Will, place me in the Dock of your Friendhip, refit me for the Ocean of your Love, and end me out a Cruiing for the Service of your Pleaure: Which Thought exalts my Heart more than Punch, and makes me depie all Dangers of interloping pight of the Joint-tock of Vander Albert; for the Scars I hall receive in your Warfare, will be more valu'd by me, than thoe I've got in my robut Youth, in the Heroick Combats of Snick or Snee; when with a furious and triumphant Rage, I have chopp'd off the Foreflap of my Antagonit's Shirt, and laid him Noeles flat on his Back. You eem tho' to make ome Bones of two or three Scruples, about my Peron and Age. You ay I'm too bulky to be your Lover: Let not Errors miguide
you, Child—Portlines is comely and graceful; and ince Bulk is valu'd in all things ele, why not in Man then? You value a great Houe more than a little one, an Elephant more than an Ox; a Firt Rate Ship more than a Frigat; a Catle more than a Fort, and the Ocean more than a Fih-pond; then why not Van Bruin more than Vander Albert. O! but you ay I'm too old too—but that's more than you know you little Wag, you; and thereby hangs a Tale. I'm not green Wood indeed, and Sixty or Sixty Five has the Advantage of o many Years eaoning; in all things ele too we value Age, Old Wine, Old Seamen, Old Soldiers, and Old Medals, Old Families, and why not then Old Van Bruin? But then you object my betraying my Friend—but that hews, that you are not o witty as you wou'd be thought—for is any Man o much my Friend, as I am to my elf: I, that never part from my elf as long as I live, as I may from Vander Albert, and hou'd I not then prefer a Friend that will certainly always tick to me, to one that may deert me the next Moment; and here I hou'd be fale to that dear Friend, to be true to Vander Albert. But what do you talk of Friendhip, I'd ooner deny my Faith for you, than for a New Rich Japan Traffick. But Words are uperfluous, when you parley, 'tis a Sign you will hearken to a Capitulation, and deliver up the Fort if you like the Terms; and to hew you that what you propos'd has not terrify'd me, I end you Cart-Blank to fill up your elf—for adod, adod, you mut be mine, and you hall
be mine; I'll win thee, and wear thee, with my old tough Vigour, you pretty little turly murly Rogue you, and I come this Evening to ign Articles, and put in a new Garrion, but ever remain

closer.signed: Your Deputy, and happy Van Bruin.

div.p: Tho' I had no need of ending an Anwer to this, where he threatens me with a peedy Viit, yet the more to divert my elf and my Company, I ent him this following Billet.

body.head: LETTER.
body.p:
YOU have made me extreamly proud of my elf, to find I can come into a Competition with the only Caue and Effect of your National Valour Punch, and Snick or Snee: Nor am I les pleas'd, to find you o notable a Logician, for I love Reaoning with an infinite Paion, epecially in a Lover; and it mut be allow'd, that you have gain'd your Point in the Defence of your Bulk, and might for a farther Vindication have added, That Elephants have danc'd on the Ropes, which hews their Bulk detroy'd not their Activity, and by Conequence—but a Word to the Wie—When the Sons of God went in to the Daughters
of Men, they begat a Race of Giants—well, I don't know, If our Planets hou'd happen to be in Conjunction, what trange things might come to pas, and what a wonderful Race we hou'd produce; but I'm atisfy'd, that betwixt the Gayety of the Mother, and the robut, portly, Activity of the Father, cou'd not be les than dancing Elephants. You have indeed, urprizingly, vanquih'd my Objection of your Age, and I hall take Care to ue you like venerable Medals valuable for their Antiquity and Rut; tho' an old Lover look'd lately more like an old Gown, than old Gold, or an old Family, and fitter for my Maid than my elf; or at leat ome decay'd Beauty, that had not Stock of Charms enough to purchae a young one. But you have convinc'd me of that Error too. Alas! I fear that deluding Tongue of your's will quite remove my Objection too of your Treachery to Vander Albert. Since you go on a National Principle, and ev'n bribe my Judgment with the Complement of acrificing your Faith or Religion (which if it be your Interet, is very coniderable in a Dutch-man to the Love of me. So that I defer Propoals of Articles, till our Plenipo's meet, and proceed regularly on thee Preliminaries, at the Place of Conference, which is agreed on all hands, to be the Abode of

You may imagine, this Letter brought my Hogen Mogen Lover, with no little hate, to my Apartment, whither we'll now adjourn; for
'twou'd be impertinent to trouble you with any more of thee foolih Letters, one or two may divert, as a Minute or two of a Coxcomb's Company, which on a longer Viit grows naueous: But to give you all, 'twou'd make you pay too dear for o trifling a Pleaure. The other part of his Courthip coniting in odd Grimaces, ridiculous Potures, and antick Motions, cannot be o well decrib'd to you, as to give you a true Image of 'em; o far at leat, as to render 'em as diverting to you as they were for a while to me. But imagine to your elf, an old, over-grown, unwieldy Dutch-man, playing awkerdly over all that he uppos'd wou'd make him look more agreeable in my Eyes. Age he found I did not admire, he therefore endeavour'd to conceal it by Dres, Peruque, and clumey Gayety; Repect he was inform'd I expected from a Lover, which he wou'd expres with uch comical Cringes, uch odd ort of ogling, and fantatick Addres, that I cou'd never force a erious Face on whatever he aid, for let the Subject be never o grave, his Peron and Delivery turn'd it into a Farce. There was no piece of Gallantry he oberv'd, perform'd by the young Gentlemen of the City, but he attempted in Imitation of them, ev'n to Poetry; but that indeed in his own Language, and o might be extraordinary for ought I know.

Thus I diverted my elf with him in Albert's Abence, till he began to aume and grow troubleome, on my bare Permiion of his Addres, for a very little Incouragement erves that Nation, full of their own dear elves; o
that to rid my elf of him, I found no more ready way, than to let Albert know all his Treachery to him, and the many coniderable Proffers he had made me to win me to his Deires. But Albert, with an unuual Reentment of thee Affairs, threaten'd his Death, which was going farther than I deir'd; for tho' I had no Kindnes for either of them, yet I had o much for my elf, as not to be the Occaion of any Murder, or become the talk of the City on o ridiculous an Occaion; o I pacified Albert, and made him ee how foolih uch an Attempt on an old Man wou'd look, and perwaded him only the next Viit he made me, to upbraid him with his Treachery, and forbid him the Houe, and if need were, to threaten him a little. But this produced a very ridiculous Scene, and worthy of more Spectators: For my Netorean Lover wou'd not give ground to Albert, but was as high, as he; challeng'd him to Snick or Snee for me, and a thouand things as comical; in hort, nothing but my poitive Command cou'd atisfie him, and on that, he promis'd no more to trouble me; ure, as he thought, of me, and was Thunder-truck when he heard me not only forbid him the Houe, but ridicule all his Addrees to his Rival Albert; and with a Countenance full of Depair, went away, not only from my Lodgings, but the next Day from Antwerp, leaving his Law-uit to the Care of his Friends, unable to tay in the Place where he had met with o dreadful a Defeat.

Thus you ee the Prowes of my Peron; how unuccesful oever my Mind has been in our Statemens Opinions, you will, in a little time,
find who is in the right of it. I'm orry I can't at this time furnih you with any more refin'd Int • igues. Thoe of a Prince that have happen'd here, are too long; and I have met with none that have touch'd me o far, as to concern my Heart, which is not the mot inenible of all my Sex, I aure you: And I'm o far from finding one fit to make a Lover of, that I can't meet with one that raies me to Warmth of a Friend; but here my Letter puts me in mind, that I have exercis'd your Patience enough for once, and I hall therefore conclude my elf

div.p: But now 'tis time to proceed to her Affairs, with Vander Albert, her other Dutch Lover, which was pleaant enough, and in which he contriv'd to preerve her Honour, without injuring her Gratitude; for he cou'd not deny but he had done uch Services that did jutly challenge a Return for o much Love as produc'd 'em.

There was a Woman of ome Remains of Beauty in Antwerp, that had often given Atrea warning of the Infidelity of Albert, auring her he was of o • ickle a Nature, that he never lov'd pat Enjoyment, and ometimes made his Change, before he had ev'n that pretence, of which Number her elf was, for whom he had profes'd o much Love as to marry her, and yet deerted her that very Night in the height
of her Expectations: This Woman came now into Atrea's Mind at the ame time, to gratifie her Admirer with a Belief of his Happines, and do Jutice to an injur'd Woman. She gives her Notice of her Deign, and orders the Appointment o, that Albert met Catalina, (for that was her Name) for Atrea, and poes'd her with all the Satisfaction of a longing Lover: But Catalina, infinitely pleas'd with the Adventure, appoints the next Night, and the following; and finding his Tranports till freh and high, began to confide in her own Charms; and keeping him longer than uual, made the Day dicover a double Diappointment of her in her future Pleaures, and him in the pat, for he cou'd not forgive her ev'n the Joys he had imparted by the fale Bait of another's Charms, but flung from her with the highet Reentment and Indignation, and return'd to Atrea to upbraid her with her ungenerous Dealing; who, for her Plea, urg'd his Duty to his Wife, and how unreaonable it was in him, to deire the acrificing of the Reputation of the Woman he profes'd to love.

Tho' Albert was forc'd to acquiece in what he aid, he cou'd not loe his Deire, now increas'd by the Pleaure of Revenge, which he promis'd himelf in the Enjoyment of her, ev'n againt her Will, and almot without her Knowledge. Mrs. Behn had an old Woman of near Threecore, which, out of Charity, he kept as her Companion, having been an old decay'd Gentlewoman; but he, guilty of the common Vice of Age, Avarice, till covetous of what they cannot enjoy, was corrupted by Albert's
Gold, to put him dres'd in her Night-cloaths to Bed in her Place (for he made her her Bedfellow) when Atrea was out at a Merchant's of Antwerp, paing the Ev'ning in Play, and Mirth as her Age, and Gayety requir'd: The Son of which Merchant was a brisk, lively, frolickome young Fellow, and with his two Siters, and ome Servants, waited on Atrea home; and as a Concluion of that Night's Mirth, propos'd to go to bed to the old Woman and urprize her, whilt they hou'd all come in with the Candles, and compleat the merry Scene: As it was agreed, o they did, but the young Spark was more urpriz'd when, in the Encounter, he found himelf met with an unexpected Ardour, and a Man's Voice, aying, Have I now caught thee, thou malicious Charmer; now I'll not let thee go till thou hat done me Jutice for all the Wrongs thou hat offer'd my doating Love.

By this time the ret of the Company were come in, all extreamly urpriz'd to find Albert in Atrea's Bed, intead of the old Woman; who being thus dicover'd, and Albert appeas'd with a Promie to marry him at her Arrival in England, was dicarded to provide for her elf according to her Deerts: But Albert taking his leave of her with a heavy Heart, and returning into Holland to make all things ready for his Voyage to England, and Matrimony, dy'd at Amsterdam of a Fever. Whilt Astrea proceeded in her Journey to Otend, and Dunkirk, where, with Sir Bernard Gacoign, and others, he took Shipping for England; in which hort Voyage he met with a trange Appearance,
that was viible to all the Paengers and Ship's-Crew. Sir Bernand Gacoign had brought with him from Italy everal admirable Telecopes and Propective-Glaes, and looking through one of them, when the Day was very calm and clear, epy'd a trange Apparition floating on the Water, which was alo een by all in their turns that look'd through it, which made 'em conclude that they were painted Glaes that were put at the ends on purpoe to urprize and amue thoe that look'd through 'em; till after having taken 'em out, rubb'd, and put 'em in again, they found the ame thing floating toward the Ship and which was now come o near as to be within View without the Glas; I've often heard her aert, that the whole Company aw it: The Figure was this: A fourquare Floor of various colour'd Marble, from which acended rows of fluted and twited Pillars, embos'd • ound with climbing Vines and Flowers, and waving Streamers, that receiv'd an eaie Motion from the Air; upon the Pillars a hundred little Cupids clamber'd with flutt'ring Wings. This trange Pageant came almot near enough for one to tep out of the Ship into it before it vanih'd; after which, and a hort Calm, followed o violent a Storm, that having driv'n the Ship upon the Coats, he plit in •• ght of Land, but the People, by the help of the Inhabitants, and Boats from hoar, were all av'd; and our Atrea arriv'd afe, tho' tir'd, to London, from a Voyage that gain'd her more Reputation than Profit.

The Ret of her Life was entirely dedicated to Pleaure and Poetry; the Succes in which
gain'd her the Acquaintance and Friendhip of the mot enible Men of the Age; and the Love of not a few of different Characters; for tho' a Sot have no Portion of Wit of his own, he yet like Old Age, covets what he cannot enjoy. I can't allow a Fool to be touch'd with the Charms of Wit, but the Reputation that is gain'd by Wit; which being a thing beyond his Reach, he is fond of it becaue it pleaes others, not himelf: Our Atrea had many of thee, who profes'd not a little Love for her, and whom he us'd as Fools hou'd be us'd, for her Sport, and the Diverion of her better Acquaintance. I went to viit her one Day, and found with her a young brisk pert Fop very gayly dres'd, and who after an Abundance of Impertinence, left us. His Figure was o extraordinary, that I cou'd not but enquire into his Name, and more particular Character, which Atrea gave me in the following manner.

This is a young vain Coxcomb, but newly come from the Univerity, and full of the impudent elf-Opinion, and Pride of that Place, takes the common Privilege of being very impertinent in all Company, epecially among Women, and Men that undertand not the Jargon of the Schools. He's of a good Family, and was left a pretty good paternal Etate, which he endeavour'd to encreae by marrying a rich Aunt he had in the Country, who had Occaion for jut uch a Fop; for tho' he has not been two Years from Oxford, he has met with everal uncommon Adventures, and among the ret, his Addrees to me hall not be the leat coniderable for all our Diverions.

Going down to take Poeion of his Paternal Etate, and full of no very good Thoughts of wronging his Brothers, he lay at this Aunts's; who, tho' none of the younget, was not old enough yet to have given off all Thoughts of Love, or to be exempted from the Effects of Enjoyment; for after a long Intrigue with the Steward of her Etate, he was, or imagin'd at leat, that he was with Child; and tho' he lik'd him well enough for a Gallant, he cou'd by no means think him fit for a Husband, either becaue her Pride wou'd not permit her to think of her Servant for her Mater, or that he fear'd to give him a Power over her Conduct, who had been a Witnes how weak a Guard of Virtue he had to ecure the conjugal Duty, he might expect from her as her Husband: But whatever was the Motive, the Arrival of her Nephew gave her other Thoughts, finding him a fit Coxcomb for her ends; for you find, that a little Converation will let you into his Character, at leat, o far as to dicover him to be a very elf-conceited Fool, and one on whom by Conequence, Flattery wou'd have no mall Effect. His Aunt having made this Dicovery, took Care to detain him ome Days longer than he intended, and by all the cunning Arts of a deigning Woman, gave him Caue to believe that his Suit wou'd not be very unuccesful, if he hou'd make his Addrees to her. He naturally thought well of himelf, and fir'd with o many Advances that his Aunt made to him, he reolv'd to trie if he cou'd gain her.

She was a Woman that had yet a Ret of Beauty, improv'd too by the help of Art, that he might pretend, without vanity, to a conquet, where no brighter or more youthful Faces interpos'd; to this he had an engaging Air, and a prightly Converation: but that which compleated the Victory over our young Spark, was her Etate; that was exceeding beautiful, becaue very great, and, join'd with her other Charms, was not to be reited by a Man who was poes'd with the contrary Vices of Avarice and Prodigality. For he had till a thirt of Wealth, which he perpetually quander'd; for he was incapable of doing a generous Action, though he wou'd do many foolih ones, which eem'd to him worthy that Name, as particularly that which I'm jut going to relate after his Marriage with his Aunt, for there ended this Amour.

Some mall time after the conummation of the Nuptials, finding her fears of being with Child vain, and quite tired of the Fool her Husband, he perpetually was contriving how to get handomly rid of him; for though he eem'd to love her well enough for a Wife, yet he was too watchful of her motions to give her opportunity of thoe Pleaures he had o long taken with liberty. This made her very ill humour'd and cros; which he endeavour'd, by pleaing her all the ways he cou'd think of, to remove: But all in vain, unles he cou'd remove himelf, and his legal Right to her Etate, all his Carees and Complaiance ignified nothing. In hort, after he had acted this part ome time, and made him very earnet
in the enquiry into the caue of her Chagrin, he inform'd him, that he was very enible the chief motive that engag'd him to make love to her was her Etate, and that all his profeions of Love were only fale baits to delude her too credulous Heart, and catch her Etate; that he cou'd never forgive herelf, being overreach'd by o unexperienc'd a Youth, or ever have patience to upport the affliction this gave her.

He us'd all the Arguments he could think of to convince her of her Error, and that he lov'd her with a incere and tender Paion, without any regard to her Etate, of which he was as entirely Mitres as before. In vain was all he aid, he turn'd it to a contrary end to what he meant it; told him 'twas eaie profeing his Love incere, when he was in poeion of the fruits of his pat Diimulation, and that he cou'd never believe her Fortune had no hare in his Affections, as long as he was Mater of it whether he wou'd or not; that he mut depair, being o much older than him, of long being able o much as of a cold Civility, when it was out of her power to give him any more. He, out of a foolih fanie of Generoity, or exceive good Opinion of his own Charms and Power over her, tells her he has now thought of a way to atisfie her Doubts, and, by a convincing proof of his Love, remove all thoe Anxieties that gave her o much Pain, and robb'd him of his Ret and Satisfaction; for to hew her that it was her Peron, and that alone which he eteem'd, he would immediately put her Fortune into her own poeion again, and
keep no other Right he had to any thing of hers but her Peron, which was the Treaure he only coveted a quiet enjoyment of.

This was the point he had all this while been lab'ring to gain, and you may imagine he lot not the lucky Minute of the Fools ridiculous Fondnes. The Writings were made, and he put in abolute poeion of all her Fortune, and had therefore no farther need of a longer Diimulation; nay, the curb that had been et on her unruly Will for the hort time of their Marriage, provok'd her to oberve no meaures with him, whom he could not forgive the many Pleaures he had diappointed her of. He was firt tormented with freh Proofs, ev'ry day, of his being a notorious Cuckold, to which were added the Affronts of the Servants, and the Contempt of the Mitres; and when none of thee wou'd rid her hands of him whoe ight he loath'd, having taken particular care to have him well beaten, he thrut him out of doors, to provide for himelf. His late treatment made him unwilling to return, for fear of a wore reception; and ince he had found all means ineffectual to reclaim her, he concluded to pas on to his own Etate, and from thence to London, out of the hearing himelf the perpetual Dicoure of the Countrey.

He had not been long in Town, when one day, walking in the Park, in a very mean Condition, (his own Etate being then eiz'd by his Brothers, for the repayment of what he had wrong'd 'em of,) he ees his Wife alone, and though maqu'd, knows her; his Neceities prompted him at leat to try if the making himelf
Mater of her Peron, and playing the Tyrant in his turn, would not furnih him with a preent Supply, if not recover him the Poeion of her Etate, by cancelling the Deed that put it in her power to abue him. She was very well dres'd, and he omething habby; he eizes her, ues all the Arguments he could to peruade her Reformation, and Re-union to a Man that yet had a value for her; but all in vain. He told her plainly he would keep her Peron, though he had nothing to do with her Etate; 'twas in vain for her to truggle, o he went with him to the Hore-Guards, contriving all the way how to get rid of him; and being come there, on ome occaion there happen'd to be a great concoure of People: This gave her a lucky hint, and tarting from him, he ought the Protection of the Mobb, auring them he was a paultry Scoundrel, that would needs pretend to educe her to his Ends, but on denial, had, on his threats, prevail'd with her to go quietly to that place, where he hop'd her Recue. He aur'd them he was her Husband, and that he only meant to reclaim her from her evil coures, and carry her home. She, with all the aurance imaginable, laughing at his Aertion, deir'd 'em to conider if that Man look'd like her Husband. Her Dres and Mien had engag'd a Gentleman of the Guards to epoue her Quarrel, and preventing the Deciion of the Mobb, declar'd his Opinion in the Lady's favour, and propos'd the giving him the civility of the Hore-pond: which hitting the brutal pleaure of the Mobb, prevail'd, and o the poor Knight was carry'd to the Enchanted
Catle, and the Lady et free, for more agreeable Encounters; for he was not ungrateful to her Deliverer.

This unlucky Adventure was no mall check to his Hopes, and unopinion of his own Conduct and Judgment; yet about half a year after, being now more gay, by the recovery of his Etate, and walking in the Park again, he meets his treacherous Spoue, and full of the Injury he had lat received from her, and out of fear of the like Misfortune, his Dres being now anwerable to her's, he upbraids her with what was pat, and aures her nothing hall now deliver her from him; and o endeavouring to force her out again at the Hore-Guards, where he enter'd, and near which he met her, he, by her cunning, and eeming orrow for what had pat, prevail'd with him to go out at St. James's; and being got out of the Gate, he makes to the firt Coach very peaceably with him, where he found three Gentlemen who waited ready for her, and on her approach came out, deliver'd her from her Husband, and without much difficulty carry'd her off.

Being thus again out-witted by her, and eeing no help for his deperate Condition, he gave over all thought of her, and et his mind on ome freh Amour, to wear off the uneaie remembrance of his pat Adventures. Among the ret that were doom'd to uffer his Addrees, it has been my fate, of late, to hare the ill luck, tho' I have the advantage of a great deal of good Company to atone for the impertinent Moments he taxes me with, his Converation diverting ometimes ome of my bet Friends, and
his Letters my elf; they are o affectedly ridiculous, that I will hew you one of them extraordinary in its kind.

body.head: To the incomparable fine hands of the Seraphick Atrea.
body.p:
SHou'd I make a Palinode for the Aggreions of my Paion, I hould diappoint the Jutice of your Expectations; for without any periodical flourihes, you know your Wit has irreitable Charms; and that we can no more reit the deire of imparting our Pain when the Paroxim approaches, than a ick Man in a Fever the deire of Water. The Horocope of my Love for the bright Atrea roe under a very noxious Influence, if its Stars ordain it abortive. You, Madam, that are Mitres of the Encyclopedy of the Sciences, who have the whole Galaxy of the Mues to attend you, that have the Corrucations of the Night in your Eyes, Jove's Bolts and Lightning in your Frowns, and the Sheers of the three fatal Siters in your Anger, hou'd alo have the commieration of the Gods in the Tribunal of your Heart, to preponderate to the Severity of your Jutice. The wie Ancients, among their other Hieroglyphicks, made Jutice Blind, that he might ee and dicover the everal hares and proportions due to the everal Pretenders to her Favour. You, Madam, are the Portraiture, the admirable Icon of that Jutice whoe Name you bear,
Terras Atraea reliquit: that is,
"'Tis full well known,
"That Jutice is flown.
Yet, mot Serene Fair One, he poees your Breat, there he nidificates, there he erects her Bower, and there I hope to have her declare in the favour of, Madam,

closer.signed: Your mot Obequious Humble Servant, and Non pareil Admirer, &c.

div.p: This, indeed, is the Soul of a meer Academic, that is, of one whom Learning, ill undertood, has fitted for a publick Coxcomb, and of whom there is carce any one o ignorant, as to have a good Opinion. You have, indeed, reply'd I, a mot extraordinary Lover of him, but whoe folly is too gros to be o long entertaining as he hall think fit to be impertinent; for, like common Beggars, they are not to be denied; and are o far Courtiers, to think perpetual Importunities merit; o that if you have no way of ridding your hands of him but laughing at him, 'twill never do; for a Fool follows you the more for laughing at him, as a Spaniel does for beating of him.

Why truly (reply'd Atrea) he is grown o troubleome now, that I hall be forced to ue him as bad as his Wife has done, in my own defence; and that I intend to put in execution the more peedily, ince I find my Lyander grows uneaie at his Addrees, which can never move any thing but laughter; however I hall eaily acrifice o trifling a Sport to the Quiet of the Man I love, in which you mut ait me; for Lyander hall have no hand in it, both to ecure him from a Quarrel, and my elf the pleaure of revenging him on a Fop that could hope, where he had poeion.

I promis'd to give her all the Aitance I was capable of, to gratifie o reaonable a Revenge; for if one Man affronts another by his Rudenes, the Peron affronted mut be look'd upon as a Coward, if he take not Satisfaction: I can imagine no reaon in the world, why a Woman of Wit, that is affronted with the aucy impertinent Love of a Fool that will not be denied, hou'd not punih his In • olence according to her power: Wit is the Weapon he had to fight with, and that he was to make ue of in her Satisfaction; to which, as a Second, I was very willing to contribute; though the Part he afterwards engag'd me to play was not o agreeable to me as I at firt imagin'd; for to give a conceited Coxcomb any reaon to believe he has an Acendant over a Woman, and then allow him the leat Opportunity, is to put her elf in a manifet hazard of her Honour and Satisfaction. But this I did not much conider, being willing to free my Friend from the Importunities of one he cou'd no more uffer, than know how to be handomly rid of.

And upon her Peruaion, I took the opportunity of his next Viit, to give him all the reaon imaginable to make him think me extremely taken with his Peron: Which Interview Atrea took care to improve on my departure, and to let him know that I was a Peron of no les Fortune than Quality, which wou'd repair the los of an unfaithful Wife. Flattery, as it has ome power on the mot Senible, o it is of uch force with a Fool, that no Conideration can withtand it. He oon thought the puruit of me more eligible, where he imagin'd his Perfections
had made uch an impreion, that I cou'd no more reit the Charm, than the barren Paion he had hitherto entertain'd for Atrea. In hort, he came to a perfect undertanding, and the Aignation was made, and ome Friends provided to be in readines to diappoint him, when he mot thought me his own. But the Gentlemen retir'd to the Balcony, to ee ome udden Hubbub in the Street, and my Lover, full of himelf, and the opinion of my being wholly at his devotion, pres'd o hard for the victory, that when nothing ele wou'd ecure me; I was forc'd to cry out: On which the Gentlemen approach'd, and he believing one of 'em my Husband, was in a mot dreadful fright, and oon dicover'd the baenes of his Spirit; for in hopes to get clear off himelf, accus'd me to him he uppos'd my Husband. But this not availing, he was handomly tos'd in a Blanket, wah'd, and turn'd out of doors. All which Misfortunes he diembl'd to Atrea, and renew'd his Suit to her; till by appointment, I and the two Gentlemen enter'd the Room, and expos'd the truth of the Story: which he cou'd not deny; and, confounded with the Reproaches of Atrea, and the whole Company's laughing at him, he never after troubl'd her with a Viit.

This was the end of this ridiculous Amour. But that which touch'd her Heart, cou'd not be o eaily dipos'd of. I have already mention'd Lyander, as a Lover he valu'd; and he having contributed her Letters to him, to the lat Impreion, I hall ay no more of it than what thoe dicover, which I have now inerted in their order.

div.head: LOVE-LETTERS To a Gentleman, BY Mrs. A. BEHN.
Printed from the Original Letters.

body.head: LETTER I.
body.p:
YOU bid me write, and I wih it were only the Effects of Complaiance that makes me obey you: I hou'd be very angry with my elf and you, if I thought it were any other Motive: I hope it is not, and will not have you believe otherwie. I cannot help, however, wihing you no Mirth, nor any content in your Dancing Deign; and this unwonted Malice in me I do not like, and wou'd have conceal'd it if I cou'd, let you hou'd take it for omething which I am not, nor will believe my elf guilty of. May your Women be all Ugly, Ill-natur'd, Ill-dres'd, Ill-fahion'd, and Unconverable; and, for your greater Diappointment,
may every Moment of your Time there be taken up with Thoughts of Me, (a ufficient Cure,) and yet you will be better entertain'd than Me, who poibly am, and hall be, uneaie with Thoughts not o good. Perhaps you had eas'd me of ome Trouble, if you had let me een you, or known you had been well: but thee are Favours for better Friends; and I'll endeavour not to reent the los, or rather the mis of 'em. It may be, ince I have o eaily granted this Deire of yours, in writing to you, you will fear you have pull'd a Trouble on—But do not: I do, by this, end for you—You know what you gave your Hand upon; the Date of Banihment is already out, and I cou'd have wih'd you had been o Good-natur'd as to have diobey'd me. Pray take notice therefore I am better Natur'd than you: I am profoundly Melancholy ince I aw you; I know not why; and hould be glad to ee you when your Occaions will permit you to viit

body.head: LETTER II.
body.p:
YOU may tell me a Thouand Years, my dear Lycidas, of your unbounded Friendhip; but after o unkind a Departure as that lat Night, give me leave (when erious) to doubt it; nay, 'tis pat doubt: I know you
rather hate me: What ele could hurry you from me, when you aw me urrounded with all the neceary Impoibilities of peaking to you? I made as broad Signs as one could do, who durt not peak, both for your ake and my own: I acted even imprudently, to make my Soul be undertood, that was then (if I may ay o) in real Agonies for your Departure. 'Tis a wonder a Woman o violent in all her Paions as I, did not (forgetting all Prudence, all Coniderations) fly out into abolute Commands, or at leat Entreaties, that you would give me a Moment's time longer. I burt to peak with you, to know a thouand things; but particularly, how you came to be o barbarous, as to carry away all that cou'd make my Satisfaction. You carry'd away my Letter, and you carry'd away Lycidas; I will not call him mine, becaue he has o unkindly taken himelf back. 'Twas with that Deign you came; for I aw all night with what reluctancy you poke, how coldly you entertain'd me, and with what pain and uneaines you gave me the only Converation I value in the World. I am aham'd to tell you this: I know your peevih Vertue will mi-interpret me: But take it how you will, think of it as you pleae; I am undone, and will be free; I will tell you, you did not ue me well: I am ruin'd, and will rail at you.—Come then, I conjure you, this Evening, that after it I may hut thoe Eyes that have been too long waking. I have committed a thouand Madnees in this; but you mut pardon the Faults you have created. Come and do o; for I mut ee you to
Night, and that in a better Humour than you were lat Night. No more; obey me as you have that Friendhip for me you profes; and aure your elf to find a very welcome Reception from

body.head: LETTER III.
body.p:
WHEN hall we undertand one another? For I thought, dear Lycidas, you had been a Man of your Parole: I will as oon believe you will forget me, as that you have not remember'd the Promie you made me. Confes you are the teazinget Creature in the World, rather than uffer me to think you neglect me, or wou'd put a light upon me, that have choen you from all the whole Creation, to give my entire Eteem to. This I had aur'd you Yeterday, but that I dreaded the Effects of your Cenure to Day; and though I corn to guard my Tongue, as hoping 'twill never offend willingly; yet I can, with much adoe, hold it, when I have a great mind to ay a thouand things I know will be taken in an ill ence. Poibly you will wonder what compells me to write, what moves me to end where I find o little Welcome; nay, where I meet with uch Returns, it may be I wonder too.
You ay I am chang'd: I had rather almot jutifie an Ill, than Repent, maintain fale Arguments, than yield I am i'th' Wrong. In fine, Charming Friend Lycidas, whatever I was ince you knew me, believe I am till the ame in Soul and Thought; but that is, what hall never hurt you, what hall never be but to erve you; Why then did you ay you wou'd not it near me? Was that, my Friend, was that the Eteem you profes? Who grows cold firt? Who is chang'd? and Who the Aggreor? 'Tis I was firt in Friendhip, and hall be lat in Contancy: You, by Inclination, and not for want of Friends, have I plac'd highet in my Eteem; and for that Reaon your Converation is the mot acceptable and agreeable of any in the World—and for this Reaon you hun mine: Take your coure; be a Friend like a Foe, and continue to impoe upon me, that you eteem me when you flie me: Renounce your fale Friendhip, or let me ee you give it entire to

body.head: LETTER IV.
body.p:
I Had rather, dear Lycidas, et my elf to write to any Man on Earth than you; for I fear your evere Prudence and Dicretion, o nice, may make an ill Judgment of what I ay: Yet you bid me not diemble; and you need not have
caution'd me, who o naturally hate thoe little Arts of my Sex, that I often run on freedoms that may well enough bear a Cenure from People o crupulous as Lycidas. Nor dare I follow all my Inclinations neither, nor tell all the little Secrets of my Soul: Why I write them, I can give no account; 'tis but fooling my elf, perhaps, into an Undoing. I do but (by this oft Entertainment) rook in my Heart, like a young Gameter, to make it venture its lat Stake: This, I ay, may be the Danger; I may come off unhurt, but cannot be a Winner: Why then hou'd I throw an uncertain Cat, where I hazard all, and you nothing? Your tanch Prudence is Proof againt Love, and all the Bank's on my ide: You are o unreaonable, you wou'd have me pay, where I have contracted no Debt; you wou'd have me give, and you, like a Mier, wou'd ditribute nothing. Greedy Lycidas! Unconcionable! and Ungenerous! You wou'd not be in Love, for all the World, yet wih I were o, Uncharitable!—Wou'd my Fever Cure you? or a Cure on me, make you Bles'd? Say, Lycidas, Will it? I have heard, when two Souls kindly meet, 'tis a vat Pleaure, as vat as the Cure mut be, when Kindnes is not equal; and why hou'd you believe that neceary for me, that will be o very incommode for you? Will you, Dear Lycidas, allow then, that you have les Good-nature than I? Pray be Jut, till you can give uch Proofs of the contrary, as I hall be Judge of; or give me a Reaon for your Ill-nature. So much for Loving.
