Now, as you are my Friend, I conjure you to conider what Reolution I took up, when I aw you lat, (which methinks is a long time) of eeing no Man till I aw your Face again; and when you remember that, you will poibly be o kind, as to make what hate you can to ee me again: Till then, have Thoughts as much in favour of me as you can; for when you know me better, you will believe I merit all. May you be impatient and uneaie till you ee me again; and bating that, may all the Bleings of Heaven and Earth light on you, is the continued Prayers of

body.head: LETTER V.
body.p:
THough it be very late, I cannot go to bed, but I mut tell thee I have been very Good ever ince I aw thee, and have been a writing, and have een no Face of Man, or other Body, ave my own People. I am mightily pleas'd with your Kindnes to me to Night; and 'twas, I hope and believe, very innocent and unditurbing on both ides. My Lycidas ays, He can be oft and dear when he pleae to put off his haughty Pride, which
is only aum'd to ee how far I dare love him ununited. Since then my Soul's Delight you are, and may ever be aur'd I am and ever will be yours, befall me what will; and that all the Devils of Hell hall not prevail againt thee. Shew then, I ay, my dearet Love, thy native weet Temper: Shew me all the Love thou hat undiembl'd; then, and never till then, hall I believe you love; and deerve my Heart, for God's ake, to keep me well: and if thou hat Love (as I hall never doubt, if thou art always as to Night) hew that Love, I beeech thee; there being nothing o grateful to God, and Mankind, as Plain-dealing. 'Tis too late to conjure thee farther: I will be purchas'd with Softnes, and dear Words, and kind Expreions, weet Eyes, and a low Voice.
Farewell; I love thee dearly, paionately, and tenderly, and am reolv'd to be eternally

closer.salute: (My only Dear Delight, and Joy of my Life)

body.head: LETTER VI.
body.p: SInce you, my dearet Lycidas, have precrib'd me Laws and Rules, how I hall behave my elf to pleae and gain you; and that one of thee is not Lying or Diembling; and that I had to Night promis'd you hou'd never have a tedious Letter from me more, I will begin to keep my Word, and tint my Heart and Hand. I promis'd tho' to write; and tho' I have no great Matter to ay more, than the Aurance of my Eternal Love to you, yet to obey you, and not only o, but to oblige my own impatient Heart, I mut, late as 'tis, ay omething to thee.

I tay'd after thee to Night, till I had read a whole Act of my new Play too; and then he led me over all the way, aying, Gad you were the Man: And beginning ome rallying Love-Dicoure after Supper, which he fancy'd was not o well receiv'd as it ought, he aid you were not handome, and call'd Philly to own it; but he did not, but was of my ide, and aid you were handome: So he went on a while, and all ended that concern'd you. And this, upon my Word, is all.

Your Articles I have read over, and do not like 'em; you have broke one, even before you have worn or eal'd 'em; that is, they are writ with Reerves. I mut have a better Account of your Heart to Morrow, when you come. I grow deperate fond of you, and wou'd fain be us'd well; if not, I will march
off: But I will believe you mean to keep your Word, as I will for ever do mine. Pray make hat to ee me to Morrow; and if I am not at home when you come, end for me over the way, where I have ingaged to Dine, there being an Entertainment on purpoe to Morrow for me.

For God's ake make no more Niceties and Scruples than need, in your way of living with me; that is, do not make me believe this Ditance is to eae you, when indeed 'tis meant to eae us both of Love; and, for God's ake, do not miinterpret my Exces of Fondnes; and if I forget my elf, let the Check you give be ufficient to make me deit. Believe me, dear Creature, 'tis more out of Humour and Jet, than any Inclination on my ide; for I could it eternally with you, without that part of Diturbance: Fear me not, for you are (from that) as afe as in Heaven it elf. Believe me, dear Lycidas, this Truth, and trut me. 'Tis late, Farewel; and come, for God's ake, betimes to Morrow, and put off your foolih Fear and Niceties, and do not hame me with your perpetual ill Opinion; my Nature is proud and inolent, and cannot bear it: I will be ued omething better, in pight of all your Apprehenions fally grounded. Adieu, keep me as I am ever yours,

argument.p: By this Letter, one would think I were the Nicet thing on Earth; yet I know a dear Friend goes far beyond me in that unneceary Fault.

body.head: LETTER VII.
body.p:
I Wou'd have gag'd my Life you cou'd not have left me o coldly, o unconcerned as you did; but you are reolv'd to give me Proofs of your No Love: Your Counel, which was given you to Night, has wrought the Effects which it uually do's in Hearts like yours. Tell me no more you love me; for 'twill be hard to make me think it, tho' it be the only Bleing I ask on Earth: But if Love can merit a Heart, I know who ought to claim yours. My Soul is ready to burt with Pride and Indignation; and at the ame time, Love, with all his Softnes aails me, and will make me write: o that, between one and the other, I can expres neither as I ought. What hall I do to make you know I do not ue to condecend to o much Submiion, nor to tell my Heart o freely? Though you think it Ue, methinks, I find my Heart well with Didain at this Minute, for my being ready to make Aeverations of the contrary, and to aure you I do not, nor never did love, or talk at the rate I do to you, ince I was born: I ay, I wou'd wear this, but omething rouls up my Boom, and checks my very Thought as it ries. You ought, Oh Faithles, and infinitely Adorable Lycidas! to know and gues my Tendernes; you ought to ee it grow, and daily increae upon your Hands: If it be troubleome, 'tis becaue I fancy you leen, whilt I encreae, in Paion;
or rather, that by your ill Judgment of mine, you never had any in your Soul for me. Oh unlucky, oh vexatious Thought! Either let me never ee that Charming Face, or eae my Soul of o tormenting an Agony, as the cruel Thought of not being belov'd. Why, my Lovely Dear, hould I flatter you? or, why make more Words of my Tendernes, than another Woman, that loves as well, wou'd do, as once you aid? No, you ought rather to believe that I ay more, becaue I have more than any Woman can be capable of: My Soul is form'd of no other Material than Love; and all that Soul of Love was form'd for my dear, faithles Lycidas—Methinks I have a Fancy, that omething will prevent my going to Morrow Morning: However, I conjure thee, if poible, to come to Morrow about Seven or Eight at Night, that I may tell you in what a deplorable Condition you left me to Night. I cannot decribe it; but I feel it, and wih you the ame Pain, for going o inhumanely: But, oh! you went to Joys, and left me to Torments! You went to Love alone, and left me Love and Rage, Fevers and Calentures, even Madnes it elf! Indeed, indeed, my Soul! I know not to what degree I love you; let it uffice I do mot paionately, and can have no Thoughts of any other Man, whilt I have Life. No! Reproach me, Defame me, Lampoon me, Cure me, and Kill me, when I do, and let Heaven do o too.

Farewel—I love you more and more every Moment of my Life—Know it, and
Goodnight. Come to Morrow, being Wedneday, to, my Adorable Lycidas, your

body.head: LETTER VIII.
body.p:
WHy, my dearet Charmer, do you diturb that Repoe I had reolved to purue, by taking it unkindly that I did not write? I cannot diobey you, becaue indeed I wou'd not, tho' 'twere better much for both I had been for ever ilent: I propheie o, but at the ame time cannot help my Fate, and know not what Force or Credit there is in the Vertue we both profes; but I am ure 'tis not good to tempt it: I think I am ure, and I think my Lycidas jut; But, oh! to what purpoe is all this fooling? You have often wiely conidered it; but I never tay'd to think till 'twas too late; and whatever Reolutions I make in the abence of my lovely Friend, one ingle ight turns me all Woman, and all his. Take notice then, my Lycidas, I will henceforth never be wie more; never make any Vows againt my Inclinations, or the little wing'd Deity. I do not only ee 'tis all in vain, but I really believe they erve only to augment my Paion. I own I have neither the Coldnes of Lycidas, nor the Prudence; I cannot either not Love, or have a Thouand Arts of hiding it; I have no Body to fear, and therefore may have ome Body to Love: But if you are detin'd to be he, the Lord have mercy on me; for I am
ure you'll have none. I expect a Reprimand for this plain Confeion; but I mut jutifie it, and I will, becaue I cannot help it: I was born to Ill Luck, and this Los of my Heart is, poibly, not the leat part on't. Do not let me ee you diapprove it, I may one Day grow aham'd on't, and reclaim, but never, whilt you blow the Flame, tho' perhaps againt your Will. I expect now a very wie Anwer; and, I believe, with abundance of Dicretion, you will caution me to avoid this Danger that threatens. Do o, if you have a mind to make me launch farther into the main Sea of Love: Rather deal with me as with a right Woman; make me believe my elf infinitely belov'd. I may chance from the natural Incontancy of my Sex, to be as fale as you wou'd wih, and leave you in quiet: For as I am atisfi'd I love in vain, and without return, I'm atisfi'd that nothing, but the thing that hates me, cou'd treat me as Lycidas do's; and 'tis only the vanity of being belov'd by me can make you countenance a oftnes o dipleaing to you. How cou'd any thing, but the Man that hates me, entertain me o unkindly? witnes your excellent Opinion of me, of loving others; witnes your paing by the end of the Street where I live, and quandring away your time at any Coffee-Houe, rather than allow me what you know in your Soul is the greatet Bleing of my Life, your dear dull melancholy Company; I call it dull, becaue you can never be gay or merry where Atrea is. How cou'd this Indifference poes you, when your malicious Soul knew I was languihing for you? I dy'd, I fainted, and pin'd for an Hour of what you lavih'd out, regardles of me, and without o
much as thinking on me! What can you ay, that Judgment may not pas? that you may not be condemn'd for the wort-natur'd, incorrigible Thing in the World? Yield, and at leat ay, My honet Friend Atrea, I neither do love thee, nor can, nor ever will; at leat let me ay, you were generous, and told me plain blunt Truth: I know it; nay wore, you impudently (but truly) told me your Buines wou'd permit you to come every Night, but your Inclinations wou'd not: At leat this was honet, but very unkind and not over civil. Do not you, my Amiable Lycidas, know I wou'd purchae your ight at any Rate; Why this Neglect then? Why keeping ditance? But as much as to ay, Atrea, truly you will make me love you, you will make me fond of you, you will pleae and delight me with your Converation, and I am a Fellow that do not deire to be pleas'd, therefore be not o civil to me; for I do not deire civil Company, nor Company that diverts me. A pretty Speech this; and yet if I do obey, deit being civil, and behave my elf very rudely, as I have done, you ay, thee two or three Days—then, Oh, Atrea! where is your Profeion? where your Love o boated? your Good-nature, &c.? Why truly, my dear Lycidas, where it was, and ever will be, o long as you have invincible Charms, and hew your Eyes, and look o dearly; tho' you may, by your prudent Counel, and your wie Conduct of Abence, and marching by my Door without calling in, oblige me to tay my Hand, and hold my Tongue: I can conceal my Kindnes, tho' not diemble one: I can make you think I am wie, if I lit; but when I tell you I have Friendhip, Love and Eteem
for you, you may pawn your Soul upon't: Believe 'tis true, and atisfie your elf you have, my dear Lycidas, in your Atrea all he profees. I hou'd be glad to ee you as oon as poible (you ay Thurday) you can: I beg you will, and hall, with Impatience, expect you betimes. Fail me not, as you wou'd have me think you have any Value for

postscript.p: I beg you will not fail to let me hear from you, to Day being Wedneday, and ee you at Night if you can.

div.p: Here I mut draw to an End; for tho' coniderable Truts were repos'd in her, yet they were of that Import, that I mut not preume here to inert 'em: But hall conclude with her Death, occaion'd by an unskilful Phyician about March or April, 1686. and was buried in the Cloyters of Wetminter-Abby, cover'd only with a plain Marble-tone, with two wretched Veres on it, made, as I'm inform'd, by a very ingenious Gentleman, tho' no Poet, the very Peron whom the Envious of our Sex, and the Malicious of the other, wou'd needs have the Author of mot of hers; which, to my Knowledge, were her own Product, without the Aitance of any thing but Nature, which hews it elf indeed without the Embarraments of Art in e'ry thing he has writ.

She was of a generous and open Temper, omething paionate, very erviceable to her Friends in all that was in her Power; and cou'd
ooner forgive an Injury, than do one. She had Wit, Honour, Good-humour, and Judgment. She was Mitres of all the pleaing Arts of Converation, but us'd 'em not to any but thoe who lov'd Plain-dealing. She was a Woman of Sene, and by Conequence a Lover of Pleaure, as indeed all, both Men and Women, are; but only ome wou'd be thought to be above the Conditions of Humanity, and place their chief Pleaure in a proud, vain Hypocriie: For my part, I knew her intimately, and never aw ought unbecoming the jut Modety of our Sex, tho' more gay and free than the Folly of the precie will allow. She was, I'm atisfy'd, a greater Honour to our Sex than all the canting Tribe of Diemblers, that die with the fale Reputation of Saints. This I may venture to ay, becaue I'm unknown, and the revengeful Cenures of my Sex will not reach me, ince they will never be able to draw the Veil, and dicover the Speaker of thee bold Truths. If I have done my dead Friend any manner of Jutice, I am atisfy'd, having obtain'd my End: If not, the Reader mut remember that there are few Atrea's arie in our Age; and till uch a one does appear, all our Endeavours in Encomiums on the lat, mut be vain and impotent.

div.head: THE HISTORY OF THE Royal Slave.
div.p: I Do not pretend, in giving you the Hitory of this Royal Slave, to entertain my Reader with the Adventures of a feign'd Hero, whoe Life and Fortunes Fancy may mamage at the Poet's Pleaure; nor in relating the Truth, deign to adorn it with any Accidents, but uch as arriv'd in earnet to him: And it hall come imply into the World, recommended by its own proper Merits, and natural Intrigues; there being enough of Reality to upport it, and to render it diverting, without the addition of Invention.

I was my elf an Eye-witnes to a great part of what you will find here et down; and what I cou'd not be Witnes of, I receiv'd from the Mouth of the chief Actor in this Hitory, the Hero himelf, who gave us the whole Tranactions of his Youth: And though I hall omit, for brevity's ake, a thouand little Accidents
of his Life, which, however pleaant to us, where Hitory was carce, and Adventures very rare; yet might prove tedious and heavy to my Reader, in a World where he finds Diverions for every Minute, new and trange: But we who were perfectly charm'd with the Character of this Great Man, were curious to gather every Circumtance of his Life.
The Scene of the lat part of his Adventures lies in a Colony in America, called Surinam, in the Wet-Indies.

But before I give you the Story of this Gallant Slave, 'tis <> I tell you the <> of bringing them to th • e new,
<>
for thoe they make ue of there, are not Natives of the place; for thoe we live with in perfect Amity, without daring to command 'em; but, on the contrary, cares 'em with all the brotherly and friendly Affection in the worl • ; trading with them for their Fih, Venion, Buffilo's Skins, and little Rarities; as Marmoets, a ort of Monkey, as big as a Rat or Weeel, but of a marvellous and delicate hape, and has Face and Hands like an Humane Creature: and Couheries, a little Beat in the form and fahion of a Lion, as big as a Kitten; but o exactly made in all Parts like that noble Beat, that it is it in Miniature. Then for little Parakeetoes, great Parrots, Muckaws and a thouand other Birds and Beats of wonderful and urpriing Forms, Shapes and Colours. For Skins of prodigious Snakes, of which there are ome threecore Yards in length; as is the Skin of one that may be een at His Majety's Antiquaries: where are alo ome rare Flies, of
amazing Forms and Colours, preented to 'em by my elf; ome as big as my Fit, ome les; and all of various Excellencies, uch as Art cannot imitate. Then we trade for Feathers, which they order into all hapes, make themelves little hort Habits of 'em, and glorious Wreaths for their Heads, Necks, Arms and Legs, whoe Tinctures are unconceivable. I had a Sett of thee preented to me, and I gave 'em to the King's Theatre, and it was the Dres of the Indian Queen, infinitely admir'd by Perons of Quality; and were unimitable. Beides thee, a thouand little Knacks, and Rarities in Nature; and ome of Art, as their Baskets, Weapons, Aprons, &c. We dealt with 'em with Beads of all Colours, Knives, Axes, Pins and Needles; which they us'd only as Tools to drill Holes with in their Ears, Noes and Lips, where they hang a great many little things; as long Beads, bits of Tin, Bras or Silver, beat thin; and any hining Trinket. The Beads they weave into Aprons about a Quarter of an Ell long, and of the ame breadth; working them very prettily in Flowers of everal Colours of Beads; which Apron they wear jut before 'em, as Adam and Eve did the Fig-leaves; the Men wearing a long tripe of Linen, which they deal with us for. They thread thee Beads alo on long Cotton threads, and make Girdles to tie their Aprons to, which come twenty times, or more, about the Wate, and then cros, like a Shoulder-belt, both ways, and round their Necks, Arms and Legs. This Adornment, with their long black Hair, and the Face painted in little Specks or Flowers
here and there, makes 'em a wonderful Figure to behold. Some of the Beauties which indeed are finely hap'd, as almot all are, and who have pretty Features, are very charming and novel; for they have all that is called Beauty, except the Colour, which is a reddih Yellow; or after a new Oiling, which they often ue to themelves, they are of the colour of a new Brick, but mooth, oft and leek. They are extreme modet and bahful, very hy, and nice of being touch'd. And though they are all thus naked, if one lives for ever among 'em, there is not to be een an indecent Action, or Glance; and being continually us'd to ee one another o unadorn'd, o like our firt Parents before the Fall, it eems as if they had no Wihes; there being nothing to heighten Curioity; but all you can ee, you ee at once, and every moment ee; and where there is no Novelty, there can be no Curioity. Not but I have een a handom young Indian, dying for Love of a very beautiful young Indian Maid; but all his Courthip was, to fold his Arms, purue her with his Eyes, and Sighs were all his Language: While he, as if no uch Lover were preent, or rather, as if he deired none uch, carefully guarded her Eyes from beholding him; and never approach'd him, but he look'd down with all the bluhing modety I have een in the mot evere and cautious of our World. And thee People repreented to me an abolute Idea of the firt State of Innocence, before Man knew how to in: And 'tis mot evident and plain, that imple Nature is the mot harmles, inoffenive and vertuous Mitres. 'Tis he
alone, if he were permitted, that better intructs the World, than all the Inventions of Man: Religion wou'd here but detroy that Tranquillity they poes by Ignorance; and Laws wou'd but teach 'em to know Offence, of which now they have no Notion. They once made Mourning and Fating for the Death of the Englih Governor, who had given his Hand to come on uch a day to 'em, and neither came nor ent; believing, when once a Man's Word was pat, nothing but Death cou'd or hou'd prevent his keeping it: And when they aw he was not dead, they ask'd him what Name they had for a Man who promis'd a thing he did not do? The Governor told them, Such a Man was a Lyar, which was a Word of Infamy to a Gentleman. Then one of 'em reply'd, Governor, you are a Lyar, and guilty of that Infamy. They have a native Jutice, which knows no Fraud; and they undertand no Vice, or Cunning, but when they are taught by the White Men. They have Plurality of Wives; which, when they grow old, they erve thoe that ucceed 'em, who are young, but with a Servitude eaie and repected; and unles they take Slaves in War, they have no other Attendants.
Thoe on that Continent where I was, had no King; but the oldet War-Captain was obey'd with great Reignation.
A War-Captain is a Man who has led them on to Battle with Conduct and Succes; of whom I hall have occaion to peak more hereafter, and of ome other of their Cutom and Manners, as they fall in my way.

With thee People, as I aid, we live in perfect Tranquillity, and good Undertanding, as it behoves us to do; they knowing all the places where to eek the bet Food of the Countrey, and the means of getting it; and for very mall and unvaluable Trifles, upply us with what 'tis impoible for us to get; for they do not only in the Wood, and over the Sevana's, in Hunting, upply the parts of Hounds, by wiftly couring through thoe almot impaable places, and by the meer Activity of their Feet, run down the nimblet Deer, and other eatable Beats: But in the Water, one wou'd think they were Gods of the Rivers, or Fellow-Citizens of the Deep; o rare an Art they have in Swimming, Diving, and almot Living in Water; by which they command the les wift Inhabitants of the Floods. And then for Shooting; what they cannot take, or reach with their Hands, they do with Arrows; and have o admirable an Aim, that they will plit almot an Hair; and at any ditance that an Arrow can reach, they will hoot down Oranges, and other Fruit, and only touch the Stalk with the Dart's Point, that they may not hurt the Fruit. So that they being, on all occaions, very ueful to us, we find it abolutely neceary to cares 'em as Friends, and not to treat 'em as Slaves; nor dare we do other, their Numbers o far urpaing ours in that Continent.
Thoe then whom we make ue of to work in our Plantations of Sugar, are Negro's, Black-Slaves altogether; which are tranported thither in this manner:

Thoe who want Slaves, make a Bargain with a Mater, or a Captain of a Ship, and contract to pay him o much a-piece, a matter of Twenty Pound a Head for as many as he agrees for, and to pay for 'em when they hall be deliver'd on uch a Plantation: So that when there arrives a Ship laden with Slaves, they who have o contracted, go a-board, and receive their number by Lot; and perhaps in one Lot that may be for ten, there may happen to be three or four Men; the ret Women and Children: or be there more or les of either Sex, you are oblig'd to be contented with your Lot.

Coramantien, a Countrey of Blacks o called, was one of thoe places in which they found the mot advantageous Trading for thee Slaves, and thither mot of our great Traders in that Merchandie traffick'd; for that Nation is very war-like and brave; and having a continual Campaign, being always in Hotility with one neighbouring Prince or other, they had the fortune to take a great many Captives; for all they took in Battle were old as Slaves; at leat, thoe common Men who cou'd not ranom themelves. Of thee Slaves o taken, the General only has all the Profit; and of thee Generals, our Captains and Maters of Ships buy all their Freights.

The King of Coramantien was himelf a Man of an Hundred and odd Years old, and had no Son, though he had many beautiful Black-Wives; for mot certainly, there are Beauties that can charm of that Colour. In his younger years he had had many gallant Men to his
Sons, thirteen of which died in Battle, conquering when they fell; and he had only left him for his Succeor, one Grand-Child, Son to one of thee dead Victors; who, as oon as he could bear a Bow in his Hand, and a Quiver at his back, was ent into the Field, to be train'd up, by one of the oldet Generals, to War; where, from his natural Inclination to Arms, and the Occaions given him, with the good Conduct of the old General, he became, at the age of Seventeen, one of the mot expert Captains, and bravet Soldiers, that ever aw the Field of Mars: So that he was ador'd as the Wonder of all that World, and the Darling of the Soldiers. Beides, he was adorn'd with a native Beauty o trancending all thoe of his gloomy Race, that he truck an Awe and Reverence, even into thoe that knew not his Quality; as he did into me, who beheld him with Surprize and Wonder, when afterwards he arriv'd in our World.

He had carce arriv'd at his Seventeenth Year, when, fighting by his ide, the General was kill'd with an Arrow in his Eye, which the Prince Oroonoko (for o was this gallant Moor call'd) very narrowly avoided; nor had he, if the General, who aw the Arrow hot, and perceiving it aim'd at the Prince, had not bow'd his Head between, on purpoe to receive it in his own Body, rather than it hou'd touch that of the Prince, and o aved him.

'Twas then, afflicted as Oroonoko was, that he was proclaim'd General in the Old Man's place; and then it was, at the finihing of that War, which had continued for two Years, that
the Prince came to Court; where he had hardly been a Month together, from the time of his Fifth Year, to that of Seventeen; and 'twas amazing to imagine where it was he learn'd o much Humanity; or, to give his Accomplihments a juter Name, where 'twas he got that real Greatnes of Soul, thoe refin'd Notions of true Honour, that abolute Generoity, and that Softnes that was capable of the highet Paions of Love and Gallantry, whoe Objects were almot continually fighting Men, or thoe mangl'd, or dead; who heard no Sounds, but thoe of War and Groans. Some part of it we may attribute to the care of a French-man of Wit and Learning; who finding it turn to very good account to be a ort of Royal Tutor to this young Black, and perceiving him very ready, apt, and quick of Apprehenion, took a great pleaure to teach him Morals, Language and Science; and was for it extremely belov'd and valu'd by him. Another reaon was; he lov'd, when he came from War, to ee all the Englih Gentlemen that traded thither; and did not only learn their Language, but that of the Spaniards alo, with whom he traded afterwards for Slaves.

I have often een and convers'd with this Great Man, and been a Witnes to many of his mighty Actions; and do aure my Reader, the mot illutrious Courts cou'd not have produc'd a braver Man, both for greatnes of Courage and Mind, a Judgment more olid, a Wit more quick, and a Converation more weet and diverting. He knew almot as much as if he had read much: He had heard of,
and admir'd the Romans; he had heard of the late Civil Wars in England, and the deplorable Death of our great Monarch; and wou'd dicoure of it with all the Sene and Abhorrence of the Injutice imaginable. He had an extreme good and graceful Mien, and all the Civility of a well-bread Great Man. He had nothing of Barbarity in his Nature, but in all Points addres'd himelf as if his Education had been in ome Europaean Court.

This great and jut Character of Oroonoko gave me an extreme Curioity to ee him, epecially when I knew he poke French and Englih, and that I could talk with him. But though I had heard o much of him, I was as greatly urpriz'd when I aw him, as if I had heard nothing of him; o beyond all Report I found him. He came into the Room, and addres'd himelf to me, and ome other Women, with the bet Grace in the World. He was pretty tall, but of a hape the mot exact that can be fany'd: The mot famous Statuary cou'd not form the figure of a Man more admirably turn • d from Head to Foot. His Face was not of that brown, ruty Black which mot of that Nation are, but a perfect Ebony, or polih'd Jett. His Eyes were the mot awful that cou'd be een, and very piercing, the White of 'em being like Snow, as were his Teeth. His Noe was riing and Roman, intead of African and flat. His Mouth, the finet hap'd that cou'd be een; far from thoe great turn'd Lips, which are o natural to the ret of the Negroes. The whole Proportion and Air of his Face was o noble, and exactly
form'd, that, bating his Colour, there cou'd be nothing in Nature more beautiful, agreeable and handome. There was no one Grace wanting, that bears the Standard of true Beauty. His Hair came down to his Shoulders, by the aids of Art; which was, by pulling it out with a Quill, and keeping it comb'd; of which he took particular care. Nor did the Perfections of his Mind come hort of thoe of his Peron; for his Dicoure was admirable upon almot any Subject; and who-ever had heard him peak, wou'd have been convinc'd of their Errors, that all fine Wit is confin'd to the White men, epecially to thoe of Chritendom; and wou'd have confes'd, that Oroonoko was as capable even of reigning well, and of governing as wiely, had as great a Soul, as politick Maxims, and was as enible of Power, as any Prince civiliz'd in the mot refined Schools of Humanity and Learning, or the mot illutrious Courts.

This Prince, uch as I have decrib'd him, whoe Soul and Body were o admirably adorn'd, was (while yet he was in the Court of his Grand-father,) as I aid, as capable of Love, as 'twas poible for a brave and gallant Man to be: and in aying that, I have nam'd the highet Degree of Love; for ure, great Souls are mot capable of that Paion.

I have already aid, the old General was kill'd by the hot of an Arrow, by the ide of this Prince in Battle; and that Oroonoko was made General. This old dead Hero had one only Daughter left of his Race; a Beauty, that to decribe her truly, one need ay only, he
was Female to the noble Male; the beautiful Black Venus, to our young Mars; as charming in her Peron as he, and of delicate Vertues. I have een an hundred White Men ighing after her, and making a thouand Vows at her Feet, all vain, and unuccesful: And he was, indeed, too great for any, but a Prince of her own Nation to adore.

Oroonoko coming from the Wars, (which were now ended) after he had made his Court to his Grand-father, he thought in honour he ought to make a Viit to Imoinda, the Daughter of his Foter-father the dead General; and to make ome Excues to her, becaue his Preervation was the occaion of her Father's Death; and to preent her with thoe Slaves that had been taken in this lat Battle, as the Trophies of her Father's Victories. When he came, attended by all the young Soldiers of any Merit, he was infinitely urpriz'd at the Beauty of this fair Queen of Night, whoe Face and Peron was to exceeding all he had ever beheld, that lovely Modety with which he receiv'd him, that Softnes in her Look, and Sighs, upon the melancholy Occaion of this Honour that was done by o great a Man as Oroonoko, and a Prince of whom he had heard uch admirable things; the Awfulnes wherewith he receiv'd him, and the Sweetnes of her Words and Behaviour while he tay'd gain'd a perfect Conquet over his fierce Heart, and made him feel, the Victor cou'd be ubdu'd. So that having made his firt Complements, and preented her an Hundred and fifty Slaves in Fetters, he told her with his Eyes, that he was not inenible
of her Charms; while Imoinda, who wih'd for nothing more than o glorious a Conquet, was pleas'd to believe, he undertood that ilent Language of new-born Love; and, from that moment, put on all her additions to Beauty.

The Prince return'd to Court with quite another Humour than before; and though he did not peak much of the fair Imoinda, he had the pleaure to hear all his Followers peak of nothing but the Charms of that Maid, inomuch that, even in the preence of the old King, they were extolling her, and heightning, if poible, the Beauties they had found in her: o that nothing ele was talk'd of, no other ound was heard in every corner where there were Whiperers, but Imoinda! Imoinda!

'Twill be imagin'd Oroonoko tay'd not long before he made his econd Viit; nor, conidering his Quality, not much longer before he told her, he ador'd her. I have often heard him ay, that he admir'd by what trange Inpiration he came to talk things o oft, and o paionate, who never knew Love, nor was us'd to the Converation of Women; but (to ue his own words) he aid; Mot happily, ome new, and, till then, unknown Power intructed his Heart and Tongue in the Language of Love, and at the ame time, in favour of him, inpir'd Imoinda with a ene of his Paion. She was touch'd with what he aid, and return'd it all in uch Anwers as went to his very Heart, with a Pleaure unknown before. Nor did he ue thoe Obligations ill, that Love had done him, but turn'd all his happy moments to the
bet advantage; and as he knew no Vice, his Flame aim'd at nothing but Honour, if uch a ditinction may be made in Love; and epecially in that Country, where Men take to themelves a many as they can maintain; and where the only Crime and Sin with Woman, is, to turn her off, to abandon her to Want, Shame and Miery: uch ill Morals are only practis'd in Chritian Countries, where they preferr the bare Name of Religion; and, without Vertue or Morality, think that ufficient. But Oroonoko was none of thoe Profeors; but as he had right Notions of Honour, o he made her uch Propoitions as were not only and barely uch; but, contrary to the cutom of his Countrey, he made her Vows, he hou'd be the only Woman he wou'd poes while he liv'd; that no Age or Wrinkles hou'd encline him to change; for her Soul wou'd be always fine, and always young; and he hould have an eternal Idea in his Mind of the Charms he now bore; and hou'd look into his Heart for that Idea, when he cou'd find it no longer in her Face.
After a thouand Aurances of his lating Flame, and her eternal Empire over him, he condecended to receive him for her Husband; or rather, receiv'd him, as the greatet Honour the Gods cou'd do her.

There is a certain Ceremony in thee caes to be oberv'd, which I forgot to ask him how perform'd; but 'twas concluded on both ides, that in obedience to him, the Grand-father was to be firt made acquainted with the Deign: For they pay a mot abolute Reignation to the Monarch, epecially when he is a Parent alo.

On the other ide, the old King, who had many Wives, and many Concubines, wanted not Court-Flatterers to in • inuate into his Heart a thouand tender Thoughts for this young Beauty; and who repreented her to his Fancy, as the mot charming he had ever poes'd in all the long race of his numerous Years. At this Character, his old Heart, like an extinguiht Brand, mot apt to take Fire, felt new Sparks of Love, and began to kindle; and now grown to his econd Childhood, long'd with impatience to behold this gay thing with whom, alas! he could but innocently play. But how he hou'd be confirm'd he was this Wonder, before he us'd his Power to call her to Court, (where Maidens never came, unles for the King's private Ue) he was next to conider; and while he was o doing, he had Intelligence brought him, that Imoinda was mot certainly Mitres to the Prince Oroonoko. This gave him ome Shagrien; however, it gave him alo an opportunity, one day, when the Prince was a-hunting, to wait on a Man of Quality, as his Slave and Attendant, who hou'd go and make a Preent to Imoinda, as from the Prince; he hou'd then, unknown, ee this fair Maid, and have an opportunity to hear what Meage he wou'd return the Prince for his Preent; and from thence gather the tate of her Heart, and degree of her Inclination. This was put in execution, and the old Monarch aw, and burnt: He found her all he had heard, and wou'd not delay his Happines, but found he hou'd have ome Obtacle to overcome her Heart; for he expres'd her ene of
the Preent the Prince had ent her, in terms o weet, o oft and pretty, with an Air of Love and Joy that cou'd not be diembl'd, inomuch that 'twas pat doubt whether he lov'd Oroonoko entirely. This gave the old King ome affliction; but he alv'd it with this, that the Obedience the People pay their King, was not at all inferior to what they paid their Gods; and what Love wou'd not oblige Imoinda to do, Duty wou'd compell her to.

He was therefore no ooner got to his Apartment, but he ent the Royal Veil to Imoinda; that is, the Ceremony of Invitation: He ends the Lady he has a mind to honour with his Bed, a Veil, with which he is cover'd, and ecur'd for the King's Ue; and 'tis Death to diobey; beides, held a mot impious Diobedience.

'Tis not to be imagin'd the Surprize and Grief that eiz'd this lovely Maid at this News and Sight. However, as Delays in thee caes are dangerous, and Pleading wore than Treaon; trembling, and almot fainting, he was oblig'd to uffer her elf to be cover'd, and led away.

They brought her thus to Court; and the King, who had caus'd a very rich Bath to be prepar'd, was led into it, where he ate under a Canopy, in State, to receive this long'd-for Virgin; whom he having commanded hou'd be brought to him, they (after di-robing her) led her to the Bath, and making fat the Doors, left her to decend. The King, without more Courthip, bad her throw off her Mantle, and come to his Arms. But Imoinda, all in Tears,
threw her elf on the Marble, on the brink of the Bath, and beought him to hear her. She told him, as he was a Maid, how proud of the Divine Glory he hould have been, of having it in her power to oblige her King: but as by the Laws, he cou'd not; and from his Royal Goodnes, wou'd not take from any Man his wedded Wife: o he believ'd he hou'd be the Occaion of making him commit a great Sin, if he did not reveal her State and Condition; and tell him, he was another's, and cou'd not be o happy to be his.

The King, enrag'd at this Delay, hatily demanded the Name of the bold Man, that had marry'd a Woman of her Degree, without his Conent. Imoinda, eeing his Eyes fierce, and his Hands tremble, (whether with Age or Anger, I know not, but he fany'd the lat,) almot repented he had aid o much, for now he fear'd the torm wou'd fall on the Prince; he therefore aid a thouand things to appeae the raging of his Flame, and to prepare him to hear who it was with calmnes; but before he poke, he imagin'd who he meant, but wou'd not eem to do o, but commanded her to lay aide her Mantle, and uffer her elf to receive his Carees, or, by his Gods he wore, that happy Man whom he was going to name hou'd die, though it were even Oroonoko himelf: Therefore (aid he) deny this Marriage, and wear thy elf a Maid. That (reply'd Imoinda) by all our Powers I do; for I am not yet known to my Husband. 'Tis enough (aid the King;) 'tis enough both to atisfie my Concience,
and my Heart. And riing from his Seat, he went and led her into the Bath; it being in vain for her to reit.

In this time, the Prince, who was return'd from Hunting, went to viit his Imoinda, but found her gone; and not only o, but heard he had receiv'd the Royal Veil. This rais'd him to a torm; and in his madnes, they had much ado to ave him from laying violent Hands on himelf. Force firt prevail'd, and then Reaon: They urg'd all to him, that might oppoe his Rage; but nothing weigh'd o greatly with him as the King's Old Age uncapable of injuring him with Imoinda. He wou'd give way to that Hope, becaue it pleas'd him mot, and flatter'd bet his Heart. Yet this erv'd not altogether to make him ceae his different Paions, which ometimes rag'd within him, and ometimes oftned into Showers. 'Twas not enough to appeae him, to tell him, his Grand-father was old and cou'd not that way injure him, while he retain'd that awful Duty which the Young Men are us'd there to pay to their grave Relations. He cou'd not be convinc'd he had no caue to igh and mourn for the los of a Mitres, he cou'd not with all his trength and courage retrieve. And he wou'd often cry, Oh, my Friends! were he in wall'd Cities, or confin'd from me in Fortifications of the greatet trength; did Inchantments or Monters detain her from me; I wou'd venture through any Hazard to free her: But here, in the Arms of a feeble Old Man, my Youth, my violent Love, my Trade in Arms, and all my vat Deire of Glory, avail me nothing: Imoinda is as irrecoverably
lot to me, as if he were natcht by the cold Arms of Death: Oh! he is never to be retriev'd. If I wou'd wait tedious Years, till Fate hou'd bow the old King to his Grave; even that wou'd not leave me Imoinda free; but till that Cutom that makes it o vile a Crime for a Son to marry his Father's Wives or Mitrees, wou'd hinder my Happines; unles I wou'd either ignobly et an ill Preident to my Succeors, or abandon my Countrey, and fly with her to ome unknown World who never heard our Story.

But it was objected to him, That his cae was not the ame; for Imoinda being his lawful Wife by olemn Contract, 'twas he was the injur'd Man, and might, if he o pleas'd, take Imoinda back, the breach of the Law being on his Grand-Father's ide; and that if he cou'd circumvent him, and redeem her from the Otan, which is the Palace of the King's Women, a ort of Seraglio, it was both jut and lawful for him o to do.

This Reaoning had ome force upon him, and he hou'd have been entirely comforted, but for the thought that he was poes'd by his Grand-father. However, he lov'd o well, that he was reolv'd to believe what mot favour'd his Hope; and to endeavour to learn from Imoinda's own Mouth, what only he cou'd atisfie him in; whether he was robb'd of that Bleing which was only due to his Faith and Love. But as it was very hard to get a ight of the Women, (for no Men ever enter'd into the Otan, but when the King went to entertain himelf with ome one of his Wives or Mitrees; and 'twas Death, at any other
time for any other to go in;) o he knew not how to contrive to get a ight of her.

While Oroonoko felt all the Agonies of Love, and uffer'd under a Torment the mot painful in the world, the old King was not exempted from his hare of Affliction. He was troubled, for having been forc'd, by an irreitible Paion, to rob his Son of a Treaure, he knew, cou'd not but be extremely dear to him, ince he was the mot beautiful that ever had been een; and had beides, all the Sweetnes and Innocence of Youth and Modety, with a Charm of Wit urpaing all. He found that, however, he was forc'd to expoe her lovely Peron to his wither'd Arms, he cou'd only igh and weep there, and think of Oroonoko; and oftentimes cou'd not for bear peaking of him, though her Life were, by Cutom, forfeited by owning her Paion. But he poke not of a Lover only, but of a Prince dear to him, to whom he poke; and of the Praies of a Man, who, till now, fill'd the old Man's Soul with Joy at every recital of his Bravery, or even his Name. And 'twas this Dotage on our young Hero, that gave Imoinda a thouand Privileges to peak of him, without offending; and this Condecention in the old King, that made her take the Satisfaction of peaking of him o very often.

Beides, he many times enquir'd how the Prince bore himelf: And thoe of whom he ask'd, being entirely Slaves to the Merits and Vertues of the Prince, till anwer'd what they thought conduc'd bet to his Service; which was, to make the old King fanie that the Prince had no more Interet in Imoinda, and had reign'd
her willingly to the Pleaure of the King; that he diverted himelf with his Mathematicians, his Fortifications, his Officers, and his Hunting.

This pleas'd the old Lover, who fail'd not to report thee things again to Imoinda, that he might, by the Example of her young Lover, withdraw her Heart, and ret better contented in his Arms. But however, he was forc'd to receive this unwelcome News, in all appearance, with Unconcern and Content; her Heart was burting within, and he was only happy when he cou'd get alone, to vent her Griefs and Moans with Sighs and Tears.

What Reports of the Prince's Conduct were made to the King, he thought good to jutifie as far as poibly he cou'd by his Actions; and when he appear'd in the Preence of the King, he hew'd a Face not at all betraying his Heart: o that in a little time, the old Man, being entirely convinc'd that he was no longer a Lover of Imoindae, he carry'd him with him, in his Train, to the Otan, often to banquet with his Mitres. But as oon as he enter'd, one day, into the Apartment of Imoinda, with the King, at the firt Glance from her Eyes, notwithtanding all his determined Reolution, he was ready to ink in the place where he tood; and had certainly done o, but for the upport of Aboan, a young Man who was next to him; which, with his Change of Countenance, had betray'd him, had the King chanc'd to look that way. And I have oberv'd, 'tis a very great error in thoe who laugh when one ays, A Negro can change Colour: for I have
een 'em as frequently bluh, and look pale, and that as viibly as ever I aw in the mot beautiful White. And 'tis certain, that both thee Changes were evident, this day, in both thee Lovers. And Imoinda, who aw with ome Joy the Change in the Prince's Face, and found it in her own, trove to divert the King from beholding either, by a forc'd Cares, with which he met him; which was a new Wound in the Heart of the poor dying Prince. But as oon as the King was buy'd in looking on ome fine thing of Imoinda's making, he had time to tell the Prince, with her angry but Love-darting Eyes, that he reented his Coldnes, and bemoan'd her own mierable Captivity. Nor were his Eyes ilent, but anwer'd hers again, as much as Eyes cou'd do, intructed by the mot tender and mot paionate Heart that ever lov'd: And they poke o well, and o effectually, as Imoinda no longer doubted but he was the only Delight and Darling of that Soul he found pleading in 'em its Right of Love, which none was more willing to reign than he. And 'twas this powerful Language alone that in an intant convey'd all the Thoughts of their Souls to each other; that they both found there wanted but Opportunity to make them both entirely happy. But when he aw another Door open'd by Onah • l (a former old Wife of the Kings, who now had Charge of Imoinda,) and aw the Propect of a Bed of State made ready, with Sweets and Flowers for the Dalliance of the King, who immediately led the trembling Victim from his ight, into that prepar'd Repoe; what Rage!
what wild Frenzies eiz'd his Heart! which forcing to keep within bounds, and to uffer without noie, it became the more inupportable, and rent his Soul with ten thouand pains. He was forc'd to retire, to vent his Groans, where he fell down on a Carpet, and lay truggling a long time, and only breathing now and then,—Oh, Imoinda! When Onahal had finiht her neceary Affair within, hutting the Door, he came forth, to wait till the King call'd; and hearing ome one ighing in the other Room, he pat on, and found the Prince in that deplorable Condition, which he thought needed her Aid. She gave him Cordials, but all in vain; till finding the nature of his Dieae, by his Sighs, and naming Imoinda; he told him, he had not o much caue as he imagin'd to afflict himelf; for if he knew the King o well as he did, he wou'd not loe a moment in Jealouie, and that he was confident that Imoinda bore, at this minute, part in his Affliction. Aboan was of the ame opinion; and both together peruaded him to re-aume his Courage; and all itting down on the Carpet, the Prince aid o many obliging things to Onahal, that he half-peruaded her to be of his Party. And he promis'd him, he wou'd thus far comply with his jut Deires, that he wou'd let Imoinda know how faithful he was, what he uffer'd, and what he aid.

This Dicoure lated till the King call'd; which gave Oroonoko a certain Satisfaction; and with the Hope Onahal had made him conceive, he aum'd a Look as gay as 'twas poible a Man in his circumtances cou'd do; and preently
after, he was call'd in with the ret who waited without. The King commanded Muick to be brought, and everal of his young Wives and Mitrees came all together by his Command, to dance before him: where Imoinda perform'd her part with an Air and Grace o paing all the ret, as her Beauty was above 'em; and receiv'd the Preent ordain'd as a Prize. The Prince was every moment more charm'd with the new Beauties and Graces he beheld in this Fair One: And while he gaz'd, and he danc'd, Onahal was retir'd to a Window with Aboan.

This Onahal, as I aid, was one of the Cat-Mitrees of the old King; and 'twas thee (now pat their Beauty) that were made Guardians or Governantee's to the new and the young ones; and whoe Buines it was, to teach them all thoe wanton Arts of Love, with which they prevail'd and charm'd heretofore in their Turn; and who now treated the triumphing happy Ones with all the Severity, as to Liberty and Freedom, that was poible, in revenge of their Honours they rob them of; envying them thoe Satisfactions, thoe Gallantries and Preents, that were once made to themelves, while Youth and Beauty lated, and which they now aw pas, as it were, regardles by, and paid only to the Bloomings. And certainly, nothing is more afflicting to a decay'd Beauty, than to behold in it elf declining Charms, that were once ador'd; and to find thoe Carees paid to new Beauties, to which once he laid a claim; to hear 'em whiper, as he paes by, That once was a delicate
Woman. Thee abandon'd Ladies therefore endeavour to revenge all the Depights, and Decays of Time, on thee flourihing happy Ones. And 'twas this Severity, that gave Oroonoko a thouand fears he hould never prevail with Onahal to ee Imoinda. But, as I aid, he was now retir'd to a Window with Aboan.

This Young Man was not only one of the bet Quality, but a Man extremely well made, and beautiful; and coming often to attend the King to the Otan, he had ubdu'd the Heart of the antiquated Onahal, which had not forgot how pleaant it was to be in Love: And though he had ome Decays in her Face, he had none in her Sence and Wit; he was there agreeable till, even to Aboan's Youth: o that he took pleaure in entertaining her with Dicoures of Love. He knew alo, that to make his Court to thee She-Favourites, was the way to be great; thee being the Perons that do all Affairs and Buines at Court. He had alo oberv'd that he had given him Glances more tender and inviting than he had done to others of his Quality. And now, when he aw that her Favour cou'd o abolutely oblige the Prince, he fail'd not to igh in her Ear, and to look with Eyes all oft upon her, and give her Hope that he had made ome Impreions on his Heart. He found her pleas'd at this, and making a thouand advances to him: but the Ceremony ending, and the King departing, broke up the Company for that Day, and his Converation.

Aboan fail'd not that night to tell the Prince of his Succes, and how advantageous the Service of Onahal might be to his Amour with Imoinda. The Prince was over-joy'd with this good News, and beought him, if it were poible, to cares her o, as to engage her entirely; which he cou'd not fail to do, if he comply'd with her Deires: For then (aid the Prince) her Life lying at your Mercy, he mut grant you the Requet you make in my behalf. Aboan undertood him, and aur'd him he would make love o effectually, that he would defie the mot expert Mitres of the Art, to find out whether he diembl'd it, or had it really. And 'twas with impatience they waited the next Opportunity of going to the Otan.

The Wars came on; the Time of taking the Field approach'd, and 'twas impoible for the Prince to delay his going at the Head of his Army, to encounter the Enemy: o that every Day eem'd a tedious Year, till he aw his Imoinda; for he believ'd he cou'd not live, if he were forc'd away without being o happy. 'Twas with impatience therefore that he expected the next Viit the King wou'd make; and, according to his wih, it was not long.

The Parley of the Eyes of thee two Lovers had not pas'd o ecretly, but an old jealous Lover could py it; or rather, he wanted not Flatterers, who told him, they oberv'd it: o that the Prince was haten'd to the Camp, and this was the lat Viit he found he hou'd make to the Otan; he therefore urg'd Aboan to make the bet of this lat Effort, and to explain himelf o to Onahal, that he, deferring
her Enjoyment of her young Lover no longer, might make way for the Prince to peak to Imoinda.

The whole Affair being agreed on between the Prince and Aboan, they attended the King, as the cutom was, to the Otan; where, while the whole Company was taken up in beholding the Dancing, and Antick Potures the Women-Royal made, to divert the King, Onahal ingl'd out Aboan whom he found mot plyable to her wih. When he had him where he believ'd he cou'd not be heard, he igh'd to him, and oftly cry'd; Ah, Aboan! when will you be enible of my Paion? I confes it with my Mouth, becaue I wou'd not give my Eyes the Lye; and you have too much already perceiv'd they have confes'd my Flame: Nor wou'd I have you believe, that becaue I am the abandon'd Mitres of a King, I eteem my elf altogether diveted of Charms: No, Aboan; I have till a Rest of Beauty enough engaging, and have learn'd to pleae too well, not to be deirable: I can have Lovers till, but will have none but Aboan. Madam, (reply'd the half-feigning Youth) you have already, by my Eyes, found you can till conquer; and I believe 'tis in pity of me, you condecend to this kind Confeion: But, Madam, Words are us'd to be o mall a part of our Country-Courthip, that 'tis rare one can get o happy an Opportunity as to tell one's Heart; and thoe few Minutes we have, are forc'd to be natcht for more certain Proofs of Love than Speaking and Sighing; and uch I languih for.

He poke this with uch a Tone, that he hop'd it true, and cou'd not forbear believing
it; and being wholly tranported with Joy, for having ubdu'd the finet of all the King's Subjects to her Deires, he took from her Ears two large Pearls, and commanded him to wear 'em in his. He wou'd have refus'd em, crying, Madam, thee are not the Proofs of your Love that I expect; 'tis Opportunity, 'tis a Lone-hour only, that can make me happy: But forcing the Pearls into his Hand, he whiper'd oftly to him; Oh! Do not fear a Woman's Invention, when Love ets her a-thinking. And preing his Hand, he cry'd, This Night you hall be happy: Come to the Gate of the Orange-Grove, behind the Otan, and I will be ready, about Mid-night, to receive you. 'Twas thus agreed, and he left him, that no notice might be taken of their peaking together.

The Ladies were till dancing; and the King laid on a Carpet, with a great deal of pleaure was beholding them, epecially Imoinda, who that day appear'd more lovely than ever, being enliven'd with the good Tidings Onahal had brought her, of the contant Paion the Prince had for her. The Prince was laid on another Carpet, at the other end of the Room, with his Eyes fix'd on the Object of his Soul; and as he turn'd or mov'd, o did they; and he alone gave his Eyes and Soul their Motions. Nor did Imoinda employ her Eyes to any other ue, than in beholding, with infinite Pleaure, the Joy he produc'd in thoe of the Prince. But while he was more regarding Him, than the Steps he took, he chanced to fall; and o near him, as that leaping with extreme force from the Carpet, he caught her in his Arms
as he fell: And 'twas viible to the whole Preence, the Joy wherewith he receiv'd her; he clap'd her cloe to his Boom, and quite forgot that Reverence that was due to the Mitres of a King, and that Punihment that is the Reward of a Boldnes of this nature; and had not the Preence of Mind of Imoinda (fonder of his afety, than her own) befriended him, in making her pring from his Arms, and fall into her Dance again, he had, at that intant, met his Death; for the old King, jealous to the lat degree, roe up in Rage, broke all the Diverion, and led Imoinda to her Apartment, and ent out word to the Prince, to go immediately to the Camp; and that if he were found another Night in Court, he hou'd uffer the Death ordain'd for diobedient Offenders.

You may imagine how welcome this News was to Oroonoko, whoe uneaonable Tranport and Cares of Imoinda was blam'd by all Men that lov'd him; and now he perceiv'd his fault, yet cry'd, That for uch another Moment, he wou'd be content to die.

All the Otan was in diorder about this Accident; and Onahal was particularly concern'd, becaue on the Prince's Stay depended her Happines; for he cou'd no longer expect that of Aboan. So that, e're they departed, they contriv'd it o, that the Prince and he hou'd come both that Night to the Grove of the Otan, which was all of Oranges and Citrons, and that there they wou'd wait her Orders.

They parted thus, with Grief enough, till Night, leaving the King in poeion of the lovely Maid. But nothing could appeae the Jealouie of the old Lover; he wou'd not be impos'd on, but wou'd have it, that Imoinda made a fale Step, on purpoe to fall into Oroonoko's Boom, and that all things look'd like a Deign on both ides, and 'twas in vain he proteted her Innocence; he was old and obtinate, and left her more than half aur'd that his Fear was true.

The King going to his Apartment, ent to know where the Prince was, and if he intended to obey his Command. The Meenger return'd, and told him, he found the Prince penive, and altogether unprepared for the Campaign; that he lay negligently on the ground, and anwer'd very little. This confirm'd the Jealouie of the King, and he commanded that they hou'd very narrowly and privately watch his Motions; and that he hou'd not tir from his Apartment, but one Spy or other hou'd be employ'd to watch him. So that the hour approaching, wherein he was to go to the Citron-Grove; and taking only Aboan along with him, he leaves his Apartment, and was watch'd to the very Gate of the Otan; where he was een to enter, and where they left him, to carry back the Tidings to the King.

Oroonoko and Aboan were no ooner enter'd, but Onahal led the Prince to the Apartment of Imoinda; who, not knowing any thing of her Happines, was laid in Bed. But Onahal only left him in her Chamber, to make the bet of his Opportunity, and took her dear Aboan to
her own; where he hew'd the height of Complaiance for his Prince, when, to give him an Opportunity, he uffer'd himelf to be cares'd in Bed by Onahal.

The Prince oftly waken'd Imoinda, who was not a little urpriz'd with Joy to find him there; and yet he trembl'd with a thouand Fears. I believe he omitted aying nothing to this young Maid, that might peruade her to uffer him to eize his own, and take the Rights of Love; and I believe he was not long reiting thoe Arms where he o long'd to be; and having Opportunity, Night and Silence, Youth, Love and Deire, he oon prevail'd, and raviht in a Moment, what his old Grand-father had been endeavouring for o many Months.

'Tis not to be imagin'd the Satisfaction of thee two young Lovers; nor the Vows he made him, that he remain'd a potles Maid, till that Night; and that what he did with his Grand-father, had robb'd him of no part of her Virgin-Honour, the Gods, in Mercy and Jutice, having reerv'd that for her plighted Lord, to whom of Right it belong'd. And 'tis impoible to expres the Tranports he uffer'd, while he liten'd to a Dicoure o charming from her lov'd Lips; and clap'd that Body in his Arms, for whom he had o long languiht; and nothing now afflicted him, but his udden Departure from her; for he told her the Neceity, and his Commands; but hould depart atisfy'd in this, That ince the old King had hitherto not been able to deprive him of thoe Enloyments which only belong'd to him, he believ'd, for the future, he would be les able to
injure him; o that, abating the Scandal of the Veil, which was no otherwie o, than that he was Wife to another: He believ'd her afe, even in the Arms of the King, and innocent; yet wou'd he have ventur'd at the Conquet of the World, and have given it all, to have had her avoided that Honour of receiving the Royal Veil. 'Twas thus, between a thouand Carees, that both bemoan'd the hard fate of Youth and Beauty, o liable to that cruel Promotion: 'Twas a Glory that cou'd well have been par'd here, though deir'd and aim'd at by all the young Females of that Kingdom.

But while they were thus fondly employ'd, forgetting how Time ran on, and that the Dawn mut conduct him far away from his only Happines, they heard a great Noie in the Otan, and unuual Voices of Men; at which the Prince, tarting from the Arms of the frighted Imoinda, ran to a little Battle-Axe he us'd to wear by his Side; and having not o much leiure as to put on his Habit, he oppos'd himelf againt ome who were already opening the Door; which they did with o much Violence, that Oroonoko was not able to defend it; but was forc'd to cry out with a commanding Voice, Whoever ye are that have the Boldnes to attempt to approach this Apartment thus rudely; know that I, the Prince Oroonoko, will revenge it with the certain Death of him that firt enters: Therefore, tand back, and know, this Place is acred to Love and Me this Night; to Morrow 'tis the King's.

This he poke with a Voice o reolv'd and aur'd, that they oon retir' • from the Door;
but cry'd; 'Tis by the King's Command we are come: and being atisfy'd by thy Voice, O Prince, as much as if we had enter'd, we can report to the King the Truth of all his Fears, and leave thee to provide for thy own Safety, as thou art advis'd by thy Friends.

At thee words they departed, and left the Prince to take a hort and ad leave of his Imoinda; who truting in the trength of her Charms, believ'd he hou'd appeae the Fury of a jealous King, by aying, She was urpriz'd, and that it was by force of Arms he got into her Apartment. All her Concern now was for his Life, and therefore he haten'd him to the Camp, and with much a-doe prevail'd on him to go. Nor was it he alone that prevail'd; Aboan and Onahal both pleaded, and both aur'd him of a Lye that hou'd be well enough contriv'd to ecure Imoinda. So that at lat, with a Heart ad as Death, dying Eyes, and ighing Soul, Oroonoko departed, and took his way to the Camp.

It was not long after the King, in Peron, came to the Otan; where beholding Imoinda, with Rage in his Eyes, he upbraided her Wickednes and Perfidy; and threatning her Royal Lover, he fell on her Face at his Feet, bedewing the Floor with her Tears, and imploring his Pardon for a Fault which he had not with her Will committed; as Onahal, who was alo protrate with her, cou'd tetifie: That, unknown to her, he had broke into her Apartment, and ravih'd her. She poke this much againt her Concience; but to ave her own Life, 'twas abolutely neceary
he hou'd feign this Fality. She knew it cou'd not injure the Prince, he being fled to an Army that wou'd tand by him, againt any Injuries that hou'd aault him. However, this lat Thought of Imoinda's being Ravih'd, chang'd the meaures of his Revenge; and whereas before he deign'd to be himelf her Executioner, he now reolv'd he hou'd not die. But as it is the greatet Crime in nature amongt 'em, to touch a Woman after having been poes'd by a Son, a Father, or a Brother; o now he look'd on Imoinda as a polluted thing, wholly unfit for his Embrace: nor wou'd he reign her to his Grand-on, becaue he had receiv'd the Royal Veil. He therefore removes her from the Otan, with Onahal; whom he put into afe Hands, with order they hou'd be both old off, as Slaves, to another Country, either Chritian or Heathen, 'twas no matter where.

This cruel Sentence, wore than Death, they implor'd might be revers'd; but their Prayers were vain, and it was put in execution accordingly, and that with o much Secrecy, that none either without or within the Otan knew any thing of their Abence, or their Detiny.

When the Meenger came, he found the Prince upon the point of Engaging with the Enemy; but as oon as he heard of the arrival of the Meenger, he commanded him to his Tent, where he embrac'd him, and receiv'd him with Joy; which was oon abated, by the Down-cat Looks of the Meenger, who was intantly demanded the caue by Oroonoko, who, impatient of Delay, ask'd a thouand Quetions in a breath; and all concerning Imoinda. But there needed little Return; for he cou'd almot anwer himelf of all he demanded from his Sighs and Eyes. At lat, the Meenger cating himelf at the Prince's Feet, and kiing them, with all the Submiion of a Man that had omething to implore which he dreaded to utter, he beought him to hear with Calmnes what he had to deliver to him, and to call up all his Noble and Heroick Courage, to encounter with his Words, and defend himelf againt the ungrateful things he mut relate. Oroonoko reply'd, with a deep Sigh, and a languihing Voice,—I am arm'd againt their wort Efforts—; for I know they will tell me, Imoinda is no more—; and after that, you may pare the rest. Then, commanding him to rie, he laid himelf on a Carpet, under a rich Pavillion, and remain'd a good while ilent, and was hardly heard to igh. When he was come a little to himelf, the Meenger ask'd him leave to deliver that part of his Embay which the
Prince had not yet devin'd: And the Prince cry'd, I permit thee.—Then he told him the Affliction the old King was in, for the Rahnes he had committed, in his Cruelty to Imoinda; and how he daign'd to ask Pardon for his Offence, and to implore the Prince wou'd not uffer that Los to touch his Heart too enibly, which now all the Gods cou'd not retore him, but might recompene him in Glory, which he begg'd he wou'd purue; and that Death, that common Revenger of all Injuries, wou'd oon even the Account between him and a feeble old Man.

Oroonoko bad him return his Duty to his Lord and Mater; and to aure him, there was no Account of Revenge to be adjuted between them; if there were, 'twas he was the Aggreor, and that Death would be jut, and, maugre his Age, wou'd fee him righted; and he was contented to leave his Share of Glory to Youths more fortunate, and worthy of that Favour from the Gods. That henceforth he wou'd never lift a Weapon, or draw a Bow, but abandon the mall remains of his Life to Sighs and Tears, and the continual Thoughts of what his Lord and Grand-father had thought good to end out of the World, with all that Youth, that Innocence and Beauty.

After having poken this, what-ever his greatet Officers and Men of the bet Rank cou'd do, they cou'd not raie him from the Carpet, or peruade him to Action, and Reolutions of Life; but commanding all to retire, he hut himelf into his Pavillion all that day, while the Enemy was ready to engage
and wondring at the Delay, the whole Body of the chief of the Army then addres'd themelves to him, and to whom they had much a-doe to get Admittance. They fell on their Faces at the Foot of his Carpet; where they lay, and beought him with earnet Prayers and Tears, to lead'em forth to Battle, and not let the Enemy take Advantages of them; and implor'd him to have regard to his Glory, and to the World, that depended on his Courage and Conduct. But he made no other Reply to all their Supplications, but this; That he had now no more buines for Glory; and for the World, it was a Trifle not worth his Care: Go (continu'd he, ighing) and divide it amongt you, and reap with Joy what you o vainly prize, and leave me to my more welcome Detiny.

They then demanded what they hou'd do, and whom he wou'd contitute in his room, that the Confuion of ambitious Youth and Power might not ruine their Order, and make them a Prey to the Enemy. He reply'd; He wou'd not give himelf the Trouble—; but wih'd 'em to chue the bravet Man amongt 'em, let his Quality or Birth be what it wou'd: For, O my Friends! (aid he) it is not Titles make Men Brave or Good; or Birth, that betows Courage and Generoity, or makes the Owner Happy: Believe this, when you behold Oroonoko, the most wretched, and abandon'd by Fortune, of all the Creation of the Gods. So turning himelf about, he wou'd make no more Reply to all they cou'd urge or implore.

The Army beholding their Officers return unuccesful, with ad Faces, and ominous
Looks, that preage'd no good Luck, uffer'd a thouand Fears to take poeion of their Hearts, and the Enemy to come ev'n upon 'em, before they wou'd provide for their Safety, by any Defence; and though they were aur'd by ome, who had a mind to animate 'em, that they hou'd be immediately Headed by the Prince, and that in the mean time Aboan had Orders to Command as General; yet they were o dimay'd for want of that great Example of Bravery, that they cou'd make but a very feeble Reitance; and at lat, downright, fled before the Enemy, who puru'd 'em to the very Tents, killing 'em: Nor cou'd all Aboan's Courage, which that day gain'd him immortal Glory, hame 'em into a Manly Defence of themelves. The Guards that were left behind about the Prince's Tent, eeing the Soldiers flee before the Enemy, and eatter themelves all over the Plain, in great Diorder, made uch Out-cries as rouz'd the Prince from his amorous Slumber, in which he had remain'd bury'd for two Days, without permitting any Sutenance to approach him. But, in pite of all his Reolutions, he had not the contancy of Grief to that degree, as to make him inenible of the Danger of his Army; and in that intant he leap'd from his Couch, and cry'd,—Come, if we must die, let us meet Death the noblet way; and 'twill be more like Oroonoko to encounter him at an Army's Head, oppoing the Torrent of a conquering Foe, than lazily, on a Couch, to wait his lingering Pleaure, and die every moment by a thouand racking Thoughts; or be tamely taken by an Enemy, and led a whining
Love-ick Slave, to adorn the Triumphs of Jamoan, that young Victor, who already is enter'd beyond the Limits I had precrib'd him.

While he was peaking, he uffer'd his People to dres him for the Field; and allying out of his Pavillion, with more Life and Vigour in his Countenance than ever he hew'd, he appear'd like ome Divine Power decended to ave his Countrey from Detruction; and his People had purpoely put him on all things that might make him hine with mot Splendor, to trike a reverend Awe into the Beholders. He flew into the thicket of thoe that were puruing his Men; and being animated with Depair, he fought as if he came on purpoe to die, and did uch things as will not be believ'd that Humane Strength cou'd perform; and uch as oon inpir'd all the ret with new Courage, and new Order: And now it was, that they began to fight indeed; and o, as if they wou'd not be out-done ev'n by their ador'd Hero; who turning the Tide of the Victory, changing abolutely the Fate of the Day, gain'd an entire Conquet; and Oroonoko having the good fortune to ingle out Jamoan, he took him Prioner with his own Hand, having wounded him almot to death.

This Jamoan afterwards became very dear to him, being a Man very gallant, and of excellent Graces, and fine Parts; o that he never put him amongt the Rank of Captives, as they us'd to do, without ditinction, for the common Sale, or Market; but kept him in his own Court, where he retain'd nothing of the Prioner but the Name, and return'd no more
into his own Countrey, o great an Affection he took for Oroonoko; and by a thouand Tales and Adventures of Love and Gallantry, flatter'd his Dieae of Melancholy and Languihment; which I have often heard him ay, had certainly kill'd him, but for the Converation of this Prince and Aboan, the French Governor he had from his Childhood, of whom I have poken before, and who was a Man of admirable Wit, great Ingenuity and Learning; all which he had infus'd into his young Pupil. This French-man was baniht out of his own Countrey, for ome Heretical Notions he held; and though he was a Man of very little Religion, he had admirable Morals, and a brave Soul.

After the total Defeat of Jamoan's Army, which all fled, or were left dead upon the Place, they pent ome time in the Camp; Oroonoko chuing rather to remain a while there in his Tents, than to enter into a Palace, or live in a Court where he had o lately uffer'd o great a Los. The Officers therefore, who aw and knew his caue of Dicontent, invented all orts of Diverions and Sports, to entertain their Prince: So that what with thoe Amuzements abroad, and others at home, that is, within their Tents, with the Peruaions, Arguments and Care of his Friends and Servants that he more peculiarly priz'd, he wore off, in time, a great part of that Shagrien, and Torture of Depair, which the firt Efforts of Imoinda's Death had given him: inomuch as having receiv'd a thouand kind Embaies from the King, and Invitations to return to Court, he obey'd,
though with no little reluctancy; and when he did o, there was a viible change in him, and for a long time he was much more melancholy than before. But Time leens all Extremes, and reduces 'em to Medium's, and Unconcern; but no Motives or Beauties, though all endeavour'd it, cou'd engage him in any ort of Amour, though he had all the Invitations to it, both from his own Youth, and others Ambitions and Deigns.

Oroonoko was no ooner return'd from this lat Conquet, and receiv'd at Court with all the Joy and Magnificence that cou'd be expres'd to a young Victor, who was not only return'd triumphant, but belov'd like a Deity, when there arriv'd in the Port an Englih Ship.
This Peron had often before been in thee Countries, and was very well known to Oroonoko, with whom he had traffick'd for Slaves, and had us'd to do the ame with his Predeceors.

This Commander was a Man of a finer ort of Addres, and Converation, better bred, and more engaging, than mot of that ort of Men are; o that he eem'd rather never to have been bred out of a Court, than almot all his life at Sea. This Captain therefore was always better receiv'd at Court, than mot of the Traders to thoe Countries were; and epecially by Oroonoko, who was more civiliz'd, according to the Europaean Mode, than any other had been, and took more delight in the White Nations; and, above all, Men of Parts and Wit. To this Captain he old abundance of
his Slaves; and for the Favour and Eteem he had for him, made him many Preents, and oblig'd him to tay at Court as long as poibly he cou'd. Which the Captain eem'd to take as a very great Honour done him, entertaining the Prince every day with Globes and Maps, and Mathematical Dicoures and Intruments; eating, drinking, hunting and living with him with o much familiarity, that it was not to be doubted but he had gain'd very greatly upon the Heart of this gallant young Man. And the Captain, in Return of all thee mighty Favours, beought the Prince to honour his Veel with his Preence, ome day or other, to Dinner, before he hou'd et ail: which he condecended to accept, and appointed his day. The Captain, • on his part, fail'd not to have all things in a readines, in the mot magnificent order he cou'd poibly: And the day being come, the Captain, in his Boat, richly adorn'd with Carpets and Velvet-Cuhions, row'd to the hore, to receive the Prince; with another Long-Boat, where was plac'd all his Muick and Trumpets, with which Oroonoko was extremely delighted; who met him on the hore, attended by his French Governor, Jamoan, Aboan, and about an hundred of the noblet of the Youths of the Court: And after they had firt carry'd the Prince on board, the Boats fetch'd the ret off: where they found a very plendid Treat, with all orts of fine Wines; and were as well entertain'd, as 'twas poible in uch a place to be.

The Prince having drank hard of Punch, and everal orts of Wine, as did all the ret,
(for great care was taken, they hou'd want nothing of that part of the Entertainment) was very merry, and in great admiration of the Ship, for he had never been in one before; o that he was curious of beholding every place where he decently might decend. The ret, no les curious, who were not quite overcome with Drinking, rambl'd at their pleaure Fore and Aft, as their Fancies guided 'em: So that the Captain, who had well laid his Deign before, gave the Word, and eiz'd on all his Guets; they clapping great Irons uddenly on the Prince, when he was leap'd down into the Hold, to view that part of the Veel; and locking him fat down, ecur'd him. The ame Treachery was us'd to all the ret; and all in one intant, in everal places of the Ship, were lah'd fat in Irons, and betray'd to Slavery. That great Deign over, they et all Hands to work to hoie Sail; and with as treacherous and fair a Wind they made from the Shore with this innocent and glorious Prize, who thought of nothing les than uch an Entertainment.

Some have commended this Act, as brave in the Captain; but I will pare my ene of it, and leave it to my Reader to judge as he pleaes. It may be eaily gues'd, in what manner the Prince reented this Indignity, who may be bet reembl'd to a Lion taken in a Toil; o he rag'd, o he truggl'd for Liberty, but all in vain; and they had o wiely manag'd his Fetters, that he cou'd not ue a Hand in his defence, to quit himelf of a Life that wou'd by no means endure Slavery; nor cou'd he move from the place where he was ty'd, to
any olid part of the Ship againt which he might have beat his Head, and have finih'd his Digrace that way: So that being deprived of all other means, he reolv'd to perih for want of Food; and pleas'd at lat with that Thought, and toil'd and tir'd by Rage and Indignation, he laid himelf down, and ullenly reolv'd upon dying, and refued all things that were brought him.

This did not a little vex the Captain, and the more o, becaue he found almot all of 'em of the ame Humour: o that the los of o many brave Slaves, o tall and goodly to behold, wou'd have been very coniderable: He therefore order'd one to go from him (for he wou'd not be een himelf) to Oroonoko, and to aure him, he was afflicted for having rahly done o unhopitable a Deed, and which cou'd not be now remedy'd, ince they were far from hore; but ince he reented it in o high a nature, he aur'd him he wou'd revoke his Reolution, and et both him and his Friends a-hore on the next Land they hou'd touch at; and of this the Meenger gave him his Oath, provided he would reolve to live: And Oroonoko, whoe Honour was uch as he never had violated a Word in his Life himelf, much les a olemn Aeveration, believ'd in an intant what this Man aid; but reply'd, He expected, for a confirmation of this, to have his hameful Fetters dimis'd. This Demand was carried to the Captain; who return'd him anwer, That the Offence had been o great which he had put upon the Prince, that he durt not trut him with Liberty while he remain'd in the Ship,
for fear let by a Valour natural to him, and a Revenge that wou'd animate that Valour, he might commit ome Outrage fatal to himelf, and the King his Mater, to whom his Veel did belong. To this Oroonoko reply'd; He would engage his Honour to behave himelf in all friendly Order and Manner, and obey the Command of the Captain, as he was Lord of the King's Veel, and General of thoe Men under his Command.

This was deliver'd to the till doubting Captain, who could not reolve to trut a Heathen, he aid, upon his Parole, a Man that had no Sene or Notion of the God that he worhipp'd. Oroonoko then reply'd; He was very orry to hear that the Captain pretended to the Knowledge and Worhip of any Gods, who had taught him no better Principles, than not to Credit as he would be Credited. But they told him, the Difference of their Faith occaion'd that Ditrut: For the Captain had proteted to him upon the Word of a Chritian, and worn in the Name of a Great GOD; which if he hou'd violate, he would expect eternal Torment in the World to come. Is that all the Obligation he has to be Jut to his Oath? (replied Oroonoko.)
