Let him know, I wear by my Honour; which to violate, would not only render me contemptible and depied by all brave and honet Men, and o give my elf perpetual pain, but it wou'd be eternally offending and dipleaing all Mankind; harming, betraying, circumventing and outraging all Men: but Punihments hereafter are uffer'd by one's elf; and the World takes no cognizances whether this God have reveng'd 'em, or not, 'tis
done o ecretly, and deferr'd o long: While the Man of no Honour uffers every moment the corn and contempt of the honeter World, and dies every day ignominiouly in his Fame, which is more valuable than Life: I peak not this to move Belief, but to hew you how you mitake, when you imagine, That he who will violate his Honour, will keep his Word with his Gods. So, turning from him with a didainful mile, he refued to anwer him, when he urg'd him to know what Anwer he hou'd carry back to his Captain; o that he departed without aying any more.

The Captain pondering and conulting what to do, it was concluded that nothing but Oroonoko's Liberty wou'd encourage any of the ret to eat, except the French-man, whom the Captain cou'd not pretend to keep Prioner, but only told him, he was ecured, becaue he might act omething in favour of the Prince, but that he hou'd be freed as oon as they came to Land. So that they concluded it wholly neceary to free the Prince from his Irons, that he might hew himelf to the ret; that they might have an eye upon him, and that they cou'd not fear a ingle Man.

This being reolv'd; to make the Obligation the greater, the Captain himelf went to Oroonoko; where, after many Complements, and Aurances of what he had already promis'd, he receiving from the Prince his Parole, and his Hand, for his good Behaviour, dimis'd his Irons, and brought him to his own Cabin; where, after having treated and repos'd him a while, (for he had neither eat nor lept in four days before) he beought him to viit thoe
obtinate People in Chains, who refus'd all manner of Sutenance; and entreated him to oblige 'em to eat, and aure 'em of their Liberty the firt Opportunity.

Oroonoko, who was too generous, not to give credit to his Words, hew'd himelf to his People, who were tranported with Exces of Joy at the ight of their Darling Prince; falling at his Feet, and kiing and embracing 'em; believing, as ome Divine Oracle, all he aur'd 'em. But he beought 'em to bear their Chains with that Bravery that became thoe whom he had een act o nobly in Arms; and that they cou'd not give him greater Proofs of their Love and Friendhip, ince 'twas all the Security the Captain (his Friend) cou'd have, againt the Revenge, he aid, they might poibly jutly take, for the Injuries utain'd by him. And they all, with one accord, aur'd him, they cou'd not uffer enough, when it was for his Repoe and Safety.

After this, they no longer refus'd to eat, but took what was brought 'em, and were pleas'd with their Captivity, ince by it they hop'd to redeem the Prince, who, all the ret of the Voyage, was treated with all the repect due to his Birth, tho' nothing cou'd divert his Melancholy; and he wou'd often igh for Imoinda, and think this a Punihment due to his Misfortune, in having left that Noble Maid behind him, that fatal Night, in the Otan, when he fled to the Camp.

Poes'd with a thouand Thoughts of pat Joys with this fair young Peron, and a thouand Griefs for her eternal Los, he endur'd a
tedious Voyage, and at lat arriv'd at the Mouth of the River of Surinam, a Colony belonging to the King of England, and where they were to deliver ome part of their Slaves. There the Merchants and Gentlemen of the Country going on Board, to demand thoe Lots of Slaves they had already agreed on, and, amongt thoe, the Over-eers of thoe Plantations where I then chanc'd to be; the Captain, who had given the Word, order'd his Men to bring up thoe • noble Slaves in Fetters, whom I have poken of; and having put 'em, ome in one, and ome in other Lots, with Women and Children (which they call Pickaninies,) they old 'em off, as Slaves, to everal Merchants and Gentlemen; not putting any two in one Lot, becaue they wou'd eparate 'em far from each other; not daring to trut 'em together, let Rage and Courage hou'd put 'em upon contriving ome great Action, to the Ruine of the Colony.

Oroonoko was firt eiz'd on, and old to our Over-eer, who had the firt Lot, with eventeen more of all orts and izes, but not one of Quality with him. When he aw this, he found what they meant; for, as I aid, he undertood Englih pretty well; and being wholly unarm'd and defenceles, o as it was in vain to make any Reitance, he only beheld the Captain with a Look all fierce and didainful, upbraiding him with Eyes that forc'd Bluhes on his guilty Cheeks, he only cry'd, in paing over the ide of the Ship; Farewell, Sir: 'Tis worth my Suffering, to gain o true a Knowledge both of you, and of your Gods by whom you wear
And deiring thoe that held him to forbear their pains, and telling 'em he wou'd make no Reitance, he cry'd, Come, my Fellow-Slaves; let us decend, and ee if we can meet with more Honour and Honety in the next World we hall touch upon. So he nimbly leapt into the Boat, and hewing no more Concern, uffer'd himelf to be row'd up the River, with his Seventeen Companions.

The Gentleman that bought him, was a young Conih Gentleman, whoe Name was Trefry; a Man of great Wit, and fine Learning, and was carry'd into thoe Parts by the Lord—Governor, to manage all his Affairs. He reflecting on the lat World of Oroonoko to the Captain, and beholding the Richnes of his Vet, no ooner came into the Boat, but he fix'd his Eyes on him; and finding omething o extraordinary in his Face, his Shape and Mien, a Greatnes of Look, and Haughtines in his Air, and finding he poke Englih, had a great Mind to be enquiring into his Quality and Fortune; which, though Oroonoko endeavour'd to hide, by only confeing he was above the Rank of common Slaves, Trefry oon found he was yet omething greater than he confes'd; and from that Moment began to conceive o vat an Eteem for him, that he ever after lov'd him as his dearet Brother, and hew'd him all the Civilities due to o great a Man.

Trefry was a very good Mathematician, and a Linguit; cou • d peak French and Spanih; and in the three Days they remain'd in the Boat (for o long were they going from the
Ship, to the Plantation) he entertain'd Oroonoko o agreeably with his Art and Dicoure, that he was no les pleas'd with Trefry, than he was with the Prince; and he thought himelf, at leat, fortunate in this, that ince he was a Slave, as long as he won'd uffer himelf to remain o, he had a Man of o excellent Wit and Parts for a Mater: So that before they had finih'd their Voyage up the River, he made no cruple of declaring to Trefry all his Fortunes, and mot part of what I have here related, and put himelf wholly into the Hands of his new Friend, whom he found reenting all the Injuries were done him, and was charm'd with all the Greatnees of his Actions; which were recited with that Modety, and delicate Sence, as wholly vanquih'd him, and ubdu'd him to his Interet. And he promis'd him on his Word and Honour, he wou'd find the Means to re-conduct him to his own Country again: auring him, he had a perfect Abhorrence of o dihonourable an Action; and that he wou'd ooner have dy'd, than have been the Author of uch a Perfidy. He found the Prince was very much concern'd to know what became of his Friends, and how they took their Slavery; and Trefry promis'd to take care about the enquiring after their Condition, and that he hou'd have an Account of 'em.

Though, as Oroonoko afterwards aid, he had little Reaon to credit the Words of a Backearary, yet he knew not why; but he aw a king of Sincerity, and awful Truth in the Face of Trefry; he aw an Honety in his Eyes, and
he found him wie and witty enough to undertand Honour: for it was one of his Maxims, A Man of Wit cou'd not be a Knave or Villain.

In their paage up the River, they put in at everal Houes for Refrehment; and ever when they landed, numbers of People wou'd flock to behold this Man; not but their Eyes were daily entertain'd with the ight of Slaves, but the Fame of Oroonoko was gone before him, and all People were in admiration of his Beauty. Beides, he had a rich Habit on, in which he was taken, o different from the ret, and which the Captain cou'd not trip him of, becaue he was forc'd to urprize his Peron in the minute he old him. When he found his Habit made him liable, as he thought, to be gaz'd at the more, he begg'd Trefry to give him omething more befitting a Slave; which he did, and took off his Robes. Nevertheles, he hone through all, and his Oenbrigs (a ort of brown Holland Suit he had on) cou'd not conceal the Graces of his Looks and Mien; and he had no les Admirers, than when he had his dazling Habit on; the Royal Youth appear'd in pite of the Slave, and People cou'd not help treating him after a different manner, without deigning it: As oon as they approach'd him, they venerated and eteem'd him; his Eyes inenibly commanded Repect, and his Behaviour ininuated it into every Soul. So that there was nothing talk'd of but this young and gallant Slave, even by thoe who yet knew not that he was a Prince.

I ought to tell you, that the Chritians never but any Slaves but they give 'em ome Name
of their own, their native ones being likely very barbarous, and hard to pronounce; o that Mr. Trefry gave Oroonoko that of Caear: which Name will live in that Countrey as long as that (carce more) glorious one of the great Roman; for 'tis mot evident, he wanted no part of the Peronal Courage of that Caear, and acted things as memorable, had they been done in ome part of the World replenih'd with People, and Hitorians, that might have given him his due. But his Misfortune was, to fall in an obcure World, that afforded only a Female Pen to celebrate his Fame; though I doubt not but it had liv'd from others Endeavours, if the Dutch, who, immediately after his time, took that Countrey, had not kill'd, banih'd and dipers'd all thoe that were capable of giving the World this great Man's Life, much better than I have done. And Mr. Trefry, who deign'd it, dy'd before he began it, and bemoan'd himelf for not having undertook it in time.

For the future therefore, I mut call Oroonoko, Caear; Since by that Name only he was known in our Wetern World, and by that Name he was receiv'd on Shore at Parham-Houe, where he was detin'd a Slave. But if the King himelf (God bles him) had come a-hore, there cou'd not have been greater Expectations by all the whole Plantation, and thoe neighbouring ones, than was on ours at that time; and he was receiv'd more like a Governor, than a Slave. Notwithtanding, as the Cutom was, they aign'd him his portion of Land, his Houe, and his Buines, up in the
Plantation. But as it was more for Form, than any Deign, to put him to his Task, he endur'd no more of the Slave but the Name, and remain'd ome Days in the Houe, receiving all Viits that were made him, without tirring towards that part of the Plantation where the Negroes were.

At lat, he wou'd needs go view his Land, his Houe, and the Buines aign'd him. But he no ooner came to the Houes of the Slaves, which are like a little Town by it elf, the Negroes all having left Work, but they all came forth to behold him, and found he was that Prince who had, at everal times, old mot of 'em to thee Parts; and, from a Veneration they pay to great Men, epecially if they know 'em, and from the Surprize and Awe they had at the ight of him, they all cat themelves at his Feet, crying out, in their Language, Live, O King! Long live, O King! And kiing his Feet, paid him even Divine Homage.

Several Englih Gentlemen were with him; and what Mr. Trefry had told 'em, was here confirm'd; of which he himelf before had no other Witnes than Caear himelf: But he was infinitely glad to find his Grandure confirm'd by the Adoration of all the Slaves.

Caear troubl'd with their Over-Joy, and Over-Ceremony, beought 'em to rie, and to receive him as their Fellow-Slave; auring them, he was no better. At which they et up with one Accord a mot terrible and hidious Mourning and Condoling, which he and the Englih had much a-do to appeae; but at lat they prevail'd with 'em, and they prepar'd
all their barbarous Muick, and every one kill'd and dres'd omething of his own Stock (for every Family has their Land a-part, on which, at their leiure-times, they breed all eatable things; and clubbing it together, made a mot magnificent Supper, inviting their Grandee Captain, their Prince, to honour it with his Preence; which he did, and everal Englih with him; where they all waited on him, ome playing, others dancing before him all the time, according to the Manners of their everal Nations; and with unwearied Indutry, endeavouring to pleae and delight him.

While they at at Meat, Mr. Trefry told Caear, that mot of thee young Salves were undone in Love, with a fine She-Slave, whom they had had about Six Months on their Land; the Prince, who never heard the Name of Love without a Sigh, nor any mention of it without the Curioity of examining further into that tale, which of all Dicoures was mot agreeable to him, asked, how they came to be o Unhappy, as to be all Undone for one fair Slave? Trefry, who was naturally Amorous, and lov'd to talk of Love as well as any body, proceeded to tell him, they had the mot charming Black that ever was beheld on their Plantation, about fifteen or ixteen Years old, as he gues'd that, for his part, he had done nothing but Sigh for her ever ince he came; and that all the White Beauties he had een, never charm'd him o abolutely as this fine Creature had done; and that no Man, of any Nation, ever beheld her, that did not fall in Love with her; and that he had all the Slaves perpetually
at her Feet; and the whole Countrey reounded with the Fame of Clemene, for o (aid he) we have Chriten'd her: But he denies us all with uch a noble Didain, that 'tis a Miracle to ee, that he, who can give uch eternal Deires, hou'd her elf be all Ice and all Unconcern. She is adorn'd with the mot graceful Modety that ever beautify'd Youth; the oftet Sigher;—that, if he were capable of Love, one wou'd wear he languih'd for ome abent happy Man; and o retir'd, as if he fear'd a Rape even from the God of Day, or that the Breezes wou'd teal Kies from her delicate Mouth: Her Task of Work, ome ighing Lover every Day makes it his Petition to perform for her; which he accepts, bluhing, and with reluctancy, for fear he will ask her a Look for a Recompence, which he dares not preume to hope; o great an Awe he trikes into the Hearts of her Admirers. I do not wonder (reply'd the Prince) that Clemene hou'd refue Slaves, being, as you ay, o Beautiful; but wonder how he ecapes thoe who can entertain her as you can do: or why, being your Slave, you do not oblige her to yield. I confes (aid Trefry) when I have, against her Will, entertain'd her with Love o long, as to be tranported with my Paion even above Decency, I have been ready to make ue of thoe advantages of Strength and Force Nature has given me: But, oh! he diarms me, with that Modety and Weeping, o tender and o moving, that I retire, and thank my Stars he overcame me. The Company laugh'd at his Civility to a Slave, and Caear only applauded the Noblenes of his Paion and Nature; ince that
Slave might be Noble, or, what was better, have true Notions of Honour and Vertue in her. Thus pas'd they this Night, after having receiv'd from the Slaves all imaginable Repect and Obedience.

The next day, Trefry ask'd Caear to walk when the Heat was allay'd, and deignedly carry'd him by the Cottage of the fair Slave; and told him, he whom he poke of lat night liv'd there retir'd: But (ays he) I wou'd not wih you to approach; for I am ure, you will be in Love as oon as you behold her. Caear aur'd him, he was Proof againt all the Charms of that Sex; and that if he imagin'd his Heart cou'd be o perfidious to Love again, after Imoinda, he believ'd he hou'd tear it from his Boom. They had no ooner poke, but a little Shock-Dog, that Clemene had preented her, which he took great delight in, ran out; and he, not knowing any body was there, ran to get it in again, and bolted out on thoe who were jut peaking of her: When, eeing them, he wou'd have run in again; but Trefry caught her by the Hand, and cry'd; Clemene, however you flie a Lover, you ought to pay ome Repect to this Stranger, (pointing to Caear.) But he, as if he had reolv'd never to raie her Eyes to the Face of a Man again, bent 'em the more to the Earth, when he poke, and gave the Prince the leiure to look the more at her. There needed no long Gazing, or Conideration, to examine who this fair Creature was; he oon aw Imoinda all over her; in a minute he aw her Face, her Shape, her Air, her Modety, and all that call'd forth his Soul with Joy at
his Eyes, and left his Body detitute of almot Life; it tood without Motion, and, for a Minute, knew not that it had a Being: and, I believe, he had never come to himelf, o oppres'd he was with Over-joy, if he had not met with this Allay, that he perceiv'd Imoinda fall dead in the Hands of Trefry: This awaken'd him, and he ran to her Aid, and caught her in his Arms, where, by degrees, he came to her elf; and 'tis needles to tell with what Tranports, what Extaies of Joy, they both a while beheld each other, without Speaking; then Snatch'd each other to their Arms; then Gaze again, as if they till doubted whether they poes'd the Bleing: They Grap'd; but when they recover'd their Speech, 'tis not to be imagin'd, what tender Things they expres'd to each other; wondering what trange Fate had brought 'em again together. They oon inform'd each other of their Fortunes, and equally bewail'd their Fate; but, at the ame time, they mutually proteted, that even Fetters and Slavery were Soft and Eaie; and wou'd be upported with Joy and Pleaure, while they cou'd be o happy to poes each other, and to be able to make good their Vows. Caear wore he didain'd the Empire of the World, while he cou'd behold his Imoinda; and he depis'd Grandure and Pomp, thoe Vanities of her Sex, when he cou'd Gaze on Oroonoko. He ador'd the very Cottage where he reided, and aid, That little Inch of the World wou'd give him more Happines than all the Univere cou'd do; and he vow'd, It was a Palace, while adorn'd with the Preence of Oroonoko.

Trefry was infinitely pleas'd with this Novel, and found this Clemene was the Fair Mitres of whom Caear had before poke; and was not a little atisfied, that Heaven was o kind to the Prince, as to weeten his Misfortunes by o lucky an Accident; and leaving the Lovers to themelves, was impatient to come down to Parham-Houe, (which was on the ame Plantation) to give me an Account of what had hapned. I was as impatient to make thee Lovers a Viit, having already made a Friendhip with Caear; and from his own Mouth learn'd what I have related, which was confirmed by his Frenchman, who was et on Shoar to eek his Fortunes; and of whom they cou'd not make a Slave, becaue a Chritian; and he came daily to Parham-Hill to ee and pay his Repects to his Puple Prince: So that concerning and intreting my elf, in all that related to Caear, whom I had aur'd of Liberty, as oon as the Governor arriv'd, I hated preently to the Place where the Lovers were, and was infinitely glad to find this Beautiful young Slave (who had already gain'd all our Eteems, for her Modety and her extraordinary Prettines) to be the ame I had heard Caear peak o much of. One may imagine then we paid her a treble Repect; and though from her being carv'd in fine Flowers and Birds all over her Body, we took her to be of Quality before, yet, when we knew Clemene was Imoinda, we cou'd not enough admire her.

I had forgot to tell you, that thoe who are Nobly born of that Country, are o delicately Cut and Rac'd all over the fore-part of the
Trunk of their Bodies, that it looks as if it were Japan'd, the Works being raied like high Poynt round the edges of the Flowers. Some are only carv'd with a little Flower, or Bird, at the ides of the Temples, as was Caear; and thoe who are o carv'd over the Body, reemble our Ancient Picts that are figur'd in the Chronicles, but thee Carvings are more delicate.

From that happy Day Caear took Clemene for his Wife, to the general Joy of all People; and there was as much Magnificence as the Countrey wou'd afford at the Celebration of this Wedding: and in a very hort time after he conceiv'd with Child; which made Caear even adore her, knowing he was the lat of his Great Race. This new Accident made him more impatient of Liberty, and he was every day treating with Trefry for his and Clemene's Liberty, and offer'd either Gold, or a vat quantity of Slaves, which hou'd be paid before they let him go, provided he cou'd have any Security that he hou'd go when his Ranom was paid. They fed him from Day to Day with Promies, and delay'd him till the Lord-Governor hou'd come; o that he began to upect them of falhood, and that they wou'd delay him till the time of his Wife's Delivery, and make a Slave of that too; for all the Breed is theirs to whom the Parents belong: This Thought made him very uneaie, and his Sullennes gave them ome Jealouies of him; o that I was oblig'd, by ome Perons who fear'd a Mutiny (which is very fatal ometimes in thoe Colonies, that abound o with Slaves,
that they exceed the Whites in vat Numbers) to dicoure with Caear, and to give him all the Satisfaction I proibly could; they knew he and Clemene were carce an Hour in a Day from my Lodgings; that they eat with me, and that I oblig'd 'em in all things I was capable of: I entertain'd 'em with the Lives of the Romans, and Great Men; which charm'd him to my Company; and her, with teaching her all the pretty Works that I was Mitres of, and telling her Stories of Nuns, and endeavouring to bring her to the Knowledge of the True God. But of all Dicoures, Caear lik'd that the wort, and wou'd never be reconcil'd to our Notions of the Trinity, of which he ever made a Jet: it was a Riddle, he aid, wou'd turn his Brain to conceive, and one cou'd not make him undertand what Faith was. However, thee Converations fail'd not altogether o well to divert him, that he lik'd the Company of us Women much above the Men: for he cou'd not drink; and he is but an ill Companion in that Countrey that cannot: So that obliging him to love us very well, we had all the liberty of Speech with him, epecially my elf, whom he calld his Great Mitres; and, indeed, my Word wou'd go a great way with him. For thee Reaons, I had opportunity to take notice to him, that he was not well pleas'd of late, as he us'd to be; was more retir'd and thoughtful; and told him, I took it ill he hou'd Supect we wou'd break our Words with him, and not permit both him and Clemene to return to his own Kingdom, which was not o long a way, but, when he was once on his Voyage,
he wou'd quickly arrive there. He made me ome Anwers that hew'd a doubt in him, which made me ask what advantage it wou'd be to doubt? it would but give us a Fear of him, and poibly compel us to treat him o as I hou'd be very loath to behold: that is, it might occaion his Confinement. Perhaps this was not o luckily poke of me, for I perceiv'd he reented that Word, which I trove to often again in vain: However, he aur'd me, that whatoever Reolutions he hou'd take, he wou'd Act nothing upon the White-People; and as for my elf, and thoe upon that Plantation where he was, he wou'd ooner forfeit his eternal Liberty, and Life it elf, than lift his Hand againt his greatet Enemy on that Place: He beought me to uffer no Fears upon his Account, for he cou'd do nothing that Honour hou'd not dictate; but he accus'd himelf for having uffer'd Slavery o long; yet he charg'd that weaknes on Love alone, who was capable of making him neglect even Glory it elf; and, for which, now he reproaches himelf every moment of the Day. Much more to this effect he poke, with an Air impatient enough to make me know he wou'd not be long in Bondage; and though he uffer'd only the Name of a Slave, and had nothing of the Toil and Labour of one, yet that was ufficient to render him Uneaie; and he had been too long Idle, who us'd to be always in Action, and in Arms: He had a Spirit all Rough and Fierce, and that cou'd not be tam'd to lazy Ret; and though all endeavours were us'd to exercie himelf in uch Actions and Sports as this
World afforded, as Running, Wretling, Pitching the Bar; Hunting and Fihing, Chaing and Killing Tigers of a montrous Size, which this Continent affords in abundance; and wonderful Snakes, uch as Alexander is reported to have incounter'd at the River of Amazons, and which Caear took great Delight to overcome; yet thee were not Actions great enough for his large Soul, which was till panting after more renown'd Action.

Before I parted that Day with him, I got, with much ado, a Promie from him to ret yet a little longer with Patience, and wait the coming of the Lord Governor, who was every Day expected on our Shore; he aur'd me he wou'd, and this Promie he deired me to know was given perfectly in Complaiance to me, in whom he had an intire Confidence.

After this, I neither thought it convenient to trut him much out of our View, nor did the Country who fear'd him; but with one accord it was advis'd to treat him fairly, and oblige him to remain within uch a compas, and that he hou'd be permitted, as eldom as cou'd be, to go up to the Plantations of the Negroes; or, if he did, to be accompany'd by ome that hou'd be rather in appearance Attendants than Spys. This Care was for ome time taken, and Caear look'd upon it as a Mark of extraordinary Repect, and was glad his dicontent had oblig'd 'em to be more obervant to him; he received new aurance from the Overeer, which was confirmed to him by the Opinion of all the Gentlemen of the Country, who made their court to him: During this time that we had
his Company more frequently than hitherto we had had, it may not be unpleaant to relate to you the Diverions we entertaind'd him with, or rather he us.

My tay was to be hort in that Countrey; becaue my Father dy'd at Sea, and never arriv'd to poes the Honour was deign'd him, (which was Lieutenant-General of Six and thirty Ilands, beides the Continent of Surinam,) nor the Advantages he hop'd to reap by them: o that though we were oblig'd to continue on our Voyage, we did not intend to tay upon the Place. Though, in a word, I mut ay thus much of it; That certainly, had his late Majety, of acred Memory, but een and known what a vat and charming World he had been Mater of in that Continent, he wou'd never have parted o eaily with it to the Dutch. 'Tis a Continent whoe vat Extent was never yet known, and may contain more Noble Earth than all the Univere beide; for, they ay, it reaches from Eat to Wet one way as far as China, and another to Peru: It affords all things both for Beauty and Ue; 'tis there Eternal Spring, always the very Months of April, May and June; the Shades are perpetual, the Trees bearing at once all degrees of Leaves and Fruit, from blooming Buds to ripe Autumn: Groves of Oranges, Limons, Citrons, Figs, Nutmegs, and noble Aromaticks, continually bearing their Fragrancies. The Trees appearing all like Noegays adorn'd with Flowers of different kinds; ome are all White, ome Purple, ome Scarlet, ome Blue, ome Yellow; bearing, at the ame time, Ripe Fruit and Blooming Young, or producing
every day new. The very Wood of all thee Trees have an intrinick Value above common Timber; for they are, when cut, of different Colours, glorious to behold; and bear a price coniderable, to Inlay withal. Beides this, they yield rich Balm, and Gums; o that we make our Candles of uch an Aromatick Subtance, as does not only give a ufficient Light, but, as they burn, they cat their Perfumes all about. Cedar is the common Firing, and all the Houes are built with it. The very Meat we eat, when et on the Table, if it be Native, I mean, of the Countrey, perfumes the whole Room; epecially a little Beat call'd an Armadilly, a thing which I can liken to nothing o well as a Rhinoceros; 'tis all in white Armour, o jointed, that it moves as well in it, as if it had nothing on; this Beat is about the bignes of a Pig of ix Weeks old. But it were endles to give an Account of all the divers Wonderful and Strange things that Countrey affords, and which we took a very great delight to go in earch of; though thoe Adventures are oftentimes Fatal, and at leat Dangerous: But while we had Caear in our Company on thee Deigns, we fear'd no harm, nor uffer'd any.

As oon as I came into the Countrey, the bet Houe in it was preented me, call'd St. John's Hill: It tood on a vat Rock of white Marble, at the foot of which the River ran a vat depth down, and not to be decended on that ide; the little Waves till dahing and wahing the foot of this Rock, made the oftet Murmurs and Purlings in the World; and the oppoite Bank was adorn'd with uch vat quantities of
different Flowers eternally Blowing, and every Day and Hour new, fenc'd behind 'em with lofty Trees of a thouand rare Forms and Colours, that the Propect was the mot ravihing that Sands can create. On the edge of this white Rock, towards the River, was a Walk or Grove of Orange and Limon-Trees, about half the length of the Mall here, whoe Flowery and Fruit-bearing Branches met at the top, and hinder'd the Sun, whoe Rays are very fierce there, from entering a Beam into the Grove; and the cool Air that came from the River, made it not only fit to entertain People in, at all the hottet hours of the day, but refreh'd the weet Blooms, and made it always Sweet and Charming; and ure, the whole Globe of the World cannot hew o delightful a Place as this Grove was: Not all the Gardens of boated Italy can produce a Shade to out-vie this, which Nature had join'd with Art to render o exceeding fine; and 'tis a marvel to ee how uch vat Trees, as big as Englih Oaks, cou'd take footing on o olid a Rock, and in o little Earth as cover'd that Rock: But all things by Nature there are Rare, Delightful and Wonderful. But to our Sports.

Sometimes we wou'd go urpriing, and in earch of young Tigers in their Dens, watching when the old ones went forth to forage for Prey; and oftentimes we have been in great danger, and have fled a-pace for our Lives, when urpriz'd by the Dams. But once, above all other times, we went on this Deign, and Caear was with us; who had no ooner toln a young Tiger from her Net, but going off,
we encounter'd the Dam, bearing a Buttock of a Cow, which he had torn off with his mighty Paw, and going with it towards his Den; we had only four Women, Caear, and an Englih Gentleman, Brother to Harry Martin the great Oliverian; we found there was no ecaping this enraged and ravenous Beat. However, we Women fled as fat as we cou'd from it; but our Heels had not aved our Lives, if Caear had not laid down his Cub, when he found the Tiger quit her Prey to make the more peed towards him; and taking Mr. Martin's Sword, deir'd him to tand aide, or follow the Ladies. He obey'd him; and Caear met this montrous Beat of might, ize, and vat Limbs, who came with open Jaws upon him; and fixing his awful tern Eyes full upon thoe of the Beat, and putting himelf into a very teddy and good aiming poture of Defence, ran his Sword quite through his Breat down to his very Heart, home to the Hilt of the Sword: the dying Beat tretch'd forth her Paw, and going to grap his Thigh, urpriz'd with death in that very moment, did him no other harm than fixing her long Nails in his Fleh very deep, feebly wounded him, but cou'd not grap the Fleh to tear off any. When he had done this, he hollow'd to us to return: which, after ome aurance of his Victory, we did, and found him lugging out the Sword from the Boom of the Tiger, who was laid in her blood on the ground; he took up the Cub, and with an Unconcern that had nothing of the Joy or Gladnes of a Victory, he came and laid the Whelp at my Feet. We
all extremely wonder'd at his Daring, and at the Bignes of the Beat, which was about the heighth of an Heifer, but of mighty great and trong Limbs.

Another time, being in the Woods, he kill'd a Tiger which had long infeted that Part, and borne away abundance of Sheep and Oxen, and other things that were for the upport of thoe to whom they belong'd: abundance of People aail'd this Beat, ome affirming they had hot her with everal Bullets quite through the Body, at everal times; and ome wearing they hot her through the very Heart, and they believ'd he was a Devil, rather than a mortal thing. Caear had often aid, he had a mind to encounter this Monter, and poke with everal Gentlemen who had attempted her; one crying, I hot her with o many poyon'd Arrows, another with his Gun in this part of her, and another in that; o that he remarking all thee places where he was hot, fancy'd till he hou'd overcome her, by giving her another ort of a Wound than any had yet done, and one day aid (at the Table,) What Trophies and Garlands, Ladies, will you make me, if I bring you home the Heart of this Ravenous Beast, that eats up all your Lambs and Pigs? We all promis'd he hou'd be rewarded at all our hands. So taking a Bow, which he choe out of a great many, he went up into the Wood, with two Gentlemen, where he imagin'd this Devourer to be; they had not pat very far in it, but they heard her Voice, growling and grumbling, as if he were pleas'd with omething he was doing. When they came in
view, they found her muzzling in the Belly of a new ravih'd Sheep, which he had torn open; and eeing her elf approach'd, he took fat hold of her Prey with her fore Paws, and et a very fierce raging Look on Caear, without offering to approach him, for fear at the ame time of loing what he had in poeion. So that Caear remain'd a good while, only taking aim, and getting an opportunity to hoot her where he deign'd: 'twas ome time before he cou'd accomplih it; and to wound her, and not kill her, wou'd but have enrag'd her the more, and endanger'd him: He had a Quiver of Arrows at his Side, o that if one fail'd, he could be upply'd; at lat, retiring a little, he gave her opportunity to eat; for he found he was ravenous, and fell too as oon as he aw him retire, being more eager of her Prey, than of doing new Michiefs: when he going oftly to one ide of her, and hiding his Peron behind certain Herbage that grew high and thick, he took o good aim, that, as he intended, he hot her jut into the Eye, and the Arrow was ent with o good a will, and o ure a hand, that it tuck in her Brain, and made her caper, and become mad for a moment or two; but being econded by another Arrow, he fell dead upon the Prey. Caear cut her open with a Knife, to ee where thoe Wounds were that had been reported to him, and why he did not die of 'em. But I hall now relate a thing that, poibly, will find no credit among Men; becaue 'tis a Notion commonly receiv'd with us, That nothing can receive a Wound in the Heart and live: But when the Heart of
this courageous Animal was taken out, there were even Bullets of Lead in it, and the Wounds eam'd up with great Scars, and he liv'd with the Bullets a great while, for it was long ince they were hot: This Heart the Conqueror brought up to us, and 'twas a very great Curioity, which all the Countrey came to ee; and which gave Caear occaion of many fine Dicoures; of Accidents in War, and trange Ecapes.

At other times he wou'd go a Fihing; and dicouring on that Diverion, he found we had in that Countrey a very trange Fih, call'd a Numb Eel (an Eel of which I have eaten) that while it is aliye, it has a quality o Cold, that thoe who are Angling, though with a Line of never o great a length, with a Rod at the end of it, it hall, in the ame minute the Bait is touched by this Eel, eize him or her that holds the Rod with benumb'dnes, that hall deprive 'em of Sene, for a while; and ome have faln into the Water, and others drop'd, as dead, on the Banks of the Rivers where they tood, as oon as this Fih touches the Bait. Caear us'd to laugh at this, and believ'd it impoible a Man cou'd loe his Force at the touch of a Fih; and cou'd not undertand that Philoophy, that a Cold Quality hould be of that nature; however, he had a great Curioity to try whether it wou'd have the ame effect on him it had on others, and often try'd, but in vain: at lat, the • ought-for Fih came to the Bait, as he tood Angling on the Bank; and intead of throwing away the Rod, or giving it a udden twitch out of the Water, whereby
he might have caught both the Eel, and have dimis'd the Rod, before it cou'd have too much power over him; for Experiment-ake, he grap'd it but the harder, and fainting fell into the River; and being till poes'd of the Rod, the Tide carry'd him, eneles as he was, a great way, till an Indian Boat took him up; and perceiv'd, when they touch'd him, a Numbnes eize them, and by that knew the Rod was in his Hand; which, with a Paddle, (that is, a hort Oar) they truck away, and nacht it into the Boat, Eel and all. If Caear was almot dead, with the effect of this Fih, he was more o with that of the Water, where he had remain'd the pace of going a League, and they found they had much a-doe to bring him back to life; but at lat they did, and brought him home, where he was in a few hours well recover'd and refreh'd, and not a little aham'd to find he hou'd be overcome by an Eel, and that all the People, who heard his Defiance, wou'd laugh at him. But we chear'd him up; and he, being convinc'd, we had the Eel at Supper, which was a Quarter of an Ell about, and mot delicate Meat; and was of the more value, ince it cot o dear as almot the Life of o gallant a Man.

About this time we were in many mortal Fears, about ome Diputes the Englih had with the Indians; o that we cou'd carce trut our elves, without great Numbers, to go to any Indian Towns or Place where they abode, for fear they hou'd fall upon us, as they did immediately after my coming away; and that it was in the poeion of the Dutch, who
us'd 'em not o civilly as the Englih; o that they cut in pieces all they cou'd take, getting into Houes, and hanging up the Mother, and all her Children about her; and cut a Footman, I left behind me, all in Joints, and nail'd him to Trees.

This Feud began while I was there; o that I lot half the Satisfaction I propos'd, in not eeing and viiting the Indian Towns. But one day, bemoaning of our Misfortunes upon this account, Caear told us, we need not fear; for if we had a mind to go, he wou'd undertake to be our Guard. Some wou'd, but mot wou'd not venture: about Eighteen of us reolv'd, and took Barge; and after eight days, arriv'd near an Indian Town: But approaching it, the Hearts of ome of our Company fail'd, and they wou'd not venture on Shore; o we Poll'd who wou'd, and who wou'd not. For my part, I aid, If Caear wou'd, I wou'd go. He reolv'd; o did my Brother, and my Woman, a Maid of good Courage. Now, none of us peaking the Language of the People, and imagining we hou'd have a half Diverion in Gazing only; and not knowing what they aid, we took a Fiherman that liv'd at the mouth of the River, who had been a long Inhabitant there, and oblig'd him to go with us: But becaue he was known to the Indians, as trading among 'em, and being, by long living there, become a perfect in Indian Colour, we, who reolv'd to urprize 'em, by making them ee omething they never had een, (that is, White People) reolv'd only my elf, my Brother and Woman hou'd go; o Caear, the Fiherman, and the ret, hiding behind
ome thick Reeds and Flowers that grew on the Banks, let us pas on towards the Town, which was on the Bank of the River all along. A little ditant from the Houes, or Huts, we aw ome Dancing, others buy'd in fetching and carrying of Water from the River: They had no ooner py'd us, but they et up a loud Cry, that frighted us at firt; we thought it had been for thoe that hou'd kill us, but it eems it was of Wonder and Amazement. They were all Naked; and we were Dres'd, o as is mot commode for the hot Countries, very Glittering and Rich; o that we appear'd extremely fine; my own Hair was cut hort, and I had a Taffaty Cap, with Black Feathers, on my Head; my Brother was in a Stuff Sute, with Silver Loops and Buttons, and abundance of Green Ribbon: This was all infinitely urpriing to them; and becaue we aw them tand till till we approach'd 'em, we took heart and advanc'd, came up to 'em, and offer'd 'em our Hands; which they took, and look'd on us round about, calling till for more Company; who came warming out, all wondering, and crying out Tepeeme; taking their Hair up in their Hands, and preading it wide to thoe they call'd out to; as if they wou'd ay (as indeed it ignify'd) Numberles Wonders, or not to be recounted, no more than to number the Hair of their Heads. By degrees they grew more bold, and from gazing upon us round, they touch'd us, laying their Hands upon all the Features of our Faces, feeling our Breats and Arms, taking up one Petticoat, then wondering to ee another; admiring our Shooes and
Stockings, but more our Garters, which we gave 'em, and they ty'd about their Legs, being lac'd with Silver Lace at the ends; for they much eteem any hining things: In fine, we uffer'd 'em to urvey us as they pleas'd, and we thought they wou'd never have done admiring us. When Caear, and the ret, aw we were receiv'd with uch wonder, they came up to us; and finding the Indian Trader whom they knew, (for 'tis by thee Fihermen, call'd Indian Traders, we hold a Commerce with 'em; for they love not to go far from home, and we never go to them;) when they aw him therefore, they et up a new Joy, and cry'd, in their language, Oh! here's our Tiguamy, and we hall now know whether thoe things can peak: So advancing to him, ome of 'em gave 'em their Hands, and cry'd, Amora Tiguamy; which is as much as, How do you; or, Welcome, Friend: and all, with one din, began to gabble to him, and ask'd, if we had Sene and Wit? if we could talk of Affairs of Life and War, as they cou'd do? if we cou'd Hunt, Swim, and do a thouand things they ue? He anwer'd 'em, We cou'd. Then they invited us into their Houes, and dres'd Venion and Buffelo for us; and, going out, gather'd a Leaf of a Tree, call'd a Sarumbo Leaf, of ix Yards long, and pread it on the Ground for a Table-Cloth; and cutting another in pieces, intead of Plates, etting us on little bow Indian Stools, which they cut out of one entire piece of Wood, and paint in a ort of Japan-work: They erve every one their Mes on thee pieces of Leaves; and it was very good, but too high eaon'd with Pepper. When we had eat, my
Brother and I took out our Flutes, and play'd to 'em, which gave 'em new Wonder; and I oon perceiv'd, by an Admiration that is natural to thee People, and by the extreme Ignorance and Simplicity of 'em, it were not difficult to etablih any unknown or extravagaut Religion among them, and to impoe any Notions or Fictions upon 'em. For eeing a Kinman of mine et ome Paper a fire with a Burning-glas, a Trick they had never before een, they were like to have ador'd him for a God, and begg'd he wou'd give 'em the Characters or Figures of his Name, that they might oppoe it againt Winds and Storms: which he did, and they held it up in thoe Seaons, and fancy'd it had a Charm to conquer them, and kept it like a holy Relique. They are very Supertitious, and call'd him the Great Peeie, that is, Prophet. They hew'd us their Indian Peeie, a Youth of about Sixteen Years old, as handom as Nature cou'd make a Man. They conecrate a beautiful Youth from his Infancy, and all Arts are ued to compleat him in the finet manner, both in Beauty and Shape: He is bred to all the little Arts and Cunning they are capable of; to all the Legerdemain Tricks, and Slight of Hand, whereby he impoes upon the Rabble; and is both a Doctor in Phyick and Divinity: And by thee Tricks makes the Sick believe he ometimes eaes their Pains, by drawing from the afflicted part little Serpents, or odd Flies, or Worms, or any trange thing; and though they have beides undoubted good Remedies for almot all their Dieaes, they cure the Patient more by Fancy than by Medicines;
and make themelves Fear'd, Lov'd, and Reverenc'd. This young Peeie had a very young Wife, who eeing my Brother kis her, came running and kis'd me: after this they kis'd one another, and made it a very great Jet, it being o novel; and new • Admiration and Laughing went round the Multitude, that they never will forget that Ceremony, never before us'd or known. Caear had a mind to ee and talk with their War-Captains, and we were conducted to one of their Houes; where we beheld everal of the great Captains, who had been at Council: But o frightful a Viion it was to ee 'em no Fancy can create; no ad Dreams can repreent o dreadful a Spectacle. For my part, I took 'em for Hobgoblins, or Fiends, rather than Men: but however their Shapes appear'd, their Souls were very Humane and Noble; but ome wanted their Noes, ome their Lips, ome both Noes and Lips, ome their Ears, and others cut through each Cheek, with long Slahes, through which their Teeth appear'd: they had other everal formidable Wounds and Scars, or rather Dimembrings: they had Comitia's, or little Aprons before 'em; and Girdles of Cotton, with their Knives naked tuck in it; a Bow at their Backs, and a Quiver of Arrows on their Thighs; and mot had Feathers on their Heads of divers Colours. They cry'd Amora Tigame to us, at our entrance, and were pleas'd we aid as much to them: They eated us, and gave us Drink of the bet ort, and wonder'd, as much as the others had done before, to ee us. Caear was marvelling as much at
their Faces, wondring how they hou'd all be o wounded in War; he was impatient to know how they all came by thoe frightful Marks of Rage or Malice, rather than Wounds got in noble Battle: They told us, by our Interpreter, That when any War was waging, two Men, choen out by ome old Captain whoe Fighting was pat, and who cou'd only teach the Theory of War, thee two Men were to tand in competition for the Generalhip, or Great War-Captain; and being brought before the old Judges, now pat Labour, they are ask'd, What they dare do, to hew they are worthy to lead an Army? When he who is firt ask'd, making no Reply, cuts off his Noe, and throws it contemptibly on the Ground; and the other does omething to himelf that he thinks urpaes him, and perhaps deprives himelf of Lips and an Eye; o they Slah on till one gives out, and many have dy'd in this Debate. And it's by a paive Valour they hew and prove their Activity; a ort of Courage too Brutal to be applauded by our Black Hero; nevertheles, he expres'd his Eteem of 'em.

In this Voyage Caear begot o good an undertanding between the Indians and the Englih, that there were no more Fears or Heart-burnings during our tay, but we had a perfect, open, and free Trade with 'em. Many things remarkable, and worthy reciting, we met with in this hort Voyage; becaue Caear made it his buines to earch out and provide for our Entertainment, epecially to pleae his dearly ador'd Imoinda, who was a Sharer in all our Adventures; we being reolv'd to make
her Chains as eaie as we cou'd, and to Complement the Prince in that manner that mot oblig'd him.

As we were coming up again, we met with ome Indians of trange Apects; that is, of a larger Size, and other ort of Features, than thoe of our Countrey: Our Indian Slaves, that row'd us, ask'd 'em ome Quetions; but they cou'd not undertand us, but hew'd us a long Cotton String, with everal Knots on it, and told us, they had been coming from the Mountains o many Moons as there were Knots; they were habited in Skins of a trange Beat, and brought along with 'em Bags of Gold Dut; which, as well as they cou'd give us to undertand, came treaming in little mall Chanels down the high Mountains, when the Rains fell; and offer'd to be the Convoy to any Body, or Perons, that wou'd go to the Mountains. We carry'd thee Men up to Parham, where they were kept till the Lord-Governor came: And becaue all the Country was mad to be going on this Golden Adventure, the Governor, by his Letters, commanded (for they ent ome of the Gold to him) that a Guard hou'd be et at the mouth of the River of Amazons (a River o call'd, almot as broad as the River of Thames) and prohibited all People from going up that River, it conducting to thoe Mountains of Gold. But we going off for England before the Project was further proecuted, and the Governor being drown'd in a Hurricane, either the Deign dy'd, or the Dutch have the Advantage of it: And 'tis to be bemoan'd what His Majety lot, by loing that part of America.
Though this Digreion is a little from my Story; however, ince it contains ome Proofs of the Curioity and Daring of this Great Man, I was content to omit nothing of his Character.

It was thus for ome time we diverted him; but now Imoinda began to hew he was with Child, and did nothing but igh and weep for the Captivity of her Lord, her elf, and the Infant yet unborn; and believ'd, if it were o hard to gain the Liberty of Two, 'twou'd be more difficult to get that for Three. Her Griefs were o many Darts in the great Heart of Caear; and taking his Opportunity, one Sunday, when all the Whites were overtaken in Drink, as there were abundance of everal Trades, and Slaves for Four Years, that inhabited among the Negro Houes; and Sunday was their Day of Debauch, (otherwie they were a ort of Spies upon Caear,) he went, pretending out of goodnes to 'em, to Feat among 'em, and ent all his Muick, and order'd a great Treat for the whole Gang, about Three hundred Negroes, and about an Hundred and fifty were able to bear Arms, uch as they had, which were ufficient to do execution with Spirits accordingly: For the Englih had none but ruty Swords, that no trength cou'd draw from a Scabbard; except the People of particular Quality, who took care to oil 'em, and keep 'em in good order: The Guns alo, unles here and there one, or thoe newly carry'd from England, wou'd do no good or harm; for 'tis the Nature of that Countrey to rut and eat up Iron, or any Metals but Gold and Silver. And they are very unexpert at the Bow, which the Negroes and Indians are perfect Maters of.

Caear, having ingl'd out thee Men from the Women and Children, made an Harangue to 'em, of the Mieries and Ignominies of Slavery; counting up all their Toils and Sufferings, under uch Loads, Burdens and Drudgeries, as were fitter for Beats than Men; Seneles Brutes, than Humane Souls. He told 'em, it was not for Days, Months or Years, but for Eternity; there was no end to be of their Misfortunes: They uffer'd not like Men who might find a Glory and Fortitude in Oppreion; but like Dogs that lov'd the Whip and Bell, and fawn'd the more they were beaten: That they had lot the Divine Quality of Men, and were become inenible Aes, fit only to bear: nay, wore; an As, or Dog, or Hore, having done his Duty, cou'd lie down in retreat, and rie to work again, and while he did his Duty, indur'd no Stripes; but Men, Villainous, Seneles Men, uch as they, Toil'd on all the tedious Week till Black Friday; and then, whether they work'd or not, whether they were faulty or meriting, they, promicuouly, the Innocent with the Guilty, uffer'd the infamous Whip, the ordid Stripes, from their fellow Slaves, till their Blood trickl'd from all Parts of their Body; Blood, whoe every drop ought to be reveng'd with a Life of ome of thoe Tyrants that impoe it: And why (aid he) my dear Friends and Fellow-ufferers, hou'd we be Slaves to an unknown People! Have they Vanquih'd us Nobly in Fight? Have they Won us in Honourable Battle? And are we, by the chance of War, become their Slaves? This wou'd not anger a Noble Heart; this wou'd
not animate a Soldier's Soul; no, but we are Bought and Sold like Apes, or Monkeys, to be the Sport of Women, Fools and Cowards; and the Support of Rogues, Runagades, that have abandon'd their own Countries for Rapine, Murders, Theft and Villanies: Do you not hear, every day, how they upbraid each other with Infamy of Life, below the Wildet Salvages? and hall we render Obedience to uch a degenerate Race, who have no one Humane Vertue left, to ditinguih 'em from the vilet Creatures? Will you, I ay, uffer the Lah from uch Hands? They all reply'd, with one accord, No, No, No; Caear has poke like a Great Captain; like a Great King.

After this, he wou'd have proceeded, but was interrupted by a tall Negro of ome more Quality than the ret, his Name was Tucan; who bowing at the Feet of Caear, cry'd, My Lord, we have liten'd with Joy and Attention to what you have aid; and, were we only Men, wou'd follow o great a Leader through the World: But oh! conider we are Husbands, and Parents too, and have things more dear to us than Life, our Wives and Children, unfit for Travel in thee unpaable Woods, Mountains and Bogs; we have not only difficult Lands to overcome, but Rivers to wade, and Mountains to encounter; Ravenous Beats of Prey—To this, Caear reply'd, That Honour was the Firt Principle in Nature, that was to be Obey'd: but as no Man wou'd pretend to that, without all the Acts of Vertue, Compaion, Charity, Love, Jutice and Reaon; he found it not inconitent with that, to take an equal care of their Wives and Children, as they wou'd of themelves; and that he did not deign, when he led them to Freedom, and Glorious Liberty, that they hou'd leave that better part of themelves
to perih by the Hand of the Tyrant's Whip: But if there were a Woman among them o degenerate from Love and Vertue, to chue Slavery before the puruit of her Husband, and with the hazard of her Life, to hare with him in his Fortunes; that uch an one ought to be abandon'd, and left as a Prey to the Common Enemy.

To which they all Agreed,—and Bowed. After this, he poke of the impaable Woods and Rivers; and convinc'd 'em, the more Danger, the more Glory. He told them, that he had heard of one Hannibal a great Captain, had cut his way through Mountains of olid Rocks; and hou'd a few Shrubs oppoe them, which they cou'd fire before 'em? No, 'twas a trifling Excue to Men reolv'd to die, or overcome. As for Bogs, they are with a little Labour fill'd and harden'd; and the Rivers cou'd be no Obtacle, ince they wam by Nature, at leat, by Cutom, from the firt hour of their birth: That when the Children were weary, they mut carry them by turns, and the Woods and their own Indutry wou'd afford them Food. To this they all aented with Joy.

Tucan then demanded, what he wou'd do? He aid they wou'd Travel towards the Sea, Plant a New Colony, and Defend it by their Valour; and when they cou'd find a Ship, either driven by tres of Weather, or guided by Providence that way, they wou'd eize it, and make it a Prize, till it had tranported them to their own Countries; at leat, they hou'd be made Free in his Kingdom, and be eteem'd as his Fellow-ufferers, and Men that had the Courage and the Bravery to attempt, at leat, for
Liberty; and if they dy'd in the attempt, it wou'd be more brave, than to live in perpetual Slavery.

They bow'd and kis'd his Feet at this Reolution, and with one accord Vow'd to follow him to Death. And that Night was appointed to begin their March, they made it known to their Wives, and directed them to tie their Hamaca about their Shoulders, and under their Arm, like a Scarf; and to lead their Children that cou'd go, and carry thoe that cou'd not. The Wives, who pay an entire Obedience to their Husbands, obey'd, and tay'd for 'em where they were appointed: The Men tay'd but to furnih themelves with what defenive Arms they cou'd get; and All met at the Rendezvous, where Caear made a new encouraging Speech to 'em, and led 'em out.

But as they cou'd not march far that Night, on Monday early, when the Overeers went to call 'em all together, to go to work, they were extremely urpriz'd, to find not one upon the Place, but all fled with what Baggage they had. You may imagine this News was not only uddenly pread all over the Plantation, but oon reach'd the neighbouring ones; and we had by Noon about Six hundred Men they call the Militia of the Country, that came to ait us in the puruit of the Fugitives: But never did one ee o comical an Army march forth to War. The Men of any Fahion wou'd not concern themelves, though it were almot the Common Caue; for uch Revoltings are very ill Examples, and have very fatal Conequences, often-times, in many
Colonies: But they had a Repect for Caear, and all hands were againt the Parhamites (as they call'd thoe of Parham Plantation;) becaue they did not, in the firt place, love the Lord-Governor; and, econdly, they wou'd have it, that Caear was ill us'd, and Baffl'd with; and 'tis not impoible but ome of the bet in the Countrey was of his Council in this Flight, and depriving us of all the Slaves: o that they of the better ort wou'd not meddle in the matter. The Deputy-Governor, of whom I have had no great occaion to peak, and who was the mot fawning fair-Tongu'd Fellow in the World, and one that pretended the mot Friendhip to Caear, was now the only violent Man againt him; and though he had nothing, and o need fear nothing, yet talk'd and look'd bigger than any Man: He was a Fellow, whoe Character is not fit to be mention'd with the wort of the Slaves. This Fellow wou'd lead his Army forth to meet Caear, or rather to purue him: mot of their Arms were of thoe ort of cruel Whips they call Cat-with Nine-Tails; ome had ruty ueles Guns for hew; others old Basket-hilts, whoe Blades had never een the Light in this Age; and others had long Staffs and Clubs. Mr. Trefry went along rather to be a Mediator than a Conqueror, in uch a Battle; for he foreaw, and knew, if by fighting they put the Negroes into depair, they were a ort of ullen Fellows, that wou'd drown or kill themelves, before they wou'd yield; and he advis'd, that fair means was bet: But Byam was one that abounded in his own Wit, and wou'd take his own Meaures.

It was not hard to find thee Fugitives; for as they fled, they were forc'd to fire and cut the Woods before 'em; o that Night or Day they puru'd 'em by the Light they made, and by the Path they had clear'd. But as oon as Caear found he was puru'd, he put himelf in a poture of Defence, placing all the Women and Children in the Rear; and himelf, with Tucan by his ide, or next to him, all promiing to Die or Conquer. Encourag'd thus, they never tood to Parley, but fell on Pellmell upon the Englih, and kill'd ome, and wounded a good many; they having recoure to their Whips, as the bet of their Weapons. And as they oberv'd no Order, they perplex'd the Enemy o orely, with lahing 'em in the Eyes; and the Women and Children eeing their Husbands o treated, being of fearful cowardly Dipoitions, and hearing the Englih cry out, Yield, and Live! Yield, and be Pardon'd! they all run in amongt their Husbands and Fathers, and hung about 'em, crying out, Yield, Yield, and leave Caear to their Revenge; that by degrees the Slaves abandon'd Caear, and left him only Tucan, and his Heroick Imoinda; who, grown big as he was, did neverthelefs pres near her Lord, having a Bow, and a Quiver full of poion'd Arrows, which he manag'd with uch dexterity, that he wounded everal, and hot the Governor into the Shoulder; of which Wound he had like to have died, but that an Indian Woman, his Mitres, uck'd the Wound, and cleans'd it from the Venom: But however, he tirr'd not from the Place till he had Parly'd with Caear,
who he found was reolv'd to die fighting, and wou'd not be taken; no more wou'd Tucan, or Imoinda. But he, more thirting after Revenge of another ort, than that of depriving him of Life, now made ue of all his Art of Talking and Diembling, and beought Caear to yield himelf upon Terms which he himelf hould propoe; and hould be acredly aented to, and kept by him: He told him, It was not that he any longer fear'd him, or cou'd believe the force of two Men, and a young Heroine, cou'd overcome all them, with all the Slaves now on their ide alo; but it was the vat Eteem he had for his Peron, the Deire he had to erve o Gallant a Man, and to hinder himelf from the Reproach hereafter, of having been the occaion of the Death of a Prince, whoe Valour and Magnanimity deerv'd the Empire of the World. He proteted to him, he look'd upon this Action as Gallant and Brave, however tending to the Prejudice of his Lord and Mater, who wou'd by it have lot o coniderable a number of Slaves; that this Flight of his, hou'd be look'd on as a heat of Youth, and a rahnes of a too forward Courage, and an unconider'd Impatience of Liberty, and no more; and that he labour'd in vain to accomplih that which they wou'd effectually perform, as oon as any Ship arriv'd that wou'd touch on his Coat: So that if you will be pleas'd (continu'd he) to urrender your elf, all imaginable Repect hall be paid you; and your Self, your Wife, and Child, if it be born here, hall depart free out of our Land. But Caear wou'd here of no Compoition;
though Byam urg'd, If he puru'd and went on in his Deign, he wou'd inevitably perih, either by great Snakes, wild Beats, or Hunger; and he ought to have regard to his Wife, whoe Condition required Eae, and not the Fatigues of tedious Travel, where he cou'd not be ecur'd from being devour'd. But Caeer told him, there was no Faith in the White Men, or the Gods they ador'd; who intructed 'em in Principles o fale, that honet Men cou'd not live amongt 'em; though no People profes'd o much, none perform'd o little; that he knew what he had to do, when he dealt with Men of Honour; but with them a Man ought to be eternally on his Guard, and never to Eat and Drink with Chritians, without his Weapon of Defence in his Hand; and, for his own Security, never to credit one Word they poke. As for the Rahnes and Inconideratenes of his Action, he wou'd confes the Governor is in the right; and that he was aham'd of what he had done, in endeavouring to make thoe Free, who were by Nature Slaves, poor wretched Rogues, fit to be us'd as Chritian •
Tools; Dogs, Treacherous and Cowardly, fit for uch Maters; and they wanted only but to be whipp'd into the Knowledge of the Chritian Gods, to be the vilet of all creeping things; to learn to worhip uch Deities as had not Power to make 'em Jut, Brave, or Honet. In fine, after a thouand things of this nature, not fit here to be recited, he told Byam, He had rather Die, than Live upon the ame Earth with uch Dogs. But Trefry and Byam pleaded and proteted together o much,
that Trefry believing the Governor to mean what he aid; and peaking very cordially himelf, generouly put himelf into Caear's Hands, and took him aide, and peruaded him, even with Tears, to Live, by Surrendring himelf, and to name his Conditions. Caear was overcome by his Wit and Reaons, and in conideration of Imoinda; and demanding what he deir'd, and that it hou'd be ratify'd by their Hands in Writing, becaue he had perceiv'd that was the common way of Contract between Man and Man, amongt the Whites. All this was perform'd, and Tucan's Pardon was put in, and they Surrender to the Governor, who walked peaceably down into the Plantation with 'em, after giving Order to bury their Dead. Caear was very much toil'd with the Butle of the Day, for he had fought like a Fury; and what Michief was done, He and Tucan perform'd alone; and gave their Enemies a fatal Proof, that they durt do any thing, and fear'd no mortal Force.

But they were no ooner arriv'd at the Place where all the Slaves receive their Punihments of Whipping, but they laid Hands on Caear and Tucan, faint with Heat and Toil; and urprizing them, bound them to two everal Stakes, and whipp'd them in a mot deplorable and inhumane manner, rending the very Fleh from their Bones; epecially Caear, who was not perceiv'd to make any Moan, or to alter his Face, only to roul his Eyes on the Faithles Governor, and thoe he believ'd Guilty, with Fiercenes and Indignation;
and, to compleat his Rage, he aw every one of thoe Slaves, who, but a few Days before, ador'd him as omething more than Mortal, now had a Whip to give him ome Lahes, while he trove not to break his Fetters; tho' if he had, it were impoible: but he pronounc'd a Woe and Revenge from his Eyes, that dar •• d Fire, that 'twas at once both Awful and Terrible to behold.

When they thought they were ufficiently Reveng'd on him, they unty'd him, almot fainting with los of Blood, from a thouand Wounds all over his Body; from which they had rent his Cloaths, and led him Bleeding and Naked as he was, and loaded him all over with Irons, and then rubb'd his Wounds, to compleat their Cruelty, with Indian Pepper; which had like to have made him raving Mad; and, in this Condition, made him o fat to the Ground, that he cou'd not tir, if his Pains and Wounds wou'd have given him leave. They par'd Imoinda, and did not let her ee this Barbarity committed towards her Lord, but carry'd her down to Parham, and hut her up; which was not in kindnes to her, but for fear he hou'd die with the Sight, or Micarry, and then they hou'd loe a young Slave, and perhaps the Mother.

You mut know, that when the News was brought, on Monday Morning, that Caear had betaken himelf to the Woods, and carry'd with him all the Negroes, we were poes'd with extreme Fear, which no Peruaions cou'd diipate, that he wou'd ecure himelf till Night; and then, that he wou'd come
down and cut all our Throats. This Apprehenion made all the Females of us fly down the River, to be ecur'd; and while we were away, they acted this Cruelty: For I uppoe, I had Authority and Interet enough there, had I upected any uch thing, to have prevented it; but we had not gone many Leagues, but the News overtook us, that Caear was taken, and whipp'd like a common Slave. We met, on the River, with Colonel Martin, a Man of great Gallantry, Wit and Goodnes, and whom I have celebrated in a Character of my New Comedy, by his own Name, in Memory of o Brave a Man: He was Wie and Eloquent, and, from the finenes of his Parts, bore a great Sway over the Hearts of all the Colony: He was a Friend to Caear, and reented this fale Dealing with him very much. We carry'd him back to Parham, thinking to have made an Accommodation. When he came, the firt News we heard, was, That the Governor was dead of a Wound Imoinda had given him; but it was not o well: But it eems, he wou'd have the Pleaure of beholding the Revenge he took on Caear; and before the cruel Ceremony was finih'd, he dropt down; and then they perceiv'd the Wound he had on his Shoulder was by a venom'd Arrow; which, as I aid, his Indian Mitres heal'd, by ucking the Wound.

We were no ooner arriv'd, but we went up to the Plantation to ee Caear; whom we found in a very mierable and unexpreible Condition; and I have a thouand times admir'd how he liv'd in o much tormenting
Pain. We aid all things to him, that Trouble, Pity and Good Nature cou'd ugget; Proteting our Innocency of the Fact, and our Abhorrence of uch Cruelties; making a thouand Profeions of Services to him, and begging as many Pardons for the Offenders, till we aid o much, that he believ'd we had no hand in his ill Treatment; but told us, He cou'd never pardon Byam; as for Trefry, he confes'd he aw his Grief and Sorrow for his Suffering, which he cou'd not hinder, but was like to have been beaten down by the very Slaves, for peaking in his Defence: But for Byam, who was their Leader, their Head,—and hou'd, by his Jutice and Honour, have been an Example to 'em,—for him he wih'd to live, to take a dire Revenge of him; and aid, It had been well for him, if he had Sacrific'd me, intead of giving me the contemptible Whip. He refus'd to talk much; but begging us to give him our Hands, he took 'em, and proteted never to lift up his, to do us any harm. He had a great Repect for Colonel Martin, and always took his Counel like that of a Parent; and aur'd him, He wou'd obey him in any thing, but his Revenge on Byam: Therefore (aid he) for his own afety, let him peedily dipatch me; for if I cou'd dipatch my elf, I wou'd not, till that Jutice were done to my injur'd Peron, and the contempt of a Soldier: No, I wou'd not kill my elf, even after a Whipping, but will be content to live with that Infamy, and be pointed at by every grinning Slave, till I have compleated my Revenge; and then you hall ee, that Oroonoko corns to live
with the Indignity that was put on Caear. All we cou'd do, cou'd get no more Words from him; and we took care to have him put immediately into a healing Bath, to rid him of his Pepper, and order'd a Chirurgeon to anoint him with healing Balm; which he uffer'd, and in ome time he began to be able to Walk and Eat. We fail'd not to viit him every Day, and to that end had him brought to an Apartment at Parham.

The Governor was no ooner recover'd, and ha • heard of the Menaces of Caear, but he call'd his Council; who (not to digrace them, or Burleque the Government there) conited of uch notorious Villains as Newgate never Tranported; and, poibly, originally were uch who undertood neither the Laws of God or Man; and had no ort of Principles to make 'em worthy the Name of Men; but, at the very Council-Table, wou'd Contradict and Fight with one another; and Swear o bloodily, that 'twas terrible to hear and ee 'em. (Some of 'em were afterwards Hang'd, when the Dutch took poeion of the Place, others ent off in Chains.) But calling thee pecial Rulers of the Nation together, and requiring their Counel in this weighty Affair, they all concluded, that (Damn 'em) it might be their own Caes; and that Caear ought to be made an Example to all the Negroes, to fright 'em from daring to threaten their Betters, their Lords and Maters; and, at this rate, no Man was afe from his own Slaves; and concluded, nemine contradicente, that Caear hou'd be Hang'd.

Trefry then thought it time to ue his Authority; and told Byam, his Command did not extend to his Lord's Plantation; and that Parham was as much exempt from the Law as Whitehall; and that they ought no more to touch the Servants of the Lord—(who there repreented the King's Peron) than they cou'd thoe about the King himelf; and that Parham was a Sanctuary; and though his Lord were abent in Peron, his Power was till in Being there; which he had entruted with him, as far as the Dominions of his particular Plantations reach'd, and all that belong'd to it; the ret of the Country, as Byam was Lieutenant to his Lord, he might exercie his Tyranny upon. Trefry had others as powerful, or more, that int'reted themelves in Caear's Life, and abolutely aid, He hou'd be Defended. So turning the Governor, and his wie Council, out of Doors, (for they at at Parham-houe) we et a Guard upon our Landing-place, and wou'd admit none but thoe we call'd Friends to us and Caear.

The Governor having remain'd wounded at Parham, till his Recovery was compleated, Caear did not know but he was till there, and indeed, for the mot part, his time was pent there; for he was one that lov'd to live at other Peoples Expence, and if he were a Day abent, he was Ten preent there; and us'd to Play, and Walk, and Hunt and Fih with Caear. So that Caear did not at all doubt, if he once recover'd Strength, but he hou'd find an opportunity of being reveng'd on him: Though, after uch a Revenge, he cou'd not
hope to live; for if he ecap'd the Fury of the Englih Mobile, who perhaps wou'd have been glad of the occaion to have kill'd him, he was reolv'd not to urvive his Whipping; yet he had ome tender Hours, a repenting Softnes, which he call'd his Fits of Cowardice; wherein he truggl'd with Love for the Victory of his Heart, which took part with his charming Imoinda there: but, for the mot part, his time was pat in melancholy Thought, and black Deigns; he conider'd, if he hou'd do this Deed, and die either in the Attempt, or after it, he left his lovely Imoinda a Prey, or at bet a Slave, to the enrag'd Multitude: His great Heart cou'd not endure that Thought: Perhaps (aid he) he may be first Ravih'd by every Brute; expoed firt to their naty Luts, and then a hameful Death: No, he cou'd not live a moment under that Apprehenion, too inupportable to be borne. Thee were his Thoughts, and his ilent Arguments with his Heart, as he told us afterwards: o that now reolving not only to kill Byam, but all thoe he thought had enrag'd him; pleaing his great Heart with the fancy'd Slaughter he hou'd make over the whole face of the Plantation; he firt reolv'd on a Deed, that (however Horrid it firt appear'd to us all) when we had heard his Reaons, we thought it Brave and Jut. Being able to walk, and, as he believ'd, fit for the execution of his great Deign, he begg'd Trefry to trut him into the Air, believing a Walk wou'd do him good. Which was granted him; and taking Imoinda with him, as he us'd to do in his more happy and calmer
Days, he led her up into a Wood, where, after (with a thouand Sighs, and long gazing ilently on her Face, while Tears guht, in pite of him, from his Eyes) he told her his Deign, firt of killing her, and then his Enemies, and next himelf, and the impoibility of ecaping, and therefore he told her the Neceity of Dying. He found the Heroick Wife fater pleading for Death than he was to propoe it, when he found his fix'd Reolution; and, on her Knees, beought him not to leave her a Prey to his Enemies. He (griev'd to Death) yet pleas'd at her noble Reolution, took her up, and embracing her with all the Paion and Languihment of a dying Lover, drew his Knife to kill this Treaure of his Soul, this Pleaure of his Eyes; while Tears trickl'd down his Cheeks, hers were miling with Joy he hou'd die by o noble a Hand, and be ent into her own Countrey, (for that's their Notion of the next World) by him he o tenderly Lov'd, and o truly Ador'd in this. For Wives have a Repect for their Husbands equal to what any other People pay a Deity: And when a Man finds any occaion to quit his Wife, if he love her, he dies by his Hand; if not, he ells her, or uffers ome other to kill her. It being thus, you may believe the Deed was oon reolv'd on; and 'tis not to be doubted, but the Parting, the eternal Leave taking of Two uch Lovers, o greatly Born, o Senible, o Beautiful, o Young, and o Fond, mut be very Moving, as the Relation of it was to me afterwards.

All that Love cou'd ay in uch caes, being ended, and all the intermitting Irreolutions being adjuted, the Lovely, Young and Ador'd Victim lays her elf down before the Sacrificer; while he, with a Hand reolv'd, and a Heart-breaking within, gave the fatal Stroke; firt cutting her Throat, and then evering her yet miling Face from that delicate Body, pregnant as it was with the Fruits of tend'ret Love. As oon as he had done, he laid the Body decently on Leaves and Flowers, of which he made a Bed, and conceal'd it under the ame Cover-lid of Nature, only her Face he left yet bare to look on: But when he found he was Dead, and pat all Retrieve, never more to bles him with her Eyes, and oft Language; his Grief well'd up to Rage; he Tore, he Rav'd, he Roar'd like ome Monter of the Wood, calling on the lov'd Name of Imoinda: A thouand times he turn'd the fatal Knife that did the Deed toward his own Heart, with a Reolution to go immediately after her; but dire Revenge, which was now a thouand times more fierce in his Soul than before, prevents him, and he wou'd cry out; No, ince I have acrific'd Imoinda to my Revenge, hall I loe that Glory which I have purchas'd o dear, as at the Price of the Fairet, Dearet, Softet Creature that ever Nature made? No, no! Then, at her Name, Grief wou'd get the acendant of Rage, and he wou'd lie down by her Side, and water her Face with howers of Tears, which never were wont to fall from thoe Eyes; and however bent he was on his intended Slaughter, he had not power to tir fro •
the Sight of this dear Object, now more Belov'd, and more Ador'd than ever.

He remain'd in this deplorable Condition for two Days, and never roe from the Ground where he had made his ad Sacrifice; at lat, rouzing from her ide, and accuing himelf with living too long, now Imoinda was dead, and that the Deaths of thoe barbarous Enemies were deferr'd too long, he reolv'd now to finih the Great Work; but offering to rie, he found his Strength o decay'd, that he reel'd to and fro, like Boughs aail'd by contrary Winds; o that he was forced to lie down again, and try to ummon all his Courage to his Aid; he found his Brains turn'd round, and his Eyes were dizzy, and Objects appear'd not the ame to him they were wont to do; his Breath was hort, and all his Limbs urprized with a Faintnes he had never felt before: He had not eat in two Days, which was one occaion of this Feeblenes, but exces of Grief was the greatet; yet till he hop'd he hou'd recover Vigour to act his Deign, and lay expecting it yet ix days longer; till mourning over the dead Idol of his Heart, and triving every day to rie, but cou'd not.

In all this time you may believe we were in no little affliction for Caear and his Wife; ome were of opinion he was ecap'd, never to return; others thought ome Accident had hap'ned to him: But however, we fail'd not to end out an hundred People everal ways, to earch for him: A Party of about forty went that way he took, among whom was Tucan, who was perfectly reconcil'd to Byam: They
had not gone very far into the Wood, but they melt an unuual Smell, as of a dead Body; for Stinks mut be very noiom, that can be ditinguih'd among uch a quantity of natural Sweets, as every Inch of that Land produces. So that they concluded they hou'd find him dead, or ome body that was o; they pas'd on towards it, as loathom as it was, and made uch a ruling among the Leaves, that lie thick on the Ground, by continual falling, that Caear heard he was approach'd; and though he had, during the pace of thee eight Days, endeavour'd to rie, but found he wanted Strength; yet looking up, and eeing his Puruers, he roe, and reel'd to a neighbouring Tree, againt which he fix'd his Back; and being within a dozen Yards of thoe that advanc'd and aw him, he call'd out to them, and bid them approach no nearer, if they wou'd be afe. So that they tood till, and hardly believing their Eyes, that wou'd peruade them that it was Caear that poke to 'em, o much was he alter'd, they ask'd him, what he had done with his Wife, for they melt a Stink that almot truck them dead? He, pointing to the dead Body, ighing, cry'd, Behold her there. They put off the Flowers that cover'd her, with their Sticks, and found he was kill'd, and cry'd out, Oh, Monter! that hast murther'd thy Wife. Then asking him, why he did o cruel a Deed? He replied, He had no leiure to anwer impertinent Quetions: You may go back (continu'd he) and tell the faithles Governor, he may thank Fortune that I am breathing my last; and that my
Arm is too feeble to obey my Heart, in what it had deign'd him: But his Tongue faultering, and trembling, he cou'd carce end what he was aying. The Englih taking Advantage by his Weaknes, cry'd, Let us take him alive by all means. He heard 'em; and, as if he had reviv'd from a Fainting; or a Dream, he cry'd out, No, Gentlemen, you are deceiv'd; you will find no more Caears to be Whipt; no more find a Faith in me: Feeble as you think me, I have Strength yet left to ecure me from a econd Indignity. They wore all a-new; and he only hook his Head, and beheld them with Scorn. Then they cry'd out, Who will venture on this ingle Man? Will no body?
