They tood all ilent while Caear replied, Fatal will be the Attempt to the firt Adventurer, let him aure himelf, (and, at that word, held up his Knife in a menacing poture,) Look ye, ye faithles Crew, aid he, 'tis not Life I eek, nor am I afraid of Dying, (and at that word, cut a piece of Fleh from his own Throat, and threw it at 'em,) yet till I wou'd Live if I cou'd, till I had perfected my Revenge: But, oh! it cannot be; I feel Life gliding from my Eyes and Heart; and if I make not hate, I hall yet fall a Victim to the hameful Whip. At that, he rip'd up his own Belly, and took his Bowels and pull'd 'em out, with what Strength he cou'd; while ome, on their Knees imploring, beought him to hold his Hand. But when they aw him tottering, they cry'd out, Will none venture on him? A bold Englih cry'd, Yes, if he were the Devil, (taking Courage when he aw him almot Dead) and wearing a horrid Oath for his
Farewell to the World, he ruh'd on him. Caear with his Arm'd Hand met him o fairly, as tuck him to the Heart, and he fell dead at his Feet. Tucan eeing that, cry'd out, I love thee, O Caear! and therefore will not let thee die, if poible; and running to him, took him in his Arms: but, at the ame time, warding a Blow that Caear made at his Boom, he receiv'd it quite through his Arm; and Caear having not the trength to pluck the Knife forth, tho' he attempted it, Tucan neither pull'd it out himelf, nor uffer'd it to be pull'd out, but came down with it ticking in his Arm; and the reaon he gave for it, was, becaue the Air hou'd not get into the Wound. They put their Hands a-cros, and carry'd Caear between ix of 'em, fainting as he was, and they thought dead, or jut dying; and they brought him to Parham, and laid him on a Couch, and had the Chirurgeon immediately to him, who dret his Wounds, and ow'd up his Belly, and us'd means to bring him to life, which they effected. We ran all to ee him; and, if before we thought him o beautiful a Sight, he was now o alter'd, that his Face was like a Death's Head black'd over; nothing but Teeth and Eye-holes: For ome Days we uffer'd no body to peak to him, but caued Cordials to be poured down his Throat; which utained his Life, and in ix or even days he recover'd his Senes: For, you mut know, that Wounds are almot to a Miracle cur'd in the Indies; unles Wounds in the Legs, which rarely ever cure.

When he was well enough to peak, we talk'd to him, and ask'd him ome Quetions about his Wife, and the Reaons why he kill'd her; and he then told us what I have related of that Reolution and of his Parting, and he beought us we wou'd let him die, and was extremely afflicted to think it was poible he might live; he aur'd us, if we did not dipatch him, he wou'd prove very fatal to a great many. We aid all we cou'd to make him live, and gave him new Aurances; but he begg'd we wou'd not think o poorly of him, or of his Love to Imoinda, to imagine we cou'd flatter him to Life again: but the Chirurgeon aur'd him he cou'd not live, and therefore he need not fear. We were all (but Caear) afflicted at this News, and the Sight was gatly: His Dicoure was ad; and the earthly Smell about him o trong, that I was peruaded to leave the place for ome time, (being my elf but ickly, and very apt to fall into Fits of dangerous Illnes upon any extraordinary Melancholy.) The Servants, and Trefry, and the Chirurgeons, promis'd all to take what poible care they cou'd of the Life of Caear; and I, taking Boat, went with other Company to Colonel Martin's, about three Days Journey down the River: but I was no ooner gone, but the Governor taking Trefry about ome pretended earnet Buines, a Day's Journey up the River, having communicated his Deign to one Baniter, a Wild Irih Man, and one of the Council, a Fellow of abolute Barbarity, and fit to execute any Villany, but was Rich: He came up to Parham, and forcibly
took Caear, and had him carried to the ame Pot where he was whip'd; and cauing him to be ty'd to it, and a great Fire made before him, he told him, he hou'd die like a Dog, as he was. Caear replied, this was the firt piece of Bravery that ever Baniter did, and he never poke Sence till he pronounc'd that Word; and, if he wou'd keep it, he wou'd declare, in the other World, that he was the only Man, of all the Whites, that ever he heard peak Truth. And turning to the Men that bound him, he aid, My Friends, am I to Die, or to be Whipt? And they cry'd; Whipt! No, you hall not ecape o well. And then he reply'd, miling, A Bleing on thee; and aur'd them, they need not tie him, for he wou'd tand fix'd like a Rock, and endure Death o as hou'd encourage them to Die: But if you Whip me (aid he) be ure you tie me fast.

He had learn'd to take Tobacco; and when he was aur'd he hou'd Die, he deir'd they wou'd give him a Pipe in his Mouth, ready lighted; which they did: and the Executioner came, and firt out off his Members, and threw them into the Fire; after that, with an ill-favour'd Knife, they cut off his Ears and his Noe, and burn'd them; he till Smoak'd on, as if nothing had touch'd him; then they hack'd off one of his Arms, and till he bore up, and held his Pipe; but at the cutting off the other Arm, his Head unk, and his Pipe dropt, and he gave up the Ghot, without a Groan, or a Reproach. My Mother and Siter were by him all the while, but not uffer'd to ave him; o rude and wild were the Rabble,
and o inhumane were the Jutices who tood by to ee the Execution, who after paid dearly enough for their Inolence. They cut Caear in Quarters, and ent them to everal of the chief Plantations: One Quarter was ent to Colonel Martin; who refus'd it, and wore, he had rather ee the Quarters of Baniter, and the Governor himelf, than thoe of Caear, on his Plantations; and that he cou'd govern his Negroes, without Terrifying and Grieving them with frightful Spectacles of a mangl'd King.

Thus Died this Great Man; worthy of a better Fate, and a more ublime Wit than mine to write his Praie: yet, I hope, the Reputation of my Pen is coniderable enough to make his Glorious Name to urvive to all Ages, with that of the Brave, the Beautiful and the Contant Imoinda.
THE Fair Jilt: OR, THE AMOURS OF Prince TARQUIN, AND MIRANDA.
Written by Mrs A. BEHN.
LONDON: Printed by W. Onley, for S. Bricoe. 1697.

div.head: The Fair JILT: OR, THE AMOURS OF Prince Tarquin and Miranda.
div.p: AS Love is the mot Noble and Divine Paion of the Soul, o it is that to which we may jutly attribute all the real Satisfactions of Life; and without it, Man is unfinih'd, and unhappy.

There are a thouand things to be aid of the Advantages this generous Paion brings to thoe, whoe Hearts are capable of receiving its oft Impreions; for 'tis not every one that can be enible of its tender Touches. How many Examples, from Hitory and Obervation, cou'd I give of its wondrous Power; nay, even to a degree of Tranmigration? How many Ideots has it made wie? How many Fools eloquent? How many Home-bred 'Squires accomplih'd? How many C • wards brave? And there is no ort or pecies of Mankind on whom it cannot work ome Change and Miracle, if it
be a noble well-grounded Paion, except on the Fop in Fahion, the harden'd incorrigible Fop; o often wounded, but never reclaim'd: For till, by a dire Mitake, conducted by vat Opinionatreim, and a greater Portion of Self-love, than the ret of the Race of Man, he believes that Affectation in his Mien and Dres, that Mathematical-movement, that Formality in every Action, that Face manag'd with Care, and often'd into Ridicule, the languihing Turn, the Tos, and the Back-hake of the Perriwig, is the direct Way to the Heart of the fine Peron he Adores; and intead of curing Love in his Soul, erves only to advance his Folly; and the more he is enamour'd, the more indutriouly he aumes (every Hour) the Coxcomb. Thee are Love's Play-things, a ort of Animals with whom he ports; and whom he never wounds, but when he is in good humour, and always hoots laughing. 'Tis the Diverion of the Little God, to ee what a fluttering and butle one of thee Sparks, new-wounded, makes; to what fantatick Fooleries he has recoure: The Glas is every moment call'd to counel, the Valet conulted and plagu'd for new Invention of Dres, the Foot-man and Scrutore perpetually employ'd; Billet-doux and Madrigals take up all his Mornings, till Playtime in Dreing, till Night in Gazing; till, like a Sun-flower, turn'd towards the Beams of the fair Eyes of his Caelia, adjuting himelf in the mot Amarous Poture he can aume, his Hat under his Arm, while the other Hand is put carelely into his Boom, as if laid upon
his panting Heart; his Head a little bent to one ide, upported with a world of Crevat-tring, which he takes mighty care not to put into diorder; as one may gues by a never-failing, and horrid Stiffnes in his Neck; and if he have an occaion to look aide, his whole Body turns at the ame time, for fear the Motion of the Head alone hould incommode the Crevat or Perriwig: And ometimes the Glove is well manag'd, and the white Hand diplay'd. Thus, with a thouand other little Motions and Formalities, all in the common Place or Road of Foppery, he takes infinite pains to hew himelf to the Pit and Boxes, a mot accomplih'd As. This is he, of all Humane Kind, on whom Love can do no Miracle; and who can no where, and upon no occaion, quit one Grain of his refin'd Foppery, unles in a Duel, or a Battle, if ever his Stars hou'd be o evere and ill-manner'd, to reduce him to the Neceity of either: Fear then wou'd ruffle that fine Form he had o long preerved in nicet Order, with grief conidering, that an unlucky Chance-wound in his Face, if uch a dire Mifortune hou'd befal him, wou'd poil the Sale of it for ever.

Perhaps it will be urg'd, that ince no Metamorphois can be made in a Fop by Love, you mut conider him one of thoe that only talks of Love, and thinks himelf that happy thing, a Lover; and wanting fine Sence enough for the real Paion, believes what he feels to be it. There are in the Quiver of the God a great many different Darts; ome that wound for a
Day, and others for a Year; they are all fine, painted, glittering Darts, and hew as well as thoe made of the noblet Metal; but the Wounds they make, reach the Deire only, and are cur'd by poeing, while the hort-liv'd Paion betrays the Cheats: But 'tis that refin'd and illutrious Paion of the Soul, whoe Aim is Vertue, and whoe End is Honour, that has the Power of changing Nature, and is capable of performing all thoe Heroick Things, of which Hitory is full.

How far ditant Paions may be from one another, I hall be able to make appear in thee following Rules. I'll prove to you the trong Effects of Love in ome unguarded and ungovern'd Hearts; where it rages beyond the Inpirations of a God all oft and gentle, and reigns more like a Fury from Hell.

I do not pretend here to entertain you with a feign'd Story, or any thing piec'd together with Romantick Accidents; but every Circumtance, to a Tittle, is Truth. To a great part of the Main, I myelf was an Eye-witnes; and what I did not ee, I was confirm'd of by Actors in the Intrigue, holy Men, of the Order of St. Francis: But for the ake of ome of her Relations, I hall give my Fair Jilt a feign'd Name, that of Miranda; but my Hero mut retain his own, it being too Illutrious to be conceal'd.

You are to undertand, that in all the Catholick Countries, where Holy Orders are etablih'd, there are abundance of differing kinds of Religious, both of Men and Women: Amongt
the Women, there are thoe we call Nuns, that make olemn Vows of perpetual Chatity: There are others who make but a imple Vow, as, for five or ten Years, or more or les; and that time expir'd, they may contract anew for longer time, or marry, or dipoe of themelves as they hall ee good; and thee are ordinarily call'd Gallopping Nuns: Of thee there are everal Orders; as, Chanonees, Begines, Quet's, Swart-Siters, and Jeuities, with everal others I have forgot: Of thoe of the Begines was our Fair Votres.

Thee Orders are taken up by the bet Perons of the Town, young Maids of Fortune, who live together, not inclos'd, but in Palaces that will hold about Fiften hundred or Two thouand of thee Fille Devotes, where they have a regulated Government, under a ort of Abbes, or Priores; or rather, a Governante. They are oblig'd to a Method of Devotion, and are under a ort of Obedience. They wear an Habit much like our Widows of Quality in England, only without a Bando; and their Veil is of a thicker Crape than what we have here, through which one cannot ee the Face; for when they go abroad, they cover themelves all over with it, but they put 'em up in the Churches, and lay 'em by in the Houes. Every one of thee have a Confeor, who is to 'em a ort of Steward: For, you mut know, they that go into thee places, have the Management of their own Fortunes, and what their Parents deign 'em. Without the Advice of this Confeor, they act nothing, nor admit
of a Lover that he hall not approve of; at leat, this Method ought to be taken, and is by almot all of 'em; though Miranda thought her Wit above it, as her Spirit was.

But as thee Women are, as I aid, of the bet Quality, and live with the Reputation of being retir'd from the World a little more than ordinary, and becaue there is a ort of difficulty to approach 'em, they are the People the mot courted, and liable to the greatet Temptations; for as difficult as it eems to be, they receive Viits from all the Men of the bet Quality, epecially Strangers. All the Men of Wit and Converation meet at the Apartments of thee fair Fille Devotes, where all manner of Gallantries are perform'd, while all the Study of thee Maids is to accomplih themelves for thee noble Converations. They receive Preents, Balls, Serenades and Billets: All the News, Wit, Veres, Songs, Novels, Muick, Gaming, and all fine Diverion, is in their Apartments, they themelves being of the bet Quality and Fortune. So that to manage thee Gallantries, there is no ort of Female Arts they are not practis'd in, no Intrigues they are ignorant of, and no Management of which they are not capable.

Of this happy Number was the Fair Miranda, whoe Parents being dead, and a vat Etate divided between herelf, and a young Siter (who liv'd with an unmarry'd old Uncle, whoe Etate afterwards was all divided between 'em) put herelf into this uninclos'd Religious Houe; but her Beauty, which had
all the Charms that ever Nature gave, became the Envy of the whole Siterhood. She was tall, and admirably hap'd; he had a bright Hair, and Hazle-Eyes, all full of Love and Sweetnes: No Art cou'd make a Face o fair as hers by a Nature, which every Feature adorn'd with a Grace that Imagination cannot reach: Every Look, every Motion charm'd, and her black Dres hew'd the Lutre of her Face and Neck. She had an Air, though gay as o much Youth cou'd inpire, yet o modet, o nobly reerv'd, without Formality, or Stiffnes, that one who look'd on her would have imagin'd her Soul the Twin-Angel of her Body; and both together, made her appear omething Divine. To this he had a great deal of Wit, read much, and retain'd all that erv'd her purpoe. She ung delicately, and danc'd well, and play'd on the Lute to a Miracle. She poke everal Languages naturally; for being Co-heires to o great a Fortune, he was bred with the nicet Care, in all the finet Manners of Education; and was now arriv'd to her Eighteenth Year.

'Twere needles to tell you how great a Noie the Fame of this young Beauty, with o coniderable a Fortune, made in the World; I may ay, the World, rather than conine her Fame to the canty Limits of a Town; it reach'd to many others: And there was not a Man of any Quality that came to Antwerp, or pas'd through the City, but made it his Buines to ee the lovely Miranda, who was univerally ador'd: Her Youth and Beauty, her
Shape and Majety of Mien, and Air of Greatnes, charm'd all her Beholders; and thouands of People were dying by her Eyes, while he was vain enough to glory in her Conquet, and make it her Buines to wound. She lov'd nothing o much as to behold ighing Slaves at her Feet, of the greatet Quality; and treated 'em all with an Affability that gave 'em Hope. Continual Muick as oon as it was dark, and Songs of dying Lovers, were ung under her Windows; and he might well have made herelf a great Fortune (if he had not been o already) by the rich Preents that were hourly made her; and every Body daily expected when he wou'd make ome one happy, by uffering herelf to be conquer'd by Love and Honour, by the Aiduities and Vows of ome one of her Adorers: But Miranda accepted their Preents, heard their Vows with pleaure, and willingly admitted all their oft Addrees; but wou'd not yield her Heart, or give away that lovely Peron to the Poeion of one, who cou'd pleae itelf with o many. She was naturally Amorous, but extreamly Incontant: She lov'd one for his Wit, another for his Face, a third for his Mein; but above all, he admir'd Quality: Quality alone had the Power to attack her entirely; yet not to one Man, but that Vertue was till admir'd by her in all; where-ever he found that, he lov'd, or at leat acted the Lover with uch Art, that (deceiving well) he fail'd not to compleat her Conquet; and yet he never durt trut her fickle Humour with Marriage; She knew the
Strength of her own Heart, and that it cou'd not uffer itelf to be confin'd to one Man, and wiely avoided thoe Inquietudes, and that Uneaines of Life he was ure to find in that married Life, which wou'd, againt her Nature, oblige her to the Embraces of one, whoe Humour was, to love all the Young and the Gay. But Love, who had hitherto but play'd with her Heart, and given it naught but pleaing wanton Wounds, uch as afforded only oft Joys, and not Pains, reolv'd, either out of Revenge to thoe Numbers he had abandon'd, and who had igh'd o long in vain; or to try what Power he had upon o fickle a Heart, ent an Arrow dipp'd in the mot tormenting Flames that rage in Hearts mot enible. He truck it home and deep, with all the Malice of an angry God.

There was a Church belonging to the Cordeliers, whither Miranda often repair'd to her Devotion; and being there one Day, accompany'd with a young Siter of the Order, after the Mas was ended, as 'tis the Cutom, ome one of the Fathers goes about the Church with a Box, for Contribution, or Charity-Money; it happen'd that Day, that a young Father, newly initiated, carried the Box about, which, in his turn, he brought to Miranda. She had no ooner cat her Eyes on this young Friar, but her Face was overpread with Bluhes of Surprize: She beheld him tedfatly, and aw in his Face all the Charms of Youth, Wit and Beauty; he wanted no one Grace that cou'd form him for Love, he appear'd
all that is adorable to the Fair Sex, nor cou'd the mihapen Habit hide from her the lovely Shape it endeavour'd to cover, nor thoe delicate Hands that approach'd her too near with the Box. Beides the Beauty of his Face and Shape, he had an Air altogether great; in pite of his profes'd Poverty, it betray'd the Man of Quality; and that Thought weigh'd greatly with Miranda. But Love, who did not deign he hou'd now feel any ort of thoe eaie Flames, with which he had heretofore burnt, made her oon lay all thoe Coniderations aide, which us'd to invite her to Love, and now lov'd he knew not why.

She gaz'd upon him, while he bow'd before her, and waited for her Charity, 'till he perceiv'd the lovely Friar to bluh, and cat his Eyes to the Ground. This awaken'd her Shame, and he put her Hand into her Pocket, and was a good while in earching for her Pure, as if he thought of nothing les, than what he was about; at lat he drew it out, and gave him a Pitole; but that with o much Deliberation and Leiure, as eaily betray'd the Satisfaction he took in looking on him; while the good Man, having receiv'd her Bounty, after a very low Obeiance, proceeded to the ret; and Miranda cating after him a Look all languihing, as long as he remain'd in the Church, departed with a Sigh as oon as he aw him go out, and return'd to her Apartment, without peaking one Word all the Way to the young Fille Devote, who attended her; o abolutely was her Soul employ'd with this young holy
Man. Cornelia (o was this Maid call'd who was with her) perceiving he was o ilent, who us'd to be all Wit and good Humour, and oberving her little Diorder at the Sight of the young Father, tho' he was far from imagining it to be Love, took an Occaion, when he was come home, to peak of him. Madam, aid he, did you not oberve that fine young Cordedelier, who brought the Box? At a Qution that nam'd that Object of her Thoughts, Miranda bluh'd; and the finding he did o, redoubl'd her Confuion, and he had carce Courage enough to ay,—Yes, I did oberve him: And then, forcing herelf to mile a little, continu'd; And I wonder'd to ee o jolly a young Friar of an Order o evere, and mortify'd. Madam, (reply'd Cornelia) when you know his Story, you will not wonder. Miranda, who was impatient to know all that concern'd her new Conqueror, oblig'd her to tell his Story; and Cornelia obey'd, and proceeded.

div.head: The Story of Prince HENRICK.

p.q:
YOU mut know, Madam, that this young holy Man is a Prince of Germany, of the Houe of—, whoe Fate it was, to fall mot paionately in Love with a fair young Lady, who lov'd him with an Ardour equal to what he vow'd her. Sure of her Heart, and wanting only the Approbation of her Parents, and his own, which her Quality did not uffer him to depair of, he boated
of his Happines to a young Prince, his elder Brother, a Youth amorous and fierce, impatient of Joys, and enible of Beauty, taking Fire with all fair Eyes: He was his Father's Darling, and Delight of his fond Mother; and by an Acendant over both their Hearts, rul'd their Wills.

This young Prince no ooner aw, but lov'd the fair Mitres of his Brother, and with an Authority of a Sovereign, rather than the Advice of a Friend, warn'd his Brother Henrick (this now young Friar) to approach no more this Lady, whom he had een; and eeing, lov'd.

In vain the poor urpriz'd Prince pleads his Right of Love, his Exchange of Vows, and Aurance of an Heart that cou'd never be but for himelf. In vain he urges his Nearnes of Blood, his Friendhip, his Paion, or his Life, which o entirely depended on the Poeion of the charming Maid. All his Pleading erv'd but to blow his Brother's Flame; and the more he implores, the more the other burns; and while Henrick follows him on his Knees, with humble Submiions, the other flies from him in Rages of tranported Love; nor cou'd his Tears, that puru'd his Brother's Steps, move him to Pity: Hot-headed, vain-conceited of his Beauty, and greater Quality, as elder Brother, he doubts not his Succes, and reolv'd to acrifice all to the Violence of his new-born Paion.

In hort, he peaks of his Deign to his Mother, who promis'd him her Aitance;
and accordingly, propoing it firt to the Prince, her Husband, urging the Languihment of her Son, he oon wrought o on him, that a Match being concluded between the Parents of this young Beauty, and Henrick's Brother, the Hour was appointed before he knew of the Sacrifice he was to be made. And while this was in Agitation, Henrick was ent on ome great Affairs, up into Germany, far out of the way; not but his boding Heart, with perpetual Sighs and Throbs, eternally foretold him his Fate.

All the Letters he writ were intercepted, as well as thoe he writ to him. She finds herelf every Day perplex'd with the Addrees of the Prince he hated; he was ever ighing at her Feet. In vain were all her Reproaches, and all her Coldnes, he was on the urer ide; for what he found Love wou'd not do, Force of Parents wou'd.

She complains, in her Heart, on young Henrick, from whom he cou'd never receive one Letter; and at lat, cou'd not forbear burting into Tears, in pite of all her Force, and feign'd Courage; when, on a Day, the Prince told her, that Henrick was withdrawn, to give him time to Court her; to whom, he aid, He confes'd he had made ome Vows; but did repent of 'em, knowing himelf too young to make 'em good: That it was for that Reaon he brought him firt to ee her; and for that Reaon, that after that, he never aw her more, nor o much as took Leave of her; (when, indeed, his Death lay upon the
next Viit, his Brother having worn to murther him; and to that End, put a Guard upon him, 'till he was ent into Germany.)

All this he utter'd with o many paionate Aeverations, Vows, and eeming Pity for her being o inhumanely abandon'd, that he almot gave Credit to all he had aid, and had much adoe to keep herelf within the Bounds of Moderation, and ilent Grief. Her Heart was breaking, her Eyes languih'd, and her Cheeks grew pale, and he had like to have fallen dead into the treacherous Arms of him that had reduc'd her to this Dicovery; but he did what he cou'd to aume her Courage, and to hew as little Reentment as poible for a Heart, like hers, oppres'd with Love, and now abandon'd by the dear Subject of its Joys and Pains.

But, Madam, not to tire you with this Adventure, the Day arriv'd wherein our till weeping fair Unfortunate was to be acrific'd to the Capriciounes of Love; and he was carry'd to Court by her Parents, without knowing to what End, where he was almot compell'd to marry the Prince.

Henrick, who, all this while, knew no more of his Unhappines, than what his Fears uggeted, returns, and paes even to the Preence of his Father, before he knew any thing of his Fortune; where he beheld his Mitres and his Brother, with his Father, in uch a Familiarity, as he no longer doubted his Detiny. 'Tis hard to judge, whether the Lady, or himelf, was mot urpriz'd; he
was all pale and unmovable in her Chair, and Henrick fix'd like a Statue; at lat Grief and Rage took place of Amazement, and he could not forbear crying out, Ah, Traytor! Is it thus you have treated a Friend and Brother? And you, O perjur'd Charmer! Is it thus you have rewarded all my Vows? He cou'd ay no more; but reeling againt the Door, had fall'n in a Swoon upon the Floor, had not his Page caught him in his Arms, who was entring with him. The good old Prince, the Father, who knew not what all this meant, was oon inform'd by the young, weeping Princes; who, in relating the Story of her Amour with Henrick, told her Tale in o moving a manner, as brought Tears to the Old Man's Eyes, and Rage to thoe of her Husband; he immediately grew jealous to the lat Degree: He finds himelf in Poeion ('tis true) of the Beauty he ador'd; but the Beauty adoring another; a Prince, young, and charming as the Light; oft, witty, and raging with an equal Paion. He finds this dreaded Rival in the ame Houe with him, with an Authority equal to his own; and fancies, where two Hearts are o entirely agreed, and have o good an Undertanding, it would not be impoible to find Opportunities to atisfie and eae that mutual Flame, that burnt o equally in both; he therefore reolv'd to end him out of the World, and to etablih his own Repoe by a Deed, wicked, cruel, and unnatural, to have him aainated the firt Opportunity he cou'd find.
This Reolution et him a little at eae, and he trove to diemble Kindnes to Henrick, with all the Art he was capable of, uffering him to come often to the Apartment of the Princes, and to entertain her oftentimes with Dicoure, when he was not near enough to hear what he poke; but till watching their Eyes, he found thoe of Henrick full of Tears, ready to flow, but retrain'd, looking all dying, and yet reproaching, while thoe of the Princes were ever bent to the Earth, and he, as much as poible, hunning his Converation. Yet this did not atisfie the jealous Husband; 'twas not her Complaiance that cou'd appeae him; he found her Heart was panting within, when ever Henrick approach'd her, and every Viit more and more confirm'd his Death

The Father often found the Diorders of the Sons; the Softnes and Addres of the one gave him as much Fear, as the angry Bluhings, the fierce Looks, and broken Replies of the other, when ever he beheld Henrick approach his Wife: So that the Father fearing ome ill Conequence of this, beought Henrick to withdraw to ome other Country, or travel into Italy, he being now of an Age that requir'd a View of the World. He told his Father, That he wou'd obey his Commands, though he was certain, that Moment he was to be eparated from the ight of the fair Princes, his Siter, wou'd be the lat of his Life; and, in fine, made o pitiful a Story of his uffering Love, as almot mov'd
the old Prince to compaionate him o far, as to permit him to tay; but he aw inevitable Danger in that, and therefore bid him prepare for his Journey.

That which pas'd between the Father and Henrick, being a Secret, none talk'd of his departing from Court; o that the Deign the Brother had, went on; and making an Hunting-match one Day, where mot young People of Quality were, he order'd ome whom he had hir'd to follow his Brother, o as if he chanc'd to go out of the way, to dipatch him; and accordingly, Fortune gave 'em an Opportunity; for he lagg'd behind the Company, and turn'd aide into a pleaant Thicket of Hazles; where alighting he walk'd on Foot in the mot pleaant part of it, full of Thought, how to divide his Soul between Love and Obedience. He was enible that he ought not to tay, that he was but an Affliction to the young Princes, whoe Honour cou'd never permit her to eae any part of his Flame; nor was he o vicious, to entertain a Thought that hou'd tain her Vertue. He beheld her now as his Brother's Wife, and that ecur'd his Flame from all looe Deires, if her native Modety had not been ufficient of itelf to have done it, and that profound Repect he paid her: And he conider'd, in obeying his Father, he left her at Eae, and his Brother freed of a thouand Fears; he went to eek a Cure, which if he cou'd not find, at lat he cou'd but die; and o he mut, even at her Feet:
However, that 'twas more noble to eek a Remedy for his Dieae, than expect a certain Death by taying. After a thouand Reflections on his hard Fate, and bemoaning himelf, and blaming his cruel Stars, that had doom'd him to die o young; after an infinity of Sighs and Tears, Reolvings and Unreolvings, he, on the udden, was interrupted by the trampling of ome Hores he heard, and their ruhing through the Boughs, and aw four Men make towards him: He had not time to mount, being walk'd ome Paces from his Hore. One of the Men advanc'd, and cry'd, Prince you must die.—I do believe thee (reply'd Henrick) but not by a Hand o bae as thine: And at the ame time, drawing his Sword, run him into the Groin. When the Fellow found himelf o wounded, he wheel'd off, and cry'd, Thou art a Prophet, and hast rewarded my Treachery with Death. The ret came up, and one hot at the Prince, and hot him in the Shoulder; the other two hatily laying hold (but too late) on the Hand of the Murtherer, cry'd, Hold, Traytor; we relent, and he hall not die. He reply'd, 'Tis too late, he is hot; and ee, he lies dead: Let us provide for our elves, and tell the Prince, we have done the Work; for you are as guilty as I am. At that, they all fled, and left the Prince lying under a Tree, weltering in his Blood.

About the Evening, the Foreter going his Walks, aw the Hore richly caparion'd, without a Rider, at the Entrance of the
Wood; and going farther, to ee if he cou'd find its Owner, found there the Prince almot dead: He immediately mounts him on the Hore, and himelf behind, bore him up, and carry'd him to the Lodge; where he had only one old Man, his Father, well skill'd in Surgery, and a Boy. They put him to Bed, and the old Foreter, with what Art he had, dres'd his Wound, and in the Morning ent for an abler Surgeon, to whom the Prince enjoyn'd Secrecy, becaue he knew him. The Man was faithful, and the Prince, in time, was recover'd of his Wound; and ae oon as he was well, he came for Flanders, in the Habit of a Pilgrim, and after ome time, took the Order of St. Francis, none knowing what became of him, 'till he was profefs'd; and then he writ his own Story to the Prince his Father, to his Mitres, and his ungrateful Brother. The young Princes did not long urvive his Los, he languih'd from the Moment of his Departure; and he had this to confirm his devout Life, to know he dy'd for him.
My Brother, Madam, was an Officer under the Prince, his Father, and knew his Story perfectly well; from whoe Mouth I had it.

div.p:
What! (reply'd Miranda then) is Father Henrick a Man of Quality? Yes, Madam, (aid Cornelia,) and has chang'd his Name to Francico. But Miranda, fearing to betray the Sentiments of her Heart, by asking any more Quetions
about him, turn'd the Dicoure; and ome Perons of Quality came in to viit her (for her Apartment was, about Six a-clock, like the Preence-Chamber of a Queen, always fill'd with the greatet People.) There meet all the Beaux Epreets, and all the Beauties. But it was viible Miranda was not o gay as he us'd to be; but penive, and anwering Mal a propo, to all that was aid to her. She was a thouand times going to peak, againt her Will, omething of the charming Friar, who was never from her Thoughts; and he imagin'd, if he could inpire Love in a coure, grey, ill-made Habit, a horn Crown, a Hair-Cord about his Wate, bare-leg'd, in Sandals intead of Shooes, what mut he do, when looking back on Time, he beholds him in a Propect of Glory, with all that Youth, and Illutrious Beauty, et off by the Advantage of Dres and Equipage. She frames an Idea of him all gay, and plendid, and looks on his preent Habit as ome Diguie proper for the Stealths of Love; ome feign'd put-on Shape, with the more Security to approach a Mitres, and make himelf happy; and that, the Robe laid by, he has the Lover in his proper Beauty, the ame he wou'd have been, if any other Habit (tho' never o rich) were put off: In the Bed, the ilent, gloomy Night, and the oft Embraces of her Arms, he loes all the Friar, and aumes all the Prince; and that awful Reverence, due alone to his holy Habit, he exchanges for a thouand Dalliances, for which his Youth was made; for Love, for tender Embraces, and
all the Happines of Life. Some Moments he fancies him a Lover, and that the fair Object that takes up all his Heart, has left no room for her there; but that was a Thought that did not long perplex her, and which, almot as oon as born, he turn'd to her Advantage: She beholds him a Lover, and therefore finds he has a Heart enible and tender; he had Youth to be fir'd, as well as to inpire; he was far from the lov'd Object, and totally without Hope: and he reaonably conider'd, that Flame wou'd of itelf oon die, that had only Depair to feed on. She beheld her own Charms; and Experience, as well as her Glas, told her, they never fail'd of Conquet; epecially where they deign'd it: And he believ'd Henrick would be glad, at leat, to quench that Flame in himelf, by an Amour with her, which was kindl'd by the young Princes of—his Siter.

Thee, and a thouand other Self-flatteries, all vain and indicreet, took up her waking Nights, and now more retir'd Days; while Love, to make her truly wretched, uffer'd her to ooth herelf with fond Imaginations; not o much as permitting her Reaon to plead one Moment to ave her from Undoing: She wou'd not uffer it to tell her, he had taken holy Orders, made acred and olemn Vows of everlating Chatity, that 'twas impoible he cou'd marry her, or lay before her any Argument that might prevent her Ruine; but Love, mad, malicious Love was always call'd to Counel, and, like eaie Monarchs, he had no Ears, but for Flatterers.

Well then, he is reolv'd to love, without conidering to what End, and what mut be the Conequence of uch an Amour. She now mis'd no Day of being at that little Church, where he had the Happines, or rather, the Misfortune (o Love ordain'd) to ee this Raviher of her Heart and Soul; and every Day he took new Fire from his lovely Eyes: Unawares, unknown and unwillingly he gave her Wounds, and the Difficulty of her Cure made her Rage the more: She burnt, he languih'd, and dy'd for the young Innocent, who knew not he was the Author of o much Michief.

Now he reolves a thouand Ways in her tortur'd Mind, to let him know her Anguih, and at lat pitch'd upon that of writing to him oft Billets, which he had learnt the Art of doing; or if he had not, he had now Fire enough to inpire her with all that cou'd charm and move. Thee he deliver'd to a young Wench, who waited on her, and whom he had entirely ubdu'd to her Interet, to give to a certain Lay-Brother of the Order, who was a very imple, harmles Wretch, and who erv'd in the Kitchen, in the nature of a Cook in the Monatery of Cordeliers: She gave him Gold to ecure his Faith and Service; and not knowing from whence they came (with o good Credentials) he undertook to deliver the Letters to Father Francico; which Letters were all afterwards, as you hall hear, produc'd in open Court. Thee Letters fail'd not to come every Day; and the Sence of the firt was, to tell him that a very beautiful young Lady, of a
great Fortune, was in love with him, without naming her; but it came as from a third Peron, to let him know the Secret, that he deir'd he wou'd let her know whether he might hope any Return from him; auring him, he needed but only ee the fair Languiher, to confes himelf her Slave.

This Letter being deliver'd him, he read by himelf, and was urpriz'd to receive Words of this nature, being o great a Stranger in that place; and cou'd not imagine, or wou'd not give himelf the trouble of gueing who this hould be, becaue he never deign'd to make Returns.

The next Day Miranda, finding no Advantage from her Meenger of Love, in the Evening ends another (impatient of Delay) confeing that he who uffer'd the Shame of Writing and Imploring, was the Peron herelf who ador'd him. 'Twas there her raging Love made her ay all things that dicover'd the nature of its Flame, and propoe to flee with him to any part of the World, if he wou'd quit the Convent; that he had a Fortune coniderable enough to make him happy, and that his Youth and Quality were not given him to o unprofitable an End as to loe themelves in a Convent, where Poverty and Eae was all their Buines. In fine, he leaves nothing unurg'd that might debauch and invite him; not forgetting to end him her own Character of Beauty, and left him to judge of her Wit and Spirit by her Writing, and her Love by the Extremity of Paion he profes'd. To all
which, the lovely Friar made no Return, as believing a gentle Capitulation or Exhortation to her wou'd but inflame her the more, and give new Occaions for her continuing to write. All her Reaonings, fale and vicious, he depis'd, pities the Error of her Love, and was Proof againt all he could plead. Yet notwithtanding his Silence, which left her in doubt, and more tormented her, he ceas'd not to purue him with her Letters, varying her Style; ometimes all wanton, looe and raving; ometimes feigning a Virgin-modety all over, accuing herelf, blaming her Conduct, and iging her Detiny, as one compell'd to the hameful Dicovery by the Auterity of his Vow and Habit, asking his Pity and Forgivenes; urging him in Charity to ue his Fatherly Care to perwade and reaon with her wild Deires, and by his Councel drive the God from her Heart, whoe Tyranny was wore than that of a Fiend; and he did not know what his pious Advice might do. But till he writes in vain, in vain he varies her Style, by a Cunning, peculiar to a Maid poes'd with uch a ort of Paion.

This cold Neglect was till Oil to the burning Lamp, and he tries yet more Arts, which for want of right Thinking, were as fruitles. She has recoure to Preents; her Letters came loaded with Rings of great price, and Jewels, which Fops of Quality had given her. Many of this ort he receiv'd, before he knew where to return 'em, or how; and on this Occaion alone he ent her a Letter, and retor'd her
Trifles, as he call'd 'em: But his Habit having not made him forget his Quality and Education, he writ to her with all the profound Repect imaginable; believing by her Preents, and the Liberality with which we parted with 'em, that he was of Quality. But the whole Letter, as he told me afterwards, was to perwade her from the Honour he did him, by loving him; urging a thouand Reaons, olid and pious, and auring her, he had wholly devoted the ret of his Days to Heaven, and had no need of thoe gay Trifles he had ent him, which were only fit to adorn Ladies o fair as herelf, and who had buines with this glittering World, which he didain'd, and had for ever abandon'd. He ent her a thouand Bleings, and told her, he hou'd be ever in his Prayers, though not in his Heart, as he deired: And abundance of Goodnes more he expres'd, and Councel he gave her, which had the ame Effect with his Silence; it made her Love but the more, and the more impatient he grew: She now had a new Occaion to write, he now is charm'd with his Wit; this was the new Subject. She rallies his Reolution, and endeavours to re-call him to the World, by all the Arguments that Humane Invention is capable of.

But when he had above four Months languih'd thus in vain, not miing one Day, wherein he went not to ee him, without dicovering herelf to him; he reolv'd, as her lat Effort, to hew her Peron, and ee what that, aited by her Tears, and oft Words
from her Mouth, cou'd do, to prevail upon him.
It happen'd to be on the Eve of that Day when he was to receive the Sacrament, that he, covering herelf with her Veil, came to Vepers, purpoing to make choice of the conquering Friar for her Confeor.

She approach'd him; and as he did o, he trembl'd with Love: At lat he cry'd, Father, my Confeor is gone for ome time from the Town, and I am oblig'd to morrow to receive, and beg you will be pleas'd to take my Confeion.

He cou'd not refue her; and let her into the Sacrite, where there is a Confeion-Chair, in which he eated himelf; and on one ide of him he kneel'd down, over againt a little Altar, where the Priets Robes lie, on which was plac'd ome lighted Wax-Candles, that made the little place very light and plendid, which hone full upon Miranda.

After the little Preparation uual in Confeion, he turn'd up her Veil, and dicover'd to his View the mot wond'rous Object of Beauty he had ever een, dres'd in all the Glory of a young Bride; her Hair and Stomacher full of Diamonds, that gave a Lutre all dazling to her brighter Face and Eyes. He was urpriz'd at her amazing Beauty, and quetion'd whether he aw a Woman or an Angel at his Feet. Her Hands, which were elevated, as if in Prayer, eem'd to be form'd of polih'd Alabater; and he confes'd, he had never een any thing in Nature o perfect, and o admirable.

He had ome pain to compoe himelf to hear her Confeion, and was oblig'd to turn away his Eyes, that his Mind might not be perplex'd with an Object o diverting; when Miranda, opening the finet Mouth in the World, and dicovering new Charms, began her Confeion.

Holy Father (aid he;) amongst the Number of my vile Offences, that which afflicts me to the greatest Degree, is, that I am in Love: Not (continu'd he) that I believe imple, and vertuous Love a Sin, when 'tis plac'd on an Object proper and uitable; but, my dear Father, (aid he, and wept,) I love with a Violence which cannot be contain'd within the Bounds of Reaon, Moderation, or Vertue. I love a Man whom I cannot poes without a Crime, and a Man who cannot make me happy without become perjur'd. Is he marry'd? (reply'd the Father.) No; (anwer'd Miranda. Are you o? (continu'd he.) Neither; (aid he) Is he too near ally'd to you? (aid Francico:) a Brother, or Relation? Neither of thee, (aid he:) He is unenjoy'd, unpromis'd; and o am I: Nothing oppoes our Happines, or makes my Love a Vice, but You:—'Tis you deny me Life: 'Tis you that forbids my Flame: 'Tis you will have me die, and eek my Remedy in my Grave, when I complain of Tortures, Wounds and Flames. O cruel Charmer, 'tis for you I languih; and here, at your Feet, implore that Pity which all my Addrees have fail'd of procuring me.—

With that, perceiving he was about to rie from his Seat, he held him by his Habit, and vow'd he wou'd in that poture follow him, where-ever he flew from her. She elevated her Voice o loud, he was afraid he might be heard, and therefore uffer'd her to force him into his Chair again; where being eated, he began, in the mot paionate Terms imaginable, to diuade her; but finding he but the more perited in Eagernes of Paion, he us'd all the tender Aurance that he cou'd force from himelf, that he wou'd have for her all the Repect, Eteem and Friendhip that he was capable of paying; that he had a real Compaion for her; and at lat, he prevail'd o far with him by her Sighs and Tears, as to own he had a Tendernes for her, and that he cou'd not behold o many Charms, without being enibly touch'd by them, and finding all thoe Effects that a Maid o young and fair caues in the Souls of Men of Youth and Sene: But that, as he was aured, he cou'd never be o happy to marry her, and as certain he cou'd not grant any thing but honourable Paion, he humbly beought her not to expect more from him than uch; and then began to tell her how hort Life was, and tranitory its Joys; how oon he wou'd grow weary of Vice, and how often change to find real Repoe in it, but never arrive to it. He made an End by new Aurance of his eternal Friendhip, but utterly forbad her to hope.

Behold her now deny'd, refus'd and defeated, with all her pleading Youth, Beauty, Tears, and Knees, imploring, as he lay, holding fat his Scapular, and embracing his Feet. What hall he do? She wells with Pride, Love, Indignation and Deire, her burning Heart is burting with Depair, her Eyes grow fierce, and from Grief, he ries to a Storm; and in her Agony of Paion, which looks all didainful, haughty, and full of Rage, he began to revile him, as the pooret of Animals: Tells him, his Soul was dwindled to the Meannes of his Habit, and his Vows of Poverty were uited to his degenerate Mind. And (aid he) ince all my nobler Ways have fail'd me; and that, for a little hypocritical Devotion, you reolve to loe the greatest Bleings of Life, and to acrifice me to your Religious Pride and Vanity, I will either force you to abandon that dull Diimulation; or you hall die, to prove your Sanctity real. Therefore anwer me immediately, anwer my Flame, my raging Fire, which your Eyes have kindled; or here, in this very Moment, I will ruine thee; and make no Scruple of revenging the Pains I uffer, by that which hall take away your Life and Honour.

The trembling young Man, who, all this while, with extream Anguih of Mind, and Fear of the dire Reult, had liten'd to her Ravings, full of Dread, demanded what he wou'd have him do. When he reply'd,— Do that which thy Youth and Beauty were ordain'd to do:—This place is private, a Sacred Silence reigns here, and no one dares to pry into the
Secrets of this holy Place: We are as ecure from Fears of Interruption as in Dearts uninhabited, or Caves foraken by wild Beats. The Tapers too hall veil their Lights, and only that glimmering Lamp hall be witnes of our dear Stealths of Love—Come to my Arms, my trembling, longing Arms; and cure the Folly of thy Bigottry, that has made thee o long loe a Bleing, for which o many Princes igh in vain.

At thee Words he roe from his Feet, and natching him in her Arms, he cou'd not defend himelf from receiving a thouand Kies from the lovely Mouth of the charming Wanton; after which, he ran herelf, and in an intant put out the Candles. But he cry'd to her, In vain, O too indicreet Fair Onè; in vain you put out the Light; for Heaven till has Eyes, and will look down upon my broken Vows. I own your Power, I own I have all the Sene in the World of your charming Touches; I am frail Fleh and Blood, but yet—yet—yet I can reist; and I prefer my Vows to all your powerful Temptations. —I will be deaf and blind, and guard my Heart with Walls of Ice, and make you know, that when the Flames of true Devotion are kindled in a Heart, it puts out all other Fires; which are as ineffectual, as Candles lighted in the Face of the Sun.—Go, vain Wanton, and repent, and mortifie that Blood which has o hamefully betray'd thee, and which will one Day ruine both thy Soul and Body.—

At thee Words Miranda, more enrag'd, the nearer he imagin'd herelf to Happines, made no Reply; but throwing herelf, in that
intant, into the Confeing-Chair, and violently pulling the young Friar into her Lap, he elevated her Voice to uch a degree, in crying out, Help, help: A Rape: Help, help, that he was heard all over the Church, which was full of People at the Evening's Devotion; who flock'd about the Door of the Sacriti; which was hut with a Spring-lock on the inide, but they durt not open the Door.

'Tis eaily to be imagin'd, in what Condition our young Friar was, at this lat devilih Stratagem of his wicked Mitres. He trove to break from thoe Arms that held him o fat; and his butling to get away, and hers to retain him, diorder'd her Hair and Habit to uch a degree, as gave the more Credit to her fale Accuation.

The Fathers had a Door on the other ide, by which they uually enter'd, to dres in this little Room; and at the Report that was in an intant made 'em, they hated thither, and found Miranda and the good Father very indecently trugling; which they mi-interpreted, as Miranda deir'd; who, all in Tears, immediately threw herelf at the Feet of the Provincial, who was one of thoe that enter'd; and cry'd, O holy Father, revenge an innocent Maid, undone and lost to Fame and Honour, by that vile Monter, born of Goats, nurs'd by Tygers, and bred up on avage Mountains, where Humanity and Religion are Strangers. For, O holy Father, cou'd it have enter'd into the Heart of Man, to have done o barbarous and horrid a Deed, as to attempt the Virgin-Honour of an unpotted
Maid, and one of my Degree, even in the Moment of my Confeion, in that holy time, when I was protrate before him and Heaven, confeing tho Sins that pres'd my tender Concience; even then to load my Soul with the blackest of Infamies, to add to my Number a Weight that must ink me to Hell? Alas! under the Security of his innocent Looks, his holy Habit, and his awful Function, I was lead into this Room, to make my Confeion; where, he locking the Door, I had no ooner began, but he gazing on me, took Fire at my fatal Beauty; and tarting up, put out the Candles, and caught me in his Arms; and raiing me from the Pavement, et me in the Confeion-Chair; and then—Oh, pare me the ret.
With that a Shower of Tears burt from her fair diembling Eyes, and Sobs o naturally acted, and o well manag'd, as left no Doubt upon the good Men, but all he had poken was Truth.

—At firt, (proceeded he,) I was unwilling to bring o great a Scandal on his Order, as to cry out; but truggl'd as long as I had Breath, pleaded the Heinounes of the Crime; urging my Quality, and the Danger of the Attempt. But he, deaf as the Winds, and ruffling as a Storm, puru'd his wild Deign with o much Force and Inolence, as I at lat, unable to reit, was wholly vanquih'd, robb'd of my native Purity: With what Life and Breath I had, I call'd for Aitance, both from Men and Heaven; but oh, alas! your Succours come too late:—You find me here a wretched, undone and ravih'd Maid. Revenge me, Fathers;
revenge me on the perfidious Hypocrite, or ele give me a Dea • h that may ecure your Cruelty and Injutice from ever being proclaim'd o'er the World; or my Tongue will be eternally reproaching you, and curing the wicked Author of my Infamy.
She ended as he began, with a thouand Sighs and Tears; and receiv'd from the Provinciall all Aurances of Revenge.

The innocent betray'd Victim, all this while he was peaking, heard her with an Atonihment that may eaily be imagin'd; yet hew'd no extravagant Signs of it, as thoe wou'd do, who feign it to be thought innocent, but being really o, he bore, with an humble, modet, and bluhing Countenance, all her Accuations: Which ilent Shame they mitook for evident Signs of his Guilt.

When the Provincial demanded, with an unwonted Severity in his Eyes and Voice, what he cou'd anwer for himelf; calling him Prophaner of his acred Vows, and Infamy to the holy Order; the Injur'd, but the innocently Accus'd, only reply'd, May Heaven forgive that bad Woman, and bring her to Repentance: For his part, he was not o much in love with Life, as to ue many Arguments to jutifie his Innocence; unles it were to free that Order from a Scandal, of which he had the Honour to be profes'd: But as for himelf, Life or Death were things indifferent to him, who heartily depis'd the World.

He aid no more, and uffer'd himelf to be led before the Magitrate; who committed him to Prion, upon the Accuation of this implacable
Beauty; who, with o much feign'd Sorrow, proecuted the Matter, even to his Tryal and Condemnation; where he refus'd to make any great Defence for himelf. But being daily viited by all the Religious, both of his own, and other Orders, they oblig'd him (ome of 'em knowing the Auterity of his Life, others his Caue of Griefs that firt brought him into Orders, and others pretending a nearer Knowledge, even of his Soul it elf) to tand upon his Jutification, and dicover what he knew of that wicked Woman; whoe Life had not been o exemplary for Vertue, not to have given the World a thouand Supicions of her Lewdnes and Protitutions.

The daily Importunities of thee Fathers made him produce her Letters: But as he had all the Gown-Men on his ide, he had all the Hats and Feathers on hers; all the Men of Quality taking her part, and all the Church-men his. They heard his daily Protetations and Vows, but not a Word of what paed at Confeion was yet dicover'd: He held that as a Secret acred on his part; and what was aid in nature of a Confeion, was not to be reveal'd, though his Life depended on the Dicovery. But as to the Letters, they were forc'd from him, and expos'd; however, Matters were carry'd with o high a Hand againt him, that they erv'd for no Proof at all of his Innocence, and he was at lat condemn'd to be burn'd at the Market-place.

After his Sentence was pas'd, the whole Body of Priets made their Addrees to Marques Cateil Roderigo, the then Governour of Flanders, for a Reprieve; which, after much a-do, was granted him for ome Weeks, but with an abolute Denial of Pardon; o prevailing were the young Cavaliers of his Court, who were all Adorers of this Fair Jilt.

About this time, while the poor, innocent, young Henrick was thus languihing in Prion, in a dark and dimal Dungeon, and Miranda, cured of her Love, was triumphing in her Revenge, expecting, and daily giving new Conquets; and who, by this time, had re-aum'd all her wonted Gaiety, there was great Noie about the Town, that a Prince of mighty Name, and fam'd for all the Excellencies of his Sex, was arrived; a Prince young, and gloriouly attended, call'd Prince Tarquin.

We had often heard of this Great Man, and that he was making his Travels in France and Germany: And we had alo heard, that ome Years before, he being about Eighteen Years of Age, in the time when our King Charles of Bleed Memory was in Bruxels, in the lat Year of his Banihment, that all on a udden, this young Man roe up upon 'em like the Sun, all glorious and dazling, demanding Place of all the Princes in that Court. And when his Pretence was demanded, he own'd himelf Prince Tarquin, of the Race of the lat Kings of Rome, made good his Title, and took his Place accordingly. After that, he travell'd for about ix Years up and down the World,
and then arriv'd at Antwerp, about the time of my being ent thither by His late Majety.

Perhaps there could be nothing een o magnificent as this Prince: He was, as I aid, extreamly handome, from Head to Foot exactly form'd, and he wanted nothing that might adorn that native Beauty to the bet Advantage. His Parts were uitable to the ret: He had an Accomplihment fit for a Prince, an Air haughty, but a Carriage affable, eaie in Converation, and very Entertaining, Liberal and Good-natur'd, Brave and Inoffenive. I have een him pas the Streets with twelve Foot-men, and four Pages; the Pages all in green Velvet Coats, lac'd with Gold, and white Velvet Trunks; the Men in Cloth, richly lac'd with Gold; his Coaches, and all other Officers, uitable to a Great Man.

He was all the Dicoure of the Town; ome laughing at his Title, others reverencing it: Some cry'd, that he was an Impotor; others, that he had made his Title as plain, as if Tarquin had reign'd but a Year ago. Some made Friendhips with him, others wou'd have nothing to ay to him; but all wonder'd where this Revenue was, that upported this Grandeur; and believ'd, though he cou'd make his Decent from the Roman Kings very well out, that he cou'd not lay o good a Claim to the Roman Land. Thus every Body medled with what they had nothing to do; and, as in other places, thought themelves on the urer ide, if, in thee doubtful Caes, they imagin'd the wort.

But the Men might be of what Opinion they pleas'd concerning him; the Ladies were all agreed that he was a Prince, and a young, handome Prince, and a Prince not to be reited: He had all their Wihes, all their Eyes, and all their Hearts: They now dres'd only for him; and what Church he grac'd, was ure, that Day, to have the Beauties, and all that thought themelves o.

You may believe, our amorous Miranda was not the lat Conquet he made. She no ooner heard of him, which was as oon as he arriv'd, but he fell in love with his very Name. Jeu!—A young King of Rome! Oh, 'twas o novel, that he doated on the Title; and had not car'd whether the ret had been Man or Monkey almot: She was reolv'd to be the Lucretia, that this young Tarquin hou'd ravih.

To this End, he was no ooner up the next Day, but he ent him a Billet Deaux, auring him how much he admir'd his Fame; and that being a Stranger in the Town, he begg'd the Honour of introducing him to all the Belle-Converations, &c. Which he took for the Invitation of ome Coquet, who had Interet in fair Ladies; and civilly return'd her an Anwer, that he wou'd wait on her. She had him that Day watch'd to Church; and impatient to ee what he heard o many People flock to ee, he went alo to the ame Church; thoe anctified Abodes being too often prophan'd by uch Devotees, whoe Buines is to ogle and ennare.

But what a Noie and Humming was heard all over the Church, when Tarquin enter'd? His Grace, his Mien, his Fahion, his Beauty, his Dres, and his Equipage urpriz'd all that were preent: And by the good Management and Care of Miranda, he got to kneel at the ide of the Altar, jut over againt the Prince; o that, if he wou'd, he cou'd not avoid looking full upon her. She had turn'd up her Veil, and all her Face and Shape appear'd uch, and o inchanting, as I have decrib'd: And her Beauty heighten'd with Bluhes, and her Eyes full of Spirit and Fire, with Joy, to find the young Roman Monarch o charming, he appear'd like omething more than mortal, and compell'd his Eyes to a fix'd Gazing on her Face: She never glanc'd that way, but he met 'em; and then would feign o modet a Shame, and Cat her Eyes downward with uch inviting Art, that he was wholly ravih'd and charm'd, and he over-joy'd to find he was o.

The Ceremony being ended, he ent a Page to follow that Lady home, himelf puruing her to the Door of the Church; where he took ome Holy Water, and threw upon her, and made her a profound Reverence. She forc'd an innocent Look, and a modet Gratitude in her Face, and bow'd, and pas'd forward, half aur'd of her Conquet; leaving him to go home to his Lodging, and impatiently wait the Return of his Page. And all the Ladies who aw this firt Beginning between the Prince and Miranda, began to cure and envy
her Charms, who had depriv'd 'em of half their Hopes.

After this, I need not tell you, he made Miranda a Viit; and from that Day, never left her Apartment, but when he went home at Nights, or unles he had Buines; o entirely was he conquer'd by this Fair One. But the Bihop, and everal Men of Quality, in Orders, that profes'd Friendhip to him, advis'd him from her Company; and poke everal things to him, that might (if Love had not made him blind) have reclaim'd him from the Puruit of his Ruin. But whatever they truted him with, he had the Art to wind herelf about his Heart, and make him unravel all his Secrets; and then knew as well, by feign'd Sighs and Tears, to make him dibelieve all. So that he had no Faith, but for her; and was wholly inchanted and bewitched by her. At lat, in pight of all that wou'd have oppos'd it, he marry'd this famous Woman, poes'd by o many Great Men and Strangers before, while all the World was pitying his Shame and Misfortunes.

Being marry'd, they took a great Houe; and as he was indeed a great Fortune, and now a great Princes, there was nothing wanting that was agreeable to their Quality; all was plendid and magnificent. But all this would not acquire 'em the World's Eteem; they had an Abhorrence for her former Life, depis'd her; and for his epouing a Woman o infamous, they depis'd him. So that tho' they admir'd, and gaz'd upon their Equipage,
and glorious Dres, they foreaw the Ruin that attended it; and paid her Quality little Repect.
She was no ooner marri'd, but her Uncle dy'd; and dividing his Fortune between Miranda, and her Siter, and leaves the young Heires, and all her Fortune, entirely in the Hands of the Princes.

We will call this Siter Alcidiana; he was about Fourteen Years of Age, and now had choen her Brother, the Prince, for her Guardian. If Alcidiana were not altogether o great a Beauty as her Siter, he had Charms ufficient to procure her a great many Lovers, though her Fortune had not been o coniderable as it was; but with that Addition, you may believe, he wanted no Courthips from thoe of the bet Quality; though every Body deplor'd her being under the Tutorage of a Lady o expert in all the Vices of her Sex, and o cunning a Manager of Sin as was the Princes; who, on her part, fail'd not, by all the Carees, and obliging Endearments, to engage the Mind of this young Maid, and to ubdue her wholly to her Government. All her Senes were eternally regal'd with the mot bewitching Pleaures they were capable of: She aw nothing but Glory and Magnificence, heard nothing but Muick of the weetet Sounds; the richet Perfumes employ'd her Smelling, and all he eat and touch'd was delicate and inviting; and being too young to conider, how this State and Grandeur was to be continu'd, little imagin'd her vat Fortune was every Day diminihing, towards its needles Support.

When the Princes went to Church, he had her Gentleman bare before her, carrying a great Velvet Cuhion, with great Golden Taels, for her to kneel on, and her Train born up a mot prodigious length; led by a Gentleman-Uher, bare; follow'd by innumerable Footmen, Pages, and Women. And in this State he wou'd walk in the Streets, as in thoe Countries 'tis the Fahion for the great Ladies to do, who are well; and in her Train two or three Coaches, and perhaps a rich Velvet Chair embroider'd, wou'd follow in State.

'Twas thus for ome time they liv'd, and the Princes was daily pres'd by young ighing Lovers, for her Conent to marry Alcidiana; but he had till one Art or other to put 'em off, and o continually broke all the great Matches that were propos'd to her, notwithtanding their Kindred, and other Friends, had indutriouly endeavour'd to make everal great Matches for her; but the Princes was till poitive in her Denial, and one way or other broke all. At lat it happen'd, there was one propos'd yet more advantageous; a young Count, with whom the young Maid grew paionately in Love, and beought her Siter to conent that he might have him, and got the Prince to peak in her behalf; but he had no ooner heard the ecret Reaons Miranda gave him, but (entirely her Slave) he chang'd his Mind, and uited it to hers, and he, as before, broke off that Amour; which o extreamly incens'd Alcidiana, that he, taking an Opportunity, got from her Guard, and ran away,
putting herelf into the Hands of a wealthy Merchant, her Kinman, and one who bore the greatet Authority in the City; him he chues for her Guardian, reolving to be no longer a Slave to the Tyranny of her Siter. And o well he ordered Matters, that he writ to this young Cavalier, her lat Lover, and retrieved him; who came back to Antwerp again, to renew his Courthip.

Both Parties being agreed, it was no hard Matter to perwade all but the Princes. But though he oppoed it, it was reolved on, and the Day appointed for Marriage, and the Portion demanded; demanded only, but never to be payed, the bet part of it being pent. However, he put 'em off from Day to Day, by a thouand frivolous Delays: And when he aw they would have recoure to Force, and that all her Magnificence would be at an End, if the Law hould prevail againt her; and that, without this Siter's Fortune, he could not long upport her Grandeur, he bethought herelf of a Means to make it all her own, by getting her Siter made away; but he being out of her Tuition, he was not able to accomplih o great a Deed of Darknes: But ince 'twas reolv'd it mut be done, he revolves on a Thouand Stratagems; and, at lat, pitches upon an effectual one.

She had a Page, called Van Brune; a Youth of great Addres and Wit, and one he had long manag'd for her purpoe. This Youth was about Seventeen Years of Age, and extreamly
beautiful; and in the time when Alcidiana lived with the Princes, he was a little in Love with this handome Boy; but 'twas check'd in its Infancy, and never grew up to a Flame: Nevertheles, Alcidiana retain'd till a ort of Tendernes for him, while he burned in good Earnet with Love for the Princes.

The Princes one Day ordering this Page to wait on her in her Cloet, he hut the Door; and after a Thouand Quetions of what he would undertake to erve her, the amorous Boy finding himelf alone, and cares'd by the fair Peron he ador'd, with joyful Bluhes that beautify'd his Face, told her, There was nothing upon Earth, he wou'd not do, to obey her least Commands. She grew more familiar with him, to oblige him; and eeing Love dance in his Eyes, of which he was o good a Judge, he treated him more like a Lover, than a Servant; till at lat the ravih'd Youth, wholly tranported out of himelf, fell at her Feet, and impatiently implor'd to receive her Commands quickly, that he might fly to execute 'em; for he was not able to bear her charming Words, Looks, and Touches, and retain his Duty. At this he mil'd, and told him, the Work was of uch a Nature, as wou'd mortifie all Flames about him; and he would have more need of Rage, Envy, and Malice, than the Aids of a Paion o oft as what he now found him capable of. He aur'd her, he would tick at nothing, though even againt his Nature, to recompence for the Boldnes he now, through his Indicretion
had dicovered. She miling, told him, he had committed no Fault; and that poibly, the Pay he hou'd receive for the Service he required at his Hands, hould be—what he mot wih'd for in the World. To this he bowed to the Earth; and kiing her Feet, bad her Command. And then he boldly told him, 'Twas to kill her Siter Alcidiana. The Youth, without o much as tarting, or pauing upon the Matter, told her, It hould be done; and bowing low, immediately went out of the Cloet. She called him back, and would have given him ome Intruction; but he refus'd it, and aid, The Action, and the Contrivance hould be all his own. And offering to go again, he —again recalled him; putting into his Hand a Pure of a Hundred Pitoles, which he took; and with a low Bow, departed.

He no ooner left her Preence, but he goes directly and buys a Doe of Poyon, and went immediately to the Houe where Alcidiana lived; where deiring to be brought to her Preence, he fell a weeping; and told her, his Lady had fallen out with him, and dimied him her Service; and ince, from a Child, he had been brought up in the Family, he humbly beought Alcidiana to receive him into hers, he being in a few Days to be married. There needed not much intreaty to a thing that pleaed her o well, and he immediately received him to Penion. And he waited ome Days on her, before he could get an Opportunity to adminiter his Devilih Potion: But one Night, when he drunk
Wine with roated Apples, which was uual with her; intead of Sugar, or with the Sugar, the baneful Drug was mixed, and he drank it down.

About this time, there was a great Talk of this Page's coming from one Siter, to go to the other. And Prince Tarquin, who was ignorant of the Deign, from the Beginning to the End, hearing ome Men of Quality at his Table peaking of Van Brune's Change of Place (the Princes then keeping her Chamber upon ome trifling Indipoition) he anwered, That urely they were mitaken, that he was not dimied from the Princes's Service. And calling ome of his Servants, he asked for Van Brune; and whether any thing had happened between Her Highnes and him, that had occaioned his being turned off. They alo eemed ignorant of this Matter; and thoe who had poken of it, began to fancy there was ome Juggle in the Cae, which Time would bring to Light.

The enuing Day 'twas all about the Town, that Alcidiana was Poyoned; and though not dead, yet very near it; and that the Doctors aid, he had taken Mercury. So that there was never o formidable a Sight as this Fair young Creature; her Head and Body wollen, her Eyes tarting out, her Face black, and all deformed: So that diligent Search was made, who it hould be that did this; who gave her Drink and Meat. The Cook and Butler were examined, the Footmen called to an Account; but all concluded, he received
nothing, but from the Hand of her new Page, ince he came into her Service. He was examined, and hewed a thouand guilty Looks: And the Apothecary, then attending among the Doctors, proved he had bought Mercury of him three or four Days before; which he could not deny; and making many Excues for his buying it, betrayed him the more; o ill he chanced to diemble. He was immediately ent to be examined by the Margrave or Jutice, who made his Mittimus, and ent him to Prion.

'Tis eaie to imagine, in what Fears and Confuion the Princes was at this News: She took her Chamber upon it, more to hide her guilty Face, than for any Indipoition. And the Doctors applied uch Remedies to Alcidiana, uch Antidotes againt the Poion, that in a hort time he recovered; but lot the finet Hair in the World, and the Complexion of her Face ever after.

It was not long before the Trials for Criminals came on; and the Day being arrived, Van Brune was tried the firt of all; every Body having already read his Detiny, according as they wih'd it; and none would believe, but jut indeed as it was: So that for the Revenge they hoped to ee fall upon the Princes, every one wihed he might find no Mercy, that he might hare of his Shame and Miery.

The Seions-Houe was filled that Day with all the Ladies, and Chief of the Town, to hear the Reult of his Trial; and the ad Youth was brought loaden with Chains, and pale as
Death; where every Circumtance being ufficiently proved againt him, and he making but a weak Defence for himelf, he was Convicted, and ent back to Prion, to receive his Sentence of Death on the Morrow; where he owned all, and who et him on to do it. He own'd 'twas not Reward of Gain he did it for, but Hope he hould command at his Pleaure, the Poeion of his Mitres, the Princes; who hould deny him nothing, after having intruted him with o great a Secret; and that beides, he had elevated him with the Promie of that glorious Reward, and had dazl'd his young Heart with o charming a Propect, that blind and mad with Joy, he ruhed forward, to gain the deired Prize, and thought on nothing but his coming Happines: That he aw too late the Follies of his preumptuous Flame, and cured the deluding Flatteries of the fair Hypocrite, who had oothed him to his Undoing: That he was a mierable Victim to her Wickednes; and hoped, he hould warn all young Men, by his Fall, to avoid the Diimulation of the deceiving Fair: That he hoped, they would have Pity on his Youth, and attribute his Crime to the ubtile Peruaions alone of his Mitres, the Princes: And that ince Alcidiana was not dead, they would grant him Mercy, and permit him to live to repent of his grievous Crime, in ome Part of the World, whither they might banih him.

He ended with Tears, that fell in abundance from his Eyes; and immediately the Princes was apprehended, and brought to Prion, to
the ame Prion, where yet the poor young Father Francico was languihing, he having been from Week to Week reprieved, by the Interceion of the Fathers; and poibly he there had time to make ome Reflections.

You may imagine Tarquin left no means uneaied, to prevent the Imprionment of the Princes, and the Publick Shame and Infamy
•• e was likely to undergo in this Affair: But the whole City being over-joyed that he hould be punih'd, as an Author of all this Michief, were o generally bent againt her, both Priets, Magitrates, and People; the whole Force of the Stream running that way, he found no more Favour than the meanet Criminal. The Prince therefore, when he aw 'twas impoible to recue her from the Hands of Jutice, uffered with Grief unpeakable, what he could not prevent; and led her himelf to the Prion, followed by all his People, in as much State, as if he had been going to his Marriage; where, when he came, he was as well attended and erved as before, he never tirring one Moment from her.

The next Day he was tried in open and common Court; where he appeared in Glory, led by Tarquin, and attended according to her Quality: And he could not deny all the Page had alledged againt her, who was brought thither alo in Chains; and after a great many Circumtances, he was found Guilty, and both received Sentence; the Page to be hanged 'till he was dead, on a Gibbet, in the Market-place; and the Princes to tand under the Gibbet,
with a Rope about her Neck, the other end of which was to be fatned to the Gibbet where the Page was hanging; and to have an Incription, in large Characters, upon her Back and Breat, of the Caue why: Where he was to tand from Ten in the Morning, to Twelve.

This Sentence, the People, with one accord, believed too favourable for o ill a Woman, whoe Crimes deerved Death, equal to that of Van Brune: Nevertheles, there were ome who aid, it was infinitely more evere than Death itelf.

The following Friday was the Day of Execution, and one need not tell of the abundance of People, who were flocked together in the Market-place: And all the Windows were taken down, and filled with Spectators, and the Tops of Houes; when at the Hour appointed, the fatal Beauty appeared. She was dres'd in a black Velvet Gown, with a rich Row of Diamonds all down the fore-part of her Breat, and a great Knot of Diamonds at the Peak behind; and a Petticoat of flowered Gold, very rich, and laced; with all Things ele uitable: A Gentleman carried her great Velvet Cuhion before her, on which her Prayer-Book, embroidered, was laid; her Train was born up by a Page, and the Prince led her, bare; followed by his Foot-men, Pages, and other Officers of his Houe.

When they arrived to the Place of Execution, the Cuhion was laid on the Ground, upon a Portugal-Mat, pread there for that purpoe;
and the Princes tood on the Cuhion, with her Prayer-Book in her Hand, and a Priet by her ide; and was accordingly tied up to the Gibbet.

She had not tood there ten Minutes, but he had the Mortification, (at leat, one would think it o to her) to ee her ad Page, Van Brune, approach; fair as an Angel, but languihing and pale. That Sight moved all the Beholders with as much Pity, as that of the Princes did Didain and Pleaure.

He was dreed all in Mourning, and very fine Linnen; bare-headed, with his own Hair, the fairet that could be een, hanging all in Curls on his Back and Shoulders, very long. He had a Prayer-Book of black Velvet in his Hand, and behaved himelf with much Penitence and Devotion.

When he came under the Gibbet, he eeing his Mitres in that Condition, hewed an infinite Concern, and his fair Face was covered over with Bluhes; and falling at her Feet, he humbly ask'd her Pardon, for having been the Occaion of o great an Infamy to her, by a weak Confeion, which the Fears of Youth, and Hopes of Life, had obliged him to make, o greatly to her Dihonour; for indeed, he had wanted that Manly Strength, to bear the Efforts of dying as he ought, in Silence, rather than of committing o great a Crime againt his Duty, and Honour itelf; and that he could not die in Peace, unles he would forgive him. The Princes only nodded her Head, and cried, I do.—

And after having poken a little to his Father Confeor, who was with him, he chearfully mounted the Ladder; and in the ight of the Princes, he was turned off, while a loud Cry was heard through all the Market-place, epecially from the fair Sex; he hanging there 'till the time the Princes was to depart: And then he was put into a rich embroidered Chair, and carried away; Tarquin going into his; for he had all that time tood upporting the Princes under the Gallows, and was very weary. She was ent back, 'till her Releaement came; which was that Night, about Seven of the Clock; and then he was conducted to her own Houe in great State, with a Dozen White Wax-flambeaus about her Chair.

If the Affairs of Alcidiana, and her Friends, before were impatient of having the Portion out of the Hands of thee Extravagants, 'tis not to be imagined, but they were now much more o; and the next Day they ent an Officer, according to Law, to demand it; or to ummon the Prince to give Reaons, why he would not. And the Officer received for Anwer, That the Money hould be called in, and paid in uch a time; etting a certain Time, which I have not been o curious as to retain, or put in my Journal Obervations; but I am ure it was not long, as may be eaily imagin'd; for they every Moment, upected the Prince wou'd pack up, and be gone ome time, or other, on the udden; and for that Reaon they would not trut him without Bail, or two Officers to remain in his Houe, to watch that nothing
hould be removed, or touched. As for Bail, or Security, he could give none; every one lunk their Heads out of the Collar, when it came to that: So that he was obliged, at his own Expence, to maintain Officers in his Houe.

The Princes finding herelf reduced to the lat Extremity, and that he mut either produce the Value of a Hundred thouand Crowns, or ee the Prince, her Husband, lodged for ever in a Prion, and all their Glory vanih; and that it was impoible to fly, ince guarded; he had recoure to an Extremity, wore than the Affair of Van Brune. And in order to this, he firt puts on a World of Sorrow and Concern, for what he feared might arrive to the Prince: And indeed, if ever he hed Tears which he did not diemble, it was upon this Occaion. But here he almot over-acted: She tirred not from her Bed, and refued to Eat, or Sleep, or ee the Light; o that the Day being hut out of her Chamber, he lived by Wax-Lights, and refued all Comfort and Conolation.

The Prince, all raving with Love, tender Compaion, and Grief, never tirred from her Bed-ide, nor ceaed to implore, that he would uffer herelf to live. But he, who was not now o paionately in Love with Tarquin, as he was with the Prince; not o fond of the Man, as his Titles, and of Glory, foreaw the total Ruin of the lat, if not prevented, by avoiding the Payment of this great Sum; which could no otherwie be, than by the Death of
Alcidiana: And therefore, without ceaing, he wept, and cried out, She could not live, unles Alcidiana dy'd. This Alcidiana, (continued he) who has been the Author of my Shame; who has expoed me under a Gibbet, in the publick Market-place—Oh!—I am deaf to all Reaon, blind to Natural Affection.
