I renounce her, I hate her as my Mortal Foe, my Stop to Glory, and the Finiher of my Days, e'er half my Race of Life be run.

Then throwing her fale, but howy, charming Arms, about the Neck of her Heart-breaking Lord, and Lover, who lay ighing, and litening by her Side, he was charmed and bewitched into aying all Things that appeaed her: And latly, told her, Alcidiana hould be no longer an Obtacle to her Repoe; but that, if he would look up, and cast her Eyes of Sweetnes and Love upon him, as heretofore; forget her Sorrow, and redeem her lost Health, he would take what Meaures he hould propoe, to dipatch this fatal Stop to her Happines, out of the way.

Thee Words fail'd not to make her cares him in the mot endearing Manner, that Love and Flattery could invent; and he kied him to an Oath, a olemn Oath, to perform what he had promied; and he vowed liberally. And he aumed in an intant, her Good Humour, and uffered a Supper to be prepared, and did eat; which, in many Days before he had not done; o obtinate and powerful was he in Diembling well.

The next Thing to be conidered was, which Way this Deed was to be done; for they doubted not, but when 'twas done, all the World would lay it upon the Princes, as done by her Command: But he urged, Supicion was no Proof; and that they never put to Death any one, but when they had great and certain Evidences, who were the Offenders. She was ure of her own Contancy, that Racks and Tortures hould never get the Secret from her Breat; and if he were as confident on his part, there was no Danger. Yet this Preparation he made, towards the laying the Fact on others, that he caued everal Letters to be written from Germany, as from the Relations of Van Brune, who threatned Alcidiana with Death, for depriving their Kinman (who was a Gentleman) of his Life, tho' he had not taken away hers. And it was the Report of the Town, how this young Maid was threatned. And indeed, the Death of the Page had o afflicted a great many, that Alcidiana had procured herelf abundance of Enemies upon that Account, becaue he might have aved him if he had pleaed; but on the contrary, he was a Spectator, and in full Health and Vigour, at his Execution: And People were not o much concerned for her at this Report, as they would have been.

The Prince, who now had, by reaoning the Matter oberly with Miranda, found it abolutely neceary to dipatch Alcidiana; he reolved himelf, and with his own Hand, to execute it; not daring to trut to any of his mot
Favourite Servants, tho' he had many, who, poibly, would have obeyed him; for they loved him as he deerved; and o would all the World, had he not been o purely deluded by this fair Enchantres. He therefore, as I aid, reolved to keep this great Secret to himelf; and taking a Pitol, charged well with two Bullets, he watched an Opportunity to hoot her as he hould go out, or into her Houe, or Coach, ome Evening.

To this End he waited everal Nights, near her Lodgings; but till, either he went not out; or when he returned, he was o guarded with Friends, or her Lover, and Flambeaus, that he could not aim at her, without endangering the Life of ome other. But one Night above the ret, upon a Sunday, when he knew he would be at the Theater; for he never mied that Day, eeing the Play: He waited at the Corner of the Stadt-Houe, near the Theater, with his Cloak cat over his Face, and a black Perriwig, all alone, with his Pitol ready cock'd; and remain'd not very long, but he aw her Kinman's Coach come along; 'twas almot dark; Day was jut hutting up her Beauties, and left uch a Light to govern the World, as erved only jut to ditinguih one Object from another, an a convenient Help to Michief. He aw a Light out of the Coach, only one young Lady, the Lover, and then the detin'd Victim; which he (drawing near) knew rather by her Tongue, than Shape. The Lady ran into the Play-Houe, and left Alcidiana to be conducted by her Lover into it;
who led her to the Door, and went to give ome Order to the Coach-man; o that the Lover was about twenty Yards from Alcidiana; when he tood the fairet Mark in the World, on the Threhold of the Entrance of the Theatre; there being many Coaches about the Door, o that hers could not come o near. Tarquin was reolved not to loe o fair an Opportunity, and advanc'd, but went behind the Coaches; and when he came over-againt the Door, through a great Booted, Velvet Coach, that tood between him and her, he hot; and he having her Train of her Gown and Petticoat on her Arm, in great quantity, he mied her Body, and hot through her Cloaths, between her Arm and her Body. She, frightned to find omething hit her, and to ee the Smoak, and hear the Report of the Pitol; running in, cried, I am hot; I am dead.

This Noie quickly alarm'd her Lover; and all the Coach-men, and Foot-men immediately ran, ome one Way, and ome another. One of 'em eeing a Man hate away in a Clock, he being a luty, bold German, topped him; and drawing upon him, bad him tand, and deliver his Pitol, or he would run him through.

Tarquin being urprized at the Boldnes of this Fellow, to demand his Pitol, as if he poitively knew him to be the Murtherer, (for o he thought himelf, ince he believed Alcidiana dead) had o much Preence of Mind, as to conider, if he uffered himelf
to be taken, he hould poorly die a publick Death; and therefore reolved upon one Michief more, to ecure himelf from the firt: And in the Moment that the German bad him deliver his Pitol, he cried, Though I have no Pitol to deliver, I have a Sword to chatie thy Inolence. And throwing off his Cloak, and flinging his Pitol from him, he drew, and wounded, and diarmed the Fellow.

This Noie of Swords brought every Body to the Place; and immediately the Bruit ran, The Murtherer was taken, the Murtherer was taken: Though none knew which was he, nor the Caue of the Quarrel between the two fighting Men, which none yet knew; for it now was darker than before. But at the Noie of the Murderer being taken, the Lover of Alcidiana, who by this time found his Lady unhurt, all but the Trains of her Gown, and Petticoat, came running to the place, jut as Tarquin had diarmed the German, and was ready to have kill'd him; when laying hold of his Arm, they arreted the Stroak, and redeemed the Footman.

They then demanded who this Stranger was, at whoe Mercy the Fellow lay; but the Prince, who now found himelf venturing for his lat Stake, made no Reply; but with two Swords in his Hands, went to fight his Way through the Rabble: And tho' there were above a hundred Perons, ome Swords, others with long Whips (as Coach-men) o invincible was the Courage of this poor unfortunate Gentleman at
that time, that all thee were not able to eize him; but he made his Way through the Ring that encompaed him, and ran away; but was, however, o cloely puru'd, the Company till gathering as they ran, that toiled with fighting, oppreed with Guilt, and Fear of being taken, he grew fainter and fainter, and uffered himelf, at lat, to yield to his Puruers, who oon found him to be Prince Tarquin in Diguie: And they carried him directly to Prion, being Sunday, to wait the coming Day, to go before a Magitrate.

In an Hours time the whole fatal Adventure was •• rried all over the City, and every one knew that Prince Tarquin was the intended Murtherer of Alcidiana; and not one but had a real Sorrow and Compaion for him. They heard how bravely he had defended himelf, how many he had wounded before he could be taken, and what Numbers he had fought through: And even thoe that aw his Valour and Bravery, and who had aited at his being eized, now repented from the bottom of their Hearts, their having any Hand in the Ruine of o gallant a Man; epecially, ince they knew the Lady was not hurt. A thouand Addrees were made to her, not to proecute him; but her Lover, a hot-headed Fellow, more fierce than brave, would by no means be pacified; but vowed to purue him to the Scaffold.

The Monday came, and the Prince being examined, confeed the Matter of Fact, ince there was no harm done; believing a generous Confeion the bet of his Game; but he was ent back to cloer Imprionment, loaded with Irons, to expect the next Seions. All his Houhold-Goods were eized, and all they could find, for the Ue of Alcidiana. And the Princes, all in Rage, tearing her Hair, was carried to the ame Prion, to behold the cruel Effects of her hellih Deigns.

One need not tell here how ad and horrid this Metting appeared between her Lord and he, let it uffice it was the mot melancholy and mortifying Object that ever Eyes beheld. On Miranda's part, 'twas ometimes all Rage and Fire, and ometimes all Tears and Groans; but till 'twas ad Love, and mournful Tendernes on his: Nor cou'd all his Sufferings, and the Propect of Death itelf, drive from his Soul one Spark of that Fire the obtinate God had fatally kindl'd there: And in the midt of all his Sighs, he would recal himelf, and cry, —I have Miranda till.

He was eternally viited by his Friends and Acquaintance; and this lat Action of Bravery had got him more, than all his former Conduct had lot. The Fathers were perpetually with him; and all joyn'd with one common Voice in this, That he ought to abandon a Woman o wicked as the Princes; and that however Fate dealt with him, he could not hew himelf a true Penitent,
while he laid the Author of o much Evil in his Boom: That Heaven would never bles him, till he had renounced her: And on uch Conditions, he would find thoe that would employ their utmot Interet to ave his Life; who ele would not tir in his Affair. But he was o deaf to all, that he could not o much as diemble a Repentance for having married her.

He lay a long time in Prion, and all that time the poor Father Francico remained there alo; and the good Fathers, who daily viited thee two amorous Prioners, the Prince and Princes; and who found, by the Management of Matters, it would go very hard with Tarquin, entertained 'em often with holy Matters relating to the Life to come; from which, before his Tryal, he gathered what his Stars had appointed, and that he was detin'd to die.

This gave an unpeakable Torment to the now repenting Beauty, who had reduced him to it; and he began to appear with a more olid Grief, which being perceived by the good Fathers, they reolved to attack her on the yielding Side; and after ome Dicoure upon the Judgment for Sin, they came to reflect on the Buines of Father Francico; and told her, he had never thriv'd ince her Accuing of that Father, and laid it very home to her Concience; auring her, that they would do their utmot in her Service, if he would confes that ecret Sin to all the World; o that he might atone for the Crime, by the aving that
good Man. At firt he eem'd inclin'd to yield; but hame of being her own Detector in o vile a Matter, recall'd her Goodnes, and he faintly perited in it.

At the end of ix Months, Prince Tarquin was call'd to his Tryal; where I will pas over the Circumtances, which are only what is uual in uch Criminal Caes, and tell you, that he, being found guilty of the Intent of killing Alcidiana, was condemn'd to loe his Head in the Market-place, and the Princes to be banih'd her Country.

After Sentence pronounc'd, to the real Grief of all the Spectators, he was carried back to Prion. And now the Fathers attack her a-new: And he, whoe Griefs daily increas'd, with a Languihment that brought her very near her Grave, at lat confes'd all her Life, all the Lewdnes of her Practices with everal Princes and Great Men, beides her Luts with People that erv'd her, and others in mean Capacity: And latly, the whole Truth of the young Friar; and how he had drawn the Page, and the Prince, her Husband, to this deign'd Murther of her Siter. This he ign'd with her Hand, in the Preence of the Prince, her Husband, and everal holy Men who were preent. Which being ignified to the Magitrates, the Friar was immediately deliver'd from his Irons (where he had languih'd more than two whole Years) in great Triumph, with much Honour, and lives a mot exemplary pious Life, as he did before; for he is now living in Antwerp.

After the Condemnation of thee two unfortunate Perons, who begot uch different Sentiments in the Minds of the People, (the Prince, all the Compaion and Pity imaginable; and the Princes all the Contempt and Depight;) they languih'd almot ix Months longer in Prion; o great an Interet there was made, in order to the aving his Life, by all the Men of the Robe. On the other ide, the Princes, and Great Men of all Nations, who were at the Court of Bruxels, who bore a ecret Revenge in their Hearts againt a Man who had, as they pretended, et up a fale Title, only to take place of them; who indeed, was but a Merchant's Son of Holland, as they aid, o incens'd them againt him, that they were too hard at Court for the Churchmen. However, this Dipute gave the Prince his Life ome Months longer than was expected; which gave him alo ome hope, that a Reprieve for Ninety Years would have been granted, as was deir'd. Nay, Father Francico o intereted himelf in this Concern, that he writ to his Father, and everal Princes of Germany, with whom Marques Catiel de Roderigo was well acquainted, to intercede with him for the aving of Tarquin; ince 'twas more by his Perwaions, than thoe of all who attack'd her, that made Miranda confes the Truth of her Affair with him. But at the end of ix Months, when all Application were found fruitles and vain, the Prince receiv'd News, that in two days he was to die, as his Sentence had been before pronounc'd; and for
which he prepar'd himelf with all Chearfulnes.

On the following Friday, as oon as it was light, all People of any Condition came to take their Leaves of him; and none departed with dry Eyes, or Hearts unconcern'd to the lat Degree: For Tarquin, when he found his Fate inevitable, bore it with a Fortitude that hew'd no igns of Regret; but addres'd himelf to all about him with the ame chearful, modet and great Air, he was wont to do in his modet flourihing Fortune. His Vallet was dreing him all the Morning, o many Interruptions they had by Viiters; and he was all in Mourning, and o were all his Followers; for even to the lat he kept up his Grandeur, to the Amazement of all People: And indeed, he was o paionately belov'd by them, that thoe he had dimis'd, erv'd him voluntarily, and would not be perwaded to abandon him while he liv'd.

The Princes was alo dres'd in Mourning, and her two Women; and notwithtanding the unheard of Leudnes and Villanies he had confes'd of herelf, the Prince till ador'd her; for he had till thoe Charms that made him firt do o: Nor, to his lat Moment, could be brought to wih, that he had never een her; but on the contrary, as a Man yet vainly proud of his Fetters, he aid, All the Satisfaction this hort Moment of Life could afford him, was, that he died in endeavouring to erve Miranda, his adorable Princes.

After he had taken Leave of all who thought it neceary to leave him to himelf for ome time, he retir'd with his Confeor; where they were about an Hour in Prayer, all the Ceremonies of Devotions that were fit to be done, being already pat. At lat the Bell toll'd, and he was to take leave of the Princes, as his lat Work of Life, and the mot hard he had to accomplih. He threw himelf at her Feet, and gazing on her, as he at more dead than alive, o'erwhelm'd with ilent Grief, they both remain'd ome Moments peechles; and then, as if one riing Tide of Tears had upply'd both their Eyes, it burt out in Streams at the ame intant; and when his Sighs gave way, he utter'd a thouand Farewels, o oft, o paionate and moving, that all who were by, were extreamly touch'd with it, and aid, That nothing could be een more deplorable and melancholy. A thouand times they bad Farewel, and till ome tender Look, or Word, would prevent his going: Then embrace, and bid Farewel again. A thouand times he ask'd his Pardon for being the Occaion of that fatal Separation; a thouand times auring him, She would follow him, for he could not live without him. And Heaven knows, when their oft and ad Carees would have an end, had not the Officers, aur'd him, 'twas time to mount the Scaffold. At which Words the Princes fell fainting in the Arms of her Women, and they led Tarquin out of Prion.

When he came to the Market-place, whither he walked on Foot, follow'd by his own Dometicks, and ome bearing a black Velvet Coffin with Silver Hinges; the Heads-man before him, with his fatal Scimiter drawn, his Confeor by his ide, and many Gentlemen, and Church-men, with Father Francico attending him, the People howering Millions of Bleings on him, and beholding, with weeping Eyes, he mounted the Scaffold; which was trew'd with ome Saw-dut, about the place where he was to kneel, to receive the Blood: For they Behead People kneeling, and with the Back-troak of a Scimiter, and not lying on a Block, and with an Ax, as we in England. The Scaffold had a low Rail about it, that every Body might more conveniently ee: This was hung with Black, and all that State that uch a Death could have, was here in mot decent Order.

He did not ay much upon the Scaffold: The Sum of what he aid to his Friends, was, To be kind, and take Care of the poor Penitent, his Wife: To others, recommending his honet and generous Servants, whoe Fidelity was o well known and commended, that they were oon promis'd Preferment. He was ome time in Prayer, and a very hort time peaking to his Confeor; then he turn'd to the Heads-man, and deired him to do his Office well, and gave him twenty Louis d' Ors; and undreing himelf with the help of his Vallet, and Page, he pull'd off his Coat, and had underneath a white Satten Wate-coat: He
took off his Perriwig, and put on a white Satten Cap, with a Holland one done with Poynt under it, which he pull'd over his Eyes, then took a chearful Leave of all, and kneel'd down, and aid, When he lifted up his Hands the Third time, the Heads-man hould do his Office. Which accordingly was done, and the Heads-man gave him his lat Stroak, and the Prince fell on the Scaffold. The People, with one common Voice, as if it had been but one entire one, pray'd for his Soul; and Murmurs of Sighs were heard from the whole Multitude, who crambl'd for ome of the bloody Saw-dut, to keep for his Memory.

The Heads-man going to take up the Head, as the manner is, to hew to the People, he found he had not truck it off, and that the Body tirr'd; with that he tepp'd to an Engine, which they always carry with 'em, to force thoe who may be refractory; thinking, as he aid, to have twited the Head from the Shoulders, conceiving it to hang but by a mall matter of Fleh. Tho' twas an odd Shift of the Fellows, yet 'twas done, and the bet Shift he could uddenly propoe. The Margrave, and another Officer, old Men, were on the Scaffold, with ome of the Prince's Friends, and Servants; who eeing the Heads-man put the Engine about the Neck of the Prince, began to call out, and the People made a great Noie. The Prince, who found himelf yet alive; or rather, who was pat thinking, but had ome Sene of feeling left, when the Heads-man took him up, and et his Back
againt the Rail, and clapp'd the Engine about his Neck, got his two Thumbs between the Rope and his Neck, feeling himelf pres'd there; and truggling between Life and Death, and bending himelf over the Rail backward, while the Heads-man pull'd forward, he threw himelf quite over the Rail, by Chance, and not Deign, and fell upon the Heads and Shoulders of the People, who were crying out with amazing Shouts of Joy. The Heads-man leap'd after him, but the Rabble had like to have pull'd him to pieces: All the City was in an Uproar, but none knew what the Matter was, but thoe who bore the Body of the Prince, whom they found yet living; but how, or by what trange Miracle preerv'd, they knew not, nor did examine; but with one Accord, as if the whole Crowd had been one Body, and had had but one Motion, they bore the Prince on their Heads, about a hundred Yards from the Scaffold, where there is a Monatery of Jeuites; and there they ecur'd him. All this was done, his Beheading, his Falling, and his being ecur'd, almot in a Moments time; the People rejoycing, as at ome extraordinary Victory won. One of the Officers being, as I aid, an old, timerous Man, was o frighten'd at the Accident, the Butle, the Noie, and the Confuion, of which he was wholly ignorant, that he dy'd with Amazement and Fear; and the other was fain to be let Blood.

The Officers of Jutice went to demand the Prioner; but they demanded in vain; they
had now a Right to protect him, and wou'd do o. All his over-joy'd Friends went to ee in what Condition he was, and all of Quality found Admittance: They aw him in Bed, going to be dres'd by the mot skilful Surgeons who yet could <> aure him of Life. They deired no Body hould peak to him, or ask him any Quetions. They found that the Heads-man had truck him too low, and had cut him into the Shoulder-bone. A very great Wound, you may be ure; for the Sword, in uch Executions, carries an extream force: However, o great Care was taken on all ides, and o greatly the Fathers were concern'd for him, that they found an Amendment, and Hopes of a good Effect of their incomparable Charity and Goodnes.

At lat, when he was permitted to peak, the firt News he ask'd was after the Princes. And his Friends were very much afflicted to find, that all his Los of Blood had not quench'd that Flame, nor let out that which made him till love that bad Woman. He was olicited daily to think no more of her: And all her Crimes were laid o open to him, and o hamefully repreented; and on the other ide, his Vertues o admir'd; and which, they aid, would have been eternally celebrated, but for his Folly with this infamous Creature; that at lat, by auring him of all their Aitance, if he abandon'd her; and to renounce him, and deliver him up, if he did not; they wrought o far upon him, as to promie, he would uffer her to go alone into Banihment, and would
not follow her, or live with her any more. But alas! this was but his Gratitude that compell'd this Complaiance, for in his Heart he reolv'd never to abandon her; nor was he able to live, and think of doing it: However, his Reaon aured him, he could not do a Deed more jutifiable, and one that would regain his Fame ooner.

His Friends ask'd him ome Quetions concerning his Ecape; and that ince he was not beheaded, but only wounded, why he did not immediately rie up? But he replied, He was o abolutely prepoeed, that at the third lifting up his Hands, he hould receive the Stroak of Death, that at the ame intant the Sword touch'd him, he had no Sene; nay, not even of Pain, o abolutely dead he was with Imagination; and knew not that he tirr'd, as the Heads-man found he did; nor did he remember any thing, from the lifting up of his Hands, to his Fall; and then awakened, as out of a Dream, or rather a Moment's Sleep, without Dream, he found he liv'd, and wonder'd what was arriv'd to him, or how he came to live; having not, as yet, any Sene of his Wound, tho' o terrible an one.

After this, Alcidiana, who was extreamly afflicted for having been the Proecutor of this Great Man; who, bating this lat Deign againt her, which we knew was the Intigation of her Siter, had oblig'd her with all the Civility imaginable; now ought all Means poible of getting his Pardon, and that of her Siter; tho' of an Hundred thouand Crowns,
which he hould have paid her, he could get but Ten thouand; which was from the Sale of her rich Beds, and ome other Furniture: So that the young Count, who before hould have marry'd her, now went off for want of Fortune; and a young Merchant (perhaps the bet of the two) was the Man to whom he was detin'd.

At lat, by great Interceion, both their Pardons were obtain'd; and the Prince, who would be no more een in a place that had prov'd every way o fatal to him, left Flanders, promiing never to live with the fair Hypocrite more; but e'er he departed, he writ her a Letter, wherein he order'd her, in a little time, to follow him into Holland; and left a Bill of Exchange with one of his truty Servants, whom he had left to wait upon her, for Money for her Accommodations: So that he was now reduced to one Woman, one Page, and this Gentleman. The Prince, in this time of his Imprionment, had everal Bills of great Sums from his Father, who was exceeding rich, and this all the Children he had in the World, and whom he tenderly loved.

As oon as Miranda was come into Holland, he was welcom'd with all imaginable Repect and Endearment by the old Father; who impos'd upon o, as that he knew not he was the fatal Occaion of all thee Diaters to his Son; but rather look'd on her as a Woman, who had brought him an Hundred and fifty thouand Crowns, which his Misfortunes had conum'd. But, above all, he was receiv'd by Tarquin with
a Joy unpeakable; who, after ome time, to redeem his Credit, and gain himelf a new Fame, put himelf into the French Army, where he did Wonders; and after three Campaigns, his Father dying, he return'd home, and retir'd to a Country-Houe; where, with his Princes, he lives as a private Gentleman, in all the Tranquility of a Man of a good Fortune. They ay Miranda has been very penitent for her Life pat, and gives Heaven the Glory for having given her thee Afflictions, that have reclaim'd her, and brought her to as perfect a State of Happines as this troubleome World can afford.
Since I began this Relation, I heard that Prince Tarquin dy'd about Three Quarters of a Year ago.

div.trailer: The End of the Fair JILT.

div.p: AGNES de CASTRO: OR, THE FORCE OF Generous LOVE.
Written in French by a Lady of Quality.
Made Englih by Mrs BEHN.
LONDON: Printed by W. Onley, for S. Bricoe. 1697.

div.head: THE HISTORY OF AGNES de CASTRO.
div.p: THough LOVE, all oft and flattering, promies nothing but Pleaures; yet its Conequences are often ad and fatal: It is not enough to be in Love, to be happy, ince Fortune, who is Capricious, and takes delight to trouble the Repoe of the mot Elevated and Virtuous, has very little repect for paionate and tender Hearts, when he deigns to produce trange Adventures.
Many Examples of pat Ages render this Maxim certain, but the Reign of Dom Alphono the Fourth, King of Portugal, furnihes us with one, the mot extraordinary that Hitory can produce.

He was the Son of that Dom Denice, who was o uccesful in all his Undertakings, that it was aid of him, that he was capable of performing whatever he deign'd: And of Iabella, a Princes of eminent Vertue, who when
he came to inherit a flourihing and tranquil State, he endeavour'd to etablih Peace and Plenty in abundance, in his Kingdom.

And to advance this his Deign, he agreed on a Marriage between his Son Don Pedro, (then about eight Years of Age) and Bianca Daughter of Don Pedro, King of Catile; and whom the young Prince married when he arrived to his ixteenth Year.

Bianca brought nothing to Coimbra but Infirmities, and very few Charms. Don Pedro, who was full of Sweetnes and Generoity, liv'd nevertheles very well with her; but thoe Ditempers of the Princes degenerating into the Palie, he made it her Requet to retire, and at her Interceion, the Pope broke the Marriage, and the melancholy Princes concealed her Languihment in a olitary Retreat: And Don Pedro, for whom they had provided another Match, married Contantia Manuel, Daughter of Dom John Manuel, a Prince of the Blood of Catile, and famous for the Enmity he had to his King.

Contantia was promied to the King of Catile, but that King not keeping his Word, they made no difficulty of betowing her on a young Prince, who was one day to Reign over a Number of fine Provinces. He was but five and twenty Years of Age, and the Man of all Spain that had the bet Fahion and Grace: And with the mot advantagious Qualities of the Body, he poet thoe of the Soul, and hew'd himelf worthy in all things of the Crown that was detin'd for him.

The Princes Contantia had Beauty, Wit, and Generoity, in as a great Meaure as 'twas poible for a Woman to be poet with; her Merit alone ought to have attach'd Don Pedro eternally to her; and certainly he had for her an Eteem, mixt with o great a Repect, as might very well pas for Love with thoe that were not of a nice and curious Obervation; but alas! his real Care was reerv'd for another Beauty.

Contantia brought into the World, the firt Year after her Marriage, a Son, who was call'd Don Louis; but it carce aw the Light, and dy'd almot as oon as born. The Los of this little Prince enibly touch'd her, but the Coldnes he oberv'd in the Prince her Husband, went yet more near her Heart; for he had given herelf abolutely up to her Duty, and had made her Tendernes for him her only Concern: But puiant Glory which ty'd her o entirely to the Interet of the Prince of Portugal, open'd her Eyes upon his Actions, where he oberv'd nothing in his Carees and Civilities that was natural, or could atisfie her delicate Heart.

At firt, he fancy'd herelf deceiv'd, but time having confirm'd her in what he feared, he ighed in ecret; yet had that Conideration for the Prince, as not to let him ee her Diorder; and which nevertheles, he could not conceal from Agnes de Catro, who liv'd with her, rather as a Companion, than a Maid of Honour, and whom her Friendhip made her infinitely ditinguih from the ret.

This maid, o dear to the Princes, very well merited the Preference her Mitres gave her; he was beautiful to exces, wie, dicreet, witty, and had more Tendernes for Contantia than he had for herelf, having quitted her Family, which was illutrious, to give herelf wholly to the Service of the Princes, and to follow her into Portugal. It was into the Boom of this Maid, that the Princes unladed her firt Moans, and the charming Agnes forgot nothing that might give eae to her afflicted Heart.

Nor was Contantia the only Peron who complain'd on Don Pedro; before his Divorce from Bianca, he had expreed ome Care and Tendernes for Elvira Gonzales, Siter to Don Alvaro Gonzales, Favourite to the King of Portugal; and this Amuement in the young Years of the Prince, had made a deep Impreion on Elvira, who flatter'd her Ambition with the Infirmities of Bianca. She aw, with a ecret Rage, Contantia take her place, who was poet with uch Charms, that quite diveted her of all Hopes.

Her Jealouie left her not idle, he examin'd all the Actions of the Prince, and eaily dicover'd the little Regard he had for the Princes; but this brought him not back to her. And it was upon very good Grounds that he upected him to be in Love with ome other Peron, and poeed with a new Paion; and which he promis'd herelf, he would detroy as oon as he could find it out. She had a Spirit altogether proper for bold and hazardous
Enterprizes; and the Credit of her Brother gave her o much Vanity, as all the Indifference of the Prince was not capable of humbling.

The Prince languih'd, and conceal'd the Caue with o much Care, that 'twas impoible for any to find it out. No publick Pleaures were agreeable to him, and all Converations were tedious; and it was Solitude alone that was able to give him any eae.

This Change urprized all the World. The King who lov'd his Son very tenderly, earnetly pres'd him to know the Reaon of his Melancholy; but the Prince made no anwer, but only this, That it was the Effects of his Temper.

But Time ran on, and the Princes was brought to Bed of a econd Son, who liv'd, and was call'd Fernando. Don Pedro forc'd himelf a little to take part in the publick Joy, o that they believ'd his Humour was changing; but this appearance of a Calm endured not long, and he fell back again into his black Melancholy.

The Artful Elvira was inceantly agitated in earching out the Knowledge of this Secret. Chance wrought for her: And, as he was walking full of Indignation and Anger, in the Garden of the Palace of Coimbra, he found the Prince of Portugal leeping in an obcure Grotto.

Her Fury could not contain itelf at the Sight of this lov'd Object, he roul'd her Eyes upon him, and perceiv'd in pight of Sleep,
that ome Tears ecap'd his Eyes; the Flame which burnt yet in her Heart, oon grew oft and tender there: But oh! he heard him igh, and after that, utter thee Words; Yes, Divine Agnes, I will ooner die, than let you know it: Contantia hall have nothing to reproach me with. Elvira was enrag'd at this Dicoure, which repreented to her immediately, the ame Moment, Agnes de Catro with all her Charms; and not at all doubting, but it was he who poet the Heart of Don Pedro, he found in her Soul more Hatred for this fair Rival, than Tendernes for him.

The Grotto was not a Place it to make Reflections in, or to form Deigns. Perhaps her firt Tranports would have made her waken'd him, if he had not perceiv'd a Paper lying under his Hand, which he oftly eiz'd on; and that he might not be urpriz'd in the reading it, he went out of the Garden with as much Hate as Confuion.
When he was retir'd to her Apartment, he open'd the Paper, trembling, and found in it thee Veres, writ by the Hand of Don Pedro; and which in appearance, he had newly then compoed.

lg.l: In vain, oh! Sacred Honour, you debate
The mighty Buines in my Heart:
Love! Charming Love! rules all my Fate,
Interest and Glory claim no part.
The God, ure of his Victory, Triumphs there,
And will have nothing in his Empire hare.
In vain, oh! Sacred Duty, you oppoe;
In vain, your Nuptial Tye you plead:
Thoe forc'd Devoirs LOVE overthrows,
And breaks the Vows he never made.
Fixing his fatal Arrows every where,
I burn, and languih, in a oft Depair.
Fair Princes, you to whom my Faith is due;
Pardon the Detiny that drags me on;
'Tis not my Fault, my Heart's untrue,
I am compell'd to be undone:
My Life is yours, I gave it with my Hand,
But my Fidelity I can't command.

div.p: Elvira did not only know the Writing of Don Pedro, but he knew alo that he could write Veres. And eeing the ad Part which Contantia had in thee which were now fallen into her Hands, he made no cruple of reolving to let the Princes ee 'em: But that he might not be upected, he took care not to appear in the Buines herelf; and ince it was not enough for Contantia to know that the Prince did not love her, but that he mut know alo he was a Slave to Agnes de Catro; Elvira caued thee few Veres to be written in an unknown Hand, under thoe writ by the Prince.

lg.l: Sleep betray'd, the unhappy Lover;
While Tears were treaming from his Eyes,
His heedles Tongue without diguie,
The Secret did dicover.
The Language of his Heart declare,
That Agnes Image Triumphs there.

div.p: Elvira regarded neither Exactnes nor Grace in thee Lines, and if they had but the Effect he deign'd, he wih'd no more.

Her Impatience could not wait till the next Day to expoe 'em; he therefore went immediately to the Lodgings of the Princes, who was then walking in the Garden of the Palace; and paing without reitance, even to her Cabinet, he put the Paper into a Book, in which the Princes us'd to read, and went out again uneen, and atisfied with her good Fortune.

As oon as Contantia was return'd, he enter'd into her Cabinet, and aw the Book open, and the Veres lying in it, which were to cot her o dear: She oon knew the Hand of the Prince which was o familiar to her, and beides the Information of what he had always fear'd, he undertood it was Agnes de Catro, (whoe Friendhip alone was able to comfort her in her Misfortunes) who was the fatal Caue of it; he read over the Paper an hundred times, deiring to give her Eyes and Reaon the Lye; but finding but too plainly he was not deceiv'd, he found her Soul poet with more Grief than Anger: When he conider'd as much in Love as the Prince was, he had kept his Torment ecret. After having made her Moan, without condemning him, the Tendernes he had for him, made her hed a Torrent of Tears, and inpir'd her
with a Reolution of concealing her Reentment.

She would certainly have done it by a Vertue extraordinary, if the Prince, who miing his Veres when he wak'd, and fearing they might fall into indicreet Hands, had not enter'd the Palace, all troubl'd with his Los, and hatily going into Contantia's Apartment, aw her fair Eyes all wet with Tears, and at the ame intant cat his own on the unhappy Veres that had ecap'd from his Soul, and now lay before the Princes.

He immediately turn'd pale at this ight, and appear'd o mov'd, that the generous Princes felt more Pain than he did: Madam, aid he, (infinitely alarm'd) from whom had you that Paper? It cannot come but from the Hand of ome Peron, anwer'd Contantia, who is an Enemy both to your Repoe and mine; it is the Work, Sir, of your own Hand; and doubtles, the Sentiment of your Heart: But be not urpriz'd, and do not fear, for if my Tendernes hould make it pas for a Crime in you, the ame Tendernes, which nothing is able to alter, hall hinder me from complaining.

The Moderation and Calmnes of Contantia, erv'd only to render the Prince more aham'd and confus'd. How Generous are you, madam, puru'd he, and how Vnfortunate am I. Some Tears accompanied his Words, and the Princes, who lov'd him with extream Ardor, was o enibly touch'd, that it was a good while before he could utter a Word: Contantia then broke Silence, and hewing him
what Elvira had caus'd to be written; You are betray'd, Sir, added he, you have been heard peak, and your Secret is known. It was at this very moment that all the Forces of the Prince abandon'd him; and his Condition was really worthy Compaion: He could not pardon himelf the unvoluntary Crime he had committed, in expoing of the lovely, and the innocent Agnes. And tho' he was convinc'd of the Vertue and Goodnes of Contantia, the Apprehenions that he had, that this modet and prudent Maid might uffer by his Conduct, carried him beyond all Conideration.

The Princes, who heedfully urveyed him, aw o many Marks of Depair in his Face and Eyes, that he was afraid of the Conequences; and holding out her Hand, in a very obliging manner to him; he aid, I promie you, Sir, I will never more complain on you; and that Agnes hall always be very dear to me; you hall never hear me make you any Reproaches: And ince I cannot poes your Heart, I will content my elf with endeavouring to render myelf worthy of it. Don Pedro more confus'd and dejected than before he had been, bent one of his Knees at the Feet of Contantia, and with repect kis'd that fair kind Hand he had given him, and perhaps forgot Agnes for a Moment.

But Love oon put a top to all the little Advances of Hymen, the fatal Star that preided over the Detiny of Don Pedro, had not yet vented its Malignity; and one Moment's ight of Agnes gave new Forces to his Paion.
The Wih and Deires of this charming Maid had no part in this Victory; her Eyes were jut, tho' penetrating, and they earched not in thoe of the Prince, what they had a deire to dicover to her.

As he was never far from Contantia, Don Pedro was no ooner gone out of the Cloet, but Agnes entred; and finding the Princes all pale and languihing in her Chair, he doubted not but there was ome ufficient Caue for her Affliction; he put herelf in the ame Poture the Prince had been in before, and expreing an Inquietude, full of Concern; Madam, aid he, by all your Goodnes, conceal not from me the Caue of your Trouble. Alas, Agnes, reply'd the the Princes, what would you know? And what hould I tell you? The Prince, the Prince, my dearest Maid, is in Love; the Hand that he gave me, was not a Preent of his Heart; and for the Advantage of this Alliance, I must become the Victim of it.—What! the Prince in Love, replied Agnes, (with an Atonihment mixt with Indignation) What Beauty can dipute the Empire over a Heart o much your due? Alas, Madam, all the Repect I owe him, cannot hinder me from murmuring against him. Accue him of nothing, interrupted Contantia, he does what he can; and I am more obliged to him for deiring to be Faithful, than if I poest his real Tendernes. It is not enough to Fight, but to Overcome; and the Prince does more in the Condition wherein he is, than I ought reaonably to hope for: In fine, he is my Husband, and an agreeable one; to whom nothing is wanting, but what I cannot inpire; that is, a Paion which would
have made me but too happy. Ah, Madam, cry'd out Agnes, tranported with her Tendernes for the Princes, he is a blind and tupid Prince, who knows not the precious Advantages he poees. He must urely know omething, reply'd the Princes, modetly. But, Madam, reply'd Agnes, Is there any thing, not only in Portugal, but in all Spain, that can compare with you? And, without conidering the charming Qualities of your Peron, can we enough admire thoe of your Soul? My dear Agnes, interrupted Contantia, ighing, he who robs me of my Husband's Heart, has but too many Charms to plead his Excue; ince it is Thou, Child, whom Fortune makes ue of, to give me the Killing Blow. Yes, Agnes, the Prince loves thee; and the Merit I know thou art poest of, puts Bounds to my Complaints, without uffering me to have the least Reentment.

The delicate Agnes little expected to hear what the Princes told her; Thunder would have les urprized, and les oppres'd her: She remained a long time without peaking, but at lat fixing her Looks all frightful on Contantia, What ay you, Madam? (cry'd he) And what Thoughts have you of me? What, that I hould betray you? And coming hither only full of Ardor to be the Repoe of your Life, do I bring a fatal Poyon to afflict it? What Detetation must I have for the Beauty they find in me, without apiring to make it appear? And how ought I to cure the unfortunate Day, in which I first aw the Prince?—But, Madam, it cannot be me, whom Heaven has choen to torment you, and to detroy all your Tranquility: No, it cannot be o much my Enemy, to put me
to o great a Tryal: And if I were that odious Peron, there is no Excue, or Punihment, to which I would not condemn myelf: It is Elvira, Madam, the Prince loves, and lov'd before his Marriage with you, and alo before his Divorce from Bianca; and ome Body has made an indicreet Report to you of this Intrigue of his Youth: But, Madam, what was in the time of Bianca, is nothing to you. It is certain that Don Pedro loves you, anwer'd the Princes; and I have Vanity enough to believe, that none beides yourelf could have diputed his Heart with me: But the Secret is dicover'd, and Don Pedro has not diown'd it. What, interrupted Ag • es, (more urprized than ever) is it then from himelf you have learn'd his Weaknes? The Princes then hew'd her the Veres; and there was never any Depair like to hers.

While they were both thus adly employed, both Sighing, and both Weeping, the impatient Elvira, who was willing to learn the Effect of her Malice, return'd to the Apartment of the Princes, where he freely entred, even to the Cabinet where thee unhappy Perons were; whom all afflicted and troubled as they were, bluh'd at her approach, whoe Company they did not deire: She had the pleaure to ee Contantia hide from her the Paper which had been the Caue of all their Trouble, and which the Princes had never een, but for her Spight and Revenge; and to oberve alo, in the Eyes of the Princes, and thoe of Agnes, an immoderate Grief: She tay'd in the Cabinet as long as it was neceary to be aur'd, that he had ucceeded in her Deign; but the
Princes, who did not deire uch a Witnes of the Diorder, in which he then was, deir'd to be left alone. Elvira then went out of the Cabinet, and Agnes de Catro withdrew at the ame time.

It was in her own Chamber, that Agnes examining more freely this Adventure, found it as cruel as Death: She lov'd Contantia incerely, and had not 'till then any thing more than an Eteem, mixt with Admiration, for the Prince of Portugal; which, indeed, none could refue to o many fine Qualities. And looking on herelf as the mot unfortunate of her Sex, as being the Caue of all the Suffering of the Princes, to whom he was obliged for the greatet Bounties, he pent the whole Night in Tears and Complaints, ufficient to have revenged Contantia of all the Griefs he made her uffer.

The Prince, on his ide, was in no greater Tranquility; the Generoity of his Princes increas'd his Remore, without diminihing his Love; he fear'd, and with Reaon, that thoe who were the occaion of Contantia's eeing thoe Veres, hould dicover his Paion to the King, from whom he hop'd for no Indulgence, and he would mot willingly have given his Life to have been free from this Extremity.

In the mean time the afflicted Princes languih'd in a mot deplorable Sadnes; he found nothing in thoe who were the Caue of her Misfortunes, but things fitter to move her Tendernes than her Anger; it was in vain that
Jealouie trove to combat the Inclination he had to love her fair Rival; nor was any occaion of making the Prince les dear to her; and he felt neither Hatred, nor o much as Indifference for innocent Agnes.

While thee three diconolate Perons abandon'd themelves to their Melancholy, Elvira, not to leave her Vengeance imperfect, tudy'd in what manner he might bring it to the Height of its Effects. Her Brother, on whom he depended, hew'd her a great deal of Friendhip; and judging rightly that the Love of Don Pedro, to Agnes de Catro, would not be approv'd by the King, he acquainted Don Alvaro, her Brother, with it, who was not ignorant of the Paion the Prince had once proteted to have for his Siter. He found himelf very much intereted in this News, from a ecret Paion he had for Agnes; whom the Buines of his Fortune had hitherto hindred him from dicovering: And he expected a great many Favours from the King, that might render the Effort of his Heart the more coniderable.
He hid not from his Siter this one thing, which he found difficult to conceal; o that he was now poet with a double Grief, to find Agnes Sovereign of all the Hearts, to which he had a pretenion.

Don Alvaro was one of thoe ambitious Men, that are Fierce without Moderation, and Proud without Generoity; of a melancholy, cloudy Humour; of a cruel Inclination, and to effect his Ends, found nothing difficult, or unlawful.
Naturally he lov'd not the Prince, who, on all Accounts ought to have held the firt Rank in the Heart of the King, which hould have et Bounds to the Favour of Don Alvaro; who when he knew the Prince was his Rival, his Jealouie increas'd his Hate of him; and he conjured Elvira to employ all her Care, to oppoe an Engagement that could not but be detructive to 'em both; he promied him, and he not very well atisfied, rely'd on her Addres.

Don Alvaro, who had too lively a Repreentation within himelf, of the Beauties and Grace of the Prince of Portugal, thought of nothing but how to combate his Merits, he himelf being not handome, or well made: His Fahion was as diagreeable as his Humour, and Don Pedro had all the Advantages that one Man may poibly have over another. In fine, all that Don Alvaro wanted, adorn'd the Prince: But as he was the Husband of Contantia, and depended upon an abolute Father, and that Don Alvaro was free, and Mater of a good Fortune, he thought himelf more aur'd of Agnes, and fix'd his Hopes on that Thought.

He knew very well, that the Paion of Don Pedro, could not but inpire a violent Anger in the Soul of the King. Indutrious in doing Ill, his firt Buines was to carry this unwelcome News to him. After he had given time to his Grief, and had compos'd himelf to his Deire, he then beought the King to Interet himelf in his amorous Affair, and to be the Protector of his Peron.

Though Don Alvaro, had no other Merit to recommend him to the King, than a continual and blind Obedience to all his Commands; yet he had favour'd him with everal Tetimonies of his vat Bounty; and conidering the height to which the King's Liberality had rais'd him, there were few Ladies that would have refus'd his Alliance. The King aur'd him of the Continuation of his Friendhip and Favour, and promis'd him, if he had any Authority, he would give him the charming Agnes.

Don Alvaro, perfectly skilful in managing his Mater, anwer'd the King's lat Bounties with a profound Submiion. He had yet never told Agnes what he felt for her; but he thought now he might make a publick Declaration of it, and and ought all means to do it.

The Gallantry which Coimbra eem'd to have forgotten, began now to be awaken'd. The King, to pleae Don Alvaro, under pretence of diverting Contantia, order'd ome Publick Sports, and commanded that every thing hould be magnificent.

Since the Adventure of the Veres, Don Pedro endeavour'd to lay a Contraint on himelf, and to appear les troubled: But in his Heart he uffer'd always alike; and it was not but with great Uneaines he prepar'd himelf for the Turnament. And ince he could not appear with the Colours of Agnes, he took thoe of his Wife, without Device, or any great Magnificence.
Don Alvaro adorn'd himelf with the Liv'ries of Agnes de Catro; and this fair Maid, who had yet found no Conolation from what the Princes had told her, had this new Caue of being dipleas'd.

Don Pedro appear'd in the Lit with an admirable Grace; and Don Alvaro, who look'd on this Day as his own, appear'd there all hining with Gold, mix'd with Stones of Blew, which were the Colours of Agnes; and there was embroider'd all over his Equipage, flaming Hearts of Gold, on blew Velvet, and Nets for the Snares of Love, with abundance of double A's; his Device was a Love coming out of a Cloud, with thee Veres written underneath.

lg.l: Love from a Cloud breaks like the God of Day,
And to the World his Glories does diplay;
To gaze on charming Eyes, and make 'em know,
What to oft Hearts, and to his Power they owe.

div.p:
The Pride of Don Alvaro was oon humbled at the Feet of the Prince of Portugal, who threw him againt the Ground, with twenty others, and carry'd alone the Glory of the Day. There was in the Evening a Noble Aembly at Contantia's, where Agnes would not have been, unles exprely commanded by the Princes. She appear'd there all negligent and careles in her Dres, but yet he appear'd all beautiful and charming. She aw, with didain, her Name, and her Colours, worn by Don Alvaro, at a Publick Triumph; and if
her Heart were capable of any tender Motions, it was not for uch a Man as he, for whom her Delicacy detin'd them: She lookd on him with a Contempt, which did not hinder him from preing o near, that there was a neceity for her to hear, and what he had to declare to her.

She treated him not uncivily, but her Coldnes would have rebated the Courage of any but Alvaro. Madam, aid he, (when he could be heard of none but herelf) I have hitherto concealed the Paion you have inpir'd me with, fearing it hould dipleae you; but it has committed a Violence on my Repect; and I could no longer conceal it from you. I never reflected on your Actions, anwer'd Agnes, with all the Indifference of which he was capable, and if you think you offend me, you are in the wrong to make me perceive it. This Coldnes is but an ill Omen for me, reply'd Don Alvaro, and if you have not found me out to be your Lover to Day, I fear you will never approve my Paion.

Oh! what a time you have choen to make it appear to me (puru'd Agnes) is it o great an Honour for me, that you must take uch Care to hew it to the World And do you think that I am o deirous of Glory, that I must apire to it by your Actions? If I must, you have very ill maintain'd it in the Turnament; and if it be that Vanity that you depend upon, you'll make no great Progres on a Soul that is not fond of Shame. If you were poest of all the Advantages, which the Prince has this Day carried away, you yet ought to conider what you are going about; and it is not a Maid
like me, who is touch'd with Enterprizes, without repect or permiion.

The Favourite of the King, was too proud to hear Agnes, without Indignation: But as he was willing to conceal it, and not offend her, he made not his Reentment appear; and conidering the Obervation he made on the Triumphs of Don Pedro, (which encreaed his Jealouies:) If I have not overcome at the Turnament, reply'd he, I am not the les in Love for being vanquih'd, nor les capable of ucces on occaions.

They were interrupted here, but from that Day, Don Alvaro, who had open'd the firt Difficulties, kept no more his wonted Ditance, but perpetually perecuted Agnes; yet tho' he were protected by the King, that inpir'd in her never the more Conideration for him. Don Pedro was always ignorant by what Means the Veres he had lot in the Garden, fell into the Hands of Contantia: As the Princes appeared to him Indulgent, he was only concerned for Agnes; and the Love of Don Alvaro, which was then o well known, increas'd the Pain; and had he been poet of the Authority, he would not have uffer'd her to have been expos'd to the Perecutions of o unworthy a Rival. He was alo afraid of the King's being advertied of his Paion, but he thought not at all of Elvira's, nor apprehended any Malice from her Reentment.

While he burnt with a Deire of detroying Agnes, againt whom he vented all her Venom; and he was never weary of making new Reports to her Brother, auring him, that tho' they could not prove, that Agnes made any returns to the Tendernes of the Prince; yet that was the Caue of Contantia's Grief. And, that if this Princes hould die of it, Don Pedro might marry Agnes. In fine, he o incens'd the jealous Don Alvaro's Jealouie, that he could not hinder himelf from running immediately to the King, with the Dicovery of all he knew, and all he guet, and whom he had the Pleaure to find, was infinitely inrag'd at the News. My dear Alvaro, aid the King, you hall intantly marry this dangerous Beauty: And let Poeion; aure your Repoe and mine. If I have protected you in other Occaions, judge what a Service of o great an Importance for me, would make me undertake; and without any reerve, the Forces of this State are in your Power, and almot any thing that I can give, hall be aured you, o you render your elf Mater of the Detiny of Agnes.

Don Alvaro pleas'd, and vain with his Mater's Bounty, made ue of all the Authority he gave him: He paionately lov'd Agnes, and would not, on the udden, make ue of Violence; but reolv'd with himelf to employ all poible Means to win her fairly; but if that fail'd, to have recoure to force, if he continued always inenible.

While Agnes de Catro (importun'd by his Aiduities, depairing at the Grief of Contantia, and perhaps made tender by thoe he had caus'd in the Prince of Portugal) took a Reolution worthy of her Vertue; yet, amiable as Don Pedro was, he found nothing in him, but his being Husband to Contantia, that was dear to her: And far from encouraging the Power he had got over his Heart, he thought of nothing but removing from Coimbra; the Paion of Don Alvaro, which he had no inclination to favour, erv'd her as a Pretext, and pres'd with the fear of cauing, in the End, a cruel Divorce between the Prince and his Princes, he went to find Contantia, with a Trouble, which all her Care was not able to hide from her.

The Princes eaily found it out; and their common Misfortune having not chang'd their Friendhip:—What ails you, Agnes? aid the Princes to her, in a oft Tone, and her ordinary Sweetnes; And what new Misfortune caues that Sadnes in thy Looks? Madam, reply'd Agnes, hedding a Rivulet of Tears, the Obligations and Tyes I have to you, put me upon a cruel Tryal; I had bounded the Felicity of my Life in hope of paing it near your Highnes; yet I must carry, to ome other part of the World, this unlucky Face of mine, which renders me nothing but ill Offices: And itis to obtain that Liberty, that I am come to throw myelf at your Feet; looking upon you as my Sovereign.

Contantia was o urpriz'd and touch'd with the Propoition of Agnes, that he lot her Speech for ome Moments; Tears, which were incere, expres'd her firt Sentiments: And after having hed abundance, to give a new Mark of her Tendernes to the Fair afflicted Agnes, he with a ad and melancholy Look, fix'd her Eyes upon her, and holding out her Hand to her, in a mot obliging manner, ighing; cry'd,—You will then, my dear Agnes, leave me? and expoe me to the Griefs of eeing you no more? Alas, Madam, interrupted this lovely Maid, hide from the unhappy Agnes a Bounty, which does but increae her Misfortunes. It is not I, Madam, that would leave you, it is my Duty, and my Reaon that orders my Fate. And thoe Days which I hall pas far from you, promie me nothing to oblige me to this Deign, if I did not ee myelf abolutely forc'd to it: I am not ignorant of what paes at Coimbra; and I hall be an Accomplice of the Injutice there committed, if I hould tay there any longer.—Ah, I I know your Vertue, cry'd Contantia, and you may remain here, in all afety, while I am your Protectres; and let what will happen, I will accue you of nothing. There's no anwering for what's to come, reply'd Agnes, adly; and I hall be ufficiently Guilty, if my Preence caue Sentiments, which cannot be innocent. Beide, Madam, the Importunities of Don Alvaro are inupportable to me; and though I find nothing but Averion for him, ince the King protects his Inolence, and he's in a Condition of undertaking any thing, my Flight is abolutely neceary: But, Madam, though he
has nothing but what eems odious to me; I ca •
Heaven to witnes, that if I could cure the Prince by marrying Don Alvaro, I would not conider of it a Moment; and finding in my Punihment the Conolation of acrificing my elf to my Princes, I would upport it without murmuring. But if I were the Wife of Don Alvaro, Don Pedro would always look upon me with the ame Eyes: So that I find nothing more reaonable for me, than to hide myelf in ome Corner of the World; where, though I hall mot certainly live without Pleaure, yet I hall preerve the Repoe of my dearest Mitres. All the Reaon you find in this Deign, anwered the Princes, cannot oblige me to approve of your Abence: Will it retore me the Heart of Don Pedro? And will he not fly away with you? his Grief is mine, and my Life is ty'd to his; do not make him depair then, if you love me. I know ye, I tell you o once more; and let your Power be never o great over the Heart of the Prince, I will not uffer you to abandon us.

Though Agnes thought he had perfectly known Contantia, yet he did not expect to find o intire a Vertue in her, which made her think herelf more happy, and the Prince more criminal. Oh, Widom! Oh, Bounty without Example! (cry'd he) Why is it, that the cruel Detinies do not give you all you deerve? You are the Dipoer of my Actions, continu'd he (in kiing the Hand of Contantia) I'll do nothing but what you'll have me: But conider, weigh well the Reaons that ought to counel you in the Meaures you oblige me to take.

Don Pedro, who had not een the Princes all that Day, came in then, and finding 'em both extreamly troubled; with a fierce Impatience, demanded the Caue: Sir, anwered Contantia, Agnes too wie, and too crupulous, fears the Effects of her Beauty, and will live no longer at Coimbra; and it was on this Subject, (which cannot be agreeable to me) that he ask'd my Advice. The Prince grew pale at this Dicoure, and natching the Words from her Mouth (with more concern, than poet either of them) cry'd with a Voice very feeble, Agnes cannot fail, if he follow your Councel Madam; and I leave you full liberty to give it her. He then immediately went out, and the Princes, whoe Heart he perfectly poet, not being able to hide her Dipleaure, aid, My dear Agnes, if my Satisfaction did not only depend on your Converation, I hould deire it of you, for Don Pedro's sake; it is the only Advantage that his unfortunate Love can hope: And would not the World have reaon to call me Barbarous, if I contributed to deprive him of that? But the ight of me will prove a Poyon to him,—reply'd Agnes, And what hould I do, my Princes, if after the Reerve he has hitherto kept, his Mouth hould add any thing to the Torments I have already felt, by peaking to me of his Flame? You would hear him ure, without cauing him to depair, reply'd Contantia; and I hould put this Obligation to the Account of the rest you have done. Would you then have me expect thoe Events which I fear, Madam? reply'd Agnes; Well—I will obey, but just Heavens, purued he, if they prove fatal, do not punih an innocent
Heart for it. Thus this Converation ended
Agnes withdrew into her Chamber, but it was not to be more at eae.

What Don Pedro had learn'd of the Deign of Agnes, caus'd a cruel Agitation in his Soul; he wih'd he had never lov'd her, and deir'd a thouand times to die: But it was not for him to make Vows againt a thing which Fate had deign'd him; and whatever Reolutions he made, to bear the Abence of Agnes, his Tendernes had not force enough to conent to it.

After having, for a long time, combated with himelf, he determin'd to do, what was impoible for him, to let Agnes do. His Courage reproach'd him with the Idlenes, in which he pat the mot Youthful and Vigorous of his Days; and making it appear to the King, that his Allies, and even the Prince Don John Emanuel, his Father-in-Law, had Concerns in the World, which demanded his Preence on the Frontiers; he eaily obtain'd Liberty to make this Journey, to which the Princes would put no Obtacle.

p.U: aw him part without any Concern, but it was not upon the Account of any Averion he had for him. Don Alvaro began then to make his Importunity, an open Perecution; he forgot nothing that might touch the inenible Agnes, and made ue, a long time, only of the Arms of Love: But eeing that this Submiions and Repect was to no purpoe, he form'd trange Deigns.

div.p: As the King had a Deference for all his Counels, it was not difficult to inpire him with what he had a Mind to: He complain'd of the ungrateful Agnes, and forgot nothing that might make him perceive that he was not cruel to him, on his Account; but from the too much Senibility he had for the Prince. The King, who was extream angry at this, reiterated all the Promies he had made him.

The King had not yet poke to Agnes, in favour of Don Alvaro; and not doubting but his Approbation would urmount all Obtacles, he took an occaion to entertain her with it: And removing ome ditance from thoe who might hear him, I thought Don Alvaro had Merit enough, aid he to her, to have obtain'd a little hare in your Eteem; and I could not imagine, there would have been any neceity of my olliciting it for him: I know you are very charming, but he has nothing that renders him unworthy of you; and when you hall reflect on the Choice my Friendhip has made of him, from among all the Great Men of my Court, you will do him, at the ame time, Jutice. His Fortune is none of the meanest, ince he has me for his Protector: He is nobly born, a Man of Honour and Courage; he adores you, and it eems to me, that all thee Reaons are ufficient to vanquih your Pride.

The Heart of Agnes was o little dipoed to give itelf to Don Alvaro, that all that the King of Portugal had aid, had no Effect on her, in his favour. If Don Alvaro, Sir, anwered he, were without Merit, he poest Advantages enough in the Bounty your Majety is pleaed to Honour him
with, to make him Mater of all things,; it is not that I find any Defect in him, that I anwer not his Deires: But, Sir, by what obtinate Power, would you that I hould Love, if Heaven has not given me a Soul that is tender? And why hould you pretend that I hould ubmit to him, when nothing is dearer to me than my Liberty? You are not o free, nor o inenile, as you ay, (anwered the King, bluhing, with Anger;) and if your Heart were exempt from all orts of Affection, he might expect a more reaonable Return than what he finds. But imprudent Maid, conducted by an ill Fate, added he, in Fury, what Pretenions have you to Don Pedro? Hitherto, I have hid the Chagreen, which his Weaknes, and yours gave me; but it was not the les violent for being hid: And ince you oblige me to break out, I must tell you, that if my Son were not already married to Contantia, he hould never be your Husband; renounce then thoe vain Ideas, which will cure him, and jutifie you.

The couragious Agnes was carce Mitres of the firt Tranports, at a Dicoure o full of Contempt; but calling her Vertue to the aid of her Anger, he recover'd herelf by the aitance of Reaon: And conidering the Outrage he receiv'd, not as coming from a Great King, but a Man blinded and poet by Don Alvaro, he thought him not worthy of her Reentment; her fair Eyes animated themelves with o hining a vivacity, they anwered for the purity of her Sentiments; and fixing them tedfatly on the King. If the Prince, Don Pedro have Weaknees, (reply'd he, with an Air didainful) he never communicated 'em to me;
and I am certain, I never contributed wilfully to 'em: But to let you ee how little I regard your Defiance, and to put my Glory in afety, I will live far from you, and all that belongs to you: Yes, Sir, I will quit Coimbra with pleaure; and for this Man, who is o dear to you, (anwer'd he with a noble Pride and Fiercenes, of which the King felt all the Force) for this Favourite, o worthy to poes the most tender affections of a great Prince, I aure you, that into whatever part of the World Fortune conducts me, I will not carry away the least Remembrance of him. At thee words he made a profound Reverence, and made uch hate from his Preence, that he could not oppoe her going if he would.

The King was now more trongly convinc'd than ever, that he favoured the Paion of Don Pedro, and immediately went to Contantia, to inpire her with the ame thought; but he was not capable of receiving uch Impreions, and following her own natural Inclinations, he generouly defended the Virtue of Actions. The King angry to ee her o well intentioned to her Rival, whom he would have had her hated, reproached her with the weetnes of her Temper, and went thence to mix his Anger with Don Alvaro's Rage, who was totally confounded when he aw the Negotiation of his Mater had taken no effect. The haughty Maid braves me then, Sir, aid he to the King, and depies the Honour which your Bounty offered her! Why cannot I reit o fatal a Paion? But I mut love her, in pight of my elf; and if this Flame conume me, I can find
no way to extinguih it; what can I farther do for you, replied the King? Alas, Sir, anwer'd Don Alvaro, I mut do by force, what I cannot otherwie hope from the Proud and Cruel Agnes. Well then, added the King, ince it is not fit for me to Authorize publickly a Violence in the midt of my Kingdom, chue thoe of my Subjects which you think mot capable of erving you, and take away by force the Beauty that charms you, and if he do not yield to your Love, put that Power you are Mater of in execution, to oblige her to marry you.

Don Alvaro, ravih'd with this Propoition, which at the ame time flatter'd both his Love and Anger, cat himelf at the feet of the King, and renew'd his Acknowledgments by freh Protetations, and thought of nothing but employing his unjut Authority againt Agnes.

Don Pedro had been about three months abent, when Alvaro undertook what the King counell'd him to; tho' the Moderation was known to him, yet he feared his Preence, and would not attend the Return of a Rival, with whom he would avoid all Diputes.

One Night, when the ad Agnes, full of her ordinary Inquietudes, in vain expected the God of Sleep, he heard a noie, and after aw ome Men unknown enter her Chamber, whoe Meaures being well conulted, they carried her out of the Palace, and putting her in a cloe Coach, forc'd her out of Coimbra, without being hinder'd by any Obtacle. She knew not of whom to complain, nor whom to upect;
Don Alvaro eem'd too puiant to eek his atisfaction this way; and he accus'd not the Prince of this Attempt, of whom he had o favourable an Opinion; whatever he could think or ay, he could not hinder her ill Fortune: They hurried her on with diligence, and before it was Day, were a coniderable way off from the Town.

As oon as Day began to break, he urveyed thoe that encompaed her, without o much as knowing one of them; and eeing that her Cries and Prayers were all in vain with thee deaf Ravihers, he atisfied herelf with imploring the Protection of Heaven, and abandon'd herelf to its Conduct.

While he ate thus overwhelmed with grief, uncertain of her Detiny, he aw a Body of Hore advance towards the Troop which conducted her; the Ravihers did not hun them, thinking it to be Don Alvaro; but when he approached more near, they found it was the Prince of Portugal, who was at the Head of 'em, and who, without foreeeing the occaion that would offer itelf of erving Agnes, was returning to Coimbra full of her Idea, after having performed what he ought in this Expedition.

Agnes, who did not expect him, changed now her Opinion, and thought that it was the Prince that had caued her to be tolen away. Oh, Sir, aid he to him, having till the ame Thought, Is it you that have torn me from the Princes? and could o cruel a Blow come from a Hand that is o dear to her, what will you
do with an nfortunate Creature, who deires nothing but Death? and why will you obcure the Glory of your Life, by an Artifice unworthy of you? This Language atonih'd the Prince no les than the Sight of Agnes had done; he found by what he had aid, that he was taken away by force; and immediately paing to the height of Rage, he made her undertand by one only Look, that he was not the bae Author of her Trouble. I tear you from Contantia, whoe only Pleaure you are, replied he: What Opinion have you of Don Pedro? No, Madam, though you ee me here, I am altogether innocent of the Violence that has been done you; and there is nothing I will refue to hinder it. He then turned himelf to behold the Ravihers, but his Preence had already cattered 'em: he ordered ome of his Men to purue 'em, and to eize ome of 'em, that he might know what Authority it was that et 'em at work.

During this, Agnes was no les confus'd than before; he admir'd the Conduct of her Detiny, that brought the Prince at a time when he was o neceary to her: Her Inclinations to do him Jutice, oon repair'd the Offence her Supicions had caus'd; he was glad to have ecap'd a Misfortune, which appear'd certain to her; but this was not a incere Joy, when he conider'd that her Lover was her Deliverer, and a Lover worthy of all her Acknowledgments, but who ow'd his Heart to the mot amiable Princes in the World.

While the Prince's Men were puruing the Ravihers of Agnes, he was left almot alone with her; and tho' he had always reolv'd to hun being o, yet his Contancy was not Proof againt o fair an Occaion: Madam, aid he to her, is it poible that Men born amongt thoe that obey us, hould be capable of offending you? I never thought my elf detin'd to revenge uch an Offence; but ince Heaven has permitted you to receive it, I will either perih or make them repent it. Sir, replied Agnes, more concern'd at this coure than at the Enterprize of Don Alvaro, thoe who are wanting in their Repect to the Princes and you, are not oblig'd to have any for me. I do not in the leat doubt but Don Alvaro was the Undertaker of this Enterprize, and I judg'd what I ought to fear from him, by what his Importunities have already made me uffer. He is ure of the King's Protection, and he will make him an Accomplice in his Crime; but, Sir, Heaven conducted you hither happily for me, and I owe you for the liberty I have of erving the Princes yet longer. You will do for Contantia, replied the Prince, what 'tis impoible not to do for you; your Goodnes attaches you to her, and my Detiny engages me to you for ever.

The modet Agnes, who fear'd this Dicoure as much as the Misfortune he had newly hunned, anwer'd nothing but by down-cat Eyes, and the Prince, who knew the trouble he was in, left her to go peak to his Men, who brought back one of thoe that belong'd to Don Alvaro,
by whoe Confeion he found the Truth: He pardon'd him, thinking not fit to punih him, who obey'd a Man whom the weaknes of his Father had render'd powerful.

Afterwards they conducted Agnes back to Coimbra, where her Adventure began to make a great noie: The Princes was ready to die with Depair, and at firt thought it was only a continuation of the Deign this fair Maid had of retiring; but ome Women that erv'd her having told the Princes, that he was carried away by Violence, Contantia made her Complaint to the King, who regarded her not at all.

p.q: Madam, aid he to her, let this fatal Plague remove itelf, who takes from you the Heart of your Husband, and without afflicting your elf for her Abence, bles Heaven and me for it.

div.p: The Generous Princes took Agnes's part with a great deal of Courage, and was then diputing her defence with the King, when Don Pedro arriv'd at Coimbra.

The firt Object that met the Prince's Eyes was Don Alvaro, who was paing through one of the Courts of the Palace, amidt a Croud of Courtiers, whom his favour with the King drew after him. This Sight made Don Pedro rage; but that of the Princes and Agnes caus'd in him another ort of Emotion: He eaily divin'd, that it was Don Pedro, who had taken her from his Men, and, if his Fury had acted what it would, it might have produc'd very ad effects.

Don Alvaro, aid the Prince to him, is it thus you make ue of the Authority which the King my Father has given you? Have you receiv'd Employments and Power from him for no other end but to do bae Actions, and to commit Rapes on Ladies? Are you ignorant how the Princes interets herelf in all that concerns this Maid? And do you not know the tender and affectionate Eteem he has for her? No, replied Don Alvaro,
(with an Inolence that had like to have put the Prince pat all Patience) I am not ignorant of it, nor of the Interet your Heart takes in her. Bae and treacherous as thou art, replied the Prince, neither the Favour which thou hat o much abued, nor the Inolence which makes thee peak this, hould hinder me from punihing thee, wert thou worthy of my Sword; but there are other ways to humble thy Pride, and 'tis not fit for uch an Arm as mine to eek o bae an Imployment to punih uch a Slave as thou art.

Don Pedro went away at thee words, and left Alvaro in a Rage, which is not to be expres'd, depairing to ee himelf defeated in an Enterprize he thought o ure, and at the Contempt the Prince hew'd him, he promied himelf to acrifice all to his Revenge.

Tho' the King loved his Son, he was o prepoes'd againt his Paion, that he could not pardon him what he had done, and condemn'd him as much for this lat Act of Jutice, in delivering Agnes, as if it had been the greatet of Crimes.
Elvira, whom the weetnes of Hope flatter'd ome moments, aw the return of Agnes with a enible Dipleaure, which uffer'd her to think of nothing but irritating her Brother.

In fine, the Prince aw the King, but intead of being receiv'd by him with a Joy due to the ucces of his Journey, he appear'd all ullen and out of Humour. After having paid him his firt Repects, and gave him an exact account of what he had done, he poke to him about the Violence committed againt the Peron of Agnes de Catro, and complain'd to him of it in the Name of the Princes, and of his own: You ought to be ilent in this Affair, replied the King, and the Motive which makes you peak is o hameful for you, that I igh and bluh at it: What is it to you, if this Maid, whoe Preence is troubleome to me, be remov'd hence, ince 'tis I that deire it? But, Sir, interrupted the Prince, what neceity is there of employing Force, Artifice, and the Night, when the leat of your Orders had been ufficient; Agnes would willingly have obey'd you, and if he continue at Coimbra, 'tis perhaps againt her will; but be it as it will, Sir, Contantia is offended, and if it were not for fear of dipleaing you, (the only thing that retains me) the Raviher hould not have gone unpunih'd. How happy are you, replied the King, miling with Didain, in making ue of the Name of Contantia to uphold the Interet of your Heart; you think I am ignorant of it, and that this unhappy Princes looks on the Injury you
do her with Indifference. Never peak to me more of Agnes, (with a Tone very evere) Content your elf, that I pardon what's pat, and think maturely of the Coniderations I have for Don Alvaro, when you would deign any thing againt him. Yes, Sir, reply'd the Prince, with fiercenes, I will peak to you no more of Agnes, but Contantia, and I will never uffer, that he hould be any more expos'd to the Inolence of your Favourite. The King had like to have broke out into Rage at this Dicoure; but he had yet a Ret of Prudence left, that hinder'd him. Retire, (aid he to Don Pedro) and go make Reflections on what my Power can do, and what you owe me.

During this Converation, Agnes was receiving from the Princes, and from all the Ladies of the Court, great Expreions of Joy, and Friendhip, Contantia aw again her Husband, with a great deal of atisfaction, and far from being orry at what he had lately done for Agnes, he privately return'd him Thanks for it, and till was the ame towards him, notwithtanding all the Jealouie which was endeavour'd to be inpir'd in her.

Don Alvaro, who found in his Siter a Maliciounes worthy of his Trut, did not conceal his Fury from her. After he had made vain Attempts to moderate it, in blotting Agnes out of his Heart, eeing that his Dieae was incurable, he made him undertand, that o long as Contantio hould not be Jealous, there was
no Hopes. That if Agnes hould once be upected by her, he would not fail of abandoning her, and that then it would be eaie to get Satisfaction, the Prince being now o proud of Contantia's Indulgency. In giving this Advice to her Brother, he promis'd to erve him effectually; and having no need of any Body but herelf to perform Ill Things, he recommended Don Alvaro to manage well the King.
Four Years were pas'd in that melancholy Station, and the Princes, beides her firt dead Child, and Ferdinand, who was till living, had brought two Daughters into the World.

Some Days after Don Pedro's Return, Elvira, who was mot dextrous in the Art of Well-governing any wicked Deign, did gain one of the Servants which belong'd to Contantia's Chamber. She firt poke her fair, then overwhelm'd her with Preents and Gifts, and finding in her as ill a Dipoition as in herelf, he readily reolv'd to employ her.

After he was ure of her, he compos'd a Letter, which was after writ over again in an unknown Hand, which he depoited in that Maid's Hands, that he might deliver to Contantia with the firt Opportunity, telling her, that Agnes had drop'd it. This was the Subtance of it.

I Employ not my own Hand to write to you, for Reaons that I hall acquaint you with. How
happy am I to have overcome all your Scruples! And what Happines hall I find in the Progres of our Intrigue! The whole Coure of my Life, hall continually repreent to you the Sincerity of my Affections; pray think on the Secret Converation that I require of you; I dare not peak to you in publick, therefore let me conjure you here, by all that I have uffer'd, to come to Night to the Place appointed, and peak to me no more of Contantia; for he must be content with my Eteem, ince my Heart can be only Yours.

The unfaithful Portuguee erv'd Elvira exactly to her Deires, and the very next Day eeing Agnes go out from the Princes, he carry'd Contantia the Letter; which he took, and found there what he was far from imagining: Tendernes never produc'd an Effect more full of Grief, than what it made her uffer: Alas, they are both culpable (aid he, ighing) and in pight of the Defence my Heart wou'd make for 'em, my Reaon Condemns 'em. nhappy Princes, the ad Subject of the Capriciounes of Fortune! Why dost not thou die, ince thou hast not a Heart of Honour to revenge itelf? O Don Pedro! Why did you give me your Hand, without your Heart? And thou, Fair, and ngrateful! Wert thou born to be the Misfortune of my Life, and, perhaps, the only Caue of my Death.
