After having given ome Moments to the Violence of her Grief, he call'd the Maid, who brought her the Letter, commanding her to peak of it tono Body, and to uffer no one to enter into her Chamber.

She conider'd then of that Prince with more liberty, whoe Soul he was not able to touch with the leat Tendernes; and of the cruel fair One that had betray'd her: Yet, even while her Soul was upon the Rack, he was willing to excue 'em, and ready to do all he could for Don Pedro; at leat, he made a firm Reolution, not to complain of him.
Elvira was not long without being inform'd of what had pas'd, nor of the Melancholly of the Princes, from whom he hop'd all he deir'd.

Agnes, far from foreeeing this Tempet, return'd to Contantia; and hearing of her Indipoition, pas'd the ret of the day at her Chamber-door, that he might from time to time learn News of her Health, for he was not uffer'd to come in, at which Agnes was both urpriz'd and troubled. The Prince had the ame Detiny, and was atonih'd at an Order which ought to have excepted him.

The next day Contantia appear'd, but o alter'd, that 'twas not difficult to imagine what he had uffer'd. Agnes was the mot impatient to approach her, and the Princes could not forbear weeping. They were both ilent for ome time, and Contantia attributed this Silence of Agnes to ome Remore which he felt; and this unhappy Maid being able to hold no longer, Is it poible Madam, (aid he,) that two Days hould have taken from me all the Goodnes you had for me? What have I done? And for what do you punih me? The Princes regarded her with a languihing look, and return'd her
no Anwer, but Sighs. Agnes, offended at this Reerve, went out with very great Diatisfaction and Anger; which contributed to her being thought criminal. The Prince came in immediately after, and found Contantia more diorder'd than uual, and conjur'd her in a mot obliging manner to take care of her Health: The greatet good for me (aid he) is not the Continuation of my Life; I hould have more Care of it if I lov'd you les; but—She could not proceed; and the Prince, exceively afflicted at her trouble, igh'd adly, without making her any Anwer, which redoubled her Grief. Spight then began to mix itelf; and all things perwading the Princes that they made a Sacrafice of her, he would enter into no Explanation with her Husband, but uffer'd him to go away without aying any thing to him.
Nothing is more capable of troubling our Reaon, and conuming our Health, then ecret Notions of Jealouie in Solitude.

Contantia, who us'd to open her Heart freely to Agnes, now believing he had deceiv'd her, abandon'd herelf o abolutely to Grief, that he was ready to ink under it; he immediately fell ick with the violence of it, and all the Court was concern'd at this Misfortune: Don Pedro was truly afflicted at it, but Agnes more than all the World beide. Contantia's Coldnes towards her, made her continually igh; and her Ditemper, created meerly by Fancy, caus'd her to reflect on every thing that offer'd itelf to her Memory; o that at lat
he began even to fear herelf, and to reproach herelf for what the Princes uffer'd.

But the Ditemper began to be uch, that they fear'd Contantia's Death, and he herelf began to feel the Approaches of it. This Thought did not at all diquiet her; he look'd on Death as the only Relief from all her Torments; and regarded the Depair of all that approach'd her without the leat concern.

The King, who lov'd her tenderly, and who knew her Vertue, was infinitely mov'd at the Extremity he was in. And Don Alvaro, who lot not the leat Occaion of making him undertand, that it was Jealouie which was the Caue of Contantia's Ditemper, did but too much incene him againt Criminals worthy of Compaion. The King was not of a Temper to conceal his Anger long: You give fine Examples, (aid he to the Prince) and uch as will render your Memory illutrious; and the Death of Contantia (of which you are only to be accus'd of) is the unhappy Fruit of your guilty Paion. Fear Heaven after this; and behold yourelf as a Monter that does not deerve to ee the Light. If the Interest you have in my Blood did not plead for you, what ought you not to fear from my just Reentment? But what must not Imprudent Agnes, to whom nothing ties me, expect from my hands? If Contantia dyes, he, who has the Boldnes, in my Court, to cherih a foolih Flame by vain Hopes, and make us loe the most Amiable Princes, whom thou art not worthy to poes, hall feel the Effects of her Indicretion.

Don Pedro knew very well, that Contantia was not ignorant of his Sentiments for Agnes; but he knew alo with what Moderation he receiv'd it: He was very enible of the King's Reproaches; but as his Fault was not voluntary, and that a commanding Power, a fatal Star had forc'd him to love in pight of himelf, he appear'd afflicted and confus'd: You condemn me, Sir, (anwered he) without having well examin'd me; and if my Intentions were known to you, perhaps you would not find me o criminal: I would take the Princes for my Judge, whom you ay, I acrifice, if he were in a condition to be conulted. If I am guilty of any Weaknes, her Jutice never reproach'd me for it; and my Tongue never inform'd Agnes of it. But, uppoe I have committed any Fault, why wou'd you punih an Innocent Lady, who perhaps condemns me for it as much as you? Ah, Villain! (interrupted the King,) he has but too much favour'd you: You would not have lov'd thus long, had he not made you ome Returns. Sir, (reply'd the Prince, pierced with Grief for the Outrage that was committed againt Agnes,) you offend a Vertue, than which nothing can be purer; and thoe Expreions which break from your Choler, are not worthy of you. Agnes never granted me any Favours; I never asked any of her; and I protest to Heaven, I never thought of any thing contrary to the Duty I owe Contantia.

As they thus argued, one of the Princes's Women came all in Tears, to acquaint Don Pedro, That the Princes was in the lat Extremities
of Life: Go ee thy fatal Work, (aid the King,) and expect from a too-long-patient Father the age thou deerv'st.

The Prince ran to Contantia, whom he found dying, and Agnes in a woon, in the Arms of ome of the Ladies. What caus'd this double Calamity, was, that Agnes, who could uffer no longer the Indifferency of the Princes, had conjur'd her to tell her what was her Crime, and either to take her Life from her, or retore her Friendhip.

Contantia, who found he mut die, could no longer keep her ecret Affliction from Agnes; and after ome Words, which were a Preparative to the ad Explanation, he hew'd her that fatal Billet which Elvira had caus'd to be written: Ah! Madam, (cry'd out the fair Agnes, after having read it;) Ah, Madam! How many cruel Inquietudes had you par'd me, had you open'd your Heart to me with your wonted Bounty? 'Tis eay to ee that this Letter is counterfeit, and that I have Enemies without compaion. Cou'd you believe the Prince o Impudent, to make ue of any other hand but his own, on an occaion like this? And do you believe me o Simple, to keep about me this Tetimony of my Shame, with o little Precaution? You are neither betray'd by your Husband nor me; I attest Heaven, and thoe Efforts I have made, to leave Coimbra. Alas, my dear Princes! how little have you known her, whom you have o much honour'd? Do not believe, that when I have jutify'd myelf, I will have any more Communication with the World. No, no; there will be no Retreat far enough from hence for me. I will take care to
hide this unlucky Face, where it hall be ure to do no more Harm.

The Princes touch'd at this Dicoure, and the Tears of Agnes, pres'd her hand, which he held in hers; and fixing looks upon her, capable of moving pity in the mot inenible Souls, If I have committed any Offence, my dear Agnes, (anwer'd he) Death, which I expect in a moment, hall revenge it. I ought alo to protest to you, That I have not ceas'd loving you, and that I believe every thing you have aid, giving you back my most tender Affections.

'Twas at this time that the Grief, which equally oppres'd 'em, put the Princes into uch an Extremity, that they ent for the Prince. He came and found himelf almot without life or motion at this ight. And what ecret Motive oever might call him to the Aid of Agnes, 'twas to Contantia he ran. The Princes, who finding her lat Moments drawing on, by a cold Sweat that cover'd her all over; and finding he had no more buines with Life, and cauing thoe Perons he mot upected to retire, Sir, (aid he to Don Pedro,) If I abandon Life without Regret, it is not without Trouble that I part with you. But, Prince, we must vanguih when we come to die; and I will forget myelf wholly, to think of nothing but of you. I have no Reproaches to make against you, knowing that 'tis Inclination that dipoes Hearts, and not Reaon. Agnes is beautiful enough to inpire the most ardent Paion, and vertuous enough to deerve the first Fortunes in the World. I ask her, once more, Pardon for the Injutice I have done her, and
recommend her to you, as a Peron most dear to me. Promie me, my dear Prince, before I Expire, to give her my Place in your Throne; it cannot be better fill'd; you cannot chue a Princes more perfect for your People, nor a better Mother for our little Children. And you, my Dear, and my faithful Agnes (puru'd he) liten not to a Vertue too crupulous, that they may make any oppoition to the Prince of Portugal: Refue him not a Heart, of which he is worthy; and give him that Friendhip which you had for me, with that which is due to his Merit. Take care of my little Fernando, and the two young Princees: let 'em find me in you, and peak to 'em ometimes of me. Adieu; live both of you happy, and receive my last Embraces.

The afflicted Agnes, who had recover'd a little her Forces, lot 'em again a econd time: Her Weaknes was follow'd with Convulions o vehement, that they were afraid of her Life; but Don Pedro never remov'd from Contantia: What, Madam, (aid he) you will leave me then; and you think 'tis for my Good. Alas, Contantia! if my Heart has committed any Outrage against you, your Vertue has ufficiently reveng'd you on me, in pight of you. Can you think me o barbarous?—As he was going on, he aw Death hut the Eyes of the mot generous Princes for ever; and he was within a very little of following her.

But what loads of Grief was this for Agnes, when he found that in that Interval, when Life and Death were truggling in her Soul, that Contantia was newly expir'd! She would then have taken away her own Life, and have let her Depair fully appear.

At the noie of the Death of the Princes, the Town and the Palace was all in Tears. Elvira, who aw then Don Pedro free to engage himelf, repented of having contributed to the Death of Agnes, who thought herelf the caue of it, promis'd her Griefs never to Pardon herelf.

She had need of being guarded everal days together; during which time, he fail'd not inceantly to weep. And the Prince gave all thoe days to deepet Mourning. But when the firt Emotions were pat, thoe of his Love made him feel that he was till the ame.
He was a long time without eeing Agnes, but this Abence of his erv'd only to make her appear the more charming when he did ee her.

Don Alvaro, who was afraid of the Liberty of the Prince, made new Efforts to move Agnes de Catro; who was now become inenible to every thing but Grief. Elvira, who was willing to make the bet of the Deign he had begun, conulted all her Womens Arts, and the delicacy of her Wit, to revive the Flames with which the Prince once burnt for her: But his Incontancy was bounded, and it was Agnes alone that was to reign over his Heart. She had taken a firm Reolution, ince the Death of Contantia, to pas the ret of her days in a olitary Retreat. In pight of the Precaution he took to hide this Deign, the Prince was inform'd of it, and did all he was able to dipoe his Contancy and Fortitude to it. He thought himelf tronger than he really was;
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
but after he had too well conulted his Heart, he found but too well how neceary the Preence of Agnes was to him: Madam, (aid he to her one day, with a Heart big, and his Eyes in Tears) Which Action of my Life has made you determine my Death? Though I never told you now much I lov'd you, yet I am perwaded you are not ignorant of it. I was contrain'd to be ilent during ome Years for your ake, for Contantia's and my own; but 'tis not poible for me to put this Force upon my Heart for ever: I must once at least tell you how it languihes. Receive then the Aurances of a Paion, full of Repect and Ardour; with an Offer of my Fortune, which I wih not better, but for your Advantage.

Agnes anwer'd not immediately to thee Words, but with abundance of Tears; which having wip'd away, and beholding Don Pedro with an Air which made him eaily comprehend he did not agree with his Deires: If I were capable of the Weaknes with which you'd inpire me, you'd be oblig'd to punih me for it. What! (aid he) Contantia is carce bury'd, and you wou'd have me offend her! No, my Princes, (added he with more Softnes;) No, no, he whom you have heap'd o many Favours on, will not call down the Anger of Heaven, and the Contempt of Men upon her, by an Action o perfidious. Be not obtinate then in a Deign in which I will never hew you Favour. You owe to Contantia, after her Death, a Fidelity that may jutifie you: And I to repair the Ills I have made her uffer, ought to hun all Convere with you. Go, Madam, reply'd the Prince, growing pale;) go, and expect the News of my
Death, in that part of the World, whither your Cruelty hall lead you, the News hall follow cloe after; you hall quickly hear of it; and I will go eek it in thoe Wars which reign among my Neighbours.

Thee words made the fair Agnes de Catro perceive that her Innocency was not o great as he imagin'd, and that her Heart intereted itelf in the Preervation of Don Pedro: You ought, Sir, to preerve your Life, (reply'd Agnes) for the ake of the little Prince and Princees, which Contantia has left you. Wou'd you abandon their Youth (continu'd he, with a tender Tone) to the Cruelty of Don Alvaro? Live, Sir, live! and let the unhappy Agnes be the only Sacrifice. Alas, cruel Maid! (interrupted Don Pedro;) why do you command me to live, if I cannot live with you? Is it an effect of your Hatred? No, Sir, (replyed Agnes) I do not hate you; and I wih to God that I cou'd be indifferent, that I might be able to defend myelf against the Weaknes with which I find myelf poes'd. Oblige me to ay no more, Sir: You ee my Bluhes, interpret them as you pleae; but conider yet, that the les Averion I find I have for you, the more culpable I am; and that I ought no more to ee, or peak to you. In fine, Sir, if you oppoe my Retreat, I declare to you, that Don Alvaro, as odious as he is to me, hall erve for a Defence against you; and that I will ooner conent to marry a Man I abhor, than to favour a Paion that cost Contantia her Life. Well then, Agnes, (reply'd the Prince, with looks all languihing and dying) follow the Motions which barbarous Vertue inpires you with; take thoe Meaures you judge neceary, against an unfortunate Lover,
and enjoy the Glory of having cruelly refus'd me.
At thee Words he went away; and as troubled as Agnes was, he would not tay him: Her Courage combated with her Grief, and he thought now, more than ever of departing.

'Twas difficult for her to go out of Coimbra; and not to defer what appear'd to her o neceary; he went immediately to the Apartment of the King, notwithtanding the interet of Don Alvaro. the King receiv'd her with a Countenance evere, not being able to conent to what he demanded: You hall not go hence, (aid he) and if you are wie, you hall enjoy here, with Don Alvaro, both my Friendhip, and my Favour. I have taken another Reolution, (anwer'd Agnes) and the World has no part in it. You will accept Don Pedro, (reply'd the King;) his Fortune is ufficient to atisfie an Ambitious Maid: But you will not ucceed Contantia, who lov'd you o tenderly; and Spain has Princees enough to fill up part of the Throne which I hall leave him. Sir, (reply'd Agnes, piqu'd at this Dicoure) If I had a dipoition to Love, and a deign to Marry, perhaps the Prince might be the only Peron on whom I would fix 'em: And you know, if my Ancetors did not poes Crowns, yet they were worthy to wear 'em. But let it be how it will, I am reolv'd to depart, and to remain no longer a Slave in a place to which I came Free.

This bold Anwer, which hew'd the Character of Agnes, anger'd and atonih'd the King: You hall go when we think fit, (reply'd he)
and without being a Slave at Coimbra, you hall attend our Orders.

p.U: aw he mut tay, and was o griev'd at it, that he kept her Chamber everal days, without daring to inform herelf of the Prince; and this Retirement par'd her the Affliction of being viited by Don Alvaro.

div.p: During this, Don Pedro fell ick, and was in o great Danger, that there was a general Apprehenion of his Death. Agnes did not in the leat doubt, but it was an Effect of his Dicontent: he thought at firt he had trength and reolution enough to ee him die, rather than to favour him; but had he reflected a little, he had oon been convinc'd to the contrary: She found not in her Heart that cruel Contancy, he thought there o well etablih'd; he felt Pains and Inquietude, hed Tears, made Wihes; and in fine, dicover'd that he Lov'd.

'Twas impoible to ee the Heir of the Crown, a Prince that deerv'd o well, even at the point of Death, without a general Affliction: The People who lov'd him, pas'd whole days at the Palace-gate to hear News of him: The Court was all overwhelm'd with Grief.

Don Alvaro knew very well how to conceal a malicious Joy, under an Appearance of Sadnes. Elvira, full of Tendernes, and perhaps of Remore, uffer'd alo on her ide. The King, altho' he condemn'd the Love of his Son, yet till had a Tendernes for him, and cou'd not reolve to loe him. Agnes de Catro, who knew the Caue of his Ditemper,
expected the end of it with trange Anxieties. In fine, after a Month had pas'd away in Fears, they began to have a little Hopes of his Recovery. The Prince, and Don Alvaro were the only Perons that were not glad of it. But Agnes rejoyc'd enough for all the ret.

Don Pedro, eeing that he mut live whether he wou'd or no, thought of nothing, but paing his days in Melancholly and Dicontent: As oon as he was in a condition to walk, he ought out the mot olitary Places, and gain'd o much upon his own Weaknes, to go everywhere, where Agnes was not; but her Idea follow'd him always, and his Memory, faithful, to repreent her to him, with all her Charms, render'd her always dangerous.

One day, when they had carry'd him into the Garden, he ought out a Labyrinth which was at the farthet part of it, to hide his Melancholly, during ome hours; there he found the ad Agnes, whom Grief, little different from his, had brought thither; the ight of her, whom he expected not, made him tremble: She aw by his pale and meagre Face, the remains of his Ditemper; his Eyes full of Languihment troubled her, and tho' her deire was o great to have fled from him, an unknown Power topt her, and 'twas impoible for her to go.

After ome Moments of Silence, which many Sighs interrupted, Don Pedro rais'd himelf from the place, where his Weaknes had forc'd him to it; he made Agnes ee, as he approached her, the ad Marks of his Sufferings, and
not content with the Pity he aw in her Eyes,
<> have reolv'd my Death then, Cruel Agnes, (aid he) my deire was the ame with yours; but Heaven has thought fit to reerve me for other Misfortunes, and I ee you again as unhappy, but more in love than ever.

There was no need of thee Words to move Agnes to Compaion, the Languihment of the Prince poke enough: And the Heart of this fair Maid, was but too much dipos'd to yield itelf: She thought then that Contantia ought to be atisfied; Love, which combated for Don Pedro, triumphed over Friendhip, and found that happy Moment, for which the Prince of Portugal had o long ighed.

Do not reproach me, for that which has cost me more than you, Sir; (reply'd he) and do not accue a <> , which is neither Ingrateful nor Barbarous; and I must tell you, that I love you. But now I have made you that Confeion, what is it farther that you require of me? Don Pedro, who expected not a Change o favourable, felt a double Satisfaction, and falling at the Feet of Agnes, he expres'd more by the Silence his Paion created, than he could have done by the mot eloquent Words.

After having known all his good Fortune, he then conulted with the Amiable Agnes, what was to be fear'd from the King; they concluded, that the cruel Billet, which o troubled the lat days of Contantia, could come from none but Elvira and Don Alvaro. The Prince, who knew that his Father had earch'd already an Alliance for him, and was reolv'd
on his Favourite's marrying Agnes,
<>
her o tenderly to prevent thee Perecu ••
by conenting to a ecret Marriage; that, <>
having a long time conidered, he at <>
conented, I will do what you will have me, (ai •
he) though I preage nothing but fatal Events <>
it; all my Blood turns to Ice, when I think of this Marriage, and the Image of Contantia
<>
hinder me from doing it.

The Amorous Prince urmounted all <>
Scruples, and eparated himelf from <>
with a Satisfaction which oon redoubled his Forces; he aw her afterward with the pleaure of a Mytery, and the Day of their Union arriv'd: Dom Gill, Bihop of Guarda; performed the Ceremony of the Marriage, in the preence of everal Witnees, faithful to Don Pedro, who aw him Poeor of all the Cha • ms of the Fair Agnes.

She liv'd not the more peaceable for belonging to the Prince of Portugal; her Enemies, who continually perecuted her, left her not without troubles; and the King, whom her Refual inrag'd, laid his abolute Commands on her, to Marry Don Alvaro, with Threats to force her to it, if he continued Rebellious.

The Prince took loudly her part, and this joyn'd to the Refual he made of marrying the Princes of Arragon, caus'd Supicions of the Truth in the King his Father. He was econded by thoe that were too much intereted, not to unriddle this Secret. Don Alvaro and his Siter acted with o much Care, gave o many Gifts, and made o many Promies, that
they dicovered the ecret Engagements of Don Pedro and Agnes.

The King wanted but little of breaking out into all the Rage and Fury o great a Diappointment could inpire him with, againt the Princes. Don Alvaro, whoe Love was chang'd into the mot violent Hatred, appeas'd the firt Tranports of the King, by making him comprehend, that if they could break the Marriage of 'em, that would not be a ufficient Revenge, and o poyoned the Soul of the King, to conent to the Death of Agnes.
The Barbarous Don Alvaro offered his Arm for this terrible Execution, and his Rage was Security for the Sacrifice.

The King, who thought the Glory of his Family digraced, by this Alliance, and his own <> particular in the Procedure of his Son, gave full Power to this Murder, to make the innocent Agnes, a Victim to his Rage.

It was not eaie to execute this horrid Deign: Though the Prince aw Agnes but in ecret, yet all his Cares were till awake for her, and he was married to her above a Year, before Don Alvaro could find out an Opportunity o long ought for.

The Prince delivered himelf but little, and very rarely went far from Coimbra: but on a Day, an Unfortunate Day, and mark'd out by Heaven for an unheard of and horrid Aain, he made a Party to hunt at a fine Houe, which the King of Portugal had near the City.

Agnes lov'd every thing that gave the Prince atisfaction; but a ecret Trouble made her
apprehend ome Misfortune in this unhappy Journey: Sir, (aid he, to him alarm'd, without knowing the Reaon why I tremble) eeing you to day, as it were deign'd the last of my Life Preerve yourelf, my Dear Prince, and though the Exercie you take be not very dangerous, beware of the least Hazards, and bring me back all that I trust with you. Don Pedro, who had never found her o Handome and o Charming before, embraced her everal times, and went out of the Palace with his Followers, with a deign not to return till the next Day.

He was no ooner gone, but the Cruel Don Alvaro prepared himelf for the Execution he had reolv'd on; he thought it of that importance, that it required more Hands than his Own; and o choe for his Companions Diego Lopes Pacheo, and Pedro Cuello, two Monters like himelf, whoe Cruelty he was aur'd of by the Preents he had made 'em.

They waited the coming of the Night, and the lovely Agnes was in her firt leep, which the lat of her Life, when thee Aains approach'd her Bed. Nothing made reitance to Don Alvaro, who could do every thing, and whom the blacket Furies introduced to Agnes, he wakened, and opening her Curtains, aw, by the Candle burning in her Chamber, the Poinard with which Don Alvaro was arm'd; he having not his Face covered he eaily knew him, and forgetting herelf, to think of nothing but the Prince: Just Heaven, (aid he, lifting up her fine Eyes) if you will revenge Contantia, atisfie yourelf with my Blood only, and
pare that of Don Pedro. The Barbarous Man that heard her, gave her not time to ay more; and finding he could never (by all he could do by Love) touch the Heart of the Fair Agnes, he pierc'd it with his Poinard; his Accomplices gave her everal Wounds, tho' there were no Neceity of o many to put an End to an Innocent Life.

What a ad Spectacle was this for thoe who approach'd her Bed the next Day: And what dimal News was this to the Unfortunate Prince of Portugal! He return'd to Coimbra, to the firt Report of this Adventure, and aw what had certainly cot him his Life, if Men could die of Grief; after having a thouand times embraced the bloody Body of Agnes, and aid all that a jut Depair could inpire him with, he ran like a Mad-man into the Palace, demanding the Murderers of his Wife, of things that could not hear him: In fine, he aw the King, and without oberving any Repect, he gave a Looe to his Reentment: after having rail'd a long time, overwhelm'd with Grief, he fell into a Swoon, which continued all that Day. They carried him into his Apartment; and the King, believing that this Misfortune would prove his Cure, repented not of what he had permitted,

Don Alvaro, and the two other Aains, quitted Coimbra. This Abence of theirs, made 'em appear guilty of the Crime, for which the Afflicted Prince vowed a peedy Vengeance to the Ghot of his Lovely Agnes, reolving to purue them to the uttermot part
of the Univere: He got a coniderable number of Men together, ufficient to have made Reitance, even on the King of Portugal himelf, if he hould yet take the Part of the Murderers; with thee he ravag'd the whole Country, as far as the Duero Waters, and carried on a War, even till the Death of the King, continually mixing Tears with Blood, which he gave to the Revenge of his Dearet Agnes.

Such was the deplorable End of the Unfortunate Love of Don Pedro of Portugal, and of the Fair Agnes de Catro, whoe Remembrance he faithfully preerved in his Heart, even upon the Throne, to which he mounted, by the Right of his Birth, after the Death of the King.
div.trailer: The End of AGNES de CASTRO.

div.p: THE LOVER's WATCH: OR, THE ART OF Making LOVE: BEING Rules for Courthip, For Every HOUR in the DAY and NIGHT.
By Mrs. BEHN.
LONDON: Printed by W. Onley, for S. Bricoe. 1697.

div.head: THE Lover's Watch: OR, THE ART OF Making LOVE.
The ARGUMENT.
div.p: 'TIS in the mot Happy and August Court of the Bet and Greatet Monarch of the World, that Damon, a young Nobleman, whom we will render under that Name, languihes for a Maid of Quality, who will give us leave to call her Iris:

Their Births are equally Illutrious; they are both Rich, and both Young; their Beauty uch, as I dae not too nicely particularize, let I hould
dicover (which I am not permitted to do) who thee charming Lovers are. Let it uffice, that Iris is the mot fair and accompliht Peron that ever adorn'd a Court; and that Damon is only worthy of the Glory of her Favour; for he has all that can render him lovely in the fair Eyes of the Amiable Iris. Nor is he Mater of thoe Superficial Beauties alone, that pleae at firt Sight; he can charm the Soul with a thouand Arts of Wit and Gallantry. And, in a word, I may ay, without flattering either, that there is no one Beauty, no one Grace, no perfection of Mind and Body, that wants to compleat a Victory on both ides.

The Agreement of Age, Fortunes, Quality and Humours in thee two fair Lovers, made the impatient Damon hope, that nothing would oppoe his Paion; and if he aw himelf every Hour languihing for the Adorable Maid, he did not however depair: And if Iris igh'd, it was not for fear of being one day more happy.

In the midst of the Tranquility of thee two Lovers, Iris was obliged to go into the Country for ome Months, whither 'twas impoible for Damon to wait on her, he being oblig'd to attend the King his Mater; and being the mot Amorous of his Sex, uffer'd with extream Impatience th • Abence of his Mitres. Nevertheles, he fail'd not to end to her every day, and gave up all his melancholly Hours to Thinking, Sighing, and Writing to her the oftest Letters that Love could inpire. So that Iris even bleed that Abence, that gave her o tender and convincing Proofs of his Paion; and found this dear way of Convering, even recompened all her Sighs for his Abence.

After a little Intercoure of this kind, Damon be thought himelf to ask Iris a Dicretion, which he had won of her, before he left the Town; and in a Billet-doux to that purpoe, prest her very earnetly for it. Iris being infinitely pleas'd with his Importunity, uffer'd him to ask it often; and he never fail'd of doing o.

But as I do not here deign to relate the Adventures of thee two Amiable Perons, nor give you all the Billet-douxes that past between them: You hall here find nothing but the Watch, this charming Maid ent her impatient Lover.

div.head: IRIS to DAMON.
div.p:
IT mut be confet, Damon, that you are the mot importuning Man in the World. Your Billets have an hundred times demanded a Dicretion, which you won of me; and tell me, you will not wait my Return, to be paid. You are either a very faithles Creditor, or believe me very unjut, that you dun with uch Impatience. But, to let you ee I am a Maid of Honour, and value my Word, I will acquit myelf of this Obligation I have to you, and end you a Watch of my fahion; perhaps you never aw any o good. It is not one of thoe, that have always omething to be mended in it; but one that is without Fault, very jut and good, and will remain o, as long as you continue to love me. But Damon, know, that the very Minute you ceae to do o, the String will break, and it will go no more. 'Tis only ueful in my Abence, and when I return, 'twill change its Motion: And though I have et it but for the Spring-time, 'twill erve you the whole Year round; and 'twill be neceary only, that you alter the buines of the Hours (which my Cupid, in the middle of my Watch, points you out) according to the length of the
Days and Nights. Nor is the Dart of that little God directed to thoe Hours, o much to inform you how they pas, as how you ought to pas them, how you ought to employ thoe of your Abence from Iris. 'Tis there you hall find the whole Buines of a Lover, from his Mitres; for I have deign'd it a Rule to all your Actions. The Conideration of the Workman, ought to make you et a Value upon the Work: And though it be not an accompliht, and perfect Piece; yet Damon, you ought to be grateful, and eteem it, ince I have made it for you alone. But however I may boat of the Deign, I know, as well as I believe, you love me; that you will not uffer me to have the Glory of it wholly, but will ay in your heart,
That Love, the great Intructor of the Mind,
That forms a new, and fahions every Soul,
Refines the gros Defects of Humane kind;
Humbles the Proud and Vain, inpires the Dull:
Gives Cowards noble Heat in Fight,
And teaches feeble Woman how to write:
That doth the nivere command;
Does from my Iris Heart direct her Hand.
I give you the liberty to ay this to your Heart, if you pleae: And that you may know, with what Jutice you do o, I will confes in my turn.

div.head: The Confeion.

lg.l: That Love's my Conduct where I go,
And Love intructs me all I do.
Prudence no longer is my Guide,
Nor take I Counel of my Pride.
In vain does Honour now invade,
In vain does Reaon take my part;
If againt Love it do perwade,
If it rebel againt my Heart.
If the oft Ev'ning do invite,
And I incline to take the Air,
The Birds, the Spring, the Flowers no more delight;
'Tis Love makes all the Pleaure there;
Love, which about me till I bear:
I'm charm'd with what I thither bring,
And add a Softnes to the Spring.
If for Devotion I deign,
Love meets me, even at the hrine;
In all my Worhips claims a part,
And robs even Heaven of my Heart.
All Day does Counel and controul,
And all the Night employs my Soul.
No wonder then, if all you think be true,
That Love's concern'd in all I do for you.

div.p:
And Damon, you know that Love is no ill Mater; and I mut ay, with a Bluh, that he has found me no unapt Scholar; and he intructs too agreeably, not to ucceed in all he undertakes:
Who can reist his oft Commands?
When he reolves, what God withtands?

But I ought to explain to you my Watch: The naked Love which you will find in the middle of it, with his Wings clip'd, to hew you he is fix'd and contant, and will not fly away, points you out, with his Arrow, the four and twenty Hours that compoe the Day and the Night: Over every Hour you will find written what you ought to do, during its Coure; and every Half-hour is marked with a Sigh, ince the quality of a Lover is, to igh day and night: Sighs are the Children of Lovers, that are born every hour. And that my Watch may always be jut, Love himelf ought to conduct it; and your Heart hould keep Time with the Movement:
My Preent's delicate, and new,
If by your Heart the Motion's et;
According as that's fale, or true,
You'll find, my Watch will anwer it.

Every hour is tedious to a Lover, eparated from his Mitres; and, to hew you how good I am, I will have my Watch intruct you, to pas ome of them without Inquietude; that the force of your Imagination may ometimes charm the Trouble you have for my Abence:
Perhaps I am mitaken here,
My Heart may too much Credit give;
But Damon, you can charm my Fear,
And oon my Error undeceive.

But I will not diturb my Repoe at this time, with a Jealouie, which, I hope is altogether frivolous and vain; but begin to intruct you in the Myteries of my Watch: Cat then your Eyes upon the Eighth Hour in the Morning, which is the Hour I would have you begin to wake: You will find there written.

div.head: Eight a Clock.
Agreeable Reverie.
div.p: DO not rie yet; you may find Thoughts agreeable enough, when you awake, to entertain you longer in Bed. And 'tis in that hour you ought to recollect all the Dreams you had in the Night. If you have dream'd any thing to my Advantage, confirm yourelf in that thought; but if to my Diadvantage, renounce it, and diown the injurious Dream. 'Tis in this Hour alo, that I give you leave to reflection all that I have ever aid and done, that has been mot obliging to you, and that gives you the mot tender Sentiments.

div.head: The Reflection.

lg.l: Remember Damon, while your mind
Reflects on things that charm and pleae,
You give me Proofs that you are kind,
And et my doubting Soul at eae:
For when your Heart receives with Joy
The thoughts of Favours which I give,
My Smiles in vain I not imploy,
And on the Square we love and live.
Think then on all I ever did,
That e're was charming, e're was dear;
Let nothing from that Soul be hid,
Whoe Griefs and Joys I feel and hare.
All that your Love and Faith have ought,
All that your Vows aad Sighs have bought,
Now render preent to your Thought.

div.p:
And for what's to come, I give you leave, Damon, to flatter your elf, and to expect, I hall till purue thoe Methods, whoe remembrance charms o well: But, if it be poible, conceive thee kind Thoughts between Sleeping and Waking, that all my too forward Complaiance, my Goodnes, and my Tendernes, which I confes to have for you, may pas for half Dreams; for 'tis mot certain,
That, though the Favours of the Fair
Are ever to the Lover dear,
Yet, let he hould reproach that eaie Flame,
That buys its Satisfaction with its Shame,
She ought but rarely to confes,
How much he finds of Tendernes;
Nicely to guard the yielding part,
And hide the hard-kept Secret in her Heart.

For, let me tell you Damon, though the Paion of a Woman of Honour be never o innocent, and the Lover never o dicreet and honet; her Heart feels I know not what of Reproach within, at the Reflection of any Favours he has allow'd him. For my part, I never call to mind the leat oft, or kind Word I have poken to Damon, without finding, at the ame intant, my Face cover'd over with Bluhes, and my Heart with enible Pain. I igh at the Remembrance of every Touch I have tol'n from his Hand, and have upbraided my Soul, which confees o much guilty Love, as that ecret deire of Touching him made appear. I am angry at the Dicovery, though I am pleas'd at the ame time, with the Satisfaction I take in doing o; and ever diorder'd at the remembrance of uch Arguments of too much Love. And thee unquiet Sentiments alone, are ufficient to perwade me, that our Sex cannot be reerv'd too much. And I have often, on thee occaions, aid to my elf,

lg.l: Though Damon every Vertue have,
With all that pleaes in his Form,
That can adorn the Just and Brave,
That can the coldest Boom warm;
Though Wit and Honour there abound;
Yet the Puruer's ne'r puru'd,
And when my Weaknes he has found,
His Love will ink to Gratitude:
While on the Asking Part he lives,
'Tis he th' Obliger is, who gives.
And he that, at one throw, the Stake has won,
Gives over Play, ince all the Stock is gone.
And what dull Gameter ventures certain Store,
With Loers, who can et no more.

div.head: Nine a Clock.
Deign to pleae no Body.
div.p: I Should continue to accue you of that Vice I have often done, that of Lazines, if you remain'd pat this Hour in Bed; 'tis time for you to rie; my Watch tells you 'tis Nine a Clock. Remember that I am abent, therefore do not take too much pains in dreing your elf, and etting your Peron off.

div.head: The Quetion.

lg.l: Tell me! What can he deign,
Who in his Mitres abence will be fine?
Why does he Cock, and Comb, and Dres?
Why is the Cravat-tring in print?
What does th' Embroyder'd Coat confes?
Why to the Glas this long Addres,
If there be nothing in't?
If no new Conquest is deign'd,
If no Beauty fill his Mind?
Let Fools and Fops, whoe Talents lie
In being neat, in being pruce,
Be drest, in vain, and tawdery;
With Men of Sence, 'tis out of ue:
The only Folly that Ditinction ets
Between the noiie flutt'ring Fools and Wits.
Remember, Iris is away;
And ighing, to your Valet cry,
Spare your Perfumes and Care, to day,
I have no buines to be gay,
Since Iris is not by.
I'll be all negligent in Dres,
And carce et off for Complaiance.
Put me on nothing that may pleae,
But only uch as may give no Offence.

div.p:
Say to your elf, as you are Dreing, Would it pleae Heaven, that I mightee Iris to day! But oh! 'tis impoible: Therefore all that I hall ee, will be but indifferent
Objects, ince 'tis Iris only that I wih to ee. And ighing, wiper to your elf:

div.head: The Sigh.
div.l: Ah! Charming Object of my wihing Thought!
Ah! Soft Idea of a ditant Blis!
That only art in Dreams and Fancy brought,
To give hort Intervals of Happines.
But when I waking, find thou abent art;
And with thee, all that I adore,
What Pains, what Anguih fills my Heart!
What Sadnes eizes me all o're!
All entertainments I neglect,
Since Iris is no longer there:
Beauty carce claims my bare Repect,
Since in the Throng I find not her.
Ah then! How vain it were to dres, and how,
Since all I wih to pleae, is abent now!
div.p:
'Tis with thee Thoughts, Damon, that your Mind ought to be employed, during your time of Dreing: And you are too knowing in Love, to be ignorant,
That when a Lover ceaes to be blet
With the dear Object he deires,
Ah! How indifferent are the ret!
How oon their Converation tires!
Though they a thouand Arts to pleae, invent,
Their Charms are dull, their Wit impertinent.

div.head: Ten a Clock.
Reading of Letters.
div.p: MY Cupid points you now to the Hour in which you ought to retire into your Cabinet, having already pat an Hour in Dreing; and for a Lover, who is ure not to appear before his Mitres, even that Hour is too much to be o employ'd. But I will think, you thought of nothing les than Dreing, while you were about it. Loe then no more Minutes, but open your Scrutore, and read over ome of thoe Billets you have receiv'd from me. Oh! what Pleaures a Lover feels about his Heart, in reading thoe from a Mitres he entirely loves!

div.head: The Joy.

lg.l: Who, but a Lover can expres
The Joys, the Pants, the Tendernes,
That the oft Amorous Soul invades,
While the dear Billet-doux he reads?
Raptures Divine the Heart o're-flow;
Which he that Loves not, cannot know.
A thouand Tremblings, thouand Fears,
The hort-breath'd Sighs, the joyful Tears;
The Tranport, where the Love's confet,
The Change, where Coldnes is expret;
The diff'ring Flames the Lover burns,
As thoe are hy, or kind, by Turns.

div.p: However you find 'em Damon, contrue 'em all to my Advantage: Poibly, ome of 'em have an Air of Coldnes, omething different from that Softnes they are uually too amply fill'd with; but where you find they have, believe there, that Sence of Honour, and my Sexes Modety, guided my Hand a little, againt the Inclinations of my Heart; and that it was a kind of an Atonement, I believed, I ought to make, for omething I feared, I had aid too kind, and too obliging before: But where-ever you find that, top that Check in my Career of Love; you will be ure to find omething that follows it to favour you, and deny that unwilling Impoition upon my Heart; which, let you hould mitake, Love hews himelf in Smiles again, and flatters more agreeably, didaining the Tyranny of Honour, and Rigid Cutom, that Impoition on our Sex; and will, in pight of me, let you ee, he Reigns abolutely in my Soul.

The reading my Billet-doux may detain you an Hour; I have had Goodnes enough to write you enough to entertain you o long, at leat, and ometimes reproach my elf for it; but, contrary to all my Scruples, I find my elf dipos'd to give you thoe frequent Marks of my Tendernes. If yours be o great as you expres it, you ought to kis my Letters a Thouand times, you ought to read them with Attention, and weigh every Word, and value every Line. A Lover may receive a Thouand indearing Words from a Mitres, more eaily than a Billet. One ays a great many kind Things of
coure to a Lover, which one is not willing to write, or to give tetify'd under one's Hand, Sign'd and Seal'd. But when once a Lover has brought his Mitres to that degree of Love, he ought to aure himelf, he loves not at the common Rate.

div.head: Love's Witnes.

lg.l: Slight unpremediated Words are born
By every common Wind, into the Air;
Carelely utter'd, die as oon as born,
And in one intant, give both Hope and Fear:
Breathing all Contraries with the ame Wind,
According to the Caprice of the Mind.
But Billets-doux are contant Witnees,
Subtantial Records to Eternity;
Just Evidence, who the Truth confes;
On which, the Lover afely may rely:
They're erious Thoughts, digeted and reolv'd;
And last, when Words are into Clouds devolv'd.

div.p: I will not doubt, but you give Credit to all that is Kind in my Letters; and I will believe, you find a Satisfaction in the Entertainment they give you, and that the Hour of Reading 'em is not diagreeable to you. I cou'd wih, your Pleaure might be extream, even to the Degree of uffering the Thought of my Abence not to diminih any part of it. And I cou'd wih too, at the End of your Reading, you wou'd igh with Pleaure, and ay to your elf,—

div.head: The Tranport.

lg.l: O Iris! While you thus can charm,
While at this Ditance, you can wound and warm;
My abent Torments I will bles and bare,
That give me uch dear Proofs, how kind you are.
Preent, the valu'd Store was only een:
Now I am rifling the bright Mas within.
Every dear pat and happy Day,
When Languihing at Iris Feet, I lay;
When all my Prayers, and all my Tears cou'd move
No more then her Permiion, I hould love:
Vain with my Glorious Detiny,
I thought, beyond, carce any Heaven cou'd be.
But, Charming Maid, now I am taught,
That Abence has a thouand Joys to give,
On which, the Lovers, preent, never thought,
That recompence the Hours we grieve.
Rather by Abence let me be undone,
Than forfeit all the Pleaures that has won.

div.p: With this little Rapture, I wih you wou'd finih the Reading my Letters, hut your Scrutore, and quit your Cabinet; for my Love leads to Eleven a Clock.

div.head: Eleven a Clock.
The Hour to Write in.
div.p:
IF my Watch did not inform you, 'tis now time to Write: I believe, Damon, your Heart wou'd; and tell you alo, that I hould take it kindly, if you would employ a whole Hour that way; and that you hould never loe an Occaion of writing to me, ince you are aured of the Welcome I give your Letters. Perhaps you will ay, an Hour is too much, and that 'tis not the Mode to write long Letters. I grant you, Damon, when we write thoe indifferent ones, of Gallantry in coure, or neceary Compliment; the handom comprizing of which, in the fewet words, renders 'em the mot agreeable: But in Love we have a Thouand foolih things to ay, that, of themelves, bear no great Sound, but have a mighty Sence in Love; for there is a peculiar Eloquence, natural alone to a Lover, and to be undertood by no other Creature: To thoe, Words have a thouand Graces and Sweetnees; which, to the Unconcerned, appears Meannes, and Eaie Sene, at the bet. But, Damon, you and I are none of thoe ill Judges of the Beauties of Love; we can penetrate beyond the Vulgar, and perceive the fine Soul in every Line, through all the humble Dres of Phrae; when poibly, they who think they dicern it bet in florid Language, do not ee it at all. Love was not born, or bred
in Courts, but Cottages; and nurs'd in Groves and Shades, miles on the Plains, and wantons in the Streams; all unador'd, and harml •••
Therefore, Damon, do not conult your Wit in this Affair, but Love alone; and peak all that he and Nature taught you, and let the fine Things you learn in Schools alone: Make ue of thoe Flowers you have gather'd there, when you convere with States-men and the Gown. Let Iris poes your Heart in all its imple Innocence, that's the bet Eloquence to her that loves; and this is my Intruction to a Lover, that would ucceed in his Amours; for I have a Heart very difficult to pleae, and this is the nearet Way to it.

div.head: Advice to Lovers.

lg.l: Lovers,-if you would gain a Heart,
Of Damon learn to win the Prize;
He'll hew you all its tend'ret Part,
And where its greatest Danger lies.
The Magazine of its Didain;
Where Honour, feebly guarded, does remain.
If preent, do but little ay;
Enough the ilent Lover peaks:
But wait, and igh, and gaze all Day:
Such Rhet'rick, more than Languages takes.
For Words, the dullest way do move;
And utter'd more to hew your Wit, than Love.
Let your Eyes tell her of your Heart:
Its Story is, for Words, too delicate.
Souls thus exchange, and thus impart,
And all their Secrets can relate.
A Tear, a broken Sigh, he'll undertand;
Or the oft trembling Preings of the Hand.
Or if your Pain must be in Words exprest,
Let 'em fall gently, unaur'd, and low;
And where they fail, your Looks may tell the rest.
Thus Damon poke, and I was conquer'd o.
The witty Talker has mitook his Art;
The modest Lover only charms the Heart.
Thus, while all Day you gazing it,
And fear to peak, and fear your Fate,
You more Advantages by Silence get,
Than the gay forward Youth, with all his Prate.
Let him be ilent here; but when away,
Whatever Love can dictate, let him ay.
There let the bahful Soul unvail,
And give a Looe to Love and Truth.
Let him improve the amorous Tale,
With all the Force of Words, and Fire of Youth.
There all, and any thing, let him expres;
Too long he cannot write, too much confes.

div.p: O Damon! How well have you made me undertand this oft Pleaure? You know my Tendernes too well, not to be enible, how I am charmed with your agreeable long Letters.

div.head: The Invention.
div.l: Ah! he who firt found out the Way
Souls to each other to convey,
Without dull Speaking, ure mut be
Something above Humanity.
Let the fond World in vain dipute,
And the firt Sacred Mystery impute
Of Letters, to the Learned Brood;
And of the Glory, cheat a God:
'Twas Love alone that firt the Art eay'd,
And Pyche was the firt fair yielding Maid
That was by the dear Billet-doux betray'd.
div.p:
It is an Art too ingenious to have been found out by Man, and too neceary to Lovers, not to have been invented by the God of Love himelf. But, Damon, I do not pretend to exact from you thoe Letters of Gallantry which, I have told you, are filled with nothing but fine Thoughts, and writ with all the Arts of Wit and Subtilty: I would have yours till, all tender unaffected Love, Words unchoen, Thoughts untudied, and Love unfeigned. I had rather find more Softnes than Wit, in your Paion; more of Nature than of Art; more of the Lover than the Poet. Nor would I have you write any of thoe little hort Letters that are read over in a minute; in Love, long Letters bring a long Pleaure: Do not trouble yourelf to make 'em fine, or write a great deal of Wit and Sence in a few Lines; that is the Notion of a witty Billet, in any Affair but that of Love:
And have a Care, rather to avoid thee Graces to a Mitres; and aure yourelf, dear Damon, that what pleaes the Soul pleaes the Eye, and the Largenes or Bulk of your Letter hall never offend me; and that I only am dipleaed when I find them mall. A Letter is ever, the bet and mot powerful Agent to a Mitres, it almot always perwades; 'tis always renewing little Impreions, that poibly, otherwie, Abence would deface. Make ue then, Damon, of your Time while it is given you, and thank me, that I permit you to write to me: Perhaps I hall not always continue in the Humor of uffering you to do o; and it may o happen, by ome Turn of Chance and Fortune, that you may be deprived, at the ame time, both of my Preence, and of the Means of ending to me. I will believe, that uch an Accident would be a great Misfortune to you, for I have often hear •
you ay, that, To make the mot happy <>
ver uffer Martyrdom, one need only for <>
him Seeing, Speaking, and Writing to <>
Object he loves. Take all the Advanta ••
then you can, you cannot give me too often, Marks too powerful of your Paion: Writ •
therefore, during this Hour, every Day, <>
give you leave to believe, that while you do o, you are Serving me the mot Obligingly and Agreeably you can, while abent; and, that you are giving me a Remedy againt all Grief, Uneaines, Melancholy, and Depair: Nay, if you exceed your Hour, you need not be aham'd. The Time you employ in this kind Devoir, id the Time that I hall be grateful for, and, no
doubt, will recompene it. You ought not, however, to neglect Heaven for me; I will give you time for your Devotion, for my Watch tells you, 'tis time to go to the Temple.

div.head: Twelve a Clock.
Indipenible Duty.
div.p: THere are certain Duties, which one ought never to neglect: That of Adoring the Gods, is of this nature; and which we ought to pay, from the bottom of our Hearts: And that, Damon, is the only time, I will dipene with your not thinking on me. But I would not have you go to one of thoe Temples, where the celebrated Beauties, and thoe that make a Profeion of Gallantry, go; and which come thither, only to ee, and be een; and whither they repair, more to hew their Beauty and Dres, than to honour the Gods. If you will take my Advice, and oblige my Wih, you hall go to thoe that are leat frequented; and you hall appear there, like a Man, that has a perfect Veneration for all things Sacred.

lg.l: Damon, if your Heart, and Flame,
You wih, hould always be the ame,
Do not give it leave to rove,
Nor expoe it to new Harms:
E're you think on't, you may love,
If you gaze on Beauty's Charms.
If with me, you wou'd not part,
Turn your Eyes into your Heart.
If you find a new Deire,
In your eaie Soul take Fire,
From the tempting Ruine fly;
Think it faithles, think it bae:
Fancy oon will fade, and die,
If you wiely ceae to gaze.
Lovers hould have Honour too,
Or they pay but half Love's due.
Do not to the Temple go,
With deign to gaze, or how:
What e're Thoughts you have abroad,
Though you can deceive elewhere,
There's no feigning with your God;
Souls hould be all perfect there.
The Heart that's to the Altar brought,
Only Heaven hould fill its Thought.
Do not your ober Thoughts perplex,
By gazing on the Ogling Sex:
Or if Beauty call your Eyes,
Do not on the Object dwell;
Guard your Heart from the Surprize,
By thinking Iris doth excel.
Above all earthly Things, I'd be,
Damon, most belov'd by thee:
And only Heaven must Rival me.

div.head: One a Clock.
Forc'd Entertainment.
div.p: I Perceive it will be very difficult for you to quit the Temple, without being urrounded with Complements, from People of Ceremony, Friends, and News-mongers, and everal of thoe orts of Perons, who afflict and buie themelves, and rejoyce at a hundred things, they have no Interet in: Coquets and Politicians, who make it the Buines of their whole Lives, to gather all the News of the Town; adding or diminihing, according to the Stock of their Wit and Invention, and preading it all abroad, to the believing Fools and Goips; and perplexing every-body with a hundred ridiculous Novels, which they pas off for Wit and Entertainment: Or ele, ome of thoe Recounters of Adventures, that are always telling of Intrigues, and that make a Secret, to a hundred People, of a Thouand foolih things they have heard: Like a certain Pert and Impertinent Lady of the Town, whoe Youth and Beauty being pat, ets up for Wit, to uphold a feeble Empire over idle Hearts; and whoe Character is this,—

div.head: The Coquet.

lg.l: Milinda, who had never been
Eteem'd a Beauty at Fifteen,
Always Amorous was, and Kind:
To every Swain he lent an Ear.
Free as Air, but Fale as Wind;
Yet none complain'd, She was evere.
She eas'd more than he made complain;
Was always Singing, Pert, and Vain.
Where-e'er the Throng was, he was een,
And wept the Youths along the Green.
With equal Grace he flatter'd all,
And fondly proud of all Addres;
Her Smiles invite, her Eyes do call,
And her vain Heart her Looks confes.
She Rallies this, to that he Bow'd,
Was Talking ever, Laughing loud.
On every ide he makes Advance,
And every where a Confidance.
She tells for Secrets all he knows,
And all to know he does pretend:
Beauty in Maids he treats as Foes;
But every handom Youth, as Friend.
Scandal till paes off for Truth;
And Noie and Nonence, Wit and Youth.
Coquet all o'er, and every part,
Yet wanting Beauty, even of Art.
Herds with the gly, and the Old;
And plays the Critick on the ret
Of Men, the Bahful, and the Bold;
Either, and all, by Turns, likes best:
Even now, tho' Youth be languiht, he
Sets up for Love, and Gallantry.

div.p:
This ort of Creature, Damon, is very dangerous; not that I fear you will quander away a Heart upon her, but your Hours; for, in pight of you, he'll detain you with a thouand Impertinencies, and eternal Tattle. She paes for a judging Wit; and there is nothing o troubleome, as uch a Pretender. She, perhaps, may get ome Knowledge of our Correpondence; and then, no doubt, will improve it, to my diadvantage. Poibly he may rail at me; that is her Fahion, by the way of Friendly Speaking; and an Aukward Commendation, the mot effectual Way of Defaming, and Traducing. Perhaps he tells you, in a cold Tone, that you are a happy Man, to be belov'd by me: That Iris, indeed, is handome; and he wonders, he has no more Lovers; but the Men are not of her Mind; if they were, you hould have more Rivals. She commends my Face, but that I have blue Eyes, and 'tis pity my Complexion is no better: My Shape, but too much inclining to Fat. Cries—She would charm infinitely with her Wit, but that he knows too well, he is Mitres of it. And concludes,—But all together, he is well enough.—Thus he runs on, without giving you leave to edge in a Word, in my Defence; and ever and anon, crying
up her own Conduct, and Management: Tell you, how he is oppret with Lovers, and fatigu'd with Addrees; and recommending her elf, at every turn, with a perceivable Cunning: And all the while, is Jilting you of your good Opinion; which he would buy, at the Price of any Body's Repoe, or her own Fame, tho' but for the Vanity of adding to the Number of her Lovers. When he ees a new Spark, the firt thing he does, he enquires into his Etate: If he find it uch, as may (if the Coxcomb be well manag'd) upply her Vanity, he makes Advances to him, and applies herelf to all thoe little Arts he uually makes ue of, to gain her Fools; and, according to his Humour, drees and affects her own. But, Damon, ince I point to no particular Peron, in this Character, I will not name who you hould avoid; but all of this ort, I conjure you, whereoever you find 'em. But if unlucky Chance throw you in their Way, hear all they ay, without Credit, or Regard, as far as Decency will uffer you: Hear 'em, without approving their Foppery: and hear 'em, without giving 'em Caue to cenure you. But 'tis o much Time lot, to liten to all the Novels, this ort of People will perplex you with; whoe Buines is to be idle; and who even tire themelves with their own Impertinencies. And be aur'd, after all, there is nothing they can tell you, that is worth your knowing. And, Damon, a perfect Lover never asks any News, but of the Maid he loves.

lg.l: Damon, If your Love be True,
To the Heart that you poes,
Tell me; What have you to do
Where you have no Tendernes?
Her Affairs who cares to learn,
For whom he has not ome Concer • ?
If a Lover fain would know
If the Object lov'd be true,
Let her but indutrious be
To watch his Curioity;
Tho' ne'r o cold his Quetions eem,
They come from warmer Thoughts within.
When I hear a Swain enquire
What gay Melinda does to live,
I conclude, there us ome Fire
In a Heart inquiitive;
Or 'tis, at leat, the Bill that's et
To hew, The Heart is to be Let.

div.head: Two a Clock.
Dinner time.
div.p:
LEave all thoe fond Entertainments, or you will dioblige me, and make Dinner wait for you; for my Cupid tells you, 'tis that Hour. Love does not pretend to make you loe that; nor is it my Province to order you your Diet. Here I give you a perfect Liberty, to do what you pleae: And poibly, 'tis the only Hour in the whole Four and twenty, that I will abolutely reign you, or dipence with your even o much as Thinking on me. 'Tis true, in eating yourelf at Table, I would not have you placed over-againt a very Beautiful Object, for in uch a one there are a thouand little Graces, in Speaking, Looking, and Laughing, that fail not to Charm if one gives way to the Eyes, to gaze and wander that way; in which, perhaps, in pight of you, you will find a Pleaure; And while you do o, though without Deign or Concern, you give the fair Charmer a ort of Vanity, in believing you have placed yourelf there, only for the Advantage of Looking on her; and aumes a hundred little Graces and Affectations, which are not Natural to her, to compleat a Conquet, which he believes o well begun already. She oftens her Eyes, and weetens her Mouth; and in <> , puts on another Air, than when he had no Deign; and when you did not, by your
continual looking on her, rouze her Vanity, and increae her eaie Opinion of her own Charms. Perhaps he knows, I have ome Interet in your Heart; and Prides herelf, at leat, with believing, he has attracted the Eyes of my Lover, if not his Heart; and thinks it eaie to vanquih the Whole, if he pleaes; and triumphs over me in her ecret Imaginations. Remember, Damon, that while you act thus in the Company and Converation of other Beauties, that every Look, or Word you give in favour of 'em, is an Indignity to my Reputation; and, which you cannot uffer, if you love me truly, and with Honour: And, aure yourelf, o much Vanity as you inpire in her, o much Fame you rob me of; for whatever Praies you give another Beauty, o much you take away from mine. Therefore, if you Dine in Company, do as others do: Be generally Civil, not applying yourelf, by Words, or Looks to any particular Peron: Be as gay as you pleae: Talk and laugh with all, for this is not the Hour for Chagrin.

lg.l: My Damon, tho' I tint your Love,
I will not tint your Appetite;
That I would have you till improve,
By every new, and freh Delight.
Feast, till Apollo hides his Head;
Or drink the am'rous God to Thetis Bed.
Be like yourelf: All witty, gay!
And o're the Bottle bles the Board,
The litening round will, all the Day,
Be charm'd, and pleas'd with every Word,
Tho' Venus Son inpire your Wit,
'Tis the Selenian God best utters it.
Here talk of ev'ry thing but me,
Since ev'ry Thing you ay with Grace.
If not dipos'd your Humour be,
And you'd this Hour in ilence pas;
Since omething must the Subject prove
Of Damon's Thoughts; let it be me, and Love.
But, Damon, this enfranchis'd Hour,
No Bounds, or Laws, will I impoe;
But leave it wholly in your Pow'r,
What Humour to refue, or chue.
I Rules precribe, but to your Flame;
For I, your Mitres, not Phyician, am.

div.head: Three a Clock.
Viits to Friends.
div.p:
DAmon, my Watch is juter than you imagine; it would not have you live retired and olitary, but permits you to go, and make Viits. I am not one of thoe that believe, Love and Friendhip cannot find a Place in one and
the ame Heart: And that Man would be very unhappy, who, as oon as he had a Mitres, hould be obliged to renounce the Society of his Friends. I mut confes, I would not that you hould have o much Concern for them, as you have for me; for I have heard a ort of a Proverb, that ays, He cannot be very fervent in Love, who is not a little cold in Friendhip. You are not ignorant, that when Love etablihes himelf in a Heart, he reigns a Tyrant there, and will not uffer even Friendhip, if it pretend to hare his Empire there.

div.head: Cupid.
div.l: Love is a God, whoe charming Sway
Both Heaven, and Earth, and Seas obey.
A Power that will not mingled be
With any dull Equality.
Since firt from Heaven, which gave him Birth,
He rul'd the Empire of the Earth,
Jealous of Sov'raign Power, he rules,
And will be Abolute in Souls.
div.p:
I hould be very angry; if you had any of thoe Friendhips, which one ought to deire in a Mitres only; for many times it happens, that you have Sentiments a little too tender for thoe Amiable Perons; and many times Love and Friendhip are o confounded together, that one cannot eaily dicern one from t'other. I have een a Man flatter himelf with an Opinion, that he had but an Eteem for a Woman, when by ome Turn of Fortune in her Life, as Marrying,
or Receiving the Addrees of Men, he has found, by Spight and Jealouies within, that that was Love, which he before took for Complaiance, or Friendhip. Therefore have a Care; for uch Amities are dangerous. Not but that a Lover may have Fair and Generous Female-Friends, whom he ought to viit; and perhaps, I hou'd eteem you les, if I did not believe you were valued by uch, if I were perfectly aured they were Friends, and not Lovers. But have a Care, you hide not a Mitres under this Veil, or that you gain not a Lover by this Pretence: For you may begin with Friendhip, and end with Love; and I hou'd be equally afflicted, hou'd you give it, or receive it. And though you charge our Sex with all the Vanity; yet I often find Nature to have given you as large a Portion of that Common Crime, which you wou'd huffle off, as aham'd to own; and are as fond and vain of the Imagination of a Conquet, as any Coquet of us all; though, at the ame time, you depie the Victim, you think it adds a Trophy to your Fame. And I have een a Man dres, and trick, and adjut his Looks and Mien, to make a Viit to a Woman he lov'd, nor ever cou'd love, not as for thoe he made to his Mitres; and only for the Vanity of making a Conquet upon a Heart, even unworthy of the little Pains he has taken about it. And what is this but buying Vanity at the Expence of Sence and Eae; and with Fatigue, purchae the Name of a Conceited Fop, beides that of a Dihonet Man? For he who takes Pains to make himelf Belov'd, only to pleae his
curious Humour, tho' he hould ay nothing that tends to it, more than by his Looks, his Sighs, and now and then breaking into Praies and Commendations of the Object, by the Care he takes, to appear well dret before her, and in good order; he lyes in his Looks, he deceives with his Mien and Fahion, and cheats with every Motion, and every Grace he puts on: He cozens when he Sings, or Dances; he diembles when he Sighs; and every thing he does, that wilfully gains upon her, is Malice propene, Baenes, and Art below a Man of Sence, or Vertue: And yet thee Arts, thee Coz'nages, are the common Practices of the Town. What's this but that damnable Vice, of which they o reproach our Sex; that of Jilting for Hearts? And 'tis in vain, that my Lover, after uch foul Play, hall think to appeae me, with aying, He did it to try how eaie he cou'd Conquer, and of how great Force his Charms were: And why hou'd I be angry, if all the Town lov'd him, ince he lov'd none but Iris? Oh foolih Pleaure! How little Sence goes to the making of uch a Happines? And how little Love mut he have for one particular Peron, who wou'd wih to inpire it into all the World, and yet himelf pretend to be inenible? But this (Damon) is rather what is but too much practied by your Sex, than any Guilt I charge on you; tho' Vanity be an Ingredient that Nature very eldom omits in the Compoition of either Sex; and you may be allow'd a Tincture of it at leat. And, perhaps, I am not wholly exempt from this Leaven in my Nature, but accue myelf ometimes of finding a ecret
Joy of being ador'd, tho' I even hate my Worhipper. But if any uch Pleaure touch my Heart, I find it at the ame time bluhing in my Cheeks with a guilty Shame; which oon checks the petty Triumph, and I have a Vertue at oberer Thoughts, that I find urmounts my Weaknes and Indicretion; and I hope Damon finds the ame: For, hould he have any of thoe Attachments, I hould have no Pity for him.

lg.l: Damon, if you wou'd have me true,
Be you my Preident and Guide:
Example ooner we purue,
Than the dull Dictates of our Pride.
Precepts of Vertue are too weak an Aim:
'Tis Demontration, that can best reclaim.
Shew me the Path you'd have me go;
With uch a Guide, I cannot tray:
What you approve, whate'er you do,
It is but just I bend the Way.
If true, my Honour favours your Deign:
If fale, Revenge is the Reult of mine,
A Lover true, a Maid incere,
Are to be priz'd, as Things Divine:
'Tis Jutice makes the Bleing dear;
Jutice of Love, without Deign.
And he that Reigns not in a Heart alone,
Is never afe, or eaie, on her Throne.

div.head: Four a Clock.
General Converation.
div.p:
IN this Viiting-Hour, many People will happen to meet at one and the ame time together, in a Place: And as you make not Viits to Friends, to be ilent, you ought to enter into Converation with 'em; but thoe Converations ought to be General, and of General Things; for there is no neceity of making your Friend the Confident of your Amours: 'Twould infinitely dipleae me, to hear you have reveal'd to them, all that I have repos'd in you; tho' Secrets never o trivial, yet, ince utter'd between Lovers, they deerve to be priz'd at a higher rate: For what can hew a Heart more indifferent and indicreet, than to declare in any Fahion, or with Mirth, or Joy, the tender Things a Mitres ays to a Lover; and which poibly, related at Second Hand, bear not the ame Sence, becaue they have not the ame Sound, and Air, they had originally, when they came from the oft Heart of her, who igh'd 'em firt to her lavih Lover. Perhaps they are told again with Mirth, or Joy, unbecoming their Character and Buines; and then they loe their Graces; (for Love is the mot Solemn Thing in Nature, and the mot unuiting with Gaiety.) Perhaps the oft Expreions uit not o well the harher Voice of the Maculine Lover, whoe Accents were not
form'd for o much Tendernes; at leat, not of that ort; for Words that have the ame Meaning, are alter'd from their Sence, by the leat Tone, or Accent of the Voice; and thoe proper, and fitted to my Soul, are not, poibly, o to yours, tho' both have the ame Efficacy upon us: yours upon my Heart, as mine upon yours; and both will be miundertood by the unjudging World. Beides this, there is a Holines in Love that's true, that ought not to be prophan'd: And as the Poet truly ays, at the latter end of an Ode; of which, I will recite the whole.

div.head: The Invitation.

lg.l: Aminta, fear not to confes,
The charming Secret of thy Tendernes:
That which a Lover can't conceal,
That which, to me, thou hould'st reveal;
And is but what thy lovely Eyes expres.
Come, whiper to my panting Heart,
That heaves, and meets thy Voice half way:
That guees what thou wou'dst impart,
And languihes for what thou hast to ay.
Confirm my trembling Doubt, and make me know,
Whence all thee Bluhings, and thee Sighings flow.
Why dost thou cruple to unfold
A Mytery that does my Life concern?
If thou ne'er peak'st, it will be told;
For Lovers all things can dicern,
From every Look, from every bahful Grace,
That till ucceed each other in thy Face,
I hall the dear tranporting Secret learn:
But 'tis a Pleaure not to be exprest,
To hear it by the Voice confest,
When oft Sighs breathe it on my panting Breast.
All calm and ilent is the Grove,
Whoe hading Boughs reist the Day:
Here thou may'st bluh, and talk of Love,
While only Winds, unheeding, tay,
That will not bear the Sound away:
While I, with olemn awful Joy,
All my attentive Faculties employ;
Lit'ning to every valu'd Word;
And in my Soul, the Sacred Treaure hoard.
There, like ome Mytery Divine,
The wondrous Knowledge I'll enhrine.
Love can his Joys no longer call his own,
Than the dear Secret's kept unknown.

div.p:
There is nothing more true, than thoe two lat Lines; and that Love ceaes to be a Pleaure, when it ceaes to be a Secret, and one you ought to keep acred: For the World, who never makes a right Judgment of Things, will miinterpret Love, as they do Religion; every one judging it, according to the Notion he had of it, or the Talent of his Sence. Love, as a great Duke aid, is like Apparitions; every one talks of 'em, but few have een 'em: Every Body thinks himelf capable of undertanding Love, and that he is a Mater in the Art of it; when there is nothing o nice, or difficult, to be rightly comprehended; and indeed, cannot be, but to a Soul very delicate. Nor will he make himelf known to the Vulgar: There mut be an
uncommon Finenes in the Mind, that contains him; the ret, he only viits in as many Diguies, as there are Dipoitions and Natures; where he makes but a hort tay, and is gone. He can fit himelf to all Hearts, being the greatet Flatterer in the World: And he poees every one with a Confidence, that they are in the Number of his Elect; and they think, they know him perfectly, when nothing but the Spirits refin'd, poes him in his Excellency. From this difference of Love, in different Souls, proceeds thoe odd fantatick Maxims, which o many hold of o different Kinds: And this makes the mot innocent Pleaures pas oftentimes for Crimes, with the unjudging Crowd, who call themelves Lovers: And you will have your Paion cenur'd, by as many as you hall dicover it to, and as many everal Ways. I advie you therefore (Damon) to make no Confidents of your Amours; and believe, that Silence has, with me, the mot powerful Charm.

'Tis alo in thee Converations, that thoe indicreetly civil Perons often are who think to oblige a good Man, by letting him know he is belov'd by ome one or other; and making him undertand how many good Qualities he is Mater of, to render him agreeable to the Fair Sex, if he wou'd but advance where Love and good Fortune calls; and that a too contant Lover loes a great part of his time, which might be manag'd to more Advantage, ince Youth hath o hort a Race to run: By this, and a thouand the like indecent Complaiances, give him a Vanity, that uits not with that Dicretion,
which has hitherto acquir'd him o good a Reputation. I wou'd not have you (Damon) act on thee Occaions, as many of the eaie Sparks have done before you, who receive uch Weaknes and Flattery for Truth; and paing it off with a Smile, uffer 'em to advance in Fol

div.head: Five a Clock.
Dangerous Viits.
div.p:
I Foreee, or fear, that thee buie, impertinent Friends will oblige you to <…>
Ladies of their Acquaintance, or <…> My Watch does not forbid you. Yet I mut tell you, I apprehend Danger in uch Viits, <> I fear, you will have need of all your <> and Precaution, in thee Encounters. That you may give me no Caue to upect you, perhaps you will argue, that Civility obliges you to't: If I were aur'd, there wou'd no other Deign be carried on, I hou'd believe it were to advance an amorous Prudence too far, to forbid you. Only keep yourelf upon your Guard; for the Buines of mot part of the Fair Sex, is, to eek only the Conquet of Hearts: All their Civilities are but o many Interets; and they do nothing without Deign. And in uch Converations, there is always a Je ne cay quoy; that is fear'd; epecially when Beauty is accompanied with Youth and Gaiety; and which they aume upon all Occaions that may erve their Turn. And I confes, 'tis not an eaie matter to be jut in thee Hours and Converations: The mot certain Way of being o, is to imagine I read all your Thoughts, oberve all your Looks,
<> hear all your Words.

div.head: The Caution.

lg.l: My Damon, if your Heart be kind,
Do not too long with Beauty tay;
For there are certain Moments, when the Mind
Iss hurry'd, by the Force of Charms, away.
<…> , a Minute Critical there lies,
<…> on Love, and takes you by Surprize.
• Lover pleas'd with Contancy,

l.U: till as if the Maid he lov'd were by:

lg.l: <> if his Actions were in View;
As if his Steps he did purue:
Or that his very Soul he knew.
<…> ; for tho' I am not preent there,
My Love, my Genius, waits you every-where.

div.p:
I am very much pleas'd with the Remedy, you ay, you make ue of to defend yourelf from the Attacks that Beauty gives your Heart; which in one of your Billets, you aid was this,
<> to this purpoe:

div.head: The Charm for Contancy.
div.l: <> to keep my Soul entire, and true,
It thinks, each Moment of the Day, on you.
And when a charming Face I ee,
That does all other Eyes incline,
It has no influence on me:
I think it ev'n deform'd to thine.
My Eyes, my Soul, and Sene, regardles move
To all, but the dear Object of my Love.
div.p:
But (Damon) I know all Lovers are naturally Flatterers, though they do not think o themelves; becaue every one makes a Sene of Beauty according to his own Fancy. But perhaps you will ay in your own Defence, That 'tis not Flattery to ay, an unbeautiful Woman it beautiful, if he that ays o believes he is o. I hou'd be content to acquit you of the <> , provided you allow me the lat: And if I appear charming in Damon's Eyes, I am not fond of the Approbation of any other. 'Tis enough the World thinks me not altogether diagreeable, to jutifie his Choice; but let your good Opinion give what Increae it pleaes to my Beauty; though your Approbation give me a Pleaure, it hall not a Vanity; and I am contented, that Damon hould think me a Beauty, without thy believing I am one. 'Tis not to draw new Aurances, and new Vows from you, that I peak this; though Tales of Love are the only ones we deire to hear often told, and which never the the Hearers, if addret to themelves: But 'tis not to this End, I now eem to doubt what you ay to my Advantage: No, my Heart knows no Diguie, nor can diemble one Thought of it to Damon; 'tis all incere and honet as his Wih: 'Tis therefore it tells you, it does not credit every thing you ay; though I believe, you ay abundance of Truths, in a great Part of my Character. But when you advance to that, which my own Sene, my Judgment, or my Glas cannot perwade me to believe; you mut give me leave either to believe you think me vain enough to credit you, or pleas'd that your
Sentiments and mine are differing in this Point. But I doubt, I may rather reply in ome Veres, a Friend of yours and mine ent to a Peron, he thought, had but indifferent Sentiments for her; yet, who nevertheles flatter'd her, becaue he imagin'd he had a very great Eteem for him. She is a Woman that, you know, naturally hates
<> : On the other ide, he was extreamly di •• isfy'd, and uneaie at his Opinion, of his being more in her Favour than he deir'd he hou'd believe. So that one Night, having left her full of Pride and Anger, he next Morning ent him thee Veres, intead of a Billet-doux.

div.head: The Defiance.

lg.l: By Heaven 'tis fale; I am not vain;
And rather wou'd the Subject be
Of your Indifference, or Didain,
Than Wit, or Raillery.
Take back the trifling Praie you give,
And pas it on ome eaier Fool,
Who may th' injuring Wit believe,
That turns her into Ridicule.
Tell her, he's witty, fair, and gay;
With all the Charms that can ubdue:
Perhaps he'll credit what you ay:
But cure me, if I do.
If your Diverion you deign,
On my good Nature you have prest:
Or if you do intend it mine.
You have mitook the Jest.
Philander, fly that guilty Art:
Your charming, facil Wit will find,
It cannot play on a Heart,
That is incere and kind.
For Wit with Softnes does reide,
Good Nature is with Pity tor'd;
But Flatt'ry's the Reult of Pride,
And fawns to be Ador'd.
Nay, even when you mile and bow,
Tis to be render'd more compleat.
Your Wit, with ev'ry Grace you hew,
Is but a Popular Chat.
Laugh on, and call me Coxcomb—do;
And, your Opinion to improve,
Think, all you think of me, is true;
And to confirm it, wear I love.
Then, while you wreck my Soul with Pain,
And of a cruel Conquest boast,
'Tis you, Philander, that are vain,
And witty at my cost.

div.p:
Poibly, the angry Aminta, when he writ thee Veres, was more offended, that he believ'd himelf belov'd, than that he flatter'd; tho' he wou'd eem to make that a great part of the Qsuarrel, and Caue of her Reentment: For we are often in an Humour to eem more modet in that Point, than naturally we are; being too apt to have a favourable Opinion of
ourelves: And 'tis rather, the Effects of a Fear that we are flatter'd, than our own ill Opinion of the Beauty flatter'd; and that the Praier does not think o well of it, as we do our elves, or as at leat he wih he hou'd. Not but there are Grains of Allowance for the Temper of him that peaks: One Man's Humour is to talk much; and he may be permitted to enlarge upon the Praie he gives the Peron he pretends to, without being accus'd of much Guilt. Another hates to be Wordy; from uch an one, I have known one oft Expreion, one tender Thing, go as far as whole Days everlating Protetations, urg'd with Vows, and mighty Eloquence: And both the one, and the other, indeed, mut be allow'd in good Manners, to tretch the Complement beyond the Bounds of nice Truth: and we mut not wonder to hear a Man call a Woman a Beauty, when he is not Ugly; or another, a Great Wit, if he have but common Sence above the Vulgar; well Bred, when well Dret; and good Natur'd when Civil. And as I hou'd be very ridiculous, if I took all you aid for abolute Truth; o I hould be very unjut, not to allow you very incere, in almot all you aid beides; and thoe Things, the mot material to Love, Honour, and Friendhip.
