And for the ret (Damon) be it true, or fale, this believe: You peak with uch a Grace, that I cannot chue but Credit you; and find an infinite Pleaure in that Faith, becaue I lovu you: And if I cannot find the Cheat, I am contented you hou'd deceive me on, becaue yoe do it o agreeably.

div.head: Six a Clock.
Walk without Deign.
div.p: YOU yet have Time to Walk; and my Watch foreaw you cou'd not refue your Friends. You mut to the Park, or to the Mall; for the Seaon is fair and inviting; and all the young Beauties love thoe Places too well, not to be there. 'Tis there, that a Thouand Intrigues are carried on, and as many more deign'd. 'Tis there, that every one is et out for Conquet; and who aim at nothing les than Hearts. Guard yours well, my Damon; and be not always admiring what you ee. Do not, in paing by, igh 'em ilent Praies. Suffer not o much as a guilty Wih to approach your Thoughts, nor a heedful Glance to teal from your fine Eyes: Thoe are Regards, you ought only to have for her you Love. But oh! above all, have a Care of what you ay. You are not reproachable, if you hould remain ilent, all the Time of your Walk; nor wou'd thoe that know you, believe it the Effects of Dulnes, but Melancholy. And if any of your Friends ask you, Why you are o? I will give you leave to igh, and ay—

div.head: The Mall-Content.

lg.l: Ah? Wonder not, if I appear
Regardles of the Pleaures here;
Or that my Thoughts are thus confin'd
To the just Limits of my Mind.
My Eyes take no Delight to rove
O've all the miling Charmers of the Grove,
Since he is abent, whom they love.
Ask me not, Why the flow'ry Spring,
Or the gay little Birds that ing,
Or the young Streams, no more delight,
Or Shades, and Arbours can't invite?
Why the oft Murmurs of the Wind,
Within the thick grown Groves confin'd,
No more my Soul tranport, or cheer?
Since all that's charming,—Iris is not here;
Nothing eems glorious, nothing fair.
Then uffer me to wander thus,
With down-cast Eyes, and Arms a-cros.
Let Beauty unregarded go;
The Trees and Flowers, unheeded trow,
Let purling Streams neglected glide;
With all the Spring's adorning Pride.
'Tis Iris only Soul can give
To the dull Shades, and Plains, and make 'em thrive;
Nature, and my lost Joys retrieve.

div.p:
I do not, for all this, wholly confine your Eyes: You may look indifferently on all; but with a particular Regard on none. You may praie all the Beauties in general; but no ingle one too much. I will not exact from you, neither an entire Silence: There are a thouand Civilities you ought to pay to all your Friends and Acquaintance; and while I caution you of Actions, that may get you the Reputation of a Lover of ome of the Fair that haunt thoe Places; I wou'd not have you, by an unneceary,
and uncomplaiant Sullennes, gain that of a Peron too negligent, or moroe. I wou'd have you remis in no one Punctilio of Good Manners. I wou'd have you very jut, and pay all you owe; but in thee Affairs, be not over generous, and give away too much. In fine, You may Look, Speak, and Walk; but (Damon) do it all without Deign: And while you do o, remember, that Iris ent you this Advice.

div.head: The Warning.

lg.l: Take heed, my Damon, in the Grove,
Where Beauties, with Deign, do walk:
Take heed, my Damon, how you look and talk;
For there are Ambucades of Love.
The very Winds, that oftly blow,
Will help betray your eaie Heart;
And all the Flowers that bluhing grow;
The Shades above, and Rivulets below,
Will take the Victor's part.
Remember (Damon) all my Safety lies
In the just Conduct of your Eyes.
The Heart, by Nature, good and brave,
Is to thoe treacherous Guards, a Slave.
If they let in the fair detructive Foe,
Scarce Honour can defend her Noble Seat:
Ev'n he will be corrupted too,
Or driv'n to a Retreat.
The Soul is but the Cully to the Sight,
And must be pleas'd in what that takes delight.

div.p:
Therefore, examine your elf well; and conduct your Eyes, during this Walk, like a Lover,
that eeks nothing: And do not tay too long in thee places.

div.head: Seven a Clock.
Voluntary Retreat.
div.p:
TIS time to be weary; 'tis Night: Take Leave of your Friends, and retire Home. 'Tis in this Retreat, that you ought to recollect in your Thoughts, all the Actions of the Day; and all thoe Things, that you ought to give me an Account of, in your Letter: You cannot hide the leat Secret from me, without Treaon againt Sacred Love. For all the World agrees, that Confidence is one of the greatet Proofs of the Paion of Love; and that Lover, who refues this Confidence to the Peron he loves, is to be upected to love but very indifferently, and to think very poorly of the Sence and Generoity of his Mitres. But, that you may acquit your elf like a Man, and a Lover of Honour, and leave me no doubt upon my Soul; think of all you have done this Day, that I may have all the Story of it in your next Letter to me: But deal faithfully; and neither add, nor diminih, in your Relation; the Truth and Sincerity of your Confeion will attone, even for little Faults that you hall commit againt me, in ome of thoe Things you hall tell me: For if you have fail'd in any Point, or Circumtance of Love, I had much rather
hear it from you than another: For 'tis a ort of Repentance to accue yourelf; and wou'd be a Crime unpardonable, if you uffer me to hear it from any other: And be aur'd, while you confes it, I hall be indulgent enough to forgive you. The noblet Quality of Man, is Sincerity; and (Damon) one ought to have as much of it in Love, as in any other Buines of one's Life, notwithtanding the mot part of Men make no Account of it there; but will believe, there ought to be double Dealing, and an Art, practis'd in Love, as well as in War. • ut Oh! beware of that Notion.

lg.l: Sincerity! Thou greatest Good!
Thou Vertue, which o many boast!
And art o nicely undertood!
And often, in the Searching, lost.
For when we do approach thee near,
The fine Idea, fram'd of thee,
Appears not now o charming fair,
As the most ueful Flattery.
Thou hast no Glitt'ring to invite;
Nor tak'st the Lover at first Sight.
The modest Vertue huns the Croud,
And lives, like Vetals, in a Cell:
In Cities 'twill not be allow'd;
Nor takes Delight, in Courts to dwell.
'Tis Nonence with the Man of Wit;
And ev'n a Scandal to the Great;
For all the Young, and Fair, unfit;
And corn'd by wier Fops of State.
<…> as never known
To the fale <> , or the fal • r Gown.
And (Damon) tho' thy Noble Blood
Be most Illutr'ous, and Refin'd;
Tho' ev'ry Grace, and ev'ry Good
Adorn thy Peron, and thy Mind;
<> , if this Vertue hine not there;
(This God-like Vertue, which alone,
Wer't thou les Witty, Brave, or Fair,
Wou'd for all thee, les priz'd, attone:)
My tender Folly I'd controul,

l.U: corn the Conquest of thy Soul.

div.head: Eight a Clock.
Impatient Demands.
div.p:
AFter you have ufficiently recollected your elf of all the pat Actions of the Day, call your Page into your Cabinet, or him whom you truted with your lat Letter to me; where you ought to enquire of him a thouand things; and all of me. Ask impatiently; and be angry, if he anwers not your Curioity oon enough: Think that he has a Dreaming in his Voice, in thee Moments, more than at other times; and reproach him with Dulnes. For 'tis mot certain, that when one loves tenderly, we wou'd know in a Minute, what cannot be related in an Hour. Ask him, How I did? How I receiv'd
his Letter? And if he examin'd the Air of my Face, when I took it? If I bluh'd, or look'd pale? If my Hand trembled, or I poke to him with hort interrupting Sighs? If I ask'd him any Quetions about you, while I was opening the Seal? Or if I cou'd not well peak, and was ilent? If I read it attentively, and with Joy? And all this, before you open the Anwer I have ent you by him: Which, becaue you are impatient to read, you, with the more Hate <>
Earnetnes, demand all you expect from him; and that you may the better know, what Humour I was in, when I writ that to you. For, Oh! A Lover has a thouand little Fears, and Dreads, he knows not why. In fine, make him recount to you all that pat, while he was with me: And then you ought to read that which I have ent, that you may inform your elf of all that paes in my Heart; for you may aure your elf, all that I ay to you that way, proceeds from thence.

lg.l: How hall a Lover come to know,
Whether he's belov'd, or no?
What dear Things must he impart,
To aure him of her Heart?
Is it, when her Bluhes rie;
And he languih in her Eyes:
Tremble, when he does approach:
Look pale, and faint, at every touch?
Is it, when a thouand ways,
She does his Wit and Beauty praie?
<> venture to explain,
<> moving Words, a Pain;
To confirm it with her Vows.
Thee ome hort-liv'd Paion moves,
<…> Object's by, he loves;
<…> and udden Fire
<…> by ome fond Deire:
<> Goldnes will enue,
When the Lover's out of View.
Then he reflects with Scandal, o'er
<> Scene, that past before.
<> , with Bluhes, wou'd recal
<> unconid'ring Criminal;
<…> thouand Faults he'll find,
<> bide the Errors of her Mind.
<…> weight is found in words,
As no ubtantial Faith affords:
Deceiv'd, and briff'd all may be,
<> that frail Security.
But a well-digeted Flame,
That will always be the ame;
And that does, from Merit, grow
Etablih'd by our Reaon too;
By a better way, will prove,
'Tis th' unerring Fire of Love.
Lating Records it will give:
And, that all he ays, may live,
Sacred and Authentick tand,
Her Heart confirms it by her Hand.
If this, a Maid, well born, allow;
Damon, believe her just and true.

div.head: Nine a Clock.
Melancholy Reflections.
div.p:
YOU will not have much trouble <…>
what my Watch deigns here. <…>
be no Thought more afflicting, than that <…>
Abence of a Mitres; and which, the <…>
of the Heart will oon make you finde • , <>
Thouand Fears oppres him; he is jealous of every Body, and envies thoe Eyes and <>
that are charm'd, by being near the <…>
dor'd. He grows impatient, and makes a <>
and Reolutions, and as oon aband •••
<>
He gives himelf wholly up to the <…>
Incertainty; and by degrees, from <…>
Thought to another, winds himelf <…> upportable Chagrin. Take this <…>
think on your Misfortunes, which <…>
mall to a Soul that is wholly enible of Love, And every one knows, that a Love • , <>
of the Object of his Heart, is depriv'd of <…>
World, and Inconolable. For though <…>
wihes, without ceaing, for the dear <…>
one loves, and though you peak of her every Minute; though you are writing to her every Day, and though you are infinitely pleas'd with the dear and tender Anwers; yet, to peak incerely, it mut be confes'd, that the Felicity of a true Lover, is to be always near his Mitres. And you may tell me, O Damon! what you pleae; and ay, that Abence inpires the Flame,
which perpetual Preence would fatiate; I love too well to be of that Mind; and when I am, I hall believe my Paion is declining. I know not whether it advances your Love; but urely, it mut ruine your Repoe: And is it impoible to be, at once, an abent Lover, and happy too? For my part, I can meet with nothing that can pleae, in the abence of Damon; but, on the contrary, I ee all things with Digut. I will flatter my elf, that 'tis o with you; and that the leat Evils appear great Misfortunes; and that all thoe who peak to you of any thing but of what you love, increae your Pain, by a new remembrance of her Abence. I will believe, that thee are your Sentiments, you are aur'd not to ee me in ome Weeks; and, if your Heart do not betray your Words, all thoe Days will be tedious to you. I would not, however, have your Melancholy too extream; and to leen it, you may perwade yourelf, that I partake it with you; for, I remember, in your lat you told me, you would wih we hould be both griev'd at the ame time, and both at the ame time pleas'd; and, I believe, I love too well, not to obey you.

lg.l: Love, of all Joys, the weetest is,
The mot ubtantial Happines;
The oftet Bleing Life can crave;
The noblest Paion Souls can have.
Yet, if no Interruptions were,
No Difficulties came between,
'Twou'd not be render'd half o dear.
The Skie is gayet when mall Clouds are een.
The weetest Flower, the bluhing Roe,
Amidst the Thorns ecurest grows.
If Love were one continu'd Joy,
How oon the Happines wou'd cloy!
The wier Gods did this foreee;
And, to preerve the Blis entire,
Mix'd it with Doubt and Jealouie,
Thoe neceary Fuels to the Fire,
Sutain'd the fleeting Pleaures with new Fears;
With little Quarrels, Sighs, and Tears;
With Abence, that tormenting Smart,
That makes a Minute eem a Day,
A Day a Year, to the impatient Heart,
That languihes in the delay,
But cannot igh the tender Pain away;
That till returns, and with a greater Force,
Through every Vein it takes its grateful Coure.
But whatoe'er the Lover does utain,
Tho' he till igh, complain, and fear;
It cannot be a Mortal Pain,
When Two do the Affliction bear.

div.head: Ten a Clock.
Reflections.
div.p:
AFter the afflicting Thoughts of my abence, make ome Reflections on your Happines. Think it a Bleing, to be permitted to love me: Think it o, becaue I permit it to you alone; and never could be drawn to allow it any other.
The firt thing you ought to conider is, that at length I have uffer'd my elf to be overcome, to quit that Nicety that is natural to me, and receive your Addrees; nay, thought 'em agreeable; and that I have at lat confet, the Preent of your Heart is very dear to me. 'Tis true, I did not accept of it the firt time it was offer'd me, nor before you had told me a thouand times, that you could not ecape expiring, if I did not give you leave to igh for me, and gaze upon me; and that there was an abolute neceity for me, either to give you leave to love, or die. And all thoe Rigors my Severity has made you uffer, ought now to be recounted to your Memory, as Subjects of Pleaure; and you ought to eteem and judge of the Price of my Affections by the Difficulties you found in being able to touch my Heart: Not but you have Charms that can conquer at firt ight; and you ought not to have valued me les, if I had been more eaily gain'd: But 'tis enough to pleae you, to think and know I am gain'd; no matter when or how. When, after a thouand Cares and Inquietudes, that which we wih for ucceeds to our Deires, the Remembrance of thoe Pains and Pleaures we encounter'd, in arriving at it, gives us a new Joy.
Remember alo (Damon) that I have prefer'd you before all thoe that have been thought worthy of my Eteem; and that I have hut my Eyes to all their pleading Merits, and cou'd urvey none but yours.

Conider then, that you had not only the Happines to pleae me, but that you only
found out the way of doing it, and I had the Goodnes at lat to tell you o, contrary to all the Delicacy and Nicenes of my Soul; contrary to my Prudence, and all thoe Scruples, you know, are natural to my Humour.

My Tendernes proceeded further, and I gave you innocent Marks of my new-born Paion, on all Occaions that preented themelves: For, after that, from my Eyes and Tongue you knew the Sentiments of my Heart, I confirm'd that Truth to you by my Letters. Confes, (Damon) that if you make thee Reflections, you will not pas this Hour very diagreeably.

div.head: Beginning Love.

lg.l: As free as wanton Winds I liv'd,
That unconcern'd do play:
No broken Faith, no Fate I griev'd;
No Fortune gave me Joy.
A dull Content crown'd all my Hours,
My Heart no Sighs opprest;
I call'd in vain on no deaf Pow'rs,
To eae a tortur'd Breast.
The ighing Swains regardles pin'd,
And trove in vain to pleae:
With Pain I civilly was kind;
But could afford no Eae.
Tho' Wit and Beauty did abound,
The Charm was wanting till,
That could inpire the tender wound,
Or bend my careles will.
Till in my Heart a kindling Flame
Your ofter Sighs had blown;
Which, I with triving, Love and Shame,
Too enibly did own.
Whate'er the God before cou'd plead;
What'er the Youth's Deert;
The feeble Siege in vain was laid
Againt my tubborn Heart.
At firt my Sighs and Bluhes poke,
Jut when your Sighs wou'd rie;
And when you gaz'd I wih'd to look,
But durt not meet your Eyes.
I trembled, when my Hand you pres'd;
Nor cou'd my Guilt controul,
But Love prevail'd, and I confes'd
The Secrets of my Soul.
And when, upon the giving part,
My Preent to avow,
By all the Ways confirm'd my Heart,
That Honour wou'd allow;
Too mean was all that I cou'd ay,
Too poorly undertood:
I gave my Soul the noblest way,
My Letters made it good.

div.p:
You may believe I did not eaily, nor uddenly, bring my Heart to this Condecenion; but I lov'd, and all things in Damon were capable of making me reolve o to do. I could not think it a Crime, where every Grace, and every Vertue jutified my Choice: And when once one is aur'd of this, we find not much difficulty in owning that Paion which will o well commend ones Judgment; and there is no Obtacle that Love does not urmount. I confes'd
my Weaknes a thouand ways, before I told it you, and I remember all thoe things with Pleaure, but yet I remember 'em alo with Shame.

div.head: Eleven a Clock.
Supper.
div.p:
I Will believe (Damon) that you have been o well entertain'd, during this Hour, and have found o much Sweetnes in thee Thoughts, that if one did not tell you, that Supper waits, you would loe yourelf in Reflections o pleaing, many more Minutes. But you mut go, where you are expected; perhaps, among the Fair, the Young, the Gay; but do not abandon your Heart to too much Joy, tho' you have o much Reaon to be contented; but the greatet Pleaures are alwaies imperfect, if the Object belov'd do not partake of it. For this Reaon be cheerful and merry with Reerve: Do not talk too much, I know you do not love it; and if you do it, 'twill be the effect of too much Complaiance, or with ome deign of pleaing too well; for you know your own charming Power, and how agreeable your Wit and Converation is to all the World. Remember, I am covetous of every Word you peak, that is not addres'd to me, and envy the happy Litner, if I am not by: And I may reply to you as Aminta did to Philander, when he charg'd her of loving a Talker: And becaue, perhaps,
you have not heard it, I will, to divert you, end it you; and at the ame time aure you, Damon, that your more noble Quality, of peaking little, has reduc'd me to a perfect Abhorrence of thoe Wordy Sparks, that value themelves upon their ready and much Talking upon every trivial Subject, and who have o good an Opinion of their Talent that way, they will let no body edge in a Word, or a Reply; but will make all the Converation themelves, that they may pas for very Entertaining Perons, and pure Company. But the Veres—

div.head: The Reformation.

lg.l: I grant, I was impertinent;
And, till this Moment, did not know,
Through all my Life, what 'twas I meant.
Your kind Opinion was the flattering Glas,
In which my Mind found how deform'd it was.
In your clear Sene, which knows no Art,
I aw the Errors of my Soul;
And all the Foibles of my Heart,
With one Reflection, you controul.
Kind as a God, and gently you chatie:
By what you hate, you teach me to be wie.
Impertinence, my Sex's Shame,
That has o long my Life puru'd,
You with uch Modety reclaim,
As all the Women has ubdu'd.
To o Divine a Power what mut I owe,
That renders me o like the perfect You?
That Converable thing I hate
Already, with a just Didain,
That prides himelf upon his Prate,
And is, of Words, that Nonence vain.
When in you few appears uch Excellence,
As have reproach'd, and charm'd me into Sene.
For ever may I lit'ning it,
Tho' but each Hour a Word be born;
I would attend the coming Wit,
And bles what can o well inform.
Let the dull World henceforth to Words be dam'd;
I'm into nobler Sene than Talking ham'd.

div.p:
I believe you are o good a Lover, as to be of my Opinion; and that you will neither force yourelf againt Nature, nor find much occaion to lavih out thoe excellent things that mut proceed from you, whenever you peak. If all Women were like me, I hould have more reaon to fear your Silence than your Talk, for you have a thouand waies to charm without peaking; and thoe which to me hew a great deal more Concern. But (Damon) you know, the greatet part of my Sex judge the fine Gentleman by the Volubility of his Tongue, by his Dexterity in Repartee, and cry,—Oh! he never wants fine things to ay: He's eternally talking the mot urprizing things. But (Damon) you are well aur'd, I hope, that Iris is none of thee Coquets; at leat, if he had any park of it once in her Nature, he is, by the Excellency of your contrary Temper, taught to know, and corn the Folly: And take heed your Conduct never
give me caue to upect you have deceiv'd me in your Temper.

div.head: Twelve a Clock.
Complaiance.
div.p:
NEvertheles (Damon) Civility requires a little Complaiance after Supper; and I am aur'd, you can never want that, though, I confes, you are not accus'd of too general a Complaiance, and do not often make ue of it to thoe Perons you have an Indifference for; though one is not the les eteemable, for having more of this than one ought; and though an exces of it be a Fault, 'tis a very excuable one: Have therefore ome for thoe with whom you are: You may laugh with 'em, drink with 'em, dance or ing with 'em; yet think of me. You may dicoure of a thouand indifferent things with 'em, and at the ame time till think of me. If the Subject be any beautiful Lady, whom they praie, either for her Peron, Wit, or Virtue, you may apply it to me: And if you dare not ay it aloud, at leat, let your Heart anwer in this Language:
Yes, the fair Object, whom you praie,
Can give us Love a thouand ways.
Her Wit and Beauty charming are;
But till my Iris is more fair.

No Body ever poke before me, of a faithful Lover, but I till igh'd, and thought of Damon: And ever when they tell me Tales of Love, any oft pleaing Intercoures of an Amour; Oh! with what Pleaure do I liten! and with Pleaure anwer 'em, either with my Eyes, or Tongue—
That Lover may his Silvia warm,
But cannot, like my Damon, charm.

If I have not all thoe excellent Qualities you meet with in thoe beautiful People, I am, however, very glad that Love prepoees your Heart to my Advantage: And I need not tell you (Damon) that a true Lover ought to perwade himelf, that all other Objects ought to give place to her, for whom his Heart ighs.—But ee, my Cupid tells you 'tis One a Clock, and that you ought not to be longer from your Apartment; where, while you are undreing. I will give you leave to ay to yourelf.—

div.head: The Regret.
div.l: Alas! and must the Sun decline
Before it have inform'd my Eyes
Of all that's glorious, all that's fine,
Of all I igh for, all I prize?
How joyful were thoe happy Days,
When Iris pread her charming Rays,
Did my unwearied Heart inpire
With never-ceaing awful Fire!
And e'ery Minute gave me new Deire
But now, alas! all dead and pale,
Like Flow'rs that wither in the Shade;
Where no kind Sun-beams can prevail,
To raie its cold and fading Head,
I ink into my ueles Bed.
I grap the enceles Pillow as I lie;
A thouand times, in vain, I ighing cry,
Ah! wou'd to Heaven my Iris were as nigh.

div.head: One a Clock.
Impoibility to Sleep.
div.p:
YOU have been up long enough; and Cupid, who takes care of your Health, tells you, 'tis time for you to go to Bed. Perhaps you may not leep as oon as you are laid, and poibly you may pas an Hour in Bed, before you hut your Eyes. In this impoibility of leeping, I think it very proper for you to imagine what I am doing, where I am. Let your Fancy take a little Journey then inviible to oberve my Actions and my Conduct. You will find me itting alone in my Cabinet (for I am one that do not love to go to Bed early) and will find me very uneaie and penive; pleas'd with none of thoe things that o well entertain others. I hun all Converation, as far as Civility will allow, and find no Satisfaction like being alone, where my Soul may, without interruption, convere with Damon. I igh, and ometimes you will ee my
Cheeks wet with Tears, that inenibly glide down at a thouand Thoughts that preent themelves oft and afflicting. I partake of all your Inquietude. On other things I think with Indifference, if ever my Thoughts do tray from the more agreeable Object. I find, however, a little Sweetnes in his Thought, that, during my Abence, your Heart thinks of me, when mine ighs for you. Perhaps I am mitaken, and that at the ame time that you are the Entertainment of all my Thoughts, I am no more in yours; and perhaps you are thinking of thoe things that immortalize the Young and Brave; either by thoe Glories the Mues flatter you with, or that of Bellona, and the God of War; and erving now a Monarch whoe glorious Acts in Arms has out-gone all the feign'd and real Heroes of any Age, who has, himelf, out-done whatever Hitory can produce of Great and Brave, and et o illutrious an Example to the Under-World, that it is not impoible, as much a Lover as you are, but you are thinking now how to render yourelf worthy the Glory of uch a God-like Mater, by projecting a thouand things of Gallantry and Danger. And tho', I confes, uch Thoughts are proper for your Youth, your Quality, and the Place you have the Honour to hold under our Sovereign, yet let me tell you (Damon) you will not be without Inquietude, if you think of either being a delicate Poet, or a brave Warriour; for Love will till interrupt your Glory, however you may think to divert him, either by Writing or Fighting. And you ought to remember thee Veres:

div.head: Love and Glory.

lg.l: Beneath the kind protecting Lawrel's hade,
For ighing Lovers, and for Warriours made,
The oft Adonis and rough Mars were laid.
Both were deign'd to take their Rest;
But Love, the gentle Boy, opprest,
And fale Alarms hook the tern Hero's Breast.
This thinks to often all his Toils of War,
In the dear Arms of the obliging Fair
And That, by Hunting to divert his Care.
All Day, o'er Hills and Plains, wild Beats he chas'd,
Swift as the flying Winds, his eager hate,
In vain! the God of Love purues as fast.
But, oh! no Sports, no Toils divertive prove,
The Evening till returns him to the Grove,
To igh and languih for the Queen of Love.
Where Elegies and Sonnets he does frame,
And to the lit'ning Ecchoes ighs her Name,
And on the Trees carves Records of his Flame.
The Warriour, in the duty Camp all Day,
With ratling Drums and Trumpets does eay,
To fright the tender flatt'ring God away.
But till, alas, in vain: whate'er Delight,
What Care he takes the wanton Boy to fright,
'Tis then he haunts the Royal Tent,
The leeping Hours in Sighs are pent,
And all his Reolutions does prevent.
In all his Pains, Love mix'd his Smart;
In every Wound he feels a Dart;
And the oft God is trembling in his Heart.
Then he retires to hady Groves,
And there, in vain, he eeks Repoe,
And trives to fly from what he cannot loe.
While thus he lay, Bellona came,
And with a generous fierce Didain
pbraids him with his feeble Flame.
Arie, the World's great Terror, and their Care;
Behold the glitt'ring Host from far,
That waits the Conduct of the God of War.
Beneath thee glorious Lawrels, which were made
To Crown the Noble Victor's Head,
Why thus upinely art thou laid?
Why on that Face, where awful Terror grew,
Thy Sun-parc'd Cheeks, why do I view
The hining Tracks of falling Tears bedew?
What God has wrought thee univeral Harms?
What fatal Nymph, what fatal Charms
Has made the Hero deaf to War's Alarms?
Now let the Conqu'ring Enigns up be furl'd:
Learn to be gay, be oft, and curl'd;
And idle, loe the Empire of the World.
In fond Effeminate Delights go on;
Loe all the Glories you have won:
Bravely reolve to love, and be undone.
'Tis thus the Martial Virgin pleads;
Thus he the Am'rous God perwades
To fly from Venus, and the flow'ry Meads.

div.p: You ee here that Poets and Warriours are oftentimes in Affliction, even under the Shades of their protecting Lawrels; and let the Nymphs and Virgins ing what they pleae to their Memory, under the Mirtles, and on Flow'ry Beds, much better Days than in the Campaign. Nor do the Crowns of Glory urpas thoe of Love: The firt is but an empty Name, which is won, kept, and lot with Hazard; but Love more nobly employs a brave Soul, and all his Pleaures are olid and lating; and when one has a worthy Object of one's Flame, Glory accompanies Love too. But go to leep, the Hour is come; and 'tis now that your Soul ought to be entertain'd in Dreams.

div.head: Two a Clock.
Converation in Dreams.
div.p:
I Doubt not but you will think it very bold and arbitrary, that my Watch hould pretend to rule even your Sleeping Hours, and that my Cupid hould govern your very Dreams; which
are but Thoughts diorder'd, in which Reaon has no part; Chimera's of the Imagination, and no more: But tho' my Watch does not pretend to Counel unreaonable, yet you mut allow it here; if not to pas the Bounds, at leat, to advance to the utmot limits of it. I am aur'd, that after having thought o much of me in the Day, you will think of me alo in the Night. And the firt Dream my Watch permits you to make, is to think you are in Converation with me.

Imagine (Damon) that you are talking to me of your Paion, with all the Tranport of a Lover, and that I hear you with Satisfaction: That all my Looks and Bluhes, while you are peaking, gives you new Hopes and Aurances, that you are not indifferent to me, and that I give you a thouand Tetimonies of my Tendernes, all Innocent and Obliging.

While you are aying all that Love can dictate, all that Wit and good Manners can invent, and all that I wih to hear from Damon, believe in this Dream, all flattering and dear; that after having hew'd me the Ardour of your Flame, that I confes to you the Bottom of my Heart, and all the loving Secrets there; that I give you Sigh for Sigh, Tendernes for Tendernes, Heart for Heart, and Pleaure for Pleaure. And I would have your Sene of this Dream o perfect, and your Joy o entire, that if it happen you hould awake with the Satisfaction from this Dream, you hould find your Heart till panting with the oft Pleaure of the dear deceiving Tranport, and you hould be ready to cry out,—
Ah! how weet it is to dream,
When Charming Iris is the Theme!
For uch, I wih, my Damon, your leeping and your waking Thoughts hould render me to your Heart.

div.head: Three a Clock.
Capricious Suffering in Dreams.
div.p: IT is but jut to mix a little Chagrin with thee Pleaures, a little Bitter with your Sweet; you may be cloy'd with too long an Imagination of my Favours: And I will have your Fancy in Dreams repreent me to it, as the mot capricious Maid in the World. I know, here you will accue my Watch, and blame me with unneceary Cruelty, as you will call it; but Lovers have their little Ends, their little Advantages, to purue by Methods wholly unaccountable to all, but that Heart that contrives 'em: And as good a Lover, as I believe you, you will not enter into my Deign at firt ight; and though, on reaonable Thoughts, you will be atisfied with this Conduct of mine, at its firt approach you will be ready to cry out,—

div.head: The Requet.

lg.l: Oh Iris! let my leeping Hours be fraught
With Joys, which you deny my waking Thought.
Is't not enough you abent are?
Is't not enough I igh all Day,
And languih out my Life in Care,
To e'ery Paion made a Prey?
I burn with Love and oft Deire;
I rave with Jealouie and Fear:
All Day, for Eae, my Soul I tire;
In vain I earch it e'ery-where:
It dwells not with the Witty or the Fair.
It is not in the Camp or Court,
In Bus'nes, Muick, or in Sport;
The Plays, the Park, and Mall afford
No more than the dull Baet-board.
The Beauties in the Drawing-room,
With all their Sweetnes, all their Bloom,
No more my faithful Eyes invite,
Nor rob my Iris of a Sigh or Glance,
nles oft Thoughts of her incite
A Smile, or trivial Complaiance.
Then ince my Days o anxious prove,
Ah, Cruel Tyrant! give
A little Looe to Joys in Love,
And let your Damon live.
Let him in Dreams be happy made,
And let his Sleep ome Blis provide:
The nicest Maid may yield, in Night's dark hade,
What he o long by Day-light had deny'd.
There let me think you preent are,
And court my Pillow for my Fair.
There let me find you kind, and that you give
All that a Man of Honour dares receive.
And may my Eyes Eternal Watches keep,
Father than want that Pleaure, when I leep.

div.p: Some uch Complaint as this, I know you will make; but (Damon) if the little Quarrels of Lovers render the reconciling Moments o infinitely Charming, you mut needs allow, that thee little Chagrins in capricious Dreams mut awaken you to more Joy to find 'em but Dreams, than if you had met with no Diorder there. 'Tis for this Reaon that I wou'd have you uffer a little Pain, for a coming Pleaure; nor, indeed, is it poible for you to ecape the Dreams my Cupid points you out. You hall dream that I have a thouand Foiblees, omething of the lightnes of my Sex; that my Soul is employ'd in a thouand Vanities; that (proud and fond of Lovers) I make Advances for the Glory of a Slave, without any other Interet, or Deign, than that of being ador'd. I will give you leave to think my Heart fickle, and that, far from reigning it to any one, I lend it only for a Day, or an Hour, and take it back at pleaure, that I am a very Coquet, even to Impertinence.

All this I give you leave to think, and to offend me; but 'tis in Sleep only that I permit it; for I would never pardon you the leat Offence of this nature, if in any other kind than in a Dream. Nor is it enough Affliction to you, to imagine me thus idly vain; but you are to pas on to an hundred more capricious Humours; as
that I exact of you a hundred unjut Things; that I pretend you hould break off with all your Friends, and for the future, have none at all; that I will, myelf, do thoe Things, which I violently condemn in you; and that I will have for others, as well as you, that tender Friendhip that reembles Love, or rather that Love which People call Friendhip; and that I will not, after all, have you dare complain on me.

In fine, be as ingenious as you pleae, to torment yourelf; and believe, that I am become unjut, ungrateful, and inenible: But were I o indeed, O Damon! Conider your awaking Heart, and tell me; Wou'd your Love tand the Proof of all thee Faults in me? But know, that I would have you believe, I have none of thee Weaknees, though I am not wholly without Faults, but thoe will be excuable to a Lover; and this Notion I have of a perfect one:
Whate'er fantatick Humours rule the Fair,
She's till the Lover's Dotage and his Care.

div.head: Four a Clock.
Jealouie in Dreams.
div.p:
DO not think (Damon) to wake yet; for I deign you hall yet uffer a little more: Jealouie mut now poes you, that Tyrant over the Heart, that compels your very Reaon, and educes all your good Nature. And in this Dream, you mut believe that in leeping which
you cou'd not do me the Injutice to do when awake. And here you mut explain all my Actions to the utmot Diadvantage: Nay, I will wih, that the force of this Jealouie may be o extream, that it may make you languih in Grief and be overcome with Anger.

You hall now imagine, that one of your Rivals is with me, interrupting all you ay, or hindring all you wou'd ay; that I have no attention to what you ay aloud to me, but that I incline my Ear to hearken to all that he whipers to me. You hall repine, that he purues me every-where, and is eternally at your Heels if you approach me; that I cares him with Sweetnes in my Eyes, and that Vanity in my Heart, that poees the Humors of almot all the Fair; that is, to believe it greatly for my Glory to have abundance of Rivals for my Lovers. I know you love too well, not to be extreamly uneaie in the Company of a Rival, and to have one perpetually near me; for let him be belov'd or not by the Mitres, it mut be confes'd, a Rival is a very troubleome Peron: But, to afflict you to the utmot, I will have you imagine that my Eyes approve of all his Thoughts; that they flatter him with Hopes, and that I have taken away my Heart from you, to make a Preent of it to this more lucky Man. You hall uffer, while poes'd with this Dream, all that a cruel Jealouie can make a tender Soul uffer.

div.head: The Torment.
div.l: O Jealouie! thou Paion most ingrate!
Tormenting as Depair, envious as Hate!
Spightful as Witchcraft, which th' Invoker harms;
Wore than the Wretch that uffers by its Charms.
Thou ubtil Poyon in the Fancy bred,
Diffus'd through every Vein, the Heart and Head,
And over all, like wild Contagion, pread.
Thou, whoe ole Property is to detroy,
Thou Oppoite to Good, Antipathy to Joy,
Whoe Attributes are cruel, Rage, and Fire,
Reaon debauch'd, fale Sence, and mad Deire.
div.p: In fine, it is a Paion that ruffles all the Senes, and diorders the whole Frame of Nature. It makes one hear and ee what was never poke and what never was in view. 'Tis the Bane of Health and Beauty, an unmannerly Intruder; and an Evil of Life wore than Death. She is a very cruel Tyrant in the Heart; he poees and pierces it with infinite Unquiets; and we may lay it down as a certain Maxim—

q.l: She that wou'd wreck a Lover's Heart
To the Extent of Cruelty,
Must his Tranquility ubvert
To tort'ring Jealouie.

div.p: I peak too enibly of this Paion, not to have lov'd well enough, to have been touch'd with it: And you hall be this unhappy Lover (Damon) during this Dream, in which nothing hall preent itelf to your tumultuous Thoughts, that hall not bring its Pain. You hall here pas and re-pas a hundred Deigns that hall confound one another. In fine (Damon) Anger, Hatred, and Revenge hall urround your Heart.

q.l: There they hall all together reign
With mighty Force, with mighty Pain;
In pight of Reaon, in Contempt of Love:
Sometimes by turns, ometimes united move.

div.head: Five a Clock.
Quarrels in Dreams.
div.p: I Perceive you are not able to uffer all this Injutice, nor can I permit it any longer; and though you commit no Crime yourelf, yet you believe, in this Dream, that I complain of Injuries you do my Fame, and that I am extreamly angry with a Jealouie o prejudicial to my Honour. Upon this Belief you accue me of Weaknes; you reolve to ee me no more, and are making a thouand feeble Vows againt Love! You eteem me as a fale one, and reolve to ceae loving the vain Coquet, and will ay to me as a certain Friend of yours aid to his fale Mitres:

div.head: The Incontant.

lg.l: Though, Sylvia, you are very fair,
Yet diagreeable to me;
And ince you o incontant are,
Your Beauty's damn'd with Levity.
Your Wit, your most offenive Arms,
For want of Judgment, wants its Charms.
To every Lover that is new,
All new and charming you urprize;
But when your fickle Mind they view,
They hun the danger of your Eyes.
Shou'd you a Miracle of Beauty how,
Yet you're incontant, and will till be o.

div.p: 'Tis thus you will think of me: And, in fine, (Damon) during this Dream, we are in a perpetual State of War.

lg.l: Thus both reolve to break their Chain,
And think to do't without much Pain,
But, Oh! Alas! we trive in vain.
For Lovers of themelves can nothing do;
There must be the Conent of Two:
You give it me, and I must give it you.

div.p:
And if we hall never be free, till we acquit one another, this Tye between you and I (Damon) is likely to lat as long as we live; therefore in vain you endeavour, but can never attain your End; and in concluion you will ay, in thinking of me:
Oh! how at Eae my Heart wou'd live,
Cou'd I renounce this Fugitive,
This dear (but fale) attracting Maid,
That has her Vows and Faith betray'd!
Reaon wou'd have it o, but Love
Dares not the dang'rous Tryal prove.
Do not be angry then, for this afflicting hour is drawing to an end, and you ought not to depair of coming into my abolute Favour again.

q.l: Then do not let your murm'ring Heart,
Against my Int'rest, take your Part.
The Feud was rais'd by Dreams, all fale and vain,
And the next Sleep hall reconcile again.

div.head: Six a Clock.
Accommodation in Dreams.
div.p:
THough the angry Lovers force themelves, all they can, to chae away the troubleome Tendernes of the Heart, in the height of their Quarrels, Love ees all their Sufferings, pities and redrees 'em: And when we begin to cool, and a oft Repentance follows the Chagrin of the Love-Quarrel, 'tis then that Love takes the advantage of both Hearts, and renews the charming Friendhip more forcibly than ever, puts a top to all our Feuds, and renders the Peace-making Minutes the mot dear and tender part of our Life. How pleaing 'tis to ee your Rage diolve! How weet, how oft is every Word that pleads for Pardon at my Feet! 'Tis there that, you tell me, your very Sufferings are over-paid, when I but aure you from my Eyes, that I will forget your Crime: And your Imagination hall here preent me the
mot enible of your pat Pain, that you can wih; and that, all my Anger being vanih'd, I give you a thouand Marks of my Faith and Gratitude; and latly, to crown all, that we again make new Vows to one another of inviolable Peace.

q.l: After thee Debates of Love,
Lovers thouand Pleaures prove,
Which they ever think to tate,
Tho' oftentimes they do not last.

div.p: Enjoy then all the Pleaures that a Heart that is very amorous, and very tender, can enjoy. Think no more on thoe Inquietudes that you have uffer'd, bles Love for his Favours, and thank me for my Graces; and reolve to endure any thing, rather than enter upon any new Quarrels. And however dear the reconciling Moments are, there proceeds a great deal of Evil from thee little frequent Quarrels; and I think, the bet Counel we can follow, is to avoid 'em as near as we can: And if we cannot, but that, in pight of Love and good Undertanding, they hould break out, we ought to make as peedy a Peace as poible, for 'tis not good to grate the Heart too long, let it grow harden'd inenibly, and loe its native Temper. A few Quarrels there mut be in Love; Love cannot upport itelf without 'em; and, beides the Joy of an Accommodation, Love becomes by it more trongly united, and more charming. Therefore let the Lover receive this as a certain Receipt againt declining Love:

lg.l: He that wou'd have the Paion be
Entire between the Am'rous Pair,
Let not the little Feuds of Jealouie
Be carried on to a Depair:
That pauls the Pleaure he would raie;
The Fire that he wou'd blow, allays.
When ndertandings fale arie,
When miinterpreted your thought;
If fale Conjectures of your Smiles and Eyes
Be up to Baneful Quarrel wrought;
Let Love the kind Occaion take,
And trait Accommodation make.
The ullen Lover, long unkind,
Ill-natur'd, hard to reconcile,
Loes the Heart he had inclin'd,
Love cannot undergo long Toil;
He's oft and weet, not born to bear
The rough Fatigues of painful War.

div.head: Seven a Clock.
Divers Dreams.
div.p:
BEhold (Damon) the lat Hour of your Sleep, and of my Watch. She leaves you at liberty now, and you may chue your Dreams: Trut 'em to your Imaginations, give a Looe to
Fancy, and let it rove at Will, provided, Damon, it be always guided by a repectful Love. For thus far I pretend to give Bounds to your Imagination, and will not have it pas beyond 'em: Take heed, in Sleeping, you give no Ear to a flatt'ring Cupid, that will favour your lumbring Minutes with Lies too pleaing and vain: You are dicreet enough when you are awake; Will you not be o in Dreams?

Damon, awake: My Watch's Coure is done; after this, you cannot be ignorant of what you ought to do during my abence. I did not believe it neceary to caution you about Balls and Comedies; you know, a Lover depriv'd of his Mitres, goes eldom there. But if you cannot handomly avoid thee Divertions, I am not o unjut a Mitres, to be angry with you for it; go, if Civility, or other Duties, oblige you: I will only forbid you, in conideration of me, not to be too much atisfied with thoe Pleaures, but ee 'em o, as the World, may have Reaon to ay, you do not eek 'em, you do not make a Buines or a Pleaure of 'em, and that 'tis Complaiance, and not Inclination, that carries you thither. Seem rather negligent than concern'd at any thing there; and let every part of you ay, Iris is not here.—

I ay nothing to you neither of your Duty elewhere; I am atisfied you know it too well, and have too great a Veneration for your Glorious Mater, to neglect any part of that for even Love itelf: And I very well know how much you love to be eternally near his illutrious Peron; and that you carce prefer your Mitres
before him, in point of Love: In all things ele, I give him leave to take place of Iris, in the noble Heart of Damon.

I am atisfied you pas your Time well now at Windor, for you adore that place, and 'tis not indeed, without great Reaon; for 'tis mot certainly now render'd the mot glorious Palace in the Chritian World. And had our late Gracious Soveraign of bleed Memory had no other Miracles and Wonders of his Life and Reign, to have immortaliz'd his Fame, (of which there hall remain a Thouand to Poterity) this Noble Structure alone, this Building (almot Divine) would have eterniz'd the great Name of Glorious Charles the Second, till the World moulder again to its old Confuion, its firt Chaos. And the Paintings of the famous Vario, and Noble Carvings of the unimitable Gibon, hall never die, but remain, to tell ucceeding Ages, that all Arts and Learning were not confin'd to ancient Rome and Greece, but that England too could boat its mightiet Share. Nor is the In-ide of this Magnificent Structure, immortaliz'd with o many eternal Images of the Illutrious Charles and Katherine, more to be admir'd than the wondrous Propects without. The tupendious Heighth, on which the famous Pile is built, renders the Fields and Flowery Meads below, the Woods, the Thickets, and the winding Streams, the mot delightful Object that ever Nature produc'd. Beyond all thee, and far below, in an inviting Vale, the venerable College, an Old, but Noble Building, raies itelf, in the midt of all the
Beauties of Nature, high-grown Trees, fruitful Plains, purling Rivulets, and pacious Gardens, adorn'd with all Variety of Sweets that can delight the Senes.

At farther ditance yet, on an Acent almot as high as that to the Royal Structure, you may behold that famous and noble Clifdon Rie, a Palace erected by the illutrious Duke of Buckingham: Who will leave this wondrous Piece of Architecture, to inform the future World of the Greatnes and Delicacy of his Mind, it being, for its Situation, its Propects, and its marvellous Contrivances, one of the finet Villa's of the World; at leat, were it finih'd as begun; and would ufficiently declare the magnifick Soul of the Hero that caus'd it to be built, and contriv'd all its Finenes. And this makes up not the leat part of the beautiful Propect from the Palace-Royal, while on the other ide lies pread a fruitful and delightful Park and Foret, well tor'd with Deer, and all that make the Propect charming; fine Walks, Groves, ditant Valleys, Downs and Hills, and all that Nature could invent, to furnih out a quiet oft Retreat for the mot Fair and mot Charming of Queens, and the mot Heroick, Good, and Jut of Kings: And thee Groves alone are fit and worthy to divert uch Earthly Gods.

Nor can Heaven, Nature, or Humane Art contrive an Addition to this Earthly Paradie, unles thoe great Inventors of the Age, Sir Samuel Morland, or Sir Robert Gorden, cou'd, by the Power of Engines, convey the Water o into the Park and Catle, as to furnih it with delightful
Fountains, both ueful and beautiful. Thee are only wanting, to render the Place all Perfection, without Exception.

This, Damon, is a long Digreion from the Buines of my Heart; but, you know, I am o in Love with that charming Court, that when you gave me an Occaion, by your being there now, but to name the Place, I could not forbear trangreing a little, in favour of its wondrous Beauty; and the rather, becaue I wou'd, in recounting it, give you to undertand how many fine Objects there are, beides the Ladies that adorn it, to employ your vacant Moments in; and hope you will, without my Intructions, pas a great part of your idle Time in urveying thee Propects, and give that Admiration you hou'd pay to living Beauty, to thoe more venerable Monuments of everlating Fame.

Neither need I (Damon) aign you your waiting Times; your Honour, Duty, Love, and Obedience will intruct you when to be near the Peron of the King; and, I believe, you will omit no part of that Devoir. You ought to etablih your Fortune aud your Glory: For I am not of the Mind of thoe Critical Lovers, who believe it a very hard Matter to reconcile Love and Interet, to adore a Mitres, and erve a Mater at the ame time. And I have heard thoe, who, on this Subject, ay, Let a Man be never o careful in thee double Duties, 'tis Ten to One but he loes his Fortune or his Mitres. Thee are Errors that I condemn: And I know, that Love and Ambition are not incompatible, but that a brave Man may preerve all his Duties to
his Soveraign, and his Paion and his Repect for his Mitres. And this is my Notion of it.

div.head: Love and Ambition.

lg.l: The Nobler Lover, who wou'd prove
ncommon in Addres,
Let him Ambition joyn with Love;
With Glory, Tendernes:
But let the Vertues o be mixt,
That when to Love he goes,
Ambition may not come betwixt,
Nor Love his Power oppoe.
The vacant Hours from ofter Sport
Let him give up to Int'rest and the Court.
'Tis Honour hall his Bus'nes be,
And Love his Noblest Play:
Thoe two hould never diagree,
For both make either gay.
Love without Honour were too mean
For any gallant Heart;
And Honour ingly, but a Dream,
Where Love mut have no part.
A Flame like this you cannot fear,
Where Glory claims an equal Share.

div.p:
Such a Paion (Damon) can never make you quit any part of your Duty to your Prince. And the Monarch you erve is o gallant a Mater, that the Inclination you have to his Peron obliges you to erve him, as much as your Duty; for Damon's Loyal Soul loves the Man, and adores the Monarch; for he is certainly
all that compels both, by a charming force and Goodnes from all Mankind.

div.head: The King.

lg.l: Darling of Mars! Bellona's Care!
The econd Deity of War!
Delight of Heaven, and Joy of Earth!
Born for great and wondrous things!
Detin'd at his Aupicious Birth
T'out do the num'rous Race of long-past Kings.
Best Repreentative of Heaven,
To whom its chiefest Attributes are given!
Great, Pious, Stedfast, Just, and Brave!
To Vengeance low, but wift to ave!
Dipencing Mercy all abroad!
Soft and Forgiving as a God!
Thou Saving Angel, who preerv'st the Land
From the Just Rage of the Avenging Hand,
Stopt the dire Plague, that o'er the Earth was hurl'd,
And heathing thy Almighty Sword,
Calm'd the wild Fears of a ditracted World,
(As Heaven first made it) with a acred Word!

div.p:
But I will top the low Flight of my humble Mue, who, when he is upon the Wing, on this Glorious Subject, knows no Bounds. And all the World has agreed to ay o much of the Vertues and Wonders of this great Monarch, that they have left me nothing new to ay; though indeed he every day gives us new Themes of his growing Greatnes, and we ee nothing that
equals him in our Age. Oh, how happy are we to obey his Laws, for he is the greatet of Kings, and the bet of Men!

You will be very unjut (Damon) if you do not confes, I have acquitted myelf like a Maid of Honour, of all the Obligations I owe you, upon the account of the Dicretion I lot to you. If it be not valuable enough, I am generous enough to make it good: And ince I am o willing to be jut, you ought to eteem me, and to make it your chiefet Care to preerve me yours; for I believe I hall deerve it, and wih you hou'd believe o too. Remember me, write to me, and oberve punctually all the Motions of my Watch: The more you regard it, the better you will like it; and, whatever you think of it at firt ight, 'tis no ill Preent. The Invention is oft and gallant; and Germany, o celebrated for rare Watches, can produce nothing to equal this.

q.l: Damon, my Watch is just, and new;
And all a Lover ought to do,
My Cupid faithfully will hew.
And every Hour he renders there,
Except L'heure du Bergere.

div.head: DAMON to IRIS.
div.p:
EXpect not, O charming Iris! that I hou'd chue Words to thank you in; (Words, that leat part of Love, and leat the Buines of the Lover) but will ay all, and every thing that a tender Heart can dictate, to make an Acknowledgment for o dear and precious a Preent, as this of your charming Watch; while all I can ay will but too dully expres my Sene of Gratitude, my Joy, and the Pleaure I receive in the mighty Favour. I confes the Preent too rich, too gay, and too magnificent for my Expectation; and though my Love and Faith deerve it, yet my humbler Hope never durt carry me to a Wih of o great a Blis, o great an Acknowledgment from the Maid I adore! The Materials are glorious, the Work
delicate, and the Movement jut, and even gives Rules to my Heart, who hall oberve very exactly all that the Cupid remarks to me, even to the Minutes, which I will point with Sighs, though I am oblig'd to 'em there but every Half-hour.—

You tell me, fair Iris, that I ought to preerve it tenderly, and yet you have ent it me without a Cae. But that I may obey you jutly, and keep it dear to me, as long as I live, I will give it a Cae of my Fahion: It hall be delicate, and uitable to the fine Preent; of uch Materials too. But becaue I would have it perfect, I will conult your admirable Wit and Invention in an Affair of o curious a conequence.

div.head: The FIGURE of the CASE.
div.p: I Deign to give it the Figure of a Heart. Does not your Watch, Iris, rule the Heart? It was your Heart that contriv'd it, and 'twas your Heart you conulted in all the management of it; and 'twas your Heart that brought it to o fine a Concluion. The Heart never acts without Reaon, and all the Heart projects, it performs with Pleaure.

Your Watch, my lovely Maid, has explain'd to me a World of rich Secrets of Love: And where hou'd Thoughts o acred be tor'd, but in the Heart, where all the Secrets of the Soul are treaur'd up, and of which only Love alone can take a View? 'Tis thence he takes his Sighs and Tears, and all his little Flatteries and Arts to pleae. All his fine Thoughts, and all his
mighty Raptures, nothing is o proper as the Heart to preerve it; nothing o worthy, as the Heart to contain it; and it concerns my Interet too much, not to be infinitely careful of o dear a Treaure: And, believe me, charming Iris, I will never part with it.

div.head: The Votary.

lg.l: Fair Goddes of my just Deire,
Inpirer of my oftest Fire!
Since you, from out the num'rous Throng,
That to your Altars do belong,
To me the Sacred Myt'ry have reveal'd,
From all my Rival-Worhippers conceal'd;
And touch'd my Soul with heav'nly Fire:
Refin'd it from its groer Sene,
And wrought it to a higher Excellence;
It can no more return to Earth,
Lake things that thence receive their Birth:
But till apiring, upward move,
And teach the World new Flights of Love.
New Arts of Secreie hall learn,
And render Youth dicreet in Love's Concern.
In his oft Heart, to hide the charming things,
A Mitres whipers to his Ear;
And e'ery tender Sigh he brings,
Mix with his Soul, and hide it there.
To bear himelf o well in Company,
That if his Mitres preent be,
It may be thought by all the Fair,
Each in his Heart does claim a hare,
And all are more belov'd than he.
But when with the dear Maid apart,
Then at her Feet the Lover lies;
Opens his Soul, hews all his Heart,
While Joy is dancing in his Eyes.
Then all that Honour may, or take, or give,
They both ditribute, both receive.
A Looker on wou'd poil a Lover's Joy;
For Love's a Game where only Two can play.
And 'tis the hardest of Love's Myteries,
To feign Love where it is not, hide it where it is.

div.p:
After having told you, my lovely Iris, that I deign to put your Watch into a Heart I ought to hew you the Ornaments of the Cae. I do intend to have 'em Crown'd Cyphers. I do not mean thoe Crowns of Vanity, which are put indifferently on all orts of Cyphers: No, I mut have uch, as may ditinguih <>
from the ret; and may be true Emblems of what I wou'd repreent. My four Cyphers therefore hall be Crown'd with thee four Wreaths of Olive, Laurel, Myrtle, and Roles: And the Letters that begin the Names of <>
and Damon, hall compoe the Cyphers; though I mut intermix ome other <>
that bear another Sence, and have another Signification.

div.head: The First CYPHER.
div.p:
THE firt Cypher is compos'd of an I, <>
a D, which are joyn'd by an L, and an E: Which ignifies, Love extream. And 'tis but jut, O adorable Iris! that Love hou'd be
mixt with our Cyphers, and that Love alone hou'd be the Union of 'em.

q.l: Love ought alone the Mytick Knot to die;
Love, that great Mater of all Arts:
And this dear Cypher, is to let you ee,
Love unites Names, as well as Hearts.

div.p:
Without this charming Union, our Souls could not communicate thoe inviible Sweetnees, which compleat the Felicity of Lovers; and which, the mot tender and paionate Expreions, are too feeble to make us comprehend. But, my adorable Iris, I am contented
<> he vat Pleaure I feel in loving well, without the Care of expreing it well; if you will imagine my Pleaure, without expreing it. For I confes, 'twou'd be no Joy to me to adore you, if you did not perfectly believe I did adore you. Nay, though you lov'd me, if you had no Faith in me, I hou'd languih, and love in as much Pain, as if you corn'd, and at the ame time believ'd I dy'd for you. For urely, Iris, 'tis a greater Pleaure to pleae, than to be pleas'd; and the glorious Power of giving, is infinitely a greater Satisfaction, than that of receiving; there is o great and Godlike a Quality in it. I wou'd have your Belief therefore equal to my Paion, extream; as indeed, all Love hou'd be, or it cannot bear that Divine Name: It can pas but for an indifferent Affection. And thee Cyphers ought to make the World find all the noble Force of delicate Paion. For, O my Iris! what wou'd
Love ignifie, if we did not love fervently. Siters and Brothers Love; Friends and Relations have Affections; but where the Souls are joyn'd, which are fill'd with eternal oft Wihes, Oh! there is ome Exces of Pleaure, which cannot be expret!

Your Looks, your dear obliging Words, and your charming Letters have ufficiently perwaded me of your Tendernes; and you might urely ee the Exces of my Paion, by my Cares, my Sighs, and entire Reignation <>
your Will. I never think of Iris, but <>
Heart feels double Flames, and pants and heaves with double Sighs; and whoe <>
makes its Ardors known, by a thouand <>
ports: And they are very much to blame <>
give the Name of Love to feeble eaie Paions: Such tranitory tranquil Inclinations are at bet but Well-wihers to Love; and a Heart that has uch Heats as thoe, ought not put, it <>
into the Rank of thoe nobler Victims that are offer'd at the Shrine of Love. But our Souls, Iris, burn with a more glorious Flame, <>
lights and conducts us beyond a Poibility of loing one another. 'Tis this that <…>
my Hopes: 'Tis this alone makes me believe myelf worthy of Iris: And let her judge of its Violence, by the Greatnes of its Sple •
dour.

Does not a Paion of this Nature, o true <>
ardent, deerve to be crown'd? And will <>
wonder to ee, over this Cypher, a <…>
Myrtles; thoe Boughs, o acred to th •
<>
of Love, and o worhipt by Lovers? 'Tis with
thee oft Wreaths, that thoe are crown'd, who undertand how to love well and faithfully.

lg.l: The Smiles, the Graces, and the Sports,
That in the acred Groves maintain their Courts,
Are with thee Myrtles crown'd.
Thither the Nymphs their Garlands bring;
Their Beauties, and their Praies ing,
While Ecchoe's do the Songs reound.
<> , tho' a God, with Myrtle Wreaths,
<> his oft Temples bind.
More valu'd are thoe conecrated Leaves,
Th • n the bright Wealth, in Eatern Rocks confin'd:
And Crowns of Glory les Ambition move,
<> thoe more acred Diadems of Love.

div.head: The Second CYPHER.
div.p:
IS crown'd with Olives; and I add to the two Letters of our Names, an R, and an L, for Reciprocal Love. Every time that I have given you, O lovely Iris! Tetimonies of my Paion, I have been o blet, as to receive ome from your Bounty; and you have been pleas'd to flatter me with a Belief, that I was not indifferent to you. I dare therefore ay, that being honour'd with the Glory of your Tendernes and Care, I ought, as a Trophy of my illutrious Conquet, to adorn the Watch with a Cypher, that is o advantageous to me. Ought I not to eteem myelf the mot fortunate and happy of Mankind, to have exchang'd my Heart with o charming and admirable a Peron
as Iris? Ah! how weet, how precious is the Change; and how vat a Glory arrives to me from it! Oh! you mut not wonder if my Soul abandon itelf to a thouand Extaies! In the Merchandize of Hearts, Oh! how dear it is, to receive as much as one gives; and better Heart for Heart! Oh! I wou'd not receive mine again, for all the Crowns the Univere contains! Nor ought you, my Adorable, make any Vows or Wihes, ever to retrieve yours; or hew the leat Repentance for the Bleing you have given me. The Exchange we made, was confirm'd by a noble Faith; and you ought to believe, you have betow'd it well, <>
you are paid for it, a Heart that is o confor •
able to yours, o true, o jut, and o full of Adoration: And nothing can be the jut Recompence of Love, but Love; and to enjoy the true Felicity of it, our Hearts ought to keep an equal Motion; and, like the Scales • f Jutice, always hang even.

'Tis the Property of Reciprocal Love, to make the Heart feel the Delicacy of Love, and to give the Lover all the Eae and Softnes he can reaonably hope. Such a Love renders all things advantageous and properous: Such a Love triumphs over all other Pleaures. And I put a Crown of Olives over the Cypher of Reciprocal Love, to make known, that two Hearts, where Love is jutly equal, enjoy a Peace, that nothing can diturb.

q.l: Olives are never fading een;
But always flourihing, and green.
The Emblem 'tis of Love and Peace;
For love that's true, will never ceae:
And Peace does Pleaure till increae.
Joy to the World, the Peace of Kings imparts;
And Peace in Love ditributes it to Hearts.

div.head: The Third CYPHER.
div.p:
THE C, and the L, which are joyn'd to the Letters of our Names in this Cypher, crown'd with Laurel, explains a contant Love. It will not, my fair Iris, uffice, that my Love is extream, my Paion violent, and my Wihes fervent, or that our Loves are reciprocal: But it ought alo to be contant; for in Love, the Imagination is oftner carried to thoe things that may arrive, and which we wih for, than to things that Time has robb'd us of: And in thoe agreeable Thoughts of Joys to come, the Heart takes more delight to wander, than in all thoe that are pat; though the Remembrance of 'em are very dear, and very charming. We hou'd be both unjut, if we were not perwaded we are poet with a Vertue, the Ue of which is o admirable, as that of Contancy. Our Loves are not of that ort, that can finih, or have end; but uch a Paion, o perfect, and o contant, that it will be a Preident for future Ages, to love perfectly; and when they wou'd expres an extream Paion, they will ay, They lov'd, as Damon did the charming Iris. And he that knows
the Glory of contant Love, will depie thoe fading Paions, thoe little Amuements, that erve for a Day. What Pleaure, or Dependance can one have in a Love of that ort? What Concern? What Raptures can uch an Amour produce in a Soul? And what, Satis ••
ction can one promie one's elf, in playing with a fale Gameter; who, though you are aware of him, in pight of all your Precaution, puts the fale Dice upon you, and wins all?

lg.l: Thoe Eyes, that can no better Conquest make,
Let 'em ne'r look abroad:
Such, but the empty Name of Lovers take,
And o prophane the God.
Better they never hou'd pretend,
Than e'er begun to make an End.
Of that fond Flame, what hall we ay,
That's born and languih'd in a Day?
Such hort-liv'd Bleings cannot bring
The Pleaure of an Envying.
Who is't will celebrate that Flame,
That's damn'd to uch a canty Fame?
While contant Love, the Nymphs and Swains
Still acred make, in lating Strains,
And chearful Lays throughout the Plains.
A contant Love knows no Decay;
But till advancing e'ery D •• ,
Will last as long as Life can tay,
With e'ery Look and Smile improves,
With the ame Ardour always moves,
With uch, as Damon, charming Iris loves!

div.p:
Contant Love finds it elf impoible to be
• ken; it reits the Attacks of Envy, and a thouand Accidents that endeavour to change it: Nothing can dioblige it, but a known Falenes, or Contempt: Nothing can remove it,
<> for a hort Moment it may lie ullen and
<> , it recovers, and returns with greater Force and Joy. I therefore, with very good Reaon, Crown this Cypher of Contant Love with a Wreath of Laurel; ince uch Love always triumphs over Time and Fortune, though it be not her Property to beiege; for he cannot overcome, but in defending herelf; but the Victories he gains, are never the les glorious.

q.l: For far les Conquest, we have known
The Victor wear the Laurel Crown.
The Triumph with more Pride let him receive;
While thoe of Love, at least, more Pleaures give.

div.head: The Fourth CYPHER.
div.p:
PErhaps, my lovely Maid, you will not find out what I mean by the S, and the L, in this lat Cypher, that is crown'd with Roes. I will therefore tell you, I mean Secret Love. There are very few People, who know the Nature of that Pleaure, which o Divine a Love creates: And let me ay what I will of it, they mut feel it themelves, who wou'd rightly undertand
it, and all its ravihing Sweets. But this there is a great deal of Reaon to believe, the Secrecy in Love doubles the Pleaures of it. And I am o abolutely perwaded of this, that I believe all thoe Favours that are not kept ••
cret, are dull and paul'd, very inipid and <>
Pleaures: And let the Favours be never ••
innocent that a Lover receives from a Mitre •• , he ought to value 'em, et a Price upon ' ••
and make the Lover pay dear; while he recei ••
'em with Difficulty, and ometimes with Hazard. A Lover that is not ecret, but uffers every one to count his Sighs, has, at mot, but a feeble Paion, uch as produces udden and tranitory Deires, which die as oon as born. A true Love has not this Character; for whenoever 'tis made Publick, it ceaes to be a Pleaure, and is only the Reult of Vanity. Not that I expect our Loves hou'd always remain a Secret: No, I hou'd never, at that Rate, arrive to a Bleing, which, above all the Glories of the Earth, I apire to; but even then, there are a thouand Joys, a thouand Pleaures that I hall be as careful to conceal from the foolih World, as if the whole Preervation of that Pleaure depended on my Silence; as indeed ••
does in a great Meaure.

To this Cypher I put a Crown of Roes, which are not Flowers of a very lating Date. And 'tis to let you ee, that 'tis impoible Love ••
be long hid. We ee every Day, with what fine Diimulation and Pains, People conceal a thouand Hates and Malices, Diguts, Diobligations, and Reentments, without being able to
conceal the leat part of their Love; but Reputation has an Ardour, as well as Roes; and a Lover ought to eteem that as the dearet and tenderet Thing; not only that of his own, which is, indeed, the leat part; but that of his Mitres, more valuable to him than Life. He ought to endeavour to give People no occaion to make fale Judgments of his Actions or to give their Cenures; which, mot certainly are never in the Favour of the fair Peron; for likely, thoe fale Cenures are of the buie Female Sex, the Coquets of that number; whoe little Spights and Railleries, joyn'd to that fancy'd Wit they boat of, ets 'em at Odds with all the Beautiful and Innocent: And how very little of that kind erves to give the World a Faith, when a thouand Vertues, told of the ame Perons, by more credible Witnees and Judges, hall pas unregarded; o willing and inclin'd is all the World to credit the Ill, and condemn the Good. And yet, Oh! what pity 'tis, we are compell'd to live in Pain, to oblige this foolih candalous World! And tho' we know each others Vertue and Honour, we are oblig'd to oberve that Caution (to humour the Talking Town) which takes away o great a part of the Pleaure of Life! 'Tis therefore that among thee Roes, you will find ome Thorns; by which you may imagine, that in Love, Precaution is neceary to its Secrecy: And we mut retrain our elves, upon a thouand Occaions, with o much Care, that, O Iris! 'tis impoible to be Dicreet, without Pain; but 'tis a Pain that creates a thouand Pleaures.

lg.l: Where hou'd a Lover hide his Joys,
Free from Malice, free from Noie?
Where no Envy can intrude:
Where no buie Rival's Spy,
Made, by Diappointment, made,
May inform his Jealouie.
The Heart will their best Refuge prove;
Which Nature meant the Cabinet of Love.
What wou'd a Lover not endure,
His Mitres, Fame and Honour to ecure?
Iris, the Care we take to be dicreet,
Is the dear Toyl, that makes the Pleaure weet.
The Thorn that does the We althinc loe,
That with les awcy Freedom we may touch the Roe.

div.head: The CLASP of the WATCH.
div.p: AH, charming Iris! Ah, my lovely Maid! 'Tis now in a more peculiar Manner, that I require your Aid in the finihing of my Deign, and compleating the whole Peice to the utmot Perfection; and without your Aid it cannot be perform'd. It is about the Clap of the Watch; a Material, in all appearance, the mot trivial of any part of it. But that it may be afe for ever, I deign it the Image, or Figure of Two Hands; that fair One of the adorable Iris, joyn'd to mine; with this Motto, Inviolable Faith: For this Cae, this Heart ought to be hut up by this eternal Clap. Oh, there is nothing o neceary as this! Nothing can ecure Love, but Faith.

That Vertue ought to be a Guard to all the Heart thinks, and all the Mouth utters: Nor can Love ay he triumphs without it. And when that remains not in the Heart, all the ret deerves no Regard. Oh! I have not lov'd o ill, to leave one Doubt upon your Soul. Why then, will you want that Faith? O unkind Charmer, that my Paion, and my Services o jutly merit!

lg.l: When two Hearts entirely love,
And in one Sphere of Honour move,
Each maintains the other's Fire,
With a Faith that is entire.
For what heedles Youth betows,
On a faithles Maid, his Vows.
Faith without Love, bears Vertue's Price;
But Love, without her Mixture, is a Vice.
Love, like Religion, till hou'd be,
In the Foundation, firm and true:
In Points of Faith, hou'd till agree:
Tho' Innovations vain and new
(Love's little Quarrels) may arie;
In Fundamentals till they're just and wie.
Then, charming Maid, be ure of this:
Allow me Faith as well as Love;
Since that alone affords no Blis,
nles your Faith your Love improve.
Either reolve to let me die
By fairer Play, your Cruelty;
Than not your Love, with Faith impart,
And with your Vows, to give your Heart.
In mad Depair I'd rather fall,
Than loe my glorious Hopes of conqu'ring all.

div.p: So certain it is, that Love without Faith, is of no value.

In fine, my adorable Iris, this Cae hall be, as near as I can, like thoe delicate ones of Filligrin Work, which do not hinder the Sight from taking a View of all within: You may therefore ee, through this Heart, all your Watch. Nor is my Deire of preerving this inetimable Piece more, than to make it the whole Rule of my Life and Actions. And my chiefet Deign in thee Cyphers, is to comprehend in them, the principal Vertues that are mot neceary to Love. Do not we know, that Reciprocal Love is Jutice; Contant Love, Fortitude; Secret Love, Prudence? Though 'tis true, that Extream Love, that is, Exces of Love, in one Sene, appears not to be Temperance; yet you mut know, my Iris, that in Matters of Love, Exces is a Vertue, and that all other Degrees of Love are worthy Scorn alone. 'Tis this alone, that can make good the glorious Title: 'Tis this alone, that can bear the true Name of Love; and this alone, that can bear the true Name of Love; and this alone, that renders the Lovers truly happy, in pight of all the Storms of Fate, and Shocks of Fortune. This is an Antidote againt all other Griefs: This bears up the Soul in all Calamity; and is the very Heaven of Life, the
lat Refuge of all Worldly Pain and Care, and may well bear the Title of Divine.

lg.l: That Love may all Perfection be;
Sweet, Charming to the last Degree,
The Heart, where the bright Flame does dwell,
In Faith and Softnes hou'd excel:
Exces of Love hou'd fill each Vein,
And all its acred Rites maintain.
The tend'rest Thoughts Heav'n can inpire,
Shou'd be the Fuel to its Fire:
And that, like Incene, burn as pure;
Or that, in rns, hou'd till endure.
No fond Deire hou'd fill the Soul,
But uch as Honour may controul.
Jealouie I will allow:
Not the amorous Winds that blow
Shou'd wanton in my Iris Hair,
Or ravih Kies from my Fair.
Not the Flowers that grow beneath,
Shou'd borrow Sweetnes of her Breath.
If her Bird he do cares,
How I grudge its Happines,
When upon her Snowy Hand,
The Wanton does triumphing tand!
Or upon her Brest he skips,
And lays her Beak to Iris Lips!
Fainting at my raviht Joy,
I cou'd the Innocent detroy.
If I can no Blis afford,
To a little harmles Bird,
Tell me, O thou dear lov'd Maid!
What Reaon cou'd my Rage perwade,
If a Rival hou'd invade?
If thy charming Eyes hou'd dart
Looks, that ally from the Heart;
If you ent a Smile, or Glance
To another, tho' by Chance;
Still thou giv't what's not thy own:
They belong to me alone.
All Submiion I wou'd pay.
Man was born, the Fair t'obey.
Your very Look I'd undertand,
And thence receive your least Command:
Never your Jutice will dipute;
But, like a Lover, execute.
I wou'd no urper be,
But in claiming acred thee.
I wou'd have all, and every part:
No Thought hou'd hide within thy Heart.
Mine a Cabinet was made,
Where Iris Secrets hou'd be laid.
In the rest, without Controul,
She hou'd triumph o're the Soul:
Protrate at her feet I'd lie,
Depiing Power and Liberty;
Glorying more by Love to fall,
Than rule the niveral Ball.
Hear me, O you awcy Youth!
And from my Maxims, learn this Truth.
Wou'd you great and powerful prove?
Be an humble Slave to Love.
'Tis nobler far, a Joy to give,
Than any Bleing to receive.

div.p: THE LADYs' Looking—Glas, TO DRESS Herelf by: OR, THE Whole ART OF CHARMING.
By Mrs. BEHN.
LONDON: Printed by W. Onley, for S. Bricoe. 1697.

div.head: THE Lady's Looking-Glas, TO DRESS Herelf by: OR, THE ART of Charming.
div.p:
HOW long, O charming Iris! hall I peak in vain of your adorable Beauty? You have been jut, and believe I love you with a Paion perfectly tender and extream; and yet you will not allow your Charms to be infinite. You mut either accue my Flames to be unreaonable, and that my Eyes and Heart are fale Judges of Wit and Beauty; or allow, that you are the mot perfect of your Sex. But intead of that, you always accue of me Flattery, when I peak of your infinite Merit; and when I refer you to your Glas, you tell me, that flatters, as well as Damon; though one
wou'd imagine, that hou'd be a good Witnes for the Truth of what I ay, and undeceive you of the Opinion of my Injutice. Look—and confirm yourelf, that nothing can equal your Perfections. All the World ays it, and you mut doubt it no longer. O Iris! Will you dipute againt the whole World?

But ince you have o long ditruted your own Glas, I have here preented you with one, which I know is very true; and having been made for you only, can erve only you. All other Glaes preent all Objects, but this reflects only Iris; whenever you conult it, it will convince you; and tell you, how much Right I have done you, when I told you, you were the fairet Peron that ever Nature made. When other Beauties look into it, it will peak to all the fair Ones; but let 'em do what they will, 'twill ay nothing to their Advantage.

lg.l: Iris, to pare what you call flattery,
Conult your Glas each Hour of the Day:
'Twill tell you where your Charms and Beauties lie,
And where your little wanton Graces play:
Where Love does revel in your Face and Eyes;
What Look invites your Slaves, and what denies.
Where all the Loves adorn you with uch Care,
Where dres your Smiles, where arm your lovely Eyes;
Where deck the flowing Trees of your Hair:
How caue your Snowy Breats to fall and rie:
How this evere Glance makes the Lover die;
How that, more oft, gives Immortality.
Where you hall ee, what 'tis enlaves the Soul;
Where e'ry Feature, e'ry Look combines:
When the adorning Air, o're all the whole,
To o much Wit, and o nice Vertue joyns.
Where the Belle Taille and Motion till afford
Graces to be eternally ador'd.

div.p: But I will be ilent now, and let your Glas peak.

div.head: THE Lady's Looking-Glas.
div.p: DAmon, (O charming Iris!) has given me to you, that you may ometimes give your elf the Trouble, and me the Honour of Conulting me in the great and weighty Affairs of Beauty. I am, my adorable Mitres! a faithful Glas; and you ought to believe all I ay to you.

div.head: The Shape of IRIS.
div.p:
I Mut begin with your Shape, and tell you, without Flattery, 'tis the finet in the World, and gives Love and Admiration to all that ee you. Pray oberve how free and eaie it is, without Contraint, Stiffnes, or Affectation; thoe mitaken Graces of the Fantatick, and the Formal; who give themelves Pain to hew their Will to pleae; and whoe Dreing makes the greatet part of its Finenes, when they are more oblig'd to the Taylor, than to Nature; who add, or diminih, as occaion erves, to form a Grace, where Heaven never gave it: And while they remain on this
Wreck of Pride, they are eternally uneaie, without pleaing any Body. Iris, I have een a Woman of your Acquaintance, who, having a greater Opinion of her own Peron, than any Body ele, has crew'd her Body into o fine a Form (as he calls it) that he dares no more tir a Hand, lift up an Arm, or turn her Head aide, than if, for the Sin of uch a Diorder, he were to be turn'd into a Pillar of Salt; the les tiff and fix'd Statue of the two. Nay, he dares not peak or mile, let he hou'd put her Face out of that order he had et it in her Glas, when he lat look'd on herelf: And is all over uch a Lady Nice (excepting in her Converation) that ever made a ridiculous Figure. And there are many Ladies more, but too much tainted with that naueous Formality, that old-fahion'd Vice: But Iris, the charming, the all-perfect Iris, has nothing in her whole Form, that is not free, natural, and eaie; and whoe every Motion cannot pleae extreamly and which has not given Damon a thouand Rivals.

lg.l: Damon. the Young, the Am'rous, and the True;
Who ighs inceantly for you:
Whoe whole Delight, now you are gone,
Is to retire to Shades alone,
And to the Eccho's make his Moan.
By purling Streams the wihing Youth is laid,
Still ighing Iris! lovely charming Maid!
See, in thy Abence, how thy Lover dies;
While to his Sighs, the Eccho till replies.
Then with the Stream he holds Dicoure:
O thou that bend't thy liquid force
To lovely Tames! upon whoe Shore
The Maid reides, whom I adore!
My Tears of Love upon thy Surface bear:
And if upon thy Banks thou eest my Fair,
In all thy oftest Murmurs ing,
From Damon I this Preent bring;
My e'ery Curl contains a Tear!
Then at her Feet thy Tribute pay:
But hate, O happy Stream! away;
Lest charm'd too much, thou houd'st for ever tay.
And thou, O gentle, murm'ring Breeze!
That plays in Air, and wantons with the Trees;
On thy young Wings, where gilded Sun-beams play,
To Iris my oft Sighs convey,
Still as they rie, each Minute of the Day:
But whiper gently in her Ear;
Let not the ruder Winds thy Meage hear,
Nor ruffle one dear Curl of her bright Hair.
Oh! touch her Cheeks with acred Reverence,
And tay not gazing on her lovely Eye!
But if thou bear'st her Roie Breath from thence,
'Tis Incene of that Excellence,
That as thou mount'st, 'twill perfume all the Skies.

div.head: IRIS'S Complexion.
