div.p: SAY what you will, I am confident, if you will confes your Heart, you are, every time you view yourelf in me, urpriz'd at the Beauty of your Complexion; and will ecretly own, you never aw any thing o fair. I am not the firt Glas, by a thouand, that has aur'd you of this. If you will not believe me, ask Damon; he tells it you every Day, but that Truth from him offends you; and becaue he loves too much, you think his Judgment too little; and ince this is o perfect, that mut be defective. But 'tis mot certain, your Complexion is infinitely fine, your Skin oft and mooth, as poliht Wax, or Ivory, extreamly white and clear; though if any Body peaks but of your Beauty, an agreeable Bluh cats itelf all over your Face, and gives you a thouand new Graces.

q.l: And then two Flowers, newly born,
Shine in your Heav'nly Face:
The Roe, that bluhes in the Morn,
Sometimes the Lilly does prevail,
And makes the gen'rous Crimon pale.

div.head: IRIS'S Hair.
div.p:
OH, the beautiful Hair of Iris! It eems, as if Nature had crown'd you with a great
Quantity of lovely fair brown Hair, to make us know, that you were born to Rule; and to repair the Faults of Fortune, that has not given you a Diadem: And do not bewail the Want of that (o much your Merit's due) ince Heaven has o gloriouly recompens'd you with what gains more admiring Slaves.

q.l: Heav'n for Sovereignty, has made your form:
And you were more than for dull Empire born.
O'er Hearts your Kingdom hall extend,
Your vast Dominion know no end.
Thither the Loves and Graces hall reort;
To Iris make their Homage, and their Court.
No envious Star, no common Fate,
Did on my Iris Birth-day wait;
But all was happy, all was delicate.
Here Fortune wou'd incontant be in vain:
Iris, and Love, eternally hall reign.

div.p:
Love does not make les ue of your Hair for new Conquets, than of all the ret of your Beauties that adorn you. If he takes our Hearts with your fine Eyes, it ties 'em fat with your Hair; and if it weaves a Chain, not eaily broken. It is not of thoe orts of Hair, whoe harhnes dicovers ill Nature; nor of thoe, whoe Softnes hews us the Weaknes of the Mind: Not that either of thee are Arguments without Exception; but 'tis uch as bears the Character of a perfect Mind, and a delicate Wit; and for its Colour, the mot faithful, dicreet, and beautiful in the World; uch as hews a Complexion and Contitution, neither
o cold, to be inenible; nor o hot, to have too much Fire; that is, neither too white, nor too black; but uch a mixture of the two Colours, as makes it the mot agreeable in the World.

q.l: 'Tis that which leads thoe captivated Hearts,
That bleeding at your Feet do lie.
'Tis that the Obtinate converts,
That dare the Power of Love deny.
'Tis that which Damon o admires;
Damon, who often tells you o.
If from your Eyes Love takes his Fires,
'Tis with your Hair he trings his Bow:
Which touching but the feather'd Dart,
It never mist the detin'd Heart.

div.head: IRIS'S Eyes.
div.p: I Believe, my fair Mitres, I hall dazle you with the Lutre of your own Eyes. They are the finet Blue in the World: They have all the Sweetnes, that ever charm'd the Heart; with a certain Languihment that's irreitable; and never any look'd on 'em, that did not igh after 'em. Believe me, Iris, they carry unavoidable Darts and Fires; and whoever expoe themelves to their Dangers, pay for their Imprudence.

lg.l: Cold as my olid Chrytal is,
Hard and impenetrable too;
Yet I am enible of Blis,
When your charming Eyes I view:
Even by me, their Flames are felt;
And at each Glance, I fear to melt.
Ah, how pleaant are my Days!
How my glorious Fate I bles!
Mortals never knew my Joys,
Nor Monarchs guest my Happines.
Every Look that's oft and gay,
Iris gives me every Day.
Spight of her Vertue, and her Pride,
Every Morning I am blest
With what to Damon is deny'd;
To view her when he is undrest.
All her Heaven of Beauty's hown
To triumphing Me—alone.
Scarce the prying Beams of Light,
Or th' impatient God of Day,
Are allow'd o dear a Sight,
Or dare prophane her with a Ray;
When he has appear'd to me,
Like Venus riing from the Sea.
But Oh! I must thoe Charms conceal,
All too Divine for vulgar Eyes:
Shou'd I my ecret Joys reveal,
Of acred Trust I break the Tyes;
And Damon wou'd with Envy die,
Who hopes, one Day, to be as blest as I.

div.p:
Extravagant with my Joys, I have tray'd beyond my Limits; for I was telling you of the wondrous Finenes of your Eyes; which no
Mortal can reit, nor any Heart tand the force of their Charms; and the mot difficult Conquets they gain, carce cot 'em the Expence of a Look. They are modet and tender, chate and languihing. There you may take a View of the whole Soul, and ee Wit and Good Nature (thoe two ineparable Vertues of the Mind) in an extraordinary Meaure. In fine, you ee all that fair Eyes can produce, to make themelves ador'd. And when they are angry, they trike an unreitable Awe upon the Soul: And thoe Severities, Damon wihes, may perpetually accompany them, during their Abence from him; for 'tis with uch Eyes, he wou'd have you receive all his Rivals.

lg.l: Keep, lovely Maid, the Softnes in your Eyes,
To flatter Damon with another Day:
When at your Feet the ravih'd Lover lies,
Then put on all that's tender, all that's gay:
And for the Griefs your Abence makes him prove,
Give him the oftest, dearest Looks of Love.
His trembling Heart with weetest Smiles cares,
And in your Eyes, oft Wihes let him find;
That your Regret of Abence may confes,
In which, no Sene of Pleaure you cou'd find:
And to retore him, let your faithful Eyes
Declare, that all his Rivals you depie.

div.head: The Mouth of IRIS.
div.p: I Perceive your Modety wou'd impoe Silence on me: But, O fair Iris! Do not think to preent yourelf before a Glas, if you wou'd not have it tell you all your Beauties: Content yourelf, that I only peak of 'em, En Paant; for hou'd I peak what I wou'd, I hou'd dwell all Day upon each particular, and till ay omething new. Give me Liberty then to peak of your fine Mouth: You need only open it a little, and you will ee the mot delicate Teeth, that ever you beheld; the whitet, and the bet et. Your Lips are the finet in the World; o round, o oft, o plump, o dimpled, and of the loveliet Colour. And when you mile, Oh! What Imagination can conceive how weet it is, that has not een you Smiling? I cannot decribe what I o admire; and 'tis in vain to thoe, who have not een Iris.

lg.l: O Iris! boast that one peculiar Charm,
That has o many Conquets made;
So innocent, yet capable of harm;
So just itelf, yet has o oft betray'd
Where a thouand Graces dwell,
And wanton round in e'ery Smile.
A thouand Loves do liten when you peak,
And catch each Accent as it flies:
Rich flowing Wit, when e're you Silence break,
Flows from your Tongue, and parkles in your Eyes
Whether you talk, or ilent are;
Your Lips immortal Beauties were.

div.head: The Neck of IRIS.
div.p: ALL your Modety, all your nice Care, cannot hide the ravihing Beauties of your Neck; we mut ee it, Coy as you are; and ee it the whitet, and finet hap'd, that ever was form'd. Oh! Why will you cover it? You know, all handome things wou'd be een. And Oh! how often have you made your Lovers envy your Scarf, or any thing that hides o fine an Object from their ight. Damon himelf complains of your too nice Severity. Pray do not hide it o carefully. See how perfectly turn'd it is; with mall blue Veins, wandring and ranging here and there, like little Rivulets, that wanton o'er the flowry Meads. See how the round white riing Breats heave with every Breath, as if they didain'd to be confin'd to a Covering; and repel the malicious Cloud, that wou'd obcure their Brightnes.

q.l: Fain I wou'd have leave to tell
The Charms that on your Boom dwell;
Decribe it like ome flow'ry Field,
That does ten thouand Pleaures yield;
A thouand gliding Springs and Groves;
All Receptacles for Loves.
But Oh! what Iris hides, must be
Ever acred kept by me.

div.head: The Arms and Hands of IRIS.
div.p: I Shall not be put to much trouble to hew you your Hands and Arms, becaue you may view them without my help; and you are very unjut, if you have not admir'd 'em a Thouand times. The beautiful Colour and Proportion of your Arm is unimitable, and your Hand is dazling, fine, mall, and plump; long-pointed Fingers, delicately turn'd; dimpl'd on the Snowy out-ide, but adorn'd within with Roe, all over the oft Palm. O Iris! Nothing equals your fair Hand; that Hand, of which Love o often makes uch ue to draw his Bow, when he wou'd end the Arrow home with more ucces; and which irreitibly wounds thoe, who poibly, have not yet een your Eyes: And when you have been veil'd, that lovely Hand has gain'd you a thouand Adorers. And I have heard Damon ay, Without the Aid of more Beauties, that alone had been ufficient to have made an abolute Conquest o'er his Soul. And he has often vow'd, It never touch'd him, but it made his Blood run with little irregular Motions in his Veins; his Breath beat hort and double; his Bluhes rie, and his very Soul dance.

lg.l: Oh! how the Hand the Lover ought to prize,
'Bove any one peculiar Grace,
While he is dying for the Eyes,
And doting on the lovely Face.
The nconid'ring little knows,
How much he to this Beauty owes.
That when the Lover abent is,
Informs him of his Mitres Heart.
'Tis that, which gives him all his Blis,
When dear Love-Secrets 'twill impart.
That plights the Faith the Maid betows:
And that confirms the tim'rous Vows.
'Tis that betrays the Tendernes,
Which the too bahful Tongue denies.
'Tis that, that does the Heart confes,
And pares the Language of the Eyes.
'Tis that, which Treaures gives o vast:
Ev'n Iris 'twill to Damon give at last.

div.head: The Grace and Air of IRIS.
div.p:
'TIS I alone, O charming Maid! that can hew you that noble part of your Beauty: That generous Air, that adorns all your lovely Peron, and renders every Motion and Action perfectly adorable. With what a Grace you walk!—How free, how eaie, and how unaffected! See how you move;—for only here you can ee it. Damon has told you a thouand times, that never any Mortal had o glorious an Air; but he cou'd not half decribe it, nor wou'd you credit even what he aid; but with a careles Smile, pas it off for the Flattery of a Lover. But here behold, and be convinc'd; and know, no part of your Beauty can charm more than this. O Iris, confes, Love has adorn'd you with all his Art and Care. Your Beauties are the Themes of all the Mues; who tell you in daily Songs, that the Graces themelves have
not more than Iris. And one may truly ay, that you alone know how to joyn the Ornaments and Dres, with Beauty; and you are till adorn'd, as if that Shape and Air had a peculiar Art to make all things appear gay and fine. Oh, how well dret you are! How every thing becomes you! Never ingular, never gawdy; but always uiting with your Quality.

lg.l: Oh, how that Negligence becomes your Air!
That careles flowing of your Hair,
That plays about with wanton Grace,
With every Motion of your Face:
Didaining all that dull Formality,
That dares not move the Lip, or Eye;
But at ome fancy'd Grace's cost;
And think, with it, at least, a Lover lost.
But the unlucky Minute to reclaim,
And eae the Coquet of her Pain,
The Pocket-Glas adjuts the Face again:
Re-ets the Mouth, and languihes the Eyes;
And thinks, the Spark that ogles that way—dies.
Of Iris learn, O ye mitaken Fair!
To dres your Face, your Smiles, your Air.
Let eaie Nature all the Bus'nes do;
She can the ofter Graces hew:
Which Art but turns to Ridicule;
And where there's none, erves but to hew the Fool.
In Iris you all Graces find;
Charms without Art, a Motion unconfin'd;
Without Contraint, he miles, he looks, he talks;
And without Affectation, moves and walks.
Beauties o perfect ne'er were een:
O ye mitaken Fair! Dres ye by Iris Mien.

div.head: The Dicretion of IRIS.
div.p:
BUT O Iris! The Beauties of the Body are imperfect, if the Beauties of the Soul do not advance themelves to an equal height. But, O Iris! What Mortal is there o damned to Malice, that does not, with Adoration, confes, that you (O charming Maid!) have an equal Portion of all the Braveries and Vertues of the Mind? And, who is it, that confees your Beauty, that does not, at the ame time acknowledge and bow to your Widom? The whole World admires both in you; and all, with impatience, ask, Which of the two is mot urpriing, your Beauty, or your Dicretion? But we dipute in vain on that excellent Subject; for after all, 'tis determin'd, that the two Charms are equal. 'Tis none of thoe idle Dicretions that conits in Words alone, and ever takes the Shadow of Reaon for the Subtance; and that makes ue of all the little Artifices of Subtilty, and florid Talking, to make the outide of the Argument appear fine, and leave the inide wholly mi-undertood: Who runs away with Words, and never thinks of Sence. But you, O lovely Maid! never make ue of thee affected Arts; but without being too brisk, or too evere; too ilent, or too talkative; you apire in all your Hearers, a Joy, and a Repect. Your Soul is an Enemy to that uual Vice of your Sex, of uing little Arguments againt the Fair; or by a Word,
or Jet, make your elf and Hearers pleaant, at the Expence of the Fame of others.

Your Heart is an Enemy to all Paions, but that of Love. And this is one of your noble Maxims: That every one ought to love, in ome part of his Life: And that, in a Heart truly brave, Love is without Folly: That Widom is a Friend to Love, and Love to perfect Widom. Since thee Maxims are your own, do not, O charming Iris! reit that noble Paion: And ince Damon is the mot tender of all your Lovers, anwer his Paion with a noble Ardour: Your Prudence never fails in the Choice of your Friends; and in chuing o well your Lover, you will tand an eternal Preident to all unreaonable fair Ones.

q.l: O thou that dost excel in Wit and Youth!
Be till a Preident for Love and Truth.
Let the dull World ay what it will,
A noble Flame's unblameable.
Where a fine Sent'ment, and oft Paion rules,
They corn the Cenure of the Fools.
Yield, Iris, then; Oh, yield to Love!
Redeem your dying Slave from pain:
The World your Conduct must approve:
Your Prudence never acts in vain.

div.head: The Goodnes and Complaiance of Iris.
div.p:
WHO but your Lovers (fair Iris!) doubts, but you are the mot complaiant Peron in the World: And that with o much Sweetnes you oblige all, that you command
in yielding; and as you gain the Heart of both Sexes, with the Affability of your noble Temper; o all are proud and vain of obliging you. And Iris, you may live aur'd, that your Empire is eternally etablih'd, by your Beauty, and your Goodnes: Your Power is confirm'd, and you grow in Strength every Minute: Your Goodnes gets you Friends, and your Beauty Lovers.

This Goodnes is not one of thoe, whoe Folly renders it eaie to every Deirer; but a pure Effect of the Generoity of your Soul; uch as Prudence alone manages, according to the Merit of the Peron, to whom it is extended; and thoe whom you eteem, receive the weet Marks of it; and only your Lovers complain: Yet even then you charm. And though ometimes you can be a little diturb'd, yet through your Anger, your Goodnes hines; and you are but too much afraid, that that may bear a fale Interpretation: For oftentimes Scandal makes that pas for an Effect of Love, which is purely that of Complaiance.

Never had any Body more Tendernes for their Friends, than Iris: Their Preence gives her Joy; their Abence, Trouble; and when he cannot ee them, he finds no Pleaure, like peaking of them obligingly. Friendhip reigns in your Heart, and Sincerity on your Tongue. Your Friendhip is o trong, o contant, and o tender, that it charms, pleaes, and atisfies all, that are not your Adorers. 'Tis therefore, Damon is excuable, if he be not contented with your noble Friendhip
alone; for he is the mot tender of that Number.

lg.l: No! Give me all, th' impatient Lover cries;
Without your Soul, I cannot live:
Dull Friendhip cannot mine uffice,
That dies for all you have to give.
The Smiles, the Vows, the Heart must all be mine:
I cannot pare one Thought, or Wih of thine.
I igh, I languih all the Day;
Each Minute uhers in my Groans:
To e'ry God in vain I pray;
In e'ry Grove repeat my Moans.
Still Iris Charms are all my Sorrows Themes!
They pain me Waking, and they wreck in Dreams.
Return, fair Iris! Oh, return!
Lest ighing long, your Slave detroys.
I wih, I rave, I faint, I burn;
Retore me quickly all my Joys:
Your Mercy ele, will come too late.
Ditance in Love more cruel is, than Hate.

div.head: The Wit of Iris.
div.p:
YOU are deceiv'd in me, fair Iris, if you take me for one of thoe ordinary Glaes, that repreent the Beauty only of the Body; I remark to you alo the Beauties of the Soul: And all about you declares yours the finet that ever was formed; that you have a Wit that urprizes, and is always new: 'Tis none of thoe that loes its Lutre, when one coniders
it; the more we examine yours, the more adorable we find it. You ay nothing, that is not at once agreeable and olid; 'tis always quick and ready, without Impertinence, that little Vanity of the Fair; who, when they know they have Wit, rarely manage it o, as not to abound in Talking; and think, that all they ay mut pleae, becaue luckily, they ometimes chance to do o. But Iris never peaks, but 'tis of ue; and gives a Pleaure to all that hears her. She has the perfect Art of penetrating, even the mot ecret Thoughts. How often have you known, without being told, all that has pat in Damon's Heart? For all great Wits are Prophets too:

lg.l: Tell me; Oh, tell me! Charming Prophetes;
For you alone can tell my Love's Succes.
The Lines in my dejected Face,
I fear, will lead you to no kind Reult:
It is your own, that you must trace;
Thoe of your Heart you must conult.
'Tis there, my Fortune I must learn,
And all that Damon does concern.
I tell you, that I love a Maid,
As bright as Heav'n, of Angel-hue:
The oftest, Nature ever made:
Whom I, with Sighs and Vows, purue.
Oh, tell me, charming Prophetes!
Shall I this lovely Maid poes?
A thouand Rivals do obtruct my Way;
A thouand Fears they do create:
They throng about her all the Day,
Whilst I at awful Ditance wait.
Say, will the lovely Maid o fickle prove,
To give my Rivals Hope, as well as Love?
She has a thouand Charms of Wit,
With all the Beauty Heav'n e're gave:
Oh! Let her not make ue of it,
To flatter me into the Slave.
Oh! Tell me Truth, to eae my Pain:
Say rather, I hall die by her Didain.

div.head: The Modety of Iris.
div.p:
I Perceive, fair Iris, you have a Mind to tell me, I have entertain'd you too long, with a Dicoure on yourelf. I know, your Modety makes this Declaration an offence, and you uffer me, with Pain, to unveil thoe Treaures you wou'd hide. Your Modety, that o commendable a Vertue in the Fair, and o peculiar to you, is here a little too evere: Did I flatter you, you hou'd bluh: Did I eek, by praiing you, to hew an Art of Speaking finely, you might chide. But, O Iris! I ay nothing, but uch plain Truths, as all the World can witnes are o. And o far I am from Flattery, that I eek no Ornament of Words. Why do you take uch Care to conceal your Vertues? They have too much Lutre, not to be een, in pight of all your Modety: Your Wit, your Youth, and
Reaon oppoe themelves, againt this dull Obtructer of our Happines. Abate, O Iris, a little of this Vertue, ince you have o many other, to defend yourelf againt the Attacks of your Adorers.

You yourelf have the leat Opinion of your own Charms: And being the only Peron in the World, that is not in love with 'em, you hate to pas whole Hours before your Looking-Glas; and to pas your time, like mot of the idle Fair, in dreing, and etting off thoe Beauties, which need o little Art. You, more wie, didain to give thoe Hours to the Fatigue of Dreing, which you know o well how to employ a thouand Ways. The Mues have blet you, above your Sex; and you know how to gain a Conquet with your Pen, more abolutely, than all the indutrious Fair, who trut to Dres and Equipage.

I have a thouand things to tell you more, but willingly reign my place to Damon, that faithful Lover; he will peak more ardently than I: For, let a Glas ue all its Force, yet, when it peaks its bet, it peaks but coldly.

If my Glas, O charming Iris! have the good Fortune (which I cou'd never entirely boat) to be believ'd, 'twill erve, at leat, to convince you, I have not been o guilty of Flattery, as I have a thouand times been charg'd. Since then my Paion is equal to your Beauty (without Comparion, or End) believe, O lovely Maid! how I igh in your Abence: And be perwaded to leen my pain, and retore me to my Joys;
for there is no Torment o great, as the Abence of a Lover from his Mitres; of which, this is the Idea.

div.head: The Effects of Abence from what we love.
div.l: Thou one continu'd Sigh! all over Pain!
Eternal Wih! but wih, alas, in vain!
Thou languihing, impatient Hoper on;
A buie Toiler, and yet till undone!
A breaking Glimpe of ditant Day,
Inticing on, and leading more atray.
Thou Joy in Propect, future Blis extream;
But ne're to be poest, but in a Dream.
Thou fab'lous Goddes, which the ravih'd Boy,
In happy Slumbers proudly did enjoy:
But waking found an Airy Cloud he prest;
His Arms came empty to his panting Breast.
Thou Shade, that only haunts the Soul by Night;
And when thou hou'dst inform, thou fly'st the Sight.
Thou fale Idea of the thinking Brain,
That labours for the charming Form in vain;
Which if by Chance it catch, thou'rt lost again.

div.p: THE Lucky Mitake.
A NEW NOVEL.
By Mrs. BEHN.
LONDON: Printed by William Onley, for S. Bricoe, and T. Chapman. 1697.

div.head: THE Lucky Mitake. A NEW NOVEL.
div.p:
THe River Loyre has on its delightful Banks abundance of handome, beautiful and rich Towns and Villages, to which the noble Stream adds no mall Graces and Advantages, bleing their Fields with Plenty, and their Eyes with a thouand Diverions: In one of thee happily ituated Towns, called Orleance, where abundance of People of the bet Quality and Condition reide, there was a rich Nobleman, now retird from the buie Court, where, in his Youth he had been bred, wearied with the Toyls of Ceremony and Noie, to enjoy that perfect Tranquility of Life, which is no where to be found, but in Retreat, a faithful Friend, and a good Library; and, as the Admirable Horace ays, in a little Houe and large Gardens, Count Bellyaurd, for o was this Nobleman call'd, was of this Opinion: and the rather, becaue he had one only Son, call'd Rinaldo, now grown to the Age of Fifteen, who having all the excellent Qualities and Graces of Youth, by Nature, he would bring him up in all Vertues and noble Sciences, which he believ'd the Gaiety and Lutre of the Court might divert: He therefore in his Retirement par'd no Cot, to thoe that could intruct and accomplih him; and he had the bet Tutors
and Maters that could be purchaed at Court; Bellyaurd making far les account of Riches than of fine Parts. He found his Son capable of all Impreions, having a Wit uitable to his delicate Peron, o that he was the ole Joy of his Life, and the Darling of his Eyes.

In the very next Houe, which joyn'd cloe to that of Bellyaurd's, there liv'd another Count, who had in his Youth been banih'd the Court of France for ome Miundertandings, in ome high Affairs wherein he was concern'd; his name was De Pais, a Man of great Birth, but no Fortune; or at leat one not uitable to the Grandeur of his Original: And as it is mot natural for great Souls to be mot proud (if I may call a handome Didain by that vulgar Name,) when they are mot depres'd; o De Pais was more retir'd, more
• trang'd from his Neighbours, and kept a greater Ditance, than if he had enjoy'd all he had lot at Court, and took more Solemnity and State upon him, becaue he would not be ubject to the Reproaches of the World, by making himelf familiar with it. So that he rarely viited, and was as rarely viited; and, contrary to the Cutom of thoe in France, who are eaie of Exces, and free of Converation, he kept his Family retir'd o cloe, that 'twas rare to ee any of 'em; but when they went abroad, which was but eldom, they wanted nothing as to outward appearance, that was fit for his Quality, and was much above his Condition.

This old Count had two only Daughters, of exceeding Beauty, who gave the generous Father Ten thouand Torments, as often as he beheld them, when he conider'd their extream Beauty, their fine W •• , their Innocence, Modety, and above all, their Birth; and that he had not the Fortune to marry them according to their Quality and below it, he had rather ee them laid in their ilent Graves, than conent to; for he corn'd the World hould ee him forced by his Poverty, to commit an Action below his Dignity.

There lived in a Neighbouring Town, a certain Nobleman, Friend to De Pais, call'd Count Vernole, a Man of about Forty Years of Age, of low Stature, Complexion very black and warthy, lean, lame, extream proud and haughty; extracted of a Decent from the Blood-Royal; not extreamly brave, but very glorious: He had no very great Etate, but was in Election of a greater, and of an Addition of Honour from the King, his Father having done mot worthy Services againt the Hugonots, and by the high Favour of Cardinal Mazarine, was repreented to his Majety, as a Man related to the Crown, of great Name, but mall Etate; o that there was now nothing but great Expectations and Preparations in the Family of Count Vernole to go to Court, to which he daily hop'd an Invitation or Command.

Vernole's Fortune being hitherto omething a kin to that of De Pais, there was a greater Correpondency between thee two Gentlemen, than they had with any other Perons; they accounting themelves above the ret of the World, believ'd none o proper and fit for their Converation, as that of each other; o that there was a very particular Intimacy between them: Whenever they went abroad, they clubb'd their Train, to make one great Show, and were always together, bemoaning each other's Fortune, that from o high a Decent, as one from Monarchs by the Mother's ide, and the other from Dukes of his ide, they were reduc'd by Fate, to the degree of private Gentlemen. They would often conult how to manage Affairs mot to advantage, and often De Pais would ask Counel of Vernole, how bet he hould dipoe of his Daughters, which now were about their ninth Year the eldet, and eight the younget. Vernole had often een thee two Buds of Beauty, and already aw opening in Atlante's Face and Mind (for that was the Name of the eldet, and Charlot the younget) a Glory of Wit and Beauty, which could not but one day diplay itelf, with dazling Lutre, to the wondring World.

Vernole was a great Virtuoo, of a Humour, Nice, Delicate, Critical and Opinionative: He had nothing of the French Mien in him, but all the Gravity of the Don. His ill-favour'd Peron, and his low Etate, put him out of Humour with the World; and becaue that hould not upbraid or reproach his Follies and Defects, he was ure to be before-hand with that, and to be always Satyrick upon it, and lov'd to live and act contrary to the Cutom and Uage of all Mankind beides.

He was infinitely delighted to find a Man of his own Humour in De Pais, or at leat a Man that would be perwaded to like his o well, to live up to it; and it was no little Joy and Satisfaction to him to find, that he kept his Daughters in that everity, which was wholly agreeable to him, and o contrary to the Manner and Fahion of the French of Quality; who allow all Freedoms, which to Vernole's rigid Nature, eem'd as o many Steps to Vice, and in his Opinion, the Ruiner of all Vertue and Honour in Woman-kind. De Pais was extreamly glad his Conduct was o well interpreted, which was no other in him, than a proud Frugality; who, becaue they could not appear, ino much Gallantry, as their Quality requir'd, kept 'em retir'd, and uneen to all, but his particular Friends, of which Vernole was chief.

Vernole never appear'd before Atlante (which was eldom,) but he aum'd a Gravity and Repect, fit to have entertain'd a Maid of Twenty, or rather a Matron, of much greater Years and Judgment. His Dicoures were always of Matters of State or Philoophy; and ometimes when De Pais would Laughing, ay, He might as well entertain Atlante with Greek and Hebrew, would reply gravely; You are mitaken Sir, I find the Seeds of great and profound Matter in the Soul of the young Maid, which ought to be nourih'd, now while he was young, and they will grow up to very great Perfection; I find Atlante capable of all the Noble Vertues of the Mind, and am infinitely mitaken in my Obervations, and Art of Phiiognomy, if Atlante be not born for greater
Things than her Fortune does now promie: She will be very Coniderable in the World, believe me, and this will arrive to her perfectly from the Force of her Charms. De Pais was extreamly overjoy'd to hear uch Good propheied to Atlante, and from that time, et a ort of an Eteem upon her, which he did not on Charlot his younger; who, by the Perwaions of Vernole, he reolv'd to put in a Monatery, that what he had might decend to Atlante; not but he confes'd Charlot had Beauty, extreamly attractive, and a Wit that promied much, when it hould be cultivated by Years and Experience; and would hew itelf with great Advantage, and Lutre in a Monatery: All this pleaed De Pais very well, who was eaily perwaded, ince he had not a Fortune to marry her well in the World.

As yet Vernole had never poke to Atlante of Love; nor did his Gravity think it Prudence to dicover his Heart to o young a Maid, he waited her more enible Years, when he could hoope to have ome return. And all he expected from this her tender Age, was by his daily Convere with her, and the Preents, he made her uitable to her Years, to ingratiate himelf inenibly into her Friendhip and Eteem: Since he was not yet capable of Love, but even in that he mitook his Aim, for every day he grew more and more diagreeable to Atlante, and would have been her abolute Averion, had he known, he had every day entertained a Lover; but as he grew in Years and Sene, he eemed the more depicable in her Eyes as to his Peron; but as he had repect to his Parts, and Qualities, he paid him all the Complaiance he could, and which was due to him; and o mut be confes'd, tho' he had a tiff Formality in all he aid and did, yet he had Wit and Learning, and was a great Philoopher; as much of his Learning, as Atlante was capable of attaining to, he made her Mitres of, and that was no mall Portion, for all his Dicoure was fine and eaily comprehended, his Notions of Philoophy fit for Ladies; and he took greater Pains with Atlante, than any Mater would have done with a
Scholar; o that it was mot certain, he added very great Accomplihment to her Natural Wit, and the more becaue he took a very great Delight in Philoophy; which very often made her impatient of his coming; epecially when he had many Quetions to ask him concerning it, and he wou'd often receive him with a Pleaure in her Face; which he did not fail to interpret to his own Advantage, being very apt to flatter himelf. Her Siter Charlot would often ask her, How he could give whole Afternoons to o diagreeable a Man: What is it, aid he, that charms <> , his tawny Leather Face, his extraordinary high Noe, ••
wide Mouth and Eye-brows, that hang lowring over ••
Eyes, his lean Carcae, and his lame and haulting Hips? But Atlante wou'd dicreetly reply, If I must grant al you ay of Count Vernole to be true, yet he has a Wit and Learning, that will attone ufficiently for all thoe Faults you mention: A fine Soul is infinitely to be preferr'd to a fine Body; this decays, but that's eternal; and Age that ruins one, refines the other. Though poibly Atlante thought as ill of the Count, as her Siter; yet in Repect to him, he would not own it.

Atlante was now arriv'd to her thirteenth Year, when her Beauty, which every day increas'd, became the Dicoure of the whole Town; which had already gain'd her as many Lovers as had beheld her, for none aw her without languihing for her, or at leat, but what were in very great Admiration of her. Every body talk'd of the young Atlante, and all the Noblemen, who had Sons (knowing the Smallnes of her Fortune, and the Lutre of her Beauty) would end them for fear of their being Charm'd with her, either to ome other part of the World, or exhorted them, by way of Precaution, to keep out of her ight. Old Bellyuard was one of thoe wie Parents, and by a timely Prevention, as he thought of Rinaldo's falling in Love with Atlante, perhaps was the Occaion of his being o; he had before heard of Atlante, and of her Beauty, but it had made no Impreions on his Heart; but his Father no ooner forbid him Loving, then he
felt a new Deire tormenting him, of eeing this lovely and dangerous young Peron; he wonders at his unaccountable Pain, which daily olicits him within, to go where he may behold this Beauty; of whom he frames a thouand Idea's, all uch as were mot agreeable to him; but then upbraids his Fancy, for not forming her half o delicate as he was; and longs yet more to ee her, to know how near he approaches to the Picture he has drawn of her in his Mind; and tho' he knew he liv'd the next Houe to him, yet he knew alo he was kept within like a Vow'd Nun, or with the Severity of a Spaniard: And tho' he had a Chamber, which had a jetting Window, that look'd jut upon the Door of Monieur De Pais, and that he would watch many Hours at a time, in hope to ee them go out, yet he could never get a glimps of her; yet he heard he often frequented the Church of our Lady: Thither then young Rinaldo reolv'd to go, and did o two or three Mornings, in which time, to his unpeakable Grief, he aw no Beauty appear that charm'd him; and yet he fancy'd that Atlante was there, and that he had een her, that ome one of thoe young Ladies, that he aw in the Church was he, tho' he had no body to enquire of, and that he was not o fair as the World reported; for which he would often igh, as if he had lot ome very great Expectation; however he ceaed not to frequent this Church, and one day aw a young Beauty, who at firt glimps made his Heart leap to his Mouth, and fell trembling again into its wanted place, for it immediately told him, that that young Maid was Atlante; he was with her Siter Charlot, who was very handome, but not comparable to Atlante: He fix'd his Eyes upon her, as he kneel'd at the Altar, he never remov • d from that charming Face as long as he remain'd there; he forgot all Devotion, but what he paid to her, he ador'd her, he burnt and languih'd already for her, and found he mut poes Atlante, or die: Often as he gaz'd upon her, he aw her fair Eyes lifted up towards his, where they often met; which he perceiving,
would cat hers down into her Boom, or on her Book, and bluh as if he had done a Fault: Charlot perceiv'd all the Motions of Rinaldo, how he folded his Arms, how he igh'd, and how he gaz'd on her Siter; he took notice of his Cloaths, his Garniture, and every particular of his Dres, as young Girls ue to do, and eeing him o very handome, and o much better dres'd than all the young Cavaliers that were in the Church, he was very much pleas'd with him; and could not forbear aying, in a low Voice, to Atlante, Look, look, my Siter, what a pretty Monieur ••
der is, ee how fine his Face is, how delicate his Hair, <>
gallant his Dres; and do but look how he gazes on you: This would make Atlante bluh anew, who durt not raie her Eyes for fear he hould encounter his. While he had the Pleaure to imagine they were talking of him, and he aw in the pretty Face of Charlot, that what he aid, was not to his diadvantage, and by the Bluhes of Atlante, that he was not dipleas'd with what was poken to her; he perceiv'd the young one importunate with her, and Atlante jogging her with her Elbow, as much as to ay, Hold your peace; all this, he made a very kind Interpretation of, and was tranported with Joy, at the good Omens. He was willing to flatter his new Flame, and to Complement his young Deire with a little Hope; but the Divine Ceremony ceaing, Atlante left the Church, and it being very fair Weather, he walk'd home, Rinaldo, who aw her going, felt all the Agonies of a Lover, who parts with all that can make him happy, and eeing only Atlante attended with her Siter, and a Footman, following with their Books, he was a thouand times about to peak to 'em, but he no ooner advanc'd a tep or two towards 'em, to that Purpoe (for he followed them) but his Heart fail'd, and a certain Awe and Reverence, or rather the Fears and Tremblings of a Lover, prevented him; but when he conider'd, that poible he might never have o favourable an Opportunity again, he reolv'd a-new, and call'd up o much Courage to his Heart, as to peak to Atlante; but before he
did o, Charlot looking behind her, aw Rinaldo very near to 'em, and cry'd out, with a Voice of Joy, Oh! Siter, Siter, look where the handome Monieur is, jut behind us; ure he is Some-body of Quality, for ee he has two Foot-men that follow him, in jut uch Liveries, and o rich as thoe of our Neighbour, Monieur Bellyaurd. At this, Atlante could not forbear, but before he was aware of it, turn'd her Head, and look'd on Rinaldo; which encourag'd him to advance, and putting off his Hat, which he clapt under his Arm, with a low Bow, aid, Ladies, you are lenderly attended, and o many Accidents arrive to the Fair in the rude Streets, that I humbly implore, you will permit me, whoe Duty it is, as a Neighbour, to wait on you to your Door. Sir, aid Atlante, bluhing, we fear no Inolence, and need no Protector; or if we did, we hould not be o rude, to take you out of your Way, to erve us. Madam, aid he, my Way lies yours, I live at the next Door, and am Son to Bellyaurd, your Neighbour. But, Madam, added he, if I were to go all my Life out of the Way, to do you Service, I hould take it for the greatest Happines, that could arrive to me; but, Madam, ure a Man can never be out of his Way, who has the Honour of o charming Company. Atlante made no Reply to this, but bluh'd and bow'd: But Charlot aid, Nay, Sir, if you are our Neighbour, we will give you leave to Conduct us home; But pray, Sir, how came you to know we are your Neighbours; for we never aw you before, to our knowledge. My pretty Mis, reply'd Rinaldo, I knew it from the trancendent Beauty appear'd in your Faces, and ine Shapes; for I have heard, there was no Beauty in the World, like that of Atlante's; and I no ooner aw her, but my Heart told me, it was he. Heart, aid Charlot laughing, Way, does Hearts ue to peak? The most intelligibly of any thing, Rinaldo reply'd, when 'tis tenderly touch'd, when 'tis charm'd and tranported. At thee Words he igh'd, and Atlante, to his extream Satisfaction, bluhed. Touch, charm'd, and tranported, aid Charlot, what's that? And how do you do to have it be all thee Things? For I would give any thing in the World to have my Heart
peak. Oh! aid Rinaldo, your Heart is too young, it is not yet arrived to the Years of peaking; about thirteen or fourteen, it may poibly be aying a thouand oft Things to you; but it must be first inpir'd by ome Noble Object, whoe Idea it must retain. What, reply'd this pretty Pratlet, I'll warrant I must be in love? Yes, aid Rinaldo, most paionately, or you will have but little Converation with your Heart. Oh! reply'd he, I am afraid the Pleaure of uch a Converation, will not make me Amends for the Pain that Love will give me. That, aid Rinaldo, is according as the Object is kind; and <>
you Hope, if he Love, and you Hope, you will have a d ••
ble Pleaure: And in this, how great an Advantage have you, fair Ladies, above us Men? 'Tis almost impoible for you to love in vain, you have your Choice of a thouand Hearts, which you have ubdu'd, and may not only chue your Slaves, but be aur'd of 'em; without peaking you are belov'd, it needs not cost you a Sigh or a Tear: But unhappy Man, is often detsn'd to give his Heart, where it is not regarded, to igh, to weep, and languih, without any hope of Pity. You peak o feelingly, Sir, aid Charlot, that I am afraid this is your Cae? Yes, Madam, reply'd Rinaldo, ighing, I am that unhappy Man, Indeed, 'tis pity, aid he, Pray how long have you been o? Ever ince I heard of the charming Atlante, reply'd he, ighing again; I ador'd her Character, but now I have een her, I die for her. For me, Sir, aid Atlante, (who had not yet poke) this is the common Complement of all the young Men, who pretend to be Lovers; and if one hould pity all thoe Sighers, we hould have but very little left for ourelves. I believe, aith Rinaldo, there are none that tell you o, who do not mean as they ay; yet among all thoe Adorers, and thoe that ay they will die for you, you will find none will be o good as their Words as Rinaldo. Perhaps, aid Atlante, of all thoe who tell me of dying, there are none that tell it with o little Reaon as Rinaldo, if that be your Name, Sir. Madam, it is, aid he, and who am tranported with an unpeakable Joy, to hear thoe last Words from your fair Mouth; and let me, O lovely Atlante, aure you, that what I have
aid, are not Words of Coure, but proceed from a Heart that has vow'd itelf eternally yours, even before I had the Happines to behold this Divine Peron; but now that my Eyes have made good all my Heart before imagin'd, and did but hope: I wear, I will die à thouand Deaths, rather than violate what I have aid to you; That Indore you, that my Soul, and all my Faculties are charm'd with your Beauty and Innocence, and that my Life and Fortune, not inconiderable, hall be laid at your Feet. This he poke with a Fervency of Paion, that left her no doubt of what he had aid; yet he bluh'd for hame, and a little angry at herelf, for uffering him to ay o much to her, the very firt time he aw him, and accued herelf for giving him any Encouragement: And in this Confuion he replied, Sir, you have aid too much to be believed; and I cannot imagine o hort an Acquaintance can make o coniderable an Impreion; of which Confeion I accue myelf much more than you, in that I did not only hearken to what you aid, without forbidding you to entertain me at that rate, but for unheedily peaking omething, that has encourag'd this Boldnes, for o must I call it, in a Man o great a Stranger to me. Madam, aid he, if I have offended by the uddennes of my preumptuous Dicovery, I beeech you to conider my Reaons for it, the few Opportunities I am like to have, and the impoibility of waiting on you, both from the Severity of your Father and mine; who e'r I aw you, warn'd me of my Fate, as if he foreaw I hould fall in Love, as oon as I hould chance to ee you; and for that Reaon has kept me cloer to my Studies, than hitherto I have been: And from that time I began to feel a Flame, which was kindled by Report alone, and the Decription my Father gave of your wondrous, and dangerous Beauty: Therefore, Madam, I have not uddenly told you of my Paion, I have been long your Lover, and have
• ong languih'd without telling of my Pain, and you ought to pardon it now, ince it is done with all the Repect and Religious Awe, that 'tis poible for a Heart to deliver and unload itelf in, therefore, Madam, if you have by Chance uttered any thing, that I have taken advantage
or hope from, I aure you, 'tis o mall, that you have no Reaon to repent it; but rather, if you would have me live, end me not from you, without a Confirmation of that little hope, See, Madam, aid he, more earnetly and trembling, ee we are almost arriv'd at our Homes, end me not to mine in a Depair, that I cannot upport with Life; but tell me, I hall be bles'd with your Sight, ometimes in your Balcony, which is very near to a jetting Window in our Houe, from whence I have ent many a longing Look towards yours, in hope to have een my Soul's Tormenter. I hall be very unwilling, aid he, to enter into an Intreigue of Love, or Friendhip, with a Man whoe Parents will be avere to my Happines, and poibly mine as refractory, tho' he cannot but know uch an Alliance would be very coniderable, my Fortune being not uitable to yours: I tell you this, that you may withdraw in time from an Engagement, in which I find there will be a great many Obtacles. Oh! Madam, replied Rinaldo, ighing, if my Peron be not diagreeable to you, you will have no occaion to fear the rest, 'tis that I dread, and that which is all my fear. He, ighing, beheld her with a languihing Look, that told her, he expected her Anwer; when he reply'd, Sir, if that will be Satisfaction enough for you at this time, I do aure you, I have no Averion for your Peron, in which I find more to be valu'd, than in any I have yet een; and if what you ay be real, and proceed from a Heart truly affected, I find, in pight of me, you will oblige me to give you hope.

They were come o near their own Houes, that he had not time to return her any Anwer, but with a low Bow he acknowledg'd her Bounty, and expres'd the Joy her lat Words had given him, by a Look that made her undertand, he was charm'd and pleas'd; and he bowing to him with an Air of Satisfaction in her Face, he was well aured, there was nothing to be een o lovely as he then appear'd, and left her to go into her own Houe; but 'till he was out of ight, he had not power to tir, and then ighing, retired to his own Appartment, to think over all that had pat
between them. He found nothing but what gave him a thouand Joys, in all he had aid; and he blet this happy Day, and wondred how his Stars came o kind, to make him one hour at once ee Atlante, and have the Happines to know from her own Mouth, that he was not diagreeable to her: Yet with this Satisfaction, he had a thouand Thoughts mix'd, which were tormenting, and thoe were the Fear of their Parents; he foreaw from what his Father had aid to him already, that it would be difficult to draw him to a Conent of his Marriage with Atlante: Thee Joys and Fears were his Companions all the Night, in which he took but little ret. Nor was Atlante without her Inquietudes: She • ound Rinaldo more in her Thoughts, than he wih'd, and a udden change of Humour, that made her know omething was the matter with her, more than uual; he calls to mind Rinaldo's peaking of the Converation with his Heart, and • ound hers would be tarling to her, if he would give way to it; and yet the more he trove to avoid it, the more it importun'd her, and in pight of all her Reitance, would tell her, that Rinaldo had a thouand Charms: It tells her, that he loves and adores her, and that he would be the mot cruel of her Sex, hould he not be enible of his Paion. She finds a thouand Graces in his Peron and Converation, and as many Advantages in his Fortune, which was one of the mot coniderable in all thoe Parts; for his Etate exceeded that of the mot Noble Men in Orleance, and he imagines he would be the mot fortunate of all Womankind, in uch a Match. With thee Thoughts he employ'd all the Hours of the Night; o that he lay o long in Bed the next Day, that Count Vernole, who had invited himelf to Dinner, came before he had quitted her Chamber, and he was forc'd to ay, he had not been well. He had brought her a very fine Book, newly come out, of delicate Philoophy, fit for the Study of Ladies. But he appear'd o diagreeable to that Heart, wholly taken up with a new and fine Object, that he could now hardly pay him that Civility he was wont to do; while
on the other ide, that little State and Pride Atlante aum'd, made her appear the more charming to him; o that if Atlante had no Mind to begin a new Leon of Philoophy, while he fancied her Thoughts were much better employ'd, the Count every Moment expreing his Tendernes and Paion, had as little an Inclination to intruct her, as he was to be intructed; Love had taught her a new Leon, and he would fain teach her a new Leon of Love, but fears it will be a diminihing of his Gravity and Grandeur, to open the Secrets of his Heart to o young a Maid; he therefore thinks it more agreeable to his Quality and Years, being about Forty, to ue her Father's Authority in this Affair, and that it was ufficient for him to declare himelf to Monieur De Pais, who he knew would be proud of the Honour he did him ome time pat, before he could perwade himelf, even to declare himelf, to her Father; he fancies, the little Coldnes and Pride he aw in Atlante's Face, which was not uual, proceeded from ome Dicovery of Paion, which his Eyes had made, or now and then a Sigh, that unawares broke forth, and accues himelf of a Levity below his Quality, and the Dignity of his Wit and Gravity; and therefore, aumes a more rigid and formal Behaviour than he was wont, which rendred him yet more diagreeable than before; and 'twas with greater Pain than ever, he gave him that Repect which was due to his Quality.

Rinaldo, after a retles Night, was up very early in the Morning; and tho' he was not certain of eeing his adorable Atlante, he dres'd himelf with all that care, as if he had been to have waited on hers and got himelf into the Window, that overlook, Monieur De Pais his Balcony, where he had not remain'd long, before he aw the pretty Charlot come into it, not with any deign of eeing Rinaldo, but to lock and gaze about her a little: Rinaldo aw her, and made her a very low Reverence, and found ome diordered Joy on the ight of even Charlot, ince he was Siter to Atlante. He call'd to her (for the Window
•• was o near her, he could eaily be heard by her) and told her, He was infinitely indebted to her Bounty, for giving him an opportunity yeterday of falling on that Dicoure, which had made him the happiest Man in the World: He aid, if he had not by her agreeable Converation encourag'd him, and drawn him from one Word to another, he hould never have had the Confidence to have told Atlante, how much he ador'd her. I am very glad, replied Charlot, that I was the Occaion of the Beginning of an Amour, which was dipleaing to neither
<> nor to the other; for I aure you, for your Comfort, my
<> nothing but thinks on you: We lie together, and
•• have taught her already to igh o, that I could not
<> for her. At this, his Face was covered over with a <> , Joy, which his Heart could not contain: And after ome Dicoure, in which this innocent Girl dicovered more than Atlante wih'd he hould, he beought her to become his Advocate; and ince he had an Brother, to give him leave to aume that Honour, and call her Siter. Thus, by degrees, he flatter'd her into a Conent, of carrying a Letter from him to At
•• te; which he, who believ'd all as innocent as her elf, and being not forbid to do o, immediately con ••• ed to, when he took his Pen and Ink, that tood in the Window, with Paper, wrote Atlante this following Letter:

body.head: RINALDO to ATLANTE.
body.p:
IF my Suit be o evere, as to deny me the Happines of
• ighing out my Pain and Paion daily at your Feet, if there be any Faith in the Hope you were pleaed to give the (as 'twere a Sin to doubt) O charming Atlante! uffer me to languih, both without beholding you, and with
••
the Bleing of now and then a Billet, in anwer to
<> that ha •• daily aure you of my eternal Faith and
<> 'tis all I ask, till Fortune and our Affairs hall allow me the unpeakable Satisfaction of claiming you; yet, if your Charity can ometimes afford me a ight of you, either from your Balcony in the Evening, or at a Church
in the Morning, it would ave me from that Depair and Torment, which must poes a Heart o unaur'd, us that of

div.p:
He having writ and eal'd this, tos'd it into the Balcony, to Charlot, having firt look'd about to ee if none perceiv'd them: She put it in her Boom, and ran into her Siter, whom by chance he found alone; Vernole having taken De Pais into the Garden, to dicoure him concerning the ending Charlot to the Monatery; which Work he deir'd to ee perform'd, before he declar'd his Intentions to Atlante; for among all his other good Qualities, he was very avaritious; and as fair as Atlante was, he thought he would be much fairer with the Addition of Charlot's Portion: This Affair of his, with Monieur De Pays, gave Charlot an Opportunity of delivering her Letter to her Siter; who no ooner drew it from her Boom, but Atlante's Face was cover'd over with Bluhes: For he imagin'd from whence it came, and had a ecret Joy in that Imagination, tho' he thought he mut put on the Severity and Nicenes of a Virgin, who would not be thought to have urrendred her Heart with o mall an Aault, and the firt too: So he demanded from whence Charlot had that Letter? Who replied with Joy, From the fine young Gentleman, our Neighbour. At which Atlante aum'd all the Gravity he could, to chide her Siter; who replied, Well, Siter, had you this Day een him, you would not have been angry to have receiv'd a Letter from him; he look'd o handome, and was o richly dres'd, ten times finer than he was yeterday; and I promis'd him, you hould read it; therefore pray let me keep my Word with him; and not only o, but carry him an Anwer. Well, aid Atl •• , to ave your Credit with Moni • ur Rinaldo, I will read it. Which he did, and finihed with a Sigh. While he was reading, Charlot ran into the Garden, to ee if they
were not likely to be urprized; and finding the Count and her Father et in an Arbor, in deep Dicoure, he brought Pen, Ink, and Paper, to her Siter, and told her, he might write without the fear of being diturbed; and urged her o long to what was enough her Inclination, he at lat obtained this Anwer:

body.head: ATLANTE to RINALDO.
body.p: CHarlot, your little importunate Advocate, has, at last ubdued me to a Conent of returning you this. She has put me on an Affair which I am wholly unacquainted with; and you ought to take this very kindly from me, ince it is the very first time I ever writ to one of your Sex, tho' perhaps I might with les Danger have done it to any other Man. I tremble while I write, ince I dread a Correpondence of this Nature, which may inenibly draw us into an Inconvenience, and engage me beyond the Limits of that Nicety I ought to preerve: For this way we venture to ay a thouand little kind Things, which in Converation we dare not do; for now none can ee us bluh. I am enible I hall this way put myelf too oon into your Power; and tho' you have abundance of Merit, I ought to be ahamed of Confeing, I am but too enible of them:—But hold —I hall dicover for your Repoe (which I would preerve) too much of the Heart of

div.p:
She gave this Letter to Charlot; who immediately ran into the Balcony with it, where he till found Rinaldo in a Melancholy Poture, leaning his Head on his Hand: She hewed him the Letter, but was afraid to tos it to him, for fear it might fall to the Ground; o he ran and fetched a long Cane, which he cleft at one end, and holding it where he put the Letter into the Cleft, and taid not to hear what he aid to it: But never was Man o tranported with Joy, as he was, at the reading of this Letter; it gives him new Wounds; for to the Generous, nothing obliges Love o much as Love:
Tho' it is now too much the Nature of that incontant Sex, to ceae too Love as oon as they are ure of the Conquet. But it was far different with our Cavalier; he was the more inflamed, by imagining he had made ome Impreions on the Heart of Atlante, and kindled ome Sparks there, that in time might increae to ome thing more; o that he now reolves to die hers; and conidering all the • btacles that may poibly hinder his Happines, he found none but his Father's Obtinacy, perhaps occaioned by the Meannes of Atlante's Fortune: To this he urged again, that he was his only Son, and a Son whom he loved equal to his own Life; and that certainly, as oon as he hould behold him dying for Atlante, which if forc'd to quit he mut be, that then he believed the Tendernes of o fond a Parent, would break forth into Pity and Compaion, and plead within for his Conent. Thee were the Thoughts that flattered this young Lover all the Day, and whether he were riding the great Hore, or at his Study of Philoophy, or Mathematicks, Singing, Dancing, or whatoever other Exercie his Tutors ordered, his Thoughts were continually on Atlante, and now he profited no more; whatever he eem'd to do, every Day he fail'd not to write to her by the Hand of the kind Charlot; who young as he was, had conceiv'd a very great Friendhip for Rinaldo, and fail'd not to fetch her Letters, and bring him Anwers, uch as he wih'd to receive. But all this did not atisfie our impatient Lover; Abence kill'd, and he was no longer able to upport himelf, without a ight of this adorable Maid; he therefore implores, he will give him that Satisfaction: And he at lat grants it, with a better Will than he imagin'd. The next Day was the appointed time, when he would, under pretence of going to Church, give him an Aignation: And becaue all Publick Places were dangerous, and might make a great Noie, and they had no Private Place to trut to, Rinaldo, under pretence of going up the River in his Pleaure-Boat, which he often did, ent to have it made ready againt the next Day, at Ten of the Clock. This was accordingly done, and he gave
Atlante Notice of his Deign, of going an Hour or two on the River, in his Boat; which lay near to uch a place, not far from the Church. She, and Charlot, came thither; and becaue they durt not come out, without a Foo • man, or two; they taking one, ent him with a How de ye? to ome young Ladies; and told him, he hould find them at Church. So getting rid of their Spy, they hatned to the River-ide, and found a Boat, and Rinaldo, waiting to carry them on Board his little Veel; which was richly adorn'd, and a very handome Collation ready for them, of Cold Meats, Sallads, and Sweetmeats. As oon as they were come into the Pleaure-Boat, uneen of any, he kneel'd at the Feet of Atlante; and there utter'd o many paionate and tender Things to her, with a Voice o trembling, and oft; with Eyes o languihing; and a Fervency, and Fire, o incere; that her young Heart, wholly uncapable of Artifice, could no longer reit uch Language, and uch Looks of Love, he grows tender, and he perceives it in her fine Eyes, who could not diemble; he reads her Heart in her Looks, and found it yielding apace; and therefore aaults it anew, with freh Forces of Sighs and Tears: He implores, he would aure him of her Heart; which he could no other way do, then by yielding to marry him: He would carry her to the next Village, there conummate that Happines, without which he was able to live no longer; for he had a thouand Fears, that ome other Lover was, or would uddenly be provided for her; and therefore he would make ure of her, while he had this Opportunity; and to that end, he anwered all the Objections he could make to the contrary: But ever, when he nam'd Marriage, he trembled, with fear of doing omething that he fancy'd he ought not to do, without the Conent of her Father: She was enible of the Advantage, but had been o us'd to a trict Obedience, that he could not, without Horrour, think of violating it; and therefore beought him, as he valu'd her Repoe, not to urge her to that. And told him further, That if he fear'd any Rival, he would give him what other Aurance, and
Satisfaction he pleas'd, but that of Marriage; which he could not conent to, 'till he knew uch an Alliance would not be fatal to him; for he fear'd as paionately as he lov'd her, when he hould find he had occaion'd him the los of his Fortune, or his Father's Affection, he would grow to hate her; tho' he anwer'd to this, all that a fond Lover could urge, yet he was reolv'd, and he was forc'd to content himelf with obliging her by his Prayers and Protetations, his Sighs, and his Showers of Tears, to a Contract, which they olemnly made each other, vowing on either ide, that they would never marry any other. This being olemnly concluded, he aum'd a Look more gay, and contented than before: He preented her a very rich Ring; which he durt not put on her Finger, but hid it in her Boom: And beholding each other now, as Man and Wife, he uffer'd him all the decent Freedoms he could wih to take; o that the Hours of this Voyage, eem'd the mot oft and charming of his Life: And doubtles they were o; every Touch of Atlante tranported him, every Look pierced his Soul, and he was all Raptures of Joy, when he conider'd this charming lovely Maid was his own.

Charlot all this while was gazing above Deck, admiring the Motion of the little Veel, and how eaily the Wind and Tide bore her up the River. She had never been in any thing of this kind before, and was very well pleaed and entertain'd, when Rinaldo call'd her down to eat; where they enjoy'd themelves as well as was poible; and Charlot was wondering to ee uch a Content in their Eyes.

But now they thought it was high time for them to return; they fancy the Foot-man miing them at Church, would go home, and alarm their Father, and the Knight of the Ill-favour'd Countenance, as Charlot call'd Count Vernole; whoe Severity put their Father on a greater Retriction of them, than naturally he would do of himelf. At the Name of this Count, Rinaldo chang'd Colour, fearing he might be ome Rival; and ask'd Atlante, if this Vernole was a-kin to her? She anwered,
No: But was a very great Friend to her Father; and on who, from their Infancy, had had a particular Concern for their Breeding, and was her Mater for Philoophy. Ah! replied Rinaldo, ighing, This Man's Concern must proceed from omething more than Friendhip for her Father; and therefore conjured her to tell him, whether he was not a Lover? A Lover, replied Atlante; I aure you, he is a perfect Antidote against that Paion; and tho' he uffered his ugly Preence now, he hould loath and hate him, hould he name but Love to her.

She aid, he believ'd he need not fear any uch Perecution, ince he was a Man, who was not at all Amorous; that he had too much of the Satyr in his Humour to harbour any oftnes there: And Nature had form'd his Body to his Mind, wholly unfit for Love; and that he might et his Heart abolutely at ret: She aur'd him her Father had never yet propos'd any Marriage to her, tho' many advantagious ones are offer'd him every day.

The Sails being turn'd to carry them back from whence they came; after having dicours'd of a thouand things, and all of Love and Contrivance, to carry on their Mutual Deign, they with Sighs parted, Rinaldo taying behind in the Pleaure-Boat, and they going a Shoar in the Wherry, that attended; after which, he cat many an amorous and ad Look, and perhaps was anwer'd by thoe of Atlante.

It was pat Church time two or three Hours; when they arriv'd at home, wholly unprepared with an Excue, o abolutely was Atlante's Soul poet with ofter Buines. The firt Peron they met withal, was the Footman, who open'd the Door, and began to cry out, how long he had waited in the Church, and how in vain; without giving them time to reply. De Pais came towards 'em; and with a frowning Look, demanded where they had been? Atlante, who was not accutomed to Excues, and Untruth, was a while at a tand; when Charlot with a Voice of Joy cried out; Oh, Sir, we have been a Board of a fine little Ship: At
this Atlante bluh'd, fearing he would tell the Truth. But he proceeded on, and aid, that they had not been above a Quarter of an Hour at Church, when the • ady—, with ome other Ladies and Cavaliers, were going out of the Church, and that pying them, they wou'd needs have them go with 'em: My Siter, Sir, continued he, was very loath to go, for fear you hould be angry; but my Lady—was o importunate with her on one ide, and I on the other; becaue I never aw a little Ship in my Life, that at lat we prevailed with her; therefore, good Sir, be not angry. He promied them, he was not: And when they came in, they found Count Vernole, who had been inpiring De Pais with Severity, and counell'd him to chide the young Ladies, for being too long abent, under pretence of going to their Devotion. Nor was it enough for him to et the Father on, but himelf, with a Gravity, where Concern and Malice were both apparent, reproach'd Atlante with Levity; and told her, He believ'd he had ome other Motive, than the Invitation of a Lady, to go on Ship-board; and that he had too many Lovers, not to make them doubt that this was a deign'd thing; and that he had heard Love from ome one, for whom it was deign'd. To this he made him but a hort Reply, That if it was o, he had no Reaon to conceal it, ince he had Sence enough to look after herelf; and if any Body had made • ove to her, he might be aur'd, it was ome one, whoe Quality and Merit deerv'd to be heard: And with a Look of Scorn, he pat on to another Room, and left him ilently raging within with Jealouie: Which, if before he tormented him, this Declaration increas'd it to a Pitch not to be conceal'd. And this Day he aid o much to the Father, that he reolv'd forthwith to end Charlot to a Nunnery: And accordingly, the next Day, he bid her prepare to go. Charlot, who was not yet arrived to the Years of Ditinction, did not much regret it; and having no Trouble, but leaving her Siter, he prepared to go to a Nunnery, not many Streets from that where he dwelt. The Lady Abbes was her Father's Kinwoman, and had treated
her very well, as often as he came to viit her; o that with Satisfaction enough, he was condemned to a Monatick Life, and was now going for her Probation-Year. Atlante was troubled at her Departure, becaue he had no Body to bring, and to carry Letters between Rinaldo and he: However he took her leave of her, and promis'd to come and ee her, as often as he hould be permitted to go abroad; for he fear'd now ome Contraint extraordinary would be put upon her; and o it happen'd.

Atlante's Chamber was that to which the Balcony belong'd, and though he durt not appear there in the Day-time, he could in the Night, and that way give her Lover as many Hours of Converation, as he pleaed, without being perceived: But how to give Rinaldo notice of this, he could not tell, who not knowing Charlot was gone to a Monatery, waited many Days at his Window to ee her; at lat they neither of them knowing who to trut with any Meage, one Day when he was, as uual, upon his watch, he aw Atlante tep into the Balcony, who having a • etter, in which he had put a Piece of Lead, he tot it into his Window, whoe Caement was open, and run in again unperceived by any but himelf, the Paper contain'd only this:
My Chamber is that which looks into the Balcony, from whence, tho' I cannot convere with you in the Day, I can at Night, when I am retired to go to Bed; therefore be at your Window. Farewel.

There needed no more to make him a diligent Watcher, and accordingly he was no ooner retired to her Chamber, but he would come into the Balcony, where he fail'd not to ee him attending at his Window. This happy Contrivance was thus carry'd on for many Nights, where they entertain'd one another, with all the Indearment that two Hearts could dictate, who were perfectly united and aured of each other, and this pleaing Converation would often lat till Day appeared, and forced them to part.

But old Belyuard perceiving his Son frequent that Chamber more than uual, fancy'd omething extraordinary mut be the Caue of it; and one Night asking for his Son, his Vallet told him, he was gone into the great Chamber; o this was called: Belyuard asked the Vallet, what he did there; he told him, he could not tell; for often he had lighted him thither; and, that his Mater would take the Candle from him, at the Chamber Door, and uffer him to go no further: Tho' the old Gentleman could not imagine, what Affairs he could have alone every Night in that Chamber, he had a Curioity to ee; and one unlucky Night, putting off his Shooes, he came to the Door of the Chamber, which was open, he entered oftly, and aw the Candle et in the Chimney, and his Son at a great open Bay Window; he topt a while to wait when he would turn, but finding him immovable, he advanced omething further, and at lat heard the oft Dialogue of Love, between him and Atlante; whom he knew to be he, by his often calling her by her Name in their Dicoure: He heard enough to confirm him how Matters went; and uneen as he came, he returned, full of Indignation, and thought how to prevent o great an Evil, as this Paion of his Son might produce; at firt he thought to round him everely in the Ear about it, and upbraid him for doing the only thing he had thought fit to forbid him; but then he thought that would but terrifie him for a while, and he would return again, where he had o great an Inclination, if he were near her: He therefore reolves to end him to Paris, that by abence he might forget the young Beauty, that had charmed his Youth: Therefore, without letting Rinaldo know the Reaon, and without taking notice that he knew any thing of his Amour, he came to him one Day, and told him all the Maters he had for the improving him in noble Sciences were very dull, or very remis; and that he reolved he hould go for a Year or two, to the Academy at Paris. To this, the Son made a thouand Evaions; but the Father was poitive, and not to be perwaded by all his Reaons;
and finding he hould abolutely dipleae him, if he refued to go, and not daring to tell him the dear Caue of his Deire to remain at Orleance. He therefore, with a breaking Heart, conents to go, nay, reolves it, though it hould be his Death: But, alas! he coniders, that this parting will not only prove the greatet Torment upon Earth to him, but that Atlante will hare in his Misfortunes alo: This Thought gives him a double Torment, and yet finds no way to evade it.

The Night that finihed this fatal Day, he goes again to his wonted Station, the Window; where he had not ig'hd very long, but he aw Atlante enter the Balcony: He was not able a great while to peak to her, or to utter one Word. The Night was light enough to ee him at the wonted place; and he admires at his Silence, and demands the Reaon in uch obliging Terms, as adds to his Grief; and he, with a deep Sigh, replied, rge me not, my fair Atlante, to peak lest by obeying you, I give you more caue of Grief, than my Silence is capable of doing: And then ighing again, he held his Peace, and gave her leave to ask the Caue of thee lat Words. But when he made no Reply, but by ighing, he imagin'd it much wore, than indeed it was; and with a trembling and fainting Voice, he cried, Oh! Rinaldo, give me leave to divine that cruel News you are o unwilling to tell me: It is o, added he, you are detined to ome more fortunate Maid than Atlante: At this, Tears topp'd her Speech, and he could utter no more. No, my dearest Charmer, replyed Rinaldo (elevating his Voice) if that were all, you hould ee with what Fortitude I would die, rather than obey any uch Commands: I am vowed yours to the last Moment of my Life; and will be yours in pight of all the Oppoition in the World; that Cruelty I could evade, but cannot this that threatens me. Ah! cried Atlante, let Fate do her wort, o he till continue Rinaldo mine, and keep that Faith he hath worn to me entire: What can he do beide that can afflict me? She can eparate me, cried he, for ome time from Atlante. Oh! replied he, all Misfortunes fall o below that which I first imagined, that
methinks I do not reent this, as I hould otherwie have done; but I know, when I have a little more conidered it, I hall even die with the Grief of it. Abence being o great an Enemy to Love, and makes us oon forget the Object beloved: This, though I never experienced, I have heard, and fear it may be my Fate. He then convinced her Fear with a thouand new Vows, and a thouand Imprecations of Contancy. She then asked him, If their Loves were dicovered, that he was with uch hate to depart? He told her, Nothing of that was the Caue; and he could almost wih it were dicovered, ince he could reolutely then refue to go: But it was only to cultivate his Mind, more effectually than he could do here; 'twas the Care of his Father to accomplih him the more; and therefore he could not contradict it. But, aid he, I am not ent where Seas hall part us, nor vast ditances of Earth, but to Paris; from whence he might come in two Days to ee her again, and that he would expect from that Balcony, that had gave him o many happy Moments, many more when he hould come to ee her. He beought her to end him away with all the Satisfaction he could, which he could no otherwie do, than by giving him new Aurances, that he would never give away that Right he had in her, to any other Lover: She vows this with innumerable Tears; and is almot angry with him for quetioning her Faith. He tells her then he has but one Night more to tay, and his Grief would be unpeakable, if he hould not be able to take a better Leave of her, than at a Window; and that, if he would give him leave, he would by a Rope or two tied together, o as it may erve for Steps, acend her Balcony; he not having time to provide a Ladder of Ropes. She tells him, he has o great a Confidence in his Vertue and Love, that he will refue him nothing, though it would be a very bold venture for a Maid, to trut herelf with a paionate young Man, in ilence of Night; and though he did not exert a Vow from him to ecure her, he expected he would have a Care of her Honour. He wore to her, his Love was too Religious for o bae an Attempt. There needed not many
Vows to confirm her Faith; and it was agreed on between them that he hould come the next Night into her Chamber.

It happened that Night, as it often did, that Count Vernole, lay with Monieur De Pays, which was in a Ground-Room, jut under that of Atlante's: And as oon as he knew all were in Bed, he gave the Word to Rinaldo, who was attending with the Impatience of a paionate Lover below, under the Window; and, who ooner heard the Balcony open, but he acended with ome difficulty, and entered the Ch • mber, where he found Atlante tremble with Joy and Fear: He throws himelf at her Feet, as unable to peak as he; who nothing but bluhed and bent down her Eyes, hardly daring to glance them towards the dear Object of her Deires, the Lord of all her Vows: She was was ahamed to ee a Man in her Chamber, where yet none had ever been alone, and by Night too. He aw her Fear, and felt her Trembling; and after a thouand Sighs of Love had made way for Speech, he beought her to fear nothing from him; for his Flame was too acred, and his Paion too holy to offer any thing, but what Honour with Love might afford him. At lat he brought her to ome Courage, and the Roes of her fair Cheeks aumed their wonted Colour, not bluhing too Red, nor languihing too Pale. But when the Converation began between them, it was the oftet in the World: They aid all that parting Lovers could ay, all that Wit and Tendernes could expres: They exchanged their Vows a-new, and to confirm his, he tied a Bracelet of Diamonds about her Arm; and he returned him one of her Hair, which he had long begged, and he had on purpoe made, which claped together with Diamonds; this he put about his Arm, and he wore to carry it to his Grave. The Night was very far pent in tender Vows, oft Sighs and Tears on both ides; and it was high time to part: But as if Death had been to have arrived to them in that Minute, they both linger'd away the time, like Lovers who had forgot themelves; and Day was near approaching,
when he bid farewel; which he repeated very often, for till he was interrupted by ome commanding Softnes from Atlante, and then lot all his Power of going; till he, more couragious and careful of his Interet, and her own Fame, forc'd him from her; and it was happy he did o; for he was no ooner got over the Balcony, and he had flung him down his Rope, and hut the Door, but Vernole, whom Love and Contrivance kept waking, fancied everal times he heard a Noie in Atlante's Chamber. And whether in paing over the Balcony, Rinaldo made any noie or not, or whether it were till his jealous Fancy, he came up in his Night-Gown, with a Pitol in his Hand. Atlante was not o much lot in Grief, though he were all in Tears, but he heard a Man come up, and imagined it had been her Father, he not knowing of Count Vernole's lying in the Houe that Night; if he had, he poibly had taken more care to have been ilent: But whoever it was, he could not get to Bed oon enough; and therefore turn'd herelf to her Dreing-table, where Candle tood, and where lay a Book open of the Story of Ariadne and Theias. The Count turning the Latch, entred halting into her Chamber, in his Night-Gown clapped cloe about him, which betrayed an ill-favoured Shape, his Night-Cap on, without a Perriwig, which dicovered all his lean withered Jaws, his pale Face, and his Eyes taring; and making altogether o dreadful a Figure, that Atlante, who no more dreamt of him than of a Devil, had poibly have rather een the lat. She gave a great Shriek, which frighted Vernole; o both tood for a while taring on each other, till both were recollected: He told her, the Care of her Honour had brought him thither; and then rolling his mall Eyes round the Chamber, to ee if he could dicover any Body; he proceed and cried, Madam, if I had no other Motive than your being up at this time of Night, or rather of Day, I could eaily gues how you have been entertained. What Inolence is this, aid he, all in a Rage, when to cover your Boldnes of approaching my Chamber at this Hour, you would quetion how I have been entertained;
either explain yourelf, or quit my Chamber; for I do not ue to ee uch terrible Objects here. Poibly thoe you do ee, aid the Count, are indeed more agreeable, but I am afraid have not that regard to your Honour as I have. And at that Word he tepped to the Balcony, opened it, and looked out, but eeing no Body, he hut it too again. This enraged Atlante beyond all Patience; and natching the Pitol out of his Hand, he told him, He deerved to have it aimed at his Head, for having the Impudence to quetion her Honour, or her Conduct; and comm • nded him to avoid her Chamber as he loved his Life; which he believed he was fonder of than of her Honour: She peaking this in a Tone wholly tranported with Rage; and at the ame time holding the Pitol towards him, made him tremble with Fear; and he now found whether he were guilty or not, it was his turn to beg pardon: For you mut know, however it came to pas, that his Jealouie made him come up in that force Poture; at other times Vernole was the mot tame and paive Man in the World, and one who was afraid of his own Shadow in the Night: He had a natural Averion for Danger, and thought it below a Man of Wit, or common Sene, to be guilty of that brutal Thing, called Courage or Fighting: His Philoophy told him, It was afe leeping in a whole Skin; and poibly he apprehended as much Danger from this Virago, as ever he did from his own Sex; he therefore fell on his Knees, and beought her to hold her fair Hand; and not to uffer that, which was the greatet Mark of his Repect, to be the Caue of her Hate or Indignation. The pitiful Faces he made, and the Signs of mortal Fear in him, had almot made her laugh, at leat it allayed her Anger; and he bid him rie and play the Fool hereafter ome-where-ele, and not in her Preence: Yet for once, he would deign to give him this Satisfaction; that he was got into a Book, which had many moving Stories very well writ; and that he found herelf o well entertained, he had forgot how the Night paed. He mot humbly thanked her
for this Satisfaction, and retired, perhaps not o well atisfied as he pretended.
After this, he appeared more ubmiive and repectful towards Atlante; and he carried herelf more reerved and haughty towards him; which was one Reaon, he would not yet dicover his Paion.

Thus the T • me ran on at Orleance, while Rinald •
found himelf daily languihing at Paris. He was indeed in the bet Academy in the City amongt a <>
of brave and noble Youths; where all things <>
