could accomplih them, was to be learn'd by the <>
had any Genius; but Rinaldo had other Thoughts, <>
other Buines; his time was wholly pat in the <>
olitary Parts of the Garden, by the melancholy <>
, and in the mot gloomy Shades; wher • he <>
with mot Liberty breath out his Paion and his <>
He was pat the Tutorage of a Boy; and his <>
could not upbraid him, but found he had <…>
Caue of Grief, which made him not mind thee <>
, which were the Delight of the ret; o <>
thing being able to divert his Melancholy, which <>
increaed upon him: He fear'd it would bring him into a Fever, if he did not give himelf the <>
of eeing Atlante. He had no ooner though • of this, but he was impatient to put it into <>
he reolves to go (having very good Hores) without acquainting any of his Servants with it. He got a very handome and light I adder of Ropes made, which he carried under his Coat, and away he rid for
<> , tay'd at a little Village, till the Darknes of the <>
might favour his Deign: And then walking about Atlante's Lodgings, till he aw a Light in her Chamber; and then making that Noie on his Sword, as <>
greed between them. He was heard by his <>
Atlante, and uffered to mount her Chamber; <>
he would tay till almot break of Day, and then ••
turn to the Village, and take Hore and away for Paris again. This, once in a Month, was his Exercie, without which he could not live; o that his whole Year
was pat in riding between Orleance and Paris, between exces of Grief and exces of Joy by turns.

It was now that Atlante arrived to her fifteenth Year, hone out with a Lutre of Beauty greater than ever; and in this Year of the Abence of Rinaldo, had carried herelf with that Severity of Life, without the youthful Deire of going abroad, or deiring any Diverion, but what he found in her own retired Thoughts: That Vernole, wholly unable longer to conceal his Paion, reolved to make a Publication of it, firt to the Father, and then to the lovely Daughter, of whom he had ome hope, becaue he had carried herelf very well towards him for this Year pat; which he would never have done, if he had imagined he would ever have been her Lover: She had een no Signs of any uch Misfortune towards her in thee many Years he had convered with her, and he had to caue to fear him. When one Day her Father taking her into the Garden, told her what Honour and Happines was in tore for her; and that now the Glory of his fallen Family would rie again, ince he had a Lover of an illutrious Blood, allied to Monarchs; and one whoe Fortune was newly encreas'd to a very coniderable Degree, anwerable to his Birth. She changed Colour at this Dicoure, imagining but too well, who this illutrious Lover was: When De Pais proceeded, and told her, Indeed his Peron was not the most agreeable that ever was een; but he married her to Glory and Fortune, not the Man: And a Woman, ays he, ought to look no farther.

She needed not any more to inform her, who this intended Husband was; and, therefore burting forth into Tears, he throws herelf at his Feet, imploring him not to ue the Authority of a Father, to force her to a thing o contrary to her Inclinations; auring, he could not conent to any uch thing; and that he would rather die than yield: She urged many Arguments for this her Diobedience. But none would pas for current with the old Gentleman, whoe Pride had
lattered him with hopes of o coniderable a Son-in-Law: He was very much urprized at Atlante's refuing what he believed he would receive with Joy; and finding that no Arguments on his ide could draw hers to an obedient Conent, he grew to uch a Rage, as very rarely poet him; vowing, if he did not conform her Will to his, he would abandon her to all the Cruelty of Contempt and Poverty; o that at lat he was forced to return him this Anwer, That he would trive all he could with her Heart; but he verily believed he hould never bring it to conent to a Marriage with Monieur the Count. The Father continued threatning her, and gave her ome Days to conider of it: So leaving her in Tears, he returned to his Chamber, to conider what Anwer he hould give Count Vernole, whom he knew would be impatient to learn what Succes he had, and what himelf was to hope: De Pais, after ome Conideration, reolved to tell him, he received the Offer very well; but, that he mut expect a little Maiden Nicety in the Cae; and accordingly did tell him o; and he was not at all doubtful of his good Fortune.

But Atlante, who reolved to die a thouand Deaths rather than break her olemn Vows to Rinaldo, or to marry the Count, cat about how he hould avoid it with the leat Hazard of her Father's Rage. She found Rinaldo the better and more advantageous Match of the two, could they but get his Father's Conent: He was beautiful and young; his Title was equal to that of Vernole, when his Father hould die; and his Etate exceeded his; yet he dares not make a Dicovery, for fear he hould injure her Lover; who at this time, though he knew it not, lay ick of a Fever, while he was wondering that he came not as he ued to do: However, he reolves to end him a Letter, and acquaint him with the Misfortune; which he did in thee Terms:

body.head: ATLANTE to RINALDO.
body.p: MY Father's Authority would force me to violate my acred Vows to you, and give them to the Count Vernole, whom I mortally hate, yet could wih him the greatest Monarch in the World, that I might how you. I could even then depie him for your ake. My Father is already too much inraged by my denial, to hear Reaon from me, if I hould confes to him my Vows to you: So that I ee nothing but a Propect of Death before me; for aure yourelf, my Rinaldo, I will die rather than conent to marry any other: Therefore come, my Rinaldo, and come quickly, to ee my Funerals, intead of thoe Nuptials they vainly expect from

div.p: This Letter Rinaldo received; and there needed no more to make him ly to Orleance: This raied him oon from his Bed of Sicknes, and getting immediately to hers, he arrived at his Father's Houe; who did not o much admire to ee him, becaue he heard he was ick of a Fever, and gave him leave to return, if he pleas'd: He went directly to his Father's Houe, becaue he knew omewhat of the Buines; he was reolv'd to make his Paion known, as oon as he had een Atlante; from whom he was to take all his Meaures: He therefore fail'd not, when all were in Bed, to rie and go from his Chamber, into the Street; where finding a Light in Atlante's Chamber, for he every Night expected him, he made the uual Sign, and he went into the Balcony; and he having no Conveniency of mounting up into it, they dicours'd, and aid all they had to ay: From thence, he tells him of the Count's Paions, of her Father's Reolution, and her own, which was rather to die his than live any body's ele: And at lat, as their lat Refuge, they reolv'd to dicover the whole Matter; he to her Father, and he to his, to ee what Accommodation they could make; if not, to die together. They parted at this Reolve, for he would permit him no longer to tay the Street, after uch a Sicknes; o he went home to Bed, but not to leep.

The next Day, at Dinner, Monigniore Bellyuard believing his Son abolutely cur'd by Abence of his Paion; and peaking of all the News of the Town; among the ret, told him, he was come in good time to Dance at the Wedding of Count Vernole with Atlante, the Match being agreed on: No, Sir, reply'd Rinaldo, I hall never Dance at the Marriage of Count Vernole with Atlante; and you will ee in Monieur De Pais's Houe a Funeral ooner than a Wedding: And thereupon, he told his Father all his Paion, for that lovely Maid; and aur'd him, if he would not ee him laid in his Grave, he mut conent to this Match: Bellyuard roe in a Fury, and told him, He had rather ee him in the
Grave, than in the Arms of Atlante: Not, continued he, o much for any dilike I have to the young Lady, or the Smallnes of her Fortune; but, becaue I have o long warn'd you from uch a Paion, and have with uch Care endeavour'd by your Abence to prevent it. He travers'd the Room very fat, till proteting againt this Alliance; and was deaf to all Rinaldo could ay: On the other ide, the Day being come, wherein Atlante was to give her final Anwer to her Father, concerning her Marriage with Count Vernole: She aum'd all the Courage and Reolution he could to withtand the Storm, that threaten'd a Denial. And her Father came to her, and demanding her Anwer; he told him, She could not be the Wife of Vernole, ince he was Wife to Rinaldo, only Son to Bellyuard. If her Father torm'd before, he grew like a Man ditracted at her Confeion; and Vernole hearing them loud, ran to the Chamber, to learn the Caue; where, jut as he entered, he found De Pais's Sword drawn, and ready to kill his Daughter, who lay all in Tears at his Feet, he withheld his Hand; and asking the Caue of this Rage, he was told all that Atlante had confes'd; which put Vernole quite beide all his Gravity, and made him dicover the Infirmity of Anger; which he us'd to ay, ought to be diembled by all wie Men: So that De Pais forgot his own to appeae his; but 'twas in vain, for he went out of the Houe, vowing Revenge on Rinaldo: And to that end, being not very well aur'd of his own Courage, as I aid before, and being of the Opinion, that no Man ought to expoe his Life to him, who has injur'd him: He hir'd Swis and Spanih Soldiers to attend him in the Nature of Footmen; and watch'd everal Nights about Bellyuard's Door: And that of De Pais, believing he hould ometime or other ee him under the Window of Atlante, or perhaps mounting in it; for now he no longer doubted, but this happy Lover was he, whom he fancy'd he heard go from the Balcony that Night, he came up with his Pitol; and being more a Spaniard than a French Man
in his Nature, he reolv'd to take him any way unguarded or unarmed, if he came in his way.

Atlante, who heard his Threatnings, when he went from her in a Rage, fear'd his Cowardize might put him on ome bae Action, to deprive Rinaldo of his Life; and therefore thought it not afe to uffer him to come to her by Night, as he had before done; but ent him word in a Note, that he hould forbear her Window, for Vernole had worn his Death: This Note came uneen by his Father to his Hands; but this could not hinder him from coming to her Window, which he did as oon as it was dark, he came thither, only attended with his Vallet and two Footmen; for now he cared not who knew the Secret: He had no ooner made the Sign, but he found himelf incompas'd with Vernole's Bravoes; and himelf tanding at a ditance, cry'd out, That he is: With that, they all drew on both ides, and Rinaldo receiv'd a Wound in the Arm. Atlante heard this, and ran crying out, That Rinaldo, pret by Numbers, would be kill'd. De Pais, who was reading in his Cloet, took his Sword, and ran out; and contrary to all expectation, eeing Rinaldo fighting with his back to the Door, pull'd him into the Houe, and fought himelf with the Bravoes. Who being very much wounded by Rinaldo, gave ground and heer'd off; and De Pais putting up old Billo into the Scabbard, went into his Houe, where he found Rinaldo almot fainting with los of Blood, and Atlante with her Maids binding up his Wound; to whom De Pais aid, This Charity Atlante very well becomes you, and is what I can allow you; and I could wih you had no other Motive for this Action. Rinaldo by degrees recovered of his Fainting, and as well as his Weaknes would permit him, he got up and made a low Reverence to De Pais; telling him, He had now a double Obligation to pay him all the Repect in the World; first, for his being the Father of Atlante; and econdly, for being the Preerver of his Life; two Tyes that hould eternally oblige him to Love and Honour him, as his own Parent: De Pais
reply'd, He had done nothing but what common Humanity compelled him to: But if he would make good that Repect he profes'd towards him, it must be in quitting all Hopes of Atlante, whom he had detin'd to another, or to an eternal Incloure in a Monatery: He had another Daughter, whom if he would think worthy of his regard, he hould take his Alliance as a very great Honour; but his Word and Reputation, nay, his Vows were past, to give Atlante to Count Vernole. Rinaldo, who before he poke, took meaure from Atlante's Eyes; which told him, her Heart was his; return'd this Anwer to De Pais: That he was infinitely glad to find by the Generoity of his Offer, that he had no Averion to his being his Son-in-Law; and that next to Atlante, the greatest Happines he could wih would be, his receiving Charlot from his Hands, but that he could not think of quitting Atlante, how neceary oever it would be for Glory, and his—(the further) Repoe. De Pais would not let him at this time, argue the Matter further, eeing he was ill, and had need of looking after; he therefore begg'd he would for his Health's ake retire to his own Houe, whither he himelf conducted him; and left him to the Care of his Men, who were ecap'd the Fray; and return'd to his own Chamber, he found Atlante retir'd, and o he went to Bed full of Thoughts; this Night had increaed his Eteem for Rinaldo, and leen'd it for Count Vernole; but his Word and Honour being pat, he could not break it, neither with Safety nor Honour; for he knew the haughty reenting Nature of the Count, and he fear'd ome Danger might arrive to the brave Rinaldo, which troubled him very much: At lat he reolv'd, that neither might take any thing ill at his Hands, to looe Atlante, and end her to the Monatery, where her Siter was, and compel her to be a Nun. This he thought would prevent Michiefs on both ides; and accordingly, the next day (having in the Morning ent word to the Lady Abbes what he would have done; he carries Atlante under pretence of viiting her Siter, which they often did) to the Monatery,
where he was no ooner come, but he was led into the Incloure: Her Father he had rather Sacrifice her than he hould be the Caue of the Murther of two uch Noble Men as Vernole and Rinaldo.

The Noie of Atlante's being inclos'd, was oon pread all over the buie Town, and Rinaldo was not the lat to whom the News arriv'd: He was for a few Days confin'd to his Chamber; where, when alone, he rav'd like a Man ditracted. But his Wounds had o incened his Father againt Atlante, that he wore he would ee his Son die of them, rather than uffer him to marry Atlante; and was extreamly over-joyed, to find he was condemned for ever to the Monatery; o that the Son thought it the wiet Coure, and the mot for the Advantage of his Love, to ay nothing to contradict his Father; but being almot aured Atlante would neither conent to be hut up in a Cloyter, and abandon him, he flatter'd himelf with hope, that he hould teal her from thence, and marry her in pight of all Oppoition. This he was impatient to put in Practice: He believed, if he were not permitted to ee Atlante, he had till a kind Advocate in Charlot, who was now arriv'd to her Thirteenth Year, and infinitely advanc'd in Wit and Beauty. Rinaldo therefore often goes to the Monatery, urrounding it, to ee what poibility there was of accomplihing his Deign; if he could get her Conent, he finds it not impoible, and goes to viit Charlot; who had Command not to ee him, or peak to him. This was a Cruelty he look'd not for, and which gave him an unpeakable Trouble, and without her Aid it was wholly impoible to give Atlante any Account of his Deign. In this Perplexity he remain'd many Days, in which he languih'd almot to Death; he was ditracted with Thought, and continually hovering about the Nunnery-Walls, in hope, at ome time or other, to ee or hear from the lovely Maid, who alone could make his Happines. In thee Traveres he often met Vernole, who had liberty to ee her
when he pleas'd: If it happen'd that they chanc'd to meet in the Day-time, tho' Vernole were attended with an Equipage of Ruffians, and Rinaldo but only with a couple of Footmen, he could perceive Vernole hun him, grow pale, and almot tremble with Fear ometimes, and get to the other ide of the Street; and if he did not, Rinaldo having a mortal hate to him, would often bear up cloe to him, that he would jotle him againt the Wall; which Vernole would patiently put up, and pas on; o that he could never be provok'd to fight by Day-light, how olitary oever the place was where they met: but if they chanc'd to meet at Night, they were certain of a Skirmih, in which he would have no part himelf; o that Rinaldo was often like to be aainated, but till came off with ome light Wound. This continued o long, and made o great a Noie in the Town, that the two Old Gentlemen were mightily alarm'd by it; and Count Bellyuard came to De Pays, one Day, to dicoure with him of this Affair; and Bellyuard, for the Preervation of his Son, as almot conenting, ince there was no Remedy, that he hould marry Atlante. De Pays confes'd the Honour he proffer'd him, and how troubled he was, that his Word was already pat to his Friend, the Count Vernole, whom he aid he hould marry, or remain for ever a Nun; but if Rinaldo could diplace his Love from Atlante, and place it on Charlot, he hould gladly conent to the Match. Bellyuard, who would now do any thing for the Repoe of his Son, tho' he believ'd this Exchange would not pas, yet reolv'd to propoe it, ince by Marrying him, he took him out of the Danger of Vernole's Aainates, who would never leave him, 'till they had dipatch'd him, hould he marry Atlante.

While Rinaldo was contriving a thouand Ways to come to peak to, or end Billets to Atlante, none of which would ucceed without the Aid of Charlot, his Father came and propoed this Agreement between De Pays, and himelf, to his Son. At firt Rinaldo receiv'd it with chang'd Countenance, and a breaking Heart;
but wiftly turning from Thought to Thought, he conceiv'd this the only way to come at Charlot, and o conequently at Atlante; he therefore, after ome diembled Regret, conents, with a ad put-on-Look: And Charlot had Notice given her, to ee and entertain Rinaldo. As yet they had not told her the Reaon; which her Father would tell her, when he came to viit her, he aid. Rinaldo over-joy'd at this Contrivance, and his own Diimulation, goes to the Monatery, viits Charlot; where he ought to have aid omething of this Propoition; but wholly bent upon other Thoughts, he olicits her to convey ome Letters, and Preents to Atlante; which he readily did, to the unpeakable Joy of the poor Ditret. Sometimes he would talk to Charlot of her own Affairs; asking her, If he reolv'd to become a Nun? To which he would igh, and ay, If he mut, it would be extreamly againt her Inclinations; and, if it pleaed her Father, he had rather begin the World with any tolerable Match.

Things pat thus for ome Days, in which our Lovers were happy, and Vernole aured he hould have Atlante. But at lat De Pays came to viit Charlot, who asked her, if he had een Rinaldo? he anwered, She had. And how does he entertain you? reply'd De Pays; Have you received him as a Husband? and has he behaved himelf like one? At this a udden Joy eized the Heart of Charlot; and loth to confes what he had done for him to her Siter, he hung down her bluhing Face, to tudy for an Anwer. De Pays continued, and told her the Agreement between Bellyuard and him, for the aving of Bloodhed.

She, who blet the Caue, whatever it was, having always a great Friendhip and Tendernes for Rinaldo, gave her Father a thouand Thanks for his Care; and aured him, ince he was commanded by him, he would receive him as her Husband.

And the next Day, when Rinaldo came to viit her, as he ued to do, and bringing a Letter with him, wherein he propoed the ight of Atlante: He found a
Coldnes in Charlot, as oon as he told her his Deign, and deired her to carry the Letter. He asked the reaon of this Change She tells him, he was informed of the Agreement between their two Fathers, and that he look'd upon herelf as his Wife, and would act no more as a Confident, that he had ever a violent Inclination of Friendhip for him, which he would oon improve into omething more oft.

He could not deny the Agreement, nor his Promie; but it was in vain to tell her, he did it only to get a Correpondence with Atlante: She is obtinate, and he as preing, with all the Tendernes of Perwaion: He vows he can never be any but Atlante's; and he may ee him die, but never break his Vows. She urges her Claim in vain, o that at lat he was overcome, and promied he would carry the Letter; which was to have her make her ecape that Night. He waits at the Grate for her Anwer, and Charlot returns with one that pleaed him very well; that was, that Night her Siter would make her ecape, and that he mut tand in uch a place of the Nunnery-Wall, and he would come out to him.

After this he upbraids him with his fale Promie to her, and of her Goodnes to erve him after uch a Diappointment. He receives her Reproaches with a thouand Sighs, and bemoans his Misfortune in not being capable of more than Friendhip for her; and vows, that next Atlante, he eteems her of all Womenkind. She eems to be obliged by this, and aured him, he would haten the Flight of Atlante; and taking leave, he went home to order a Coach, and ome Servants to ait him.

In the mean time, Count Vernole came to viit Atlante; but he refued to be een by him: And all he could do there that Afternoon, was entertaining Charlot at the Grate; to whom he poke a great many fine Things, both of her improved Beauty and Wit; and how happy Rinaldo would be in o fair a Bride. She received this with all the Civility that was due to his
Quality; and their Dicoure being at an end, he took his leave, it being towards the Evening.

Rinaldo, wholly impatient, came betimes to the Corner of the dead Wall, where he was appointed to tand, having ordered his Footmen and Coach to come to him as oon as it was dark: While he was there walking up and down, Vernole came by the end of the Wall to go home, and looking about, he aw at the other end Rinaldo walking, whoe Back was towards him; but he knew him well; and tho' he feared and dreaded his Bus • nes there, he durt not encounter him, they being both attended but by one Footman a piece. But Vernole's Jealouie and Indignation was o high, that he reolv'd to fetch his Bravoes to his Aid, and come and aault him; for he knew he waited there for ome Meage from Atlante.

In the mean time it grew dark, and Rinaldo's Coach came with another Footman; which were hardly arrived, when Vernole, with his aitance, came to the Corner of the Wall, and creening themelves a little behind it, near to the place where Rinaldo tood, who waited now cloe to a little Door, out of which the Gardeners ued to throw the Weeds and Dirt. Vernole could perceive anon, the Door to open, and a Woman come out of it, calling Rinaldo by his Name; who tept up to her, and caught her in his Arms, with Signs of infinite Joy. Vernole being now all Rage, cried to his Aainate, Fall on, and kill the Raviher: And immediately they all fell on. Rinaldo, who had only his two Footmen on his ide, was forced to let go the Lady; who would have run into the Garden again, but the Door fell too, and lock'd; o that while Rinaldo was fighting, and beaten back by the Bravoes, one of which he laid dead at his Feet, Vernole came up to the frighted Lady, and taking her by the Hand, cried, Come, my fair Fugitive, you must along with me. She, wholly cared out of her Senes, was willing to go any where out of the Terror he heard o near her, and without Reply, gave herelf into his Hand; who carried
her directly to her Father's Houe; where he was no ooner come, but he told her Father all that had pat, and how he was running away with Rinaldo, but that his good Fortune brought him jut in the lucky Minute. Her Father turning to reproach her, found by the Light of a Candle, that this was Charlot, and not Atlante, whom Vernole had brought home: At which Vernole was extreamly atonih'd. Her Father demanded of her, Why he was running away with a Man, who was deigned her by Conent. Yes, aid Charlot, you had his Conent, Sir, and that of his Father; but I was far from getting it: I found he reolved to die, rather than quit Atlante; And promiing him my aitance in his Amour, ince he could never be mine, he got me to carry a Letter to Atlante; which was, to deire her to fly away with him. Intead of carrying her this Letter, I told her, he was deigned for me, and had cancelled all his Vows to her: She wooned at this News; and being recovered a little, I left her in the Hands of the Nuns, to perwade her to live; which he reolves not to do without Rinaldo. Though they pres'd me, yet I reolved to purue my Deign, which was to tell Rinaldo, he would obey his kind Summons. He waited for her; but I put myelf into his Hands in lieu of Atlante; and had not the Count received me, we had been married by this time, by ome fale Light that could not have dicovered me: But I am atisfied, if I had, he would never have lived with me longer than the Cheat had been undicovered; for I find them both reolved to die, rather than change: And for my part, Sir, I was not o much in Love with Rinaldo, as I was out of Love with a Nunnery; and took any Opportunity to quit a Life abolutely contrary to my Humour. She poke this with a Gaiety o brisk, and an Air o agreeable, that Vernole found it touch'd his Heart; and the rather, becaue he found Atlante would never be his; or if he were, he hould be till in Danger from the Reentment of Rinaldo; he therefore bowing to Charlot, and taking her by the Hand, cryed, Madam, ince Fortune has dipos'd you thus luckily for me, in my
Poeion, I humbly implore you would conent he hould make me entirely happy, and give me the Prize for which I fought, and have conquered with my Sword. My Lord, replied Charlot, with a modet Air, I am upertitious enough to believe, that ince Fortune, o contrary to all our Deigns, has given me into your Hands, that he from the beginning dotined me to the Honour; which, with my Father's Conent, I hall receive as becomes me. De Pais tranported with Joy, to find all things would be o well brought about; it being all one to him, whether Charlot or Atlante gave him Count Vernole for his Son-in-Law, readily conented; and immediately a Priet was ent for; and they were that Night married. And it being now not above Seven a Clock, many of their Friends were invited, the Muick ent for, and as good a Supper as o hort a time would provide, was made ready.

All this was performed in as hort a time as Rinaldo was fighting; and having killed one, and wounded the ret, they all fled before his conquering Sword; which was never drawn with o good a Will. When he came where his Coach tood, jut againt the Back-Garden-Door, he looked for his Mitres: But the Coachman told him, He was no ooner engaged, but a Man came, and with a thouand Reproaches on her Levity, bore her off.

This made our young Lover rave; and he is atisfied he is in the Hands of his Rival; and that he had been fighting, and hedding his Blood, only to ecure her Flight with him. He lot all Patience; and it was with much ado his Servants perwaded him to return; telling him, in their Opinion, he was more likely to get out of the Hands of his Rival, and come to him, than when he was in the Monatery.

He uffers himelf to go into his Coach, and be carry'd home; but he was no ooner alighted, but he heard Muick, and a Noie of Fetival at De Pays's Houe. He aw Coaches urround his Door, and Pages and Footmen, with Flambeaus. This Sight and Noie of
Joy made him ready to ink at the Door; and ending his Footman to learn the Caue of this Triumph; the Pages that waited there, told him, That Count Vernole was, this Night, married to Monieur De Pais's Daughter. He needed no more to deprive him of all Sene; and taggering againt his Coach, he was caught by his Footmen, and carried into his Houe, and to his Chamber, where they put him to Bed, all enles as he was, and had much ado to recover him to Life. He asked for his Father, with a faint Voice; for he deired to ee him before he died. It was told him, he was gone to Count Vernole's Wedding, where there was a perfect Peace agreed on between them, and all Animoities laid aide. At this News Rinaldo fainted again; and his Servants called his Father home, and told him in what Condition they had brought home their Mater, recounting to him all that was pat. He hated to Rinaldo, whom he found jut recovered of his Swooning; who, putting his Hand out to his Father, all cold, and trembling, cry'd, Well, Sir, now you are atisfied, ince you have een Atlante married to Count Vernole: I hope now you will give your unfortunate Son leave to die; as you wih'd he hould, rather than give him to the Arms of Atlante. Here his Speech failed, and he fell again into a Fit of Swoooning: His Father ready to die with Fear of his Son's Death, kneeled down by his Bed-ide; and after having recovered him a little, he aid, My dear Son, I have been indeed at the Wedding of Count Vernole; but 'tis not to Atlante, to whom he is married, but Charlot; who was the Peron you were bearing from the Monatery, intead of Atlante; who is till reerved for you, and is dying • till he hear you are reerved for her: Therefore, as you regard her Life, make much of your own, and make your elf fit to receive her: For her Father and I have agreed the Marriage already. And without giving him leave to thank him, he called to one of his Gentlemen, and ent him to the Monatery, with this News to Atlante. Rinaldo bowed himelf as low as he could in his Bed, and kis'd the Hand of his
Father, with Tears of Joy: But his Weaknes continued all next Day; and they were fain to bring Atlante to him, to confirm his Happines.

It mut only be gueed by Lovers, the perfect Joy thee two received in the ight of each other. Bellyuard received her as his Daughter; and the next Day made her o with very great Solemnity; at which were Vernole and Charlot: Between Rinaldo, and him, was concluded a perfect Peace, and all thought themelves happy in this double Union.
MEMOIRS ON THE COURT OF THE King of Bantam.
A NOVEL.
WRITTEN By Mrs. A. BEHN.
LONDON, Printed for Samuel Bricoe, near Covent-Garden, 1697.

div.head: THE COURT OF THE King of Bantam.
div.p:
THIS Money, certainly, is a mot Dev'lih Thing! I'm ure, the want of it had like to have ruin'd my dear Philibella in her Love to Valentine Goodland; who was, really, a pretty deerving Gentleman, Heir to about Fifteen-hundred Pound a Year; which, however did not o much recommend him, as the Sweetnes of his Temper, the Comelines of his Peron, and the Excellency of his Parts: In all which Circumtances my obliging Acquaintance equall'd him, unles in the advantage of their Fortune. Old Sir George Goodland knew of his Son's Paion for Philibella; and though he was Generous, and of an Humour ufficiently Complying, yet he cou'd by no means think it convenient, that his only Son hou'd marry with a young Lady of o lender a Fortune as my Friend, who had not above Five hundred Pound, and that the Gift of her Uncle Sir Philip Friendly; though her Vertue and Beauty might have deerv'd and
have adorn'd the Throne of an Alexander or Caear.

Sir Philip himelf, indeed, was but a Younger Brother, though of a Good Family, and of a Generous Education; which with his Peron, Bravery and Wit, recommended him to his Lady Philadelphia, Widow of Sir Bartholomew Banquier, who left her poes'd of Two thouand Pound per Annum, beides Twenty thouand Pound in Money and Jewels; which oblig'd him to get himelf Dubb'd, that he might not decend to an inferior Quality. When he was in Town, he liv'd—Let me ee! in the Strand; or, as near as I can remember, omewhere about Charing-Cros; where, firt of all, Mr. Wou'd be King, a Gentleman of a large Etate in Houes, Land and Money, of a ha • ghty, extravagant and profue Humour, very fond of every new Face, had the misfortune to fall paionately in love with Philibella, who then liv'd with her Uncle.

This Mr. Wou'd be (it eems) had often been told, when he was yet a Stripling, either by one of his Nures, by his own Grand-mother, or by ome other Gypie, that he hou'd infallibly be what his Sirname imply'd, a King, by Providence or Chance, e're he dy'd, or never. This glorious Prophecy had o great an Influence on all his Thoughts and Actions, that he ditributed and dipers'd his Wealth ometimes o largely, that one wou'd ha' thought he had undoubtedly been King of ome part of the Indies; to ee a Preent made, to day, of a Diamond-Ring, worth Two or Three hundred Pound, to Madam Flippant; tomorrow, a large Chet of the finet China,
to my Lady Fleecewell; and next day (perhaps) a rich Necklace of large Oriental Pearl, with a Locquet to it of Saphires, Emeralds, Rubies, &c. to pretty Mi. Ogleme, for an Amorous Glance, for a Smile, and (it may be, though but rarely) for the mighty Bleing of one ingle Kis. But uch were his Largees, not to reckon his Treats, his Balls, and Serenades beides, that at the ame time he had marry'd a Vertuous Lady, and of Good Quality: but her Relation to him (it may be fear'd) made her very diagreeable: For a Man of his Humour and Etate can no more be atisfy'd with one Woman, than with one Dih of Meat: And, to ay truth, 'tis omething unmodih. However, he might ha' dy'd a pure Celibate, and altogether unexpert of Woman, had his good or bad hopes only terminated in Sir Philip's Niece. But the Brave and Haughty Mr. Wou'd be was not to be baulk'd by Appearances of Virtue, which he thought all Womankind did only affect; beides, he promis'd himelf the Victory over any Lady whom he attempted, by the force of his damn'd Money, though her Virtue were never o real and trict.

With Philibella he found another pretty young Creature, very like her, who had been a quondam Mitres to Sir Philip: He, with young Goodland, was then diverting his Mitres and Niece at a Game of Cards, when Wou'd be came to viit him: he found 'em very merry, with a Flaque of Claret or two before 'em, and Oranges roating by a large Fire, (for it was Chritmas-time.) The Lady Friendly underdertanding that this Extraordinary Man was
with Sir Philip in the Parlour, came in to 'em, to make the number of both Sexes equal, as well as in hopes to make up a Pure of Guinea's toward the purchae of ome new fine bus'nes that he had in her head, from his accutom'd Deign of loing at play to her. Indeed, he had part of her Wih; for he got Twenty Guinea's of him; Philibella, Ten; and Lucy, Sir Philip's Quondam, Five: Not but that Wou'd be intended better Fortune to the young ones, than he did to Sir Philip's Lady; but her Ladyhip was utterly unwilling to give him over to their Management, though at the lat. When they were all tir'd with the Cards, after Wou'd be had aid as many obliging things as his preent Genius wou'd give him leave, to Philibella and Lucy, epecially to the firt, not forgetting his Baiemains to the Lady Friendly, he bid the Knight and Goodland adieu; but with a Promie of repeating his Viit at ix a clok in the Evening o' Twelfth-day, to renew the famous and ancient Solemnity of Chuing King and Queen; to which Sir Philip before invited him, with a Deign yet unknown to you, I hope.

As oon as he was gone, every one made their Remarks on him, but with very little or no difference in all their figures of him. In hort, all Mankind, had they ever known him, wou'd have univerally agreed in this his Character, That he was an Original; ince nothing in Humanity was ever o Vain, o Haughty, o Profue, o Fond, and o ridiculouly Ambitious as Mr. Wou'd be King. They Laugh'd and Talk'd about an hour longer, and then young Goodland was oblig'd to ee Lucy home in his Coach; tho'
he had rather have ate up all Night in the ame Houe with Philibella, I fanie, of whom he took but an unwilling leave; which was viible enough to every one there, ince they were all acquainted with his Paion for my Fair Friend.

About Twelve a' clock on the Day prefix'd, young Goodland came to Dine with Sir Philip, whom he found jut return'd from Court, in a very good Humour. On the ight of Valentine, the Knight ran to him, and embracing him, told him, That he had prevented his Wihes, in coming thither before he ent for him, as he had jut then deign'd. T'other return'd, That he therefore hop'd he might be of ome ervice to him, by o happy a prevention of his intended Kindnes. No doubt, (reply'd Sir Philip,) the Kindnes, I hope, will be to us both; I am aur'd it will, if you will act according to my meaures. I deire no better Precriptions for my Happines (return'd Valentine) than what you hall pleae to et down to me: But is it neceary or convenient that I hou'd know 'em firt? It is, (anwer'd Sir Philip;) Let us it, and you hall undertand 'em.—I am very enible (continu'd he) of your incere and honourable Affection and Pretention to my Niece, who, perhaps, is as dear to me as my own Child cou'd be, had I one; nor am I ignorant how avere Sir George your Father is to your marriage with her, inomuch that I am confident he would dihinherit you immediately upon it, meerly for want of a Fortune omewhat proportionable to your Etate; but I have now contriv'd the means to add Two or Three thouand
Pounds to the Five hundred I deign'd to give with her; I mean, if you marry her, Val. not otherwie; for I will not labour o for any other Man. What inviolable Obligations you put upon me! (cry'd Goodland.) No Returns by way of Complements, good Val. (aid the Knight:) Had I not engag'd to my Wife, before marriage, that I wou'd not dipoe of any part of what he brought me, without her conent, I wou'd certainly make Philibella's Fortune anwerable to your Etate: And beides, my Wife is not yet full Eight and twenty, and we may therefore expect Children of our own, which hinders me from propoing any thing more for the advantage of my Niece:—But now to my Intructions;—King will be here this Evening, without fail, and, at ome time or other to night, will hew the Haughtines of his Temper to you, I doubt not, ince you are in a manner a Stranger to him: Be ure therefore you eem to quarrel with him before you part, but uffer as much as you can firt from his tongue; for I know he will give you occaions enough to exercie your paive Valour: I mut appear his Friend; and you mut retire home, if you pleae, for this night, but let me ee you early as your convenience will permit to morrow: My late Friend Lucy mut be my Niece too:—Oberve this, and leave the ret to me. I hall mot punctually, and will in all things be directed by you, (return'd Valentine.) I had forgot to tell you (aid Friendly) that I have o order'd matters, that He mut be King to Night, and Lucy Queen, by the Lo • s in the Cake. By
all means, (return'd Goodland;) It mut be Majety.

Exactly at Six a' clock came Wou'd be in his Coach and Six, and found Sir Philip and his Lady, Goodland, Philibella and Lucy ready to receive him; Lucy as Fine as a Dutches, and almot as Beautiful as he was before her Fall. All things were in ample Order for his Entertainment. They Play'd till Supper was erv'd in, which was between Eight and Nine. The Treat was very eaonable and plendid. Jut as the Second Coure was et on the Table, they were all on a udden urpriz'd, except Wou'd be, with a Flourih of Violins, and other Intruments, which proceeded to entertain 'em with the bet and newet Airs in the lat new Plays, being then in the Year 1683. The Ladies were curious to know to whom they ow'd this chearful part of their Entertainment: On which he call'd out, Hey! Tom Farmer! Aleworth! Eccles! Hall! and the ret of you! Here's a Health to thee Ladies, and all this Honourable Company. They Bow'd; He Drank, and commanded another Glas to be fill'd, into which he put omething yet better than the Wine, I mean, Ten Guinea's: Here, Farmer, (aid he then;) This for you and your Friends. We humbly thank the Honourable Mr. Wou'd be King. They all return'd, and truck up with more pritelynes than before. For Gold and Wine, doubtles, are the bet Roin for Muicians.

After Supper, they took a hearty Glas or two to the King, Queen, Duke, &c. And then the mighty Cake, Teeming with the Fate of this Extraordinary Peronage was brought in,
the Muicians playing an Overture at the Entrance of the Alimental Oracle; which was then Cut and Conulted, and the Royal Bean and Pea fell to thoe to whom Sir Philip had deign'd 'em. 'Twas then the Knight began a merry Bumper, with Three Huzza's, and, Long live King Wou'd be! to Goodland; who Echo'd, and Pledg'd him, putting the Glas about to the Harmonious Attendants: while the Ladies drank their own quantities, among themelves, To his aforeaid Majety. Then of coure, you may believe, Queen Lucy's Health went merrily round, with the ame Ceremony. After which, he aluted his Royal Conort, and condecended to do the ame Honour to the two other Ladies.

Then they fell a Dancing like Lightning; I mean, they mov'd as wift, and made almot as little Noie: But His Majety was oon weary of that; for he long'd to be making Love both to Philibella and Lucy, who (believe me) that Night might well enough have pas'd for a Queen.

They fell then to Quetions and Commands; to Cros Purpoes; I Think a Thought, What is it like? &c. In all which, His Wou'd be Majety took the opportunity of hewing the Excellency of his Parts, as, How Fit he was to Govern; How Dexterous at Mining and Countermining; and, How he cou'd Reconcile the mot Contrary and Ditant Thoughts. The Muick, at lat, good as it was, grew troubleom, and too loud; which made him dimis 'em: And then he began to this effect, addreing himelf to Philibella; Madam, had Fortune
been Jut, and were it poible that the World hou'd be Govern'd and Influenc'd by Two Suns, undoubtedly we had all been Subjects to you, from this Night's Chance, as well as to that Lady, who, indeed, alone can Equal you in the Empire of Beauty, which yet you hare with Her Majety here preent, who only cou'd dipute it with you, and is only Superior to you in Title. My Wife is infinitely oblig'd to your Majety, (interrupted Sir Philip,) who, in my opinion, has greater Charms, and more than both of 'em together. You ought to think o, Sir Philip, (return'd the New Dubb'd King;) However, you hou'd not o liberally have expres'd your elf, in Oppoition and Derogation to Majety:—Let me tell you, 'tis a awcy Boldnes that thus has loos'd your Tongue! —What think you, young Kinman and Counellor? (aid he to Goodland.) With all Repect due to your Sacred Title, (return'd Valentine, riing and bowing,) Sir Philip poke as became a truly affectionate Husband; and it had been Preumption in him, unpardonable, to have eem'd to preferr her Majety, or that other weet Lady, in his Thoughts, ince your Majety has been pleas'd to ay o much and o particularly of their Merits: 'Twou'd appear as if he durt lift up his Eyes, with Thoughts, too near the Heaven you only wou'd enjoy. And only can deerve, you hou'd have added, (aid King, no longer Wou'd be.) How! May it pleae your Majety, (cry'd Friendly,) Both my Nieces! Though you deerve Ten thouand more, and better, wou'd your Majety enjoy 'em Both? Are they then Both your Nieces?
(ask'd Chance's King.) Yes; Both, Sir, (return'd the Knight;) Her Majety's the Eldet, and in that Fortune has hewn ome Jutice. So he has, (reply'd the Titular Monarch;) My Lot is fair, (puru'd he,) though I can be blet but with One:
Let Majety with Majety be join'd,
To 'get and leave a Race of Kings behind.
Come, Madam, (continu'd he, kiing Lucy:) This, as an Earnet of our future Endeavours. I fear (return'd the pretty Queen) your Majety will forget the unhappy Statira, when you return to the Embraces of your Dear and Beautiful Roxana. There is none Beautiful but you, (reply'd the Titular King,) unles this Lady, to whom I yet cou'd pay my Vows mot zealouly, were't not that Fortune thus has preengag'd me: But, Madam, (continu'd he,) to hew that till you hold our Royal Favour, and that, next to our Royal Conort, we Eteem you, we greet you thus, (kiing Philibella;) And, as a Signal of our continued Love, wear this rich Diamond: (here he put a Diamond-Ring on her Finger, worth Three hundred Pounds.) Your Majety (puru'd he to Lucy) may pleae to wear this Necklace, with this Locket of Emeralds. Your Majety is Bounteous as a God! (aid Valentine.) Art thou in want, young Spark? (ask'd the King of Bantam,) I'll give thee an Etate hall make thee merit the Mitres of thy Vows, be he who he will. That is, my other Niece, Sir, (cry'd Friendly.) How! How! Preumptuous Youth! How are
thy Eyes and Thoughts exalted? Ha! To Blis your Majety mut never hope for, (reply'd Goodland.) How now, thou Creature of the baet Mold! Not hope for what thou dot apire to! Mock-King, thou cant not, dar't not, hall not hope it, (return'd Valentine, in a Heat.) Hold, Val. (cry'd Sir Philip,) you grow warm; forget your Duty to Their Majeties, and abue your Friends, by making us upected. Good-night, Dear Philibella, and my Queen! Madam, I am your Ladyhip's Servant, (aid Goodland:) Farewell, Sir Philip, Adieu, thou Pageant! thou Property-King! I hall ee thy Brother on the Stage, e're long; but firt I'll viit Thee; and in the mean time, by way of return to thy proffer'd Etate, I will add a real Territory to the ret of thy empty Titles; for, from thy Education, Barbarous manner of Converation, and Complexion, I think, I may jutly proclaim thee, King of Bantam:—So, Hail, King that Wou'd be! Hail, thou King of Chritmas! All Hail, Wou'd be King of Bantam!—And o he left 'em.—They all eem'd amaz'd, and gaz'd on one another, without peaking a yllable; till Sir Philip broke the Charm, and igh'd out, Oh, the montrous effects of Paion! Say rather, Oh, the foolih effects of a mean Education! (interrupted his Majety of Bantam;) For Paions were given us for Ue, Reaon to govern and direct us in the Ue, and Education to cultivate and refine that Reaon: But (puru'd he) for all his Impudence to me, which I hall take a time to correct, I am oblig'd to him, that at lat he has found me out a Kingdom
to my Title; and if I were Monarch of that Place, (Believe me, Ladies,) I wou'd make you all Princees and Dutchees; and Thou, my old Companion, Friendly! hould't Rule the Roat with me: But thee Ladies hou'd be with us there; where we would erect Temples and Altars to 'em: Build Golden Palaces of Love, and Catles—In the Air (interrupted her Majety Lucy the Firt, miling.) 'Gad take me, (cry'd King Woud be,) thou dear Part'ner of my Greatnes, and halt be, of all my Pleaures! thy pretty atyrical Obervation has oblig'd me beyond Imitation. I think your Majety is got into a vein of Rhiming to night, (aid Philadelphia.) Ay! Pox o' that young inipid Fop, we cou'd ele have been as Great as an Emperor of China, and as Witty as Horace in his Wine; but let him go, like a pragmatical, captious, giddy Fool as he is! I hall take a time to ee him. Nay, Sir, (aid Philibella,) he has promis'd your Majety a Viit, in our hearing: Come, Sir, I beg your Majety to pledge me this Glas to your Long and Happy Reign; laying aide all thoughts of ungovern'd Youth: Beides, this Dicoure mut needs be ungreatful to her Majety, to whom, I fear, he will be marry'd within this Month. How! (cry'd King and no King,) Marry'd to my Queen! I mut not, cannot uffer it! Pray retrain your elf a little, Sir, (aid Sir Philip,) and when once thee Ladies have left us, I will dicoure your Majety further about this Buines. Well, Pray, Sir Philip, (aid his Lady,) let not your Worhip be pleas'd to it up too long for his Majety: About Five o'clock
I hall expect you: 'Tis your old Hour. And yours, Madam, to wake, to receive me coming to Bed:—Your Ladyhip undertands me, (return'd Friendly.) You're merry, my Love, you're merry, (cry'd Philadelphia:) Come, Niece, to Bed! to Bed! Ay, (aid the Knight,) Go both of you and leep together, if you can, without the thoughts of a Lover, or a Husband. His Majety was pleas'd to wih 'em a good Repoe; and o, with a Kis, they parted for that time.

Now we're alone, (aid Sir Philip,) let me aure you, Sir, I reent this Affront done to you by Mr. Goodland, almot as highly as you can; and though I can't wih that you hou'd take uch Satisfaction as, perhaps, ome other hotter Sparks wou'd; yet let me ay, his Micarriage ought not to go unpunih'd in him. Fear not, (reply'd t'other,) I hall give him a harp Leon. No, Sir, (return'd Friendly,) I wou'd not have you think of a Bloody Revenge; for 'tis that which, poibly, he deigns on you: I know him Brave as any Man: However, were it convenient that the Sword hou'd determine betwixt you, you hou'd not want mine: The Affront is partly to me, ince done in my Houe: But I've already laid down afer meaures for us, though of more fatal conequence to him; that is, I've form'd 'em in my Thoughts: Dimis your Coach and Equipage, all but one Servant, and I will dicoure it to you at large: 'Tis now pat Twelve; and, if you pleae, I wou'd invite you to take up as eaie a Lodging here, as my Houe will afford. (Accordingly they were dimis'd, and
he proceeded:)—As I hinted to you before, he is in love with my younget Niece, Philibella; but her Fortune not exceeding Five hundred Pound, his Father will auredly diinherit him, if he marries her; though he has given his Conent that he hou'd marry her Eldet Siter, whoe Father dying e're he knew his Wife was with Child of the Younget, left Lucy Three thouand Pounds, being as much as he thought convenient to match her handomly; and accordingly, the Nuptials of Young Goodland and Lucy are to be celebrated next Eater. They hall not, if I can hinder 'em, (interrupted his offended Majety.) Never endeavour the obtruction, (aid the Knight,) for I'll hew you the way to a dearer Vengeance: Women are Women, your Majety knows; he may be won to your Embraces before that time, and then you antedate him, your Creature. A Cuckold, you mean, (cry'd King in Fanie;) O Exquiite Revenge! But can you conent that I hou'd attempt it? What is't to me? we live not in Spain, where all the Male Relations of the Family are oblig'd to vindicate a Whore; No, I wou'd wound him in his mot Tender Part. But how hall we compas it? (ask'd t'other.) Why thus; Throw away Three thouand Pounds on the Younget Siter, as a Portion, to make her as happy as he can be in her new Lover Sir Frederick Flygold, an Extravagant young Fop, and wholly given over to Gaming; o, ten to one, but you may retrieve your Money of him, and have the two Siters at your devotion. Oh, Thou my better Genius than that which was given to me by Heav'n at my
birth! What Thanks, what Praies hall I return and ing to Thee, for this! (cry'd King Conundrum.) No Thanks, no Praies, I beeech your Majety; ince in this I gratifie my elfe—You think I am your Friend? And, you will agree to this? (aid Friendly, by way of Quetion.) Mot readily, (return'd the Fop-King;) Wou'd it were broad-Day, that I might end for the Money to my Bankers; for in all my Life, in all my Frolicks, Encounters and Extravagancies, I never had one o grateful and pleaant as this will be, if you are in earnet, to gratifie both my Love and Revenge! That I am in earnet, you will not doubt, when you ee with what Application I hall purue my Deign: In the mean time, My Duty to your Majety; To our good Succes in this Affair. While he drank, t'other return'd, With all my Heart; and pledg'd him. Then Friendly began afreh;—Leave the whole Management of this to me; only one thing more I think neceary, that you make a Preent of Five hundred Guinea's to Her Majety, the Bride that mut be. By all means, (return'd the wealthy King of Bantam;) I had o deign'd before. Well, Sir, (aid Sir Philip,) what think you of a Sett Party or two at Piquet, to pas away ome few hours, till we can leep? A eaonable and welcome Propoition, (return'd that King;) but I won't play above Twenty Guinea's the Game, and Forty the Lurch. Agreed, (aid Friendly;) Firt call in your Servant; mine is here already. The Slave came in, and they began, with unequal fortune at firt; for the Knight had lot an Hundred
Guinea's to Majety; which he paid in Specie; and then propos'd Fifty Guinea's the Game, and an Hundred the Lurch. To which t'other conented; and without winning more than three Games, and thoe not together, made hift to get Three thouand two hundred Guinea's in debt to Sir Philip: For which Majety was pleas'd to give him Bond, whether Friendly wou'd or no, Seal'd and Deliver'd in the Preence of
The Mark of (W.) Will. Watchful,
And, [S.] Sim. Slyboots.
A Couple of delicate Beagles, their mighty Attendants.

It was then about the hour that Sir Philip's (and, it may be, other Ladies) began to Yawn and Stretch; when the Spirits Refreh'd, Troul'd about and Tickl'd the Blood with Deires of Action; which made Majety and Worhip think of a Retreat to Bed; where, in les than Half an hour, or, before ever he could ay his Prayers, I'm ure, the firt • ell fat aleep: but the lat, perhaps, paid his accutom'd Devotion, e're he began his Progres to the Shadow of Death: However, he wak'd earlier than his Cully-Majety, and got up to receive young Goodland, who came to his Word, with the firt Opportunity. Sir Philip receiv'd him with more than uual Joy, though not with greater Kindnes, and let him know every Syllable and Accident that had pas'd between 'em till they went to bed: which you may believe was not a little pleaantly urpriing to Valentine,
who began then to have ome Aurance of his Happines with Philibella. His Friend told him, that he mut now be reconcil'd to his Mock-Majety, though with ome difficulty; and o taking one hearty Glas a piece he left Valentine in the Parlour, to carry the ungrateful News of his Viit to him that Morning. King—was in an odd ort of Taking, when he heard that Valentine was Below; and had been, as Sir Philip inform'd Majety, at Majety's Palace, to enquire for him there: but when he told him, that he had already chool'd him, on his own behalf, for the Affront done in his Houe, and that he believ'd he cou'd bring his Majety off without any los of preent Honour, his Countenance viibly dicover'd his pat Fear, and preent Satisfaction; which was much encreas'd too, when Friendly, hewing him his Bond for the Money he won of him at Play, let him know, that if he paid Three thouand Guinea's to Philibella, he wou'd immediately deliver him up his Bond, and not expect the Two hundred Guinea's Over-plus. His Majety of Bantam was then in o good an humour, that he cou'd have made love to Sir Philip; nay, I believe he cou'd a kis'd Valentine, intead of eeming angry. Down they came, and aluted like Gentlemen: But after the Greeting was over, Goodland began to talk omething of Affront, Satisfaction, Honour, &c. when immediately Friendly interpos'd, and after a little eeming Uneaines and Reluctancy, reconcil'd the Hot and Cholerick Youth to the Cold Phlegmatick King.

Peace was no ooner proclaim'd, than the King of Bantan took his Rival and late Ant •
gonit with him in his own Coach, not excluding Sir Philip by any means, to Locket's; where they Din'd: Thence he wou'd have 'em to Court with him, where he met the Lady Flippant, the Lady Harpy, the Lady Crocodile, Madam Tattlemore, Mis Medler, Mrs. Gingerly a rich Grocer's Wife, and ome others, beides Knights and Gentlemen of as good humours as the Ladies; all whom he invited to a Ball at his own Houe, the Night following; his own Lady being then in the Countrey. Madam Tattlemore, I think, was the firt he poke to in Court, and whom firt he urpriz'd with the happy News of his Advancement to the Title of King of Bantam. How wondrous haty was he to be gone, as oon as he heard it! 'Twas not in her Power, becaue not in her Nature, to tay long enough to take a civil Leave of the Company, but away he flew, big with the Empty Title of a Fantatick King, proclaiming it to every one of her Acquaintance, as he pas'd through every Room, till he came to the Preence-Chamber, where he only whiper'd it; but her Whipers made above half the Honourable Company quit the Preence of the King of Great Britain, to go make their Court to His Majety of Bantam; ome cry'd, God Bles Your Majety! ome, Long live the King of Bantam! others, All Hail to Your Sacred Majety! In hort, he was Congratulated on all ides. Indeed, I don't hear that His Majety, King Charles the Second ever ent any Embaador to Complement him; though, poibly,
He aluted him by his Title, the firt time he aw him afterwards: For, you know, He is a wonderful Good-natur'd and a Well-bred Gentleman.

After he thought the Court of England was univerally acquainted with his mighty Honour, he was pleas'd to think fit to retire to his own more private Palace, with Sir Philip and Goodland, whom he Entertain'd that night very handomly, till about Seven a clock; when they went together to the Play, which was, that Night, A King and No King. His Attendant-Friends cou'd not forbear miling, to think how aptly the Title of the Play uited his Circumtances. Nor cou'd he chue but take notice of it behind the Scenes, between Jet and Earnet; telling the Players how kind Fortune had been the Night pat, in dipoing the Bean to him; and jutifying what one of her Prophetees had foretold, ome Years ince: I hall now no more regard (aid he) that old Doating Fellow Pythagoras's Saying, Abtineto à Fabis; That is, (added he, by way of Contruction,) Abtain from Beans: For, I find the Excellency of 'em in Cakes and Dihes: From the firt, they inpire the Soul with mighty Thoughts; and from the lat, our Bodies receive a trong and wholom Nourihment. That is, (aid a Wag among thoe harp Youths, I think 'twas my Friend the Count;) Thee Puff you up in Mind, Sir; Thoe, in Body. They had ome further Dicoure among the Nymphs of the Stage, e're they went into the Pit; where Sir Philip pread the News of his Friend's Acceion to the Title, tho' not yet to the Throne
of Bantam; upon which he was there again Complemented on that Occaion. Several of the Ladies and Gentlemen who aluted him, he invited to the next Night's Ball at his Palace.

The Play done, they took each of 'em a Bottle at the Roe, and parted till Seven the Night following: which came not ooner than deired; for he had taken uch care, that all things were in readines before Eight, only he was to expect the Muick, till the end of the Play. About Nine, Sir Philip, his Lady, Goodland, Philibella and Lucy came. Sir Philip return'd him Rabelais, which he had borrow'd of him, wherein the Knight had written, in an old odd ort of Character, this Prophecy of his own making; with which he urpriz'd the Majety of Bantam, who vow'd he had never taken notice of 'em before; but he aid, he perceiv'd they had been long written, by the Character; and here it follows, as near as I can remember:
When M. D. C. come L before,
Three XXXs. two IIs. & one I more;
Then, KING, tho' now but Name to thee,
Shall both thy Name and Title be.
They had hardly made an end of reading 'em, e're the whole Company, and more than he had invited, came in, and were receiv'd with a great deal of Formality and Magnificence Lucy was there attended as his Queen; and Philibella, as the Princes her Siter. They Danc'd then till they were weary; and afterwards
retir'd to another large Room, where they found the Tables pread and furnih'd with all the mot eaonable Cold Meats; which was ucceeded by the choicet Fruits and the richet Diert of Sweet-meats that Luxury cou'd think on, or, at leat, that this Town cou'd afford. The Wines were all mot excellent in their kind; and their Spirits flew about through every corner of the Houe: There was carce a Spark ober in the whole Company, with drinking repeated Glaes to the Health of the King of Bantam and his Royal Conort, with the Princes Philibella's, who ate together under a Royal Canopy of State, his Majety between the two Beautiful Siters: only Friendly and Goodland wiely manag'd that Part of the Engagement where they were concern'd, and preerv'd themelves from the Heat of the Debauch.

Between Three and Four mot of 'em began to draw off, laden with Fruit and Sweet-meats, and rich Favours compos'd of Yellow, Green, Red and White, the Colours of his New Majety of Bantam. Before Five they were left to themelves; when the Lady Friendly was dicompos'd, for want of Sleep, and her uual Cordial; which oblig'd Sir Philip to wait on her home, with his two Nieces: But his Majety wou'd by no means part with Goodland; whom, before Nine that Morning, he made as Drunk as a Lord, and by conequence one of his Peers; for Majety was then, indeed, as Great as an Emperor: He fancy'd himelf Alexander, and young Valentine his Hephaetion; and did o Be-bus him, that the young Gentleman fear'd he was faln into the hands of an Italian. However, by the
kind Peruaions of his Condecending and Diembling Majety, he ventur'd to go into Bed with him; where King Wou'd be fell aleep, hand-over-head; and not long after, Goodland, his new made Peer, follow'd him to the cool Retreats of Morpheus.

About Three the next afternoon they both Wak'd, as by conent, and call'd to Dres. And after that bus'nes was over, I think, they wallow'd each of 'em a Pint of Old-Hook, with a little Sugar, by the way of Healing. Their Coaches were got ready in the mean time; but the Peer was forc'd to accept of the Honour of being carry'd in his Majety's to Sir Philip's; whom they found jut rien from Dinner, with Philadelphia and his two Nieces. They ate down, and ask'd for omething to relih a Glas of Wine; and Sir Philip order'd a cold Chine to be et before 'em; of which they eat about an Ounce a-piece: but they drank more by the half, I dare ay.

After their little Repat, Friendly call'd the Wou'd be-Monarch aide, and told him, that he wou'd have him go the Play that Night, which was, The London Cuckolds; promiing to meet him there in les than Half an Hour after his departure; telling him withal, that he wou'd urprize him with a much better Entertainment than the Stage afforded. Majety took the Hint, imagining, and that rightly, that the Knight had ome Intrigue in his head, for the Promotion of the Commonwealth of Cuckoldom: in order therefore to his Advice, he took his leave, about a Quarter of an Hour after.

When he was gone, Sir Philip thus bepoke his pretended Niece; Madam, I hope your Majety will not refue me the Honour of waiting on you to a Place where you will meet with better Entertainment than your Majety can expect from the bet Comedy in Chritendom. Val. (continu'd he,) you mut go with us, to ecure me againt the Jealouie of my Wife. That, indeed, (return'd his Lady) is very material; and you are mightily concern'd not to give me occaion, I mut own. You ee I am now, (reply'd he:) But—Come! on with Hoods and Scarf! (puru'd he, to Lucy.) Then addreing himelf again to his Lady; Madam, (aid he,) we'll wait on you in les time than I cou'd have drank a Bottle to my hare. (The Coach was got ready, and on they drove to the Play-houe.) By the way, aid Friendly to Val.—Your Honour, Noble Peer, mut be et down at Long's; for only Lucy and I mut be een to his Majety of Bantam: And now, I doubt not, you undertand what you mut trut to.—To be robb'd of her Majety's Company, I warrant, (return'd t'other) for thee long three Hours. Why, (cry'd Lucy,) you don't mean, I hope, to leave me with his Majety of Bantam? 'Tis for thy Good, Child! 'Tis for thy Good! (return'd Friendly.) To the Roe they got then; where Goodland lighted, and expected Sir Philip; who led Lucy into the King's Box, to his New Majety; where, after the firt Scene, he left 'em together. The over-joy'd Fantatick Monarch wou'd fain have aid ome fine obliging things to the Knight, as he was going out; but Friendly's
hate prevented 'em, who went directly to Valentine, took one Glas, call'd a Reck'ning, mounted Chariot, and away home they came: where, I believe, he was welcome to his Lady; for I never heard any thing to the contrary.

In the mean time, his Majety had not the patience to tay out half the Play, at which he was aluted by above twenty Gentlemen and Ladies by his New and Mighty Title: but out he led Mis Majety, e're the Third Act was half done; pretetending, that it was o Damn'd Bawdy a Play, that he knew her Modety had been already but too much offended at it; o into his Coach he got her. When they were eated, he told him he wou'd go to no place with him, but to the Lodgings her Mother had taken for her, when he firt came to Town, and which till he kept. Your Mother! Madam, (cry'd he;) Why, is Sir Philip's Siter living then? His Brother's Widow is, Sir, (he reply'd.) Is he there? (he ask'd.) No, Sir, (he return'd;) he's in the Countrey. Oh, then we'll go thither to chue. The Coach-man was then order'd to drive to Germin's-treet; where, when he came into the Lodgings, he found 'em very rich and modihly furnih'd. He preently call'd one of his Slaves, and whiper'd him to get three or four pretty Dihes for Supper; and then getting a Pen, Ink and Paper, writ a Note to C—d the Goldmith, within Temple-Barr, for Five hundred Guinea's; which Watchwell brought him in little more than an Hour's time, when they were jut in the height of Supper; Lucy having invited her Landlady, for the better colour of the matter.
His Bantamite Majety took the Gold from his Slave, and threw it by him in the Window, that Lucy might take notice of it; (which, you may aure your elf he did, and after Supper, wink'd on the goodly Matron of the Houe to retire; which he immediately obey'd.) Then his Majety began his Court very earnetly and hotly, throwing the naked Guinea's into her Lap: which he eem'd to refue, with much Didain; but, upon his repeated Promies, confirm'd by unheard of Oaths and Imprecations, that he wou'd give her Siter Three thouand Guinea's to her Portion, he began by degrees to mollifie, and let the Gold lie quietly in her Lap: And the next night, after he had drawn Notes on two or three of his Bankers, for the Payment of Three thouand Guinea's to Sir Philip, or Order, and receiv'd his own Bond, made for what he had lot at Play, from Friendly, he made no great difficulty to admit his Majety to her Bed. Where I think fit to leave 'em for the preent; for (perhaps) they had ome private Bus'nes.

The next Morning, before the Titular King was (I won't ay, up, or tirring, but) our o' bed, young Goodland and Philibella were privately marry'd; the Bills being all Accepted and Paid in Two Days time. As oon as ever the Phantatick Monarch cou'd find in his heart to divorce himelf from the dear and charming Embraces of his Beautiful Bedfellow, he came flying to Sir Philip, with all the hate that Imagination Big with Pleaure cou'd inpire him with, to dicharge it elf to a uppos'd Friend. The Knight told him, that he was really much
troubl'd, to find that his Niece had yielded o oon and eaily to him; however, he wih'd him Joy. To which t'other return'd, That he cou'd never want it, whilt he had the Command of o much Beauty, and that without the ungrateful Obligations of Matrimony, which certainly are the mot Naueous, Hateful, Pernicious and Detructive of Love imaginable. Think you o, Sir? (ask'd the Knight;) We hall hear what a Friend of mine will ay on uch an occaion, to morrow about this time: but I beeech your Majety to conceal your Sentiments of it to him, let you make him as uneaie as you eem to be in that circumtance. Be aur'd I will, (return'd t'other;) But when hall I ee the Sweet, the Dear, the Blooming, the Charming Philibella? She will be with us at Dinner. Where's her Majety? (ask'd Sir Philip.) Had you enquir'd before, he had been here; for, Look, he comes. Friendly eem'd to regard her with a kind of Dipleaure, and whiper'd Majety, that he hou'd expres no particular Symptoms of Familiarity with Lucy in his Houe, at any time, epecially when Goodland was there, as then he was above with his Lady and Philibella, who came down preently after to Dinner.

About Four a clock, as his Majety had intrigu'd with her, Lucy took a Hackney-Coach and went to her Lodgings; whither, about an hour after, he follow'd her. Next Morning, at Nine, he came to Friendly's, who carry'd him up to ee his new marry'd Friends—But (O Damnation to Thought!) what Torments did he feel, when he aw young Goodland and
Philibella in bed together; the lat of which return'd him humble and hearty Thanks for her Portion and Husband, as the firt did for his Wife. He hook his Head at Sir Philip, and without peaking one word, left 'em and hurry'd to Lucy, to lament the ill treatment he had met with from Friendly. They Coo'd and Bill'd as long as He was able; he (Sweet Hypocrite) eeming to 'moan his Misfortunes: which he took o kindly, that when he left her, which was about Three in the Afternoon, he caus'd a Scrivener to draw up an Intrument, wherein he ettl'd a Hundred Pounds a Year on Lucy, for her Life, and gave her an Hundred Guinea's more againt her Lying-in: (For he told him (and indeed 'twas true) that he was with Child, and knew her elf to be o, from a very good Reaon—) And indeed he was o—by the Friendly Knight. When he return'd to her, he threw the Obliging Intrument into her Lap; (it eems, he had a particular Kindnes for that Place—) then call'd for Wine, and omething to eat; for he had not drank a Pint to his hare all the day, (tho' he had ply'd it at the Chocolate-houe—) The Landlady, who was invited to Sup with 'em, bid 'em Good-night, about Eleven; when they went to bed, and, partly, lept till about Six; when they were entertain'd by ome Gentlemen of their Acquaintance, who Play'd and Sung very finely, by way of Epithalamium, thee words and more:
Joy to Great Bantam!
Live long Love and Wanton!
And thy Royal Conort!
For, Both are of one ort, &c.
The ret I have forgot. He took ome offence at the Words; but more at the Viit that Sir Philip and Goodland made him, about an hour after, who found him in Bed with his Royal Conort, and after having wih'd 'em Joy, and thrown their Majeties own Shooes and Stockings at their Heads, retreated. This gave Monarch in Fanie o great a Caution, that he took his Royal Conort into the Countrey, (but above Forty Miles off the Place where his own Lady was,) where, in les than Eight Months, he was Deliver'd of a Princely Babe, who was Chriten'd by the Heathenih Name of Hayoumorecake Bantam; while her Majety Lay-in like a petty Queen.
THE NUN: OR, THE Perjur'd Beauty.
A True HISTORY.
BY Mrs. A. BEHN.
LONDON, Printed for Samuel Bricoe, near Covent-Garden, 1697.

div.head: THE NUN: OR, THE Perjur'd Beauty.
div.p: DOn Henrique was a Peron of Great Birth, of a Great Etate, of Bravery equal to either, of a mot Generous Education; but of more Paion than Reaon: He was beides of an Opener and Freer Temper than generally his Countrey-men are; I mean, the Spaniards; always engag'd in ome Love-Intrigue or other.

One Night, as he was retreating from one of thoe Engagements, Don Sebatian, whoe Siter he had abus'd with a Promie of Marriage, et upon him at the Corner of a Street, in Madrid, and by the help of three of his Friends, deign'd to have dipatcht him on a doubtful Embay to the Almighty Monarch: But he receiv'd their firt Intructions with better Addres than they expected, and dimis'd his Envoy firt, killing one of Don Sebatian's Friends.
Which o enrag'd the Injur'd Brother, that his Strength and Reolution eem'd to be redoubl'd, and o animated his two urviving Companions, that (doubtles) they had gain'd a dihonourable Victory, had not Don Antonio accidentally come in to his Recue; who, after a very hort Dipute, kill'd one of the two who attack'd him only; whilt Don Henrique with the greatet difficulty defended his Life, for ome moments, againt Sebatian, whoe Rage depriv'd him of Strength, and gave his Adverary the unwih'd Advantage of his eeming Death, though not without bequeathing ome Bloody Legacies to Don Henrique. Antonio had receiv'd but one light Wound in the Left Arm, and his urviving Antagonit none; who, however thought it not advieable to begin a fre •• h Dipute againt two, of whoe Courage he •• d but too fatal a Proof, though one of 'em <>
ufficiently diabl'd. The Conquerors, on •• e other ide, politickly Retreated, and quitting the Field to the Conquer'd, left the Living to bury the Dead, if he cou'd, or thought convenient.

As they were marching off, Don Antonio, who all this while knew not whoe Life he had o happily preerv'd, told his Companion in Arms, that he thought it indipenably neceary that he hould quarter with him that Night, for his further Preervation. To which he prudently conented, and went, with no little uneaines, to his Lodgings; where he urpriz'd Antonio with the ight of his Dearet Friend. For they had certainly the nearet Sympathy in all their Thoughts, that ever made two
Brave Men unhappy! And, undoubtedly, nothing but Death, or more Fatal Love, cou'd have divided 'em. However, at preent, they were united and ecure:

In the mean time, Don Sebatian's Friend was jut going to call help to carry off the Bodies, as the—came by; who eeing three Men lie dead, eiz'd the fourth; who, as he was about to jutifie himelf, by dicovering one of the Authors of o much Bloodhed, was interrupted by a Groan from his uppos'd dead Friend Don Sebatian; whom, after a brief account of ome part of the matter, and the knowledge of his Quality, they took up, and carry'd to his Houe; where, within a few days, he was recover'd pat the fear of Death. All this while, Henrique and Antonio durt not appear, o much as by Night; nor cou'd be found, though diligent and daily earch was made after the firt: but upon Don Sebatian's Recovery, the Search ceaing, they took the advantage of the Night, and, in Diguize, retreated to Sevil. 'Twas there they thought themelves mot ecure, where indeed they were in the greatet danger; for tho' (hap'ly) they might there have ecap'd the murtherous Attempt of Don Sebatian and his Friends, yet they cou'd not there avoid the malicious Influence of their Stars.

This City gave Birth to Antonio, and to the caue of his greatet Misfortunes, as well as of his Death. Donna Ardelia was born there, a Miracle of Beauty and Falhood. 'Twas more than a Year ince Don Antonio had firt een and lov'd her. (For 'twas impoible any Man
hou'd do one without t'other.) He had had the unkind opportunity of peaking and conveying a Billette to her at Church; and to his greater misfortune, the next time he found her there, he met with too kind a return both from her Eyes, and from her Hand, which privately lipt a Paper into his; in which he found abundantly more than he expected, directing him in that, how he hou'd proceed, in order to carry her off from her Father with the leat danger he cou'd look for in uch an Attempt; ince it wou'd have been vain and fruitles to have ask'd her of her Father, becaue their Families had been at enmity for everal Years; though Antonio was as well decended as he, and had as ample a Fortune; nor was his Peron, according to his Sex, any way inferior to her's; and certainly, the Beauties of his Mind were more excellent, epecially if it be an Excellence to be Contant.

He had made everal Attempts to take poeion of her, but all prov'd ineffectual; however, he had the good fortune not to be known, tho' once or twice he narrowly 'cap'd with Life, bearing off his Wounds with difficulty.—(Alas, that the Wounds of Love hou'd caue thoe of Hate!) Upon which he was trictly confin'd to one Room, whoe only Window was towards the Garden, and that too was Grated with Iron; and, once a Month, when he went to Church, he was contantly and carefully attended by her Father, and a Mother-in-Law, wore than a Duegna. Under this mierable Confinement Antonio undertood he till continu'd, at his return to Sevil with Don
Henrique, whom he acquainted with his invincible Paion for her; lamenting the everity of her preent circumtances, that admitted of no propect of relief: which caus'd a generous Concern in Don Henrique, both for the Sufferings of his Friend, and of the Lady: He propos'd everal ways to Don Antonio, for the Releae of the Fair Prioner; but none of 'em was thought practicable, or, at leat, likely to ucceed. But Antonio, who (you may believe) was then more nearly engag'd, bethought himelf of an Expedient that wou'd undoubtedly reward their Endeavours. 'Twas, That Don Henrique, who was very well acquainted with Ardelia's Father, hou'd make him a Viit, with pretence of begging his Conent and Admiion to make his Addrees to his Daughter; which, in all probability, he cou'd not refue to Don Henrique's Quality and Etate: And then this freedom of acces to her wou'd give him the opportunity of delivering the Lady to his Friend. This was thought o reaonable, that the very next day it was put in practice; and with o good ucces, that Don Henrique was receiv'd by the Father of Ardelia with the greatet and mot repectful Ceremony imaginable: And when he made the Propoal to him of Marrying his Daughter, it was embrac'd with a viible Satisfaction and Joy in the Air of his Face. This their firt Converation ended with all imaginable Content on both Sides; Don Henrique being invited by the Father to Dinner, the next day, when Donna Ardelia was to be preent; who, at that time, was aid to be indipos'd, (as 'tis very probable he
was, with o cloe an Imprionment.) Henrique return'd to Antonio, and made him happy with the Account of his Reception; which cou'd not but have terminated in the perfect Felicity of Antonio, had his Fate been jut to the Merits of his Love. The Day and Hour came which brought Henrique with a private Commiion from his Friend to Ardelia. He aw her;—(Ah! wou'd he had only een her Veil'd!) and, with the firt opportunity, gave her the Letter, which held o much Love and o much Truth, as ought to have preerv'd him in the Empire of her Heart. It contain'd, beides, a Dicovery of his whole Deign upon her Father, for the compleating of their Happines; which nothing then cou'd obtruct but her elf. But Henrique had een her; he had gaz'd and wallow'd all her Beauties at his Eyes. How greedily his Soul drank the trong Poyon in! But yet his Honour and his Friendhip were trong as ever, and bravely fought againt the Uurper Love, and got a noble Victory, at leat he thought and wih'd o. With this, and a hort Anwer to his Letter, Henrique return'd to the Longing Antonio; who receiving the Paper with the greatet Devotion, and kiing it with the greatet Zeal, open'd and read thee words to himelf:

body.p:
YOu have, at lat made ue of the bet and only Expedient for my Enlargement; for which I thank you, ince I know it is purely the Effect of your Love. Your
Agent has a mighty Influence on my Father: And you may aure your elf, that as you have Advis'd and Deir'd me, he hall have no les on me, till I am

closer.signed: Your's entirely, And only Your's, ARDELIA.

div.p:
Having repectfully and tenderly kis'd the Name, he cou'd not chue but hew the Billette to his Friend; who reading that part of it which concern'd himelf, tarted and bluh'd: Which Antonio oberving, was curious to know the caue of it. Henrique told him, That he was urpriz'd to find her expres o little Love, after o long an Abence. To which his Friend reply'd, for her, That, doubtles, he had not Time enough to attempt o great a Matter as a perfect Account of her Love; and added, That it was Confirmation enough to him of its continuance, ince he Subcrib'd her elf His entirely, and only His.—How Blind is Love! Don Henrique knew how to make it bear another meaning; which, however, he had the Dicretion to conceal. Antonio, who was as Real in his Friendhip, as Contant in his Love, ask'd him what he thought of her Beauty? To which t'other anwer'd, That he thought it irreitible to any, but to a Soul prepoes'd and nobly fortify'd with a perfect Friendhip:—Such as is Thine, my
Henrique, (added Antonio;) yet as incere and perfect as that is, I know you must, nay, I know you do Love her. As I ought, I do, (reply'd Henrique.)
