Yes, Yes, (return'd his Friend,) it mut be o; otherwie the Sympathy which unites our Souls wou'd be wanting, and conequently our Friendhip were not in a tate of Perfection. How indutriouly you wou'd argue me into a Crime that wou'd tear and detroy the very Foundation of the tronget Ties of Truth and Honour! (aid Henrique.) But (he continu'd) I hope, within a few Days, to put it out of my power to be guilty of o great a Sacrilege. I can't determine, (aid Antonio,) if I knew that you Lov'd one another, whether I cou'd eaier part with my Friend, or my Mitres. Tho' what you ay, is highly Generous, (reply'd Henrique,) yet give me leave to urge, that it looks like a Trial of your Friend, and argues you inclinable to Jealouie: But, Pardon me, I know it to be incerely meant by you; and mut therefore own, that 'tis the Bet, becaue 'tis the Noblet way of ecuring both your Friend and Mitres. I need make ue of no Arts to ecure me of either, (reply'd Antonio;) but expect to enjoy 'em both in a little time.

Henrique, who was a little uneaie with a Dicoure of this nature, diverted it, by reflecting on what had pas'd at Madrid, between them two and Don Sebatian and his Friends; which caus'd Antonio to bethink himelf of the Danger to which he expos'd his Friend, by appearing daily, tho' in Diguie: For, doubtles,
Don Sebatian wou'd purue his Revenge to the utmot Extremity. Thee Thoughts put him upon deiring his Friend, for his own ake, to haten the performance of his Attempt; and accordingly, each day Don Henrique brought Antonio the nearer hopes of Happines, while he himelf was hourly inking into the lowet tate of Miery. The lat Night before the Day in which Antonio expected to be bles'd in her Love, Don Henrique had a long and fatal Conference with her, about his Liberty. Being then with her alone in an Arbour of the Garden, which Privilege he had had for ome days: After a long ilence, and oberving Don Henrique in much diorder, by the Motion of his Eyes, which were ometimes tedfatly fix'd on the Ground, then lifted up to her or Heaven, (for he cou'd ee nothing more Beautiful on Earth,) he made ue of the Privilege of her Sex, and began the Dicoure firt, to this effect;—Has any thing happen'd, Sir, ince our retreat hither, to occaion that Diorder which is but too viible in your Face, and too dreadful in your hitherto continu'd ilence? Speak, I beeech you, Sir, and let me know if I have any way unhappily contributed to it! No, Madam, (reply'd he;) my Friendhip is now likely to be the only caue of my greatet Miery; for to morrow I mut be guilty of an unpardonable Crime, in betraying the generous Confidence which your noble Father has plac'd in me: To morrow (added he, with a pitious Sigh) I mut deliver you into the Hands of one whom your Father hates even to death, intead of doing my elf the Honour of becoming
his Son-in-Law within a few Days more:—But—I will conider and remind my elf, that I give you into the hands of my Friend; of my Friend, that Loves you better than his Life which he has often expos'd for your ake; and what is more than All, to my Friend, whom you Love more than any Conideration on Earth.—And must this be done? (he ask'd.) Is it inevitable as Fate?—Fix'd as the Laws of Nature, Madam, (reply'd he;) Don't you find the Neceity of it, Ardelia? (continu'd he, by way of Quetion:) Does not your Love require it? Think! you are going to your Dear Antonio, who alone can merit you, and whom only you can love. Were your lat words true, (return'd he,) I hou'd yet be unhappy in the Dipleaure of a Dear and Tender Father, and infinitely more, in being the caue of your Infidelity to him: No, Don Henrique, (continu'd he;) I cou'd with greater Satisfaction return to my mierable Confinement, than by any means diturb the Peace of your Mind, or occaion one moment's interruption of your Quiet.—Wou'd to Heaven you did not, (igh'd he to himelf.) Then addreing his words more ditinctly to her, cry'd he, Ah, Cruel! Ah, Unjut Ardelia! Thee Words belong to none but Antonio; why then wou'd you endeavour to peruade me, that I do, or ever can merit the Tendernes of uch an Expreion:—Have a care! (puru'd he,) Have a care, Ardelia! your outward Beauties are too powerful to be reited; even your Frowns have uch a weetnes, that it attracts the very Soul that is not
trongly prepoes'd with the noblet Friendhip, and the highet Principles of Honour: Why then, alas! did you add uch Sweet and Charming Accents? Why—Ah, Don Henrique! (he interrupted,) why did you appear to me o Charming in your Peron, o great in your Friendhip, and o Illutrious in your Reputation? Why did my Father, e'er ince your firt Viit, continually fill my Ears and Thoughts with Noble Characters and Glorious Idea's, which yet but imperfectly and faintly repreent the Inimitable Original!—But—(what is mot evere and cruel) why, Don Henrique, why will you defeat my Father in his Ambition of your Alliance! and me of thoe glorious Hopes with which you had bles'd my Soul, by cating me away from you to Antonio!—Ha! (cry'd he, tarting,) What aid you, Madam! What did Ardelia ay! That I had bles'd your Soul with Hopes! That I wou'd cast you away to Antonio!—Can they who afely arrive in their wih'd for Port, be aid to be Shipwrack'd! Or, Can an Abject, Indigent Wretch make a King?—Thee are more than Riddles, Madam; and I mut not think to Expound 'em. No, (aid he;) Let it alone, Don Henrique; I'll eae you of that trouble, and tell you plainly that I Love you. Ah! (cry'd he,) now all my Fears are come upon me!—How! (ask'd he,) Were you afraid I hou'd Love you? Is my Love o dreadful then? Yes, when miplac'd, (reply'd he;) but 'twas your Falhood that I fear'd: Your Love were what I wou'd have ought, with utmot hazard of my Life;
nay, even of my Future Happines, I fear, had you not been Engag'd; trongly oblig'd to Love ele where, both by your own Choice and Vows, as well as by his dangerous Services, and matchles Contancy. For which (aid he) I do not Hate him; though his Father kill'd my Uncle: Nay, perhaps (continu'd he) I have a Friendhip for him, but no more. No more! aid you, Madam? (cry'd he;)—But tell me, Did you never Love him? Indeed, I did, (reply'd he;) but the Sight of You, has better intructed me, both in my Duty to my Father, and in cauing my Paion for you, without whom I hall be eternally mierable: Ah, then! purue your honourable Propoal, and make my Father happy in my Marriage! It mut not be, (return'd Don Henrique;) my Honour, my Friendhip forbids it. No, (he return'd,) your Honour requires it; and if your Friendhip oppoes your Honour, it can have no ure nor olid Foundation. Female Sophitry! (cry'd Henrique;) But you need no Art nor Artifice, Ardelia, to make me Love you: Love you! (puru'd he;) By that bright Sun, the Light and Heat of all the World, You are my only Light and Heat.—Oh, Friendhip! Sacred Friendhip, now ait me!—[Here for a time he paus'd, and then afreh proceeded,] thus,—You told me, or my Ears deceiv'd me, that you Lov'd me, Ardelia. I did, (he reply'd;) and that I do Love you, is as true as that I told you o. 'Tis well;—But wou'd it were not o! Did ever Man receive a Bleing thus!—Why, I cou'd wih I did not Love you, Ardelia! But that were impoible—
At leat, unjut, (interrupted he.) Well then, (he went on) to hew you that I do incerely conult your particular Happines, without any regard to my own, to morrow I will give you to Don Antonio; and as a Proof of your Love to me, I expect your ready Conent to it. To let you ee, Don Henrique, how perfectly and tenderly I Love you, I will be acrific'd to morrow to Don Antonio, and to your Quiet. Oh, Stranget, Dearet Obligation! (cry'd Henrique;) To morrow then, as I have told your Father, I am to bring you to ee the Dearet Friend I have on Earth, who dare not appear within this City for ome unhappy Reaons, and therefore cannot be preent at our Nuptials; for which caue, I cou'd not but think it my Duty to one o nearly related to my Soul, to make him happy in the Sight of my Beautiful Choice, e're yet he be my Bride. I hope (aid he) my Loving Obedience may merit your Compaion; and that at lat, e're the Fire is lighted that mut conume the Offering, I mean, the Marriage-Tapers, (alluding to the old Roman Ceremony) that you, or ome other pitying Angel, will natch me from the Altar. Ah, No more, Ardelia! Say no more! (cry'd he;) we mut be Cruel, to be Jut to our elves. [Here their Dicoure ended, and they walk'd into the Houe, where they ound the Good Old Gentleman and his Lady, with whom he tay'd till about an Hour after Supper, when he return'd to his Friend with joyful News, but a orrowful Heart.]

Antonio was all Rapture with the Thoughts of the approaching Day; which though it
brought Don Henrique and his Dear Ardelia to him, about Five a clock in the Evening, yet at the ame time brought his lat and greatet Misfortune. He aw her then at a She-Relations of his, about three Miles from Sevil, which was the Place aign'd for their fatal Interview. He aw her, I ay; but, Ah! how trange, how alter'd from the Dear, Kind Ardelia he was when lat he left her! 'Tis true, he flew to her with Arms expanded, and with o wift and eager a motion, that he cou'd not avoid nor get looe from his Embrace, till he had kis'd, and igh'd, and dropt ome Tears, which all the trength of his Mind cou'd not retrain; whether they were the effects of Joy, or whether (which rather may be fear'd) they were the Heat-drops which preceded and threaten'd the Thunder and Tempet that hou'd fall on his Head, I cannot poitively ay; yet all this he was then forc'd to endure, e're he had liberty to peak, or, indeed, to breathe. But as oon as he had freed her elf from the Loving Circle that hou'd have been the dear and lov'd Confinement or Centre of a Faithful Heart, he began to dart whole howers of Tortures on him from her Eyes; which that Mouth that he had but jut before o tenderly and acredly kis'd, econded with whole volleys of Deaths cramm'd in every Sentence, pointed with the keenet Affliction that ever pierc'd a Soul! Antonio, (he began) you have treated me now, as if you were never like to ee me more; and wou'd to Heav'n you were not!—Ha! (cry'd he, tarting, and taring wildly on her;) What aid you, Madam? What aid you, my
Ardelia? If you like the Repetition, Take it! (reply'd he, unmov'd,) Wou'd to Heav'n you were ne'er like to ee me more! Good! Very Good! (cry'd he, with a Sigh that threw him trembling into a Chair behind him, and gave her the opportunity of proceeding thus,)—Yet, Antonio, I mut not have my Wih; I mut continue with you, not out of Choice, but by Command, by the trictet and everet Obligation that ever bound Humanity; Don Henrique, your Friend, Commands it; Don Henrique, the Dearet Object of my Soul, Enjoins it; Don Henrique, whoe only Averion I am, will have it o. Oh, Do not wrong me, Madam! (cry'd Don Henrique.) Lead me, Lead me a little more by the Light of your Dicoure, I beeech you, (aid Don Antonio,) that I may ee your Meaning! for hitherto 'tis Darknes all to me. Attend therefore with your bet Faculties, (puru'd Ardelia) and know, That I do mot incerely and mot paionately Love Don Henrique; and as a Proof of my Love to him, I have this Day conented to be deliver'd up to you by Him; not for your ake in the leat, Antonio, but purely to acrifice all the Quiet of my Life to his Satisfaction. And now, Sir, (continu'd he, addreing her elf to Don Henrique,) Now, Sir, if you can be o cruel; execute your own mot dreaded Decree, and join our Hands, though our Hearts ne'er can meet. All this to Try me! It's too much, Ardelia,—(aid Antonio:) And then turning to Don Henrique, he went on, Speak Thou! if yet thou'rt not Apotate to our Friendhip! Yet Speak, however! Speak, though the Devil
has been Tampering with Thee too! Thou art a Man, a Man of Honour once. And when I forfeit my jut Title to that, (interrupted Don Henrique, may I be made mot mierable! —May I loe the Bleings of thy Friendhip!—May I loe Thee!—Say on then, Henrique! (cry'd Antonio;) And I charge thee, by all the Sacred Tyes of Friendhip, ay, Is this a Trial of me? Is't Eluion, Sport? or hameful, murtherous Truth?—O! my Soul burns within me, and I can bear no longer!—Tell! Speak! Say on!—[Here, with folded Arms, and Eyes fix'd tedfatly on Henrique, he tood like a Statue, without motion; unles ometimes, when his welling Heart rais'd his o'er-charg'd Breat.] After a little Paue, and a hearty Sigh or two, Henrique began;—Oh, Antonio! O my Friend! prepare thy elf to hear yet more dreadful Accents!—I am (puru'd he) unhappily the Greatet and mot Innocent Criminal that e'er, till now, offended:—I Love her, Antonio,—I Love Ardelia, with a Paion trong and violent as Thine!—Oh, ummon all that us'd to be more than Man about thee, to uffer to the end of my Dicoure, which nothing but a Reolution like Thine can bear! I know it by my elf.—Though there be Wounds, Horror and Death in each Syllable, (interrupted Antonio,) yet prithee, now, go on, but with all hate. I will, (return'd Don Henrique,) though I feel, my own Words have the ame cruel effects on me. I ay again, my Soul Loves Ardelia. And how can it be otherwie? Have we not Both the elf-ame
Appetites? the ame Diguts? How then cou'd I avoid my Detiny, that has decreed that I hou'd Love and Hate jut as you do? Oh, hard Neceity! that oblig'd you to ue Me, in the Recovery of this Lady! Alas, Can you think that any Man of Sene or Paion cou'd have een, and not have Lov'd her! Then how hou'd I, whoe Thoughts are Unions to Yours, evade thoe Charms that had prevail'd on you?—And now, to let you know 'tis no Eluion, no Sport, but erious and amazing woful Truth, Ardelia bet can tell you whom he Loves. What I've already aid, is true, by Heav'n, (cry'd he;) 'Tis you, Don Henrique, whom I only Love, and who alone can give me Happines: Ah, wou'd you wou'd! —With you, Antonio, I mut remain Unhappy, Wretched, Curs'd: Thou art my Hell; Don Henrique is my Heaven. And Thou art mine, (return'd he,) which here I part with to my Dearet Friend. Then taking her Hand; Pardon me, Antonio, (puru'd he) that I thus take my lat Farewell of all the Tats of Blis from your Ardelia, at this moment. [At which words he kis'd her Hand, and gave it to Don Antonio; who receiv'd it, and gently pres'd it cloe to his Heart, as if he wou'd have her feel the Diorders he had caus'd there.] Be Happy, Antonio, (cry'd Henrique;) Be very Tender of her; To morrow early I hall hope to ee thee.—Ardelia, (puru'd he,) all Happines and Joy urround Thee! May't thou ne'er want thoe Bleings thou cant give Antonio! —Farewell to Both! (added he, going out.) Ay, (cry'd he,) Farewell to all
Joys, Bleings, Happines, if you forake me —Yet do not go!—Ah, Cruel! (continu'd he, eeing him quit the Room;) But you hall take my Soul with you. Here he wooned away in Don Antonio's Arms; who, though he was happy that he had her fat there, yet was oblig'd to call in his Couin, and Ardelia's Attendants, e're he cou'd be perfectly recover'd. In the mean while, Don Henrique had not the power to go out of ight of the Houe, but wander'd to and fro about it, ditracted in his Soul, and not being able longer to refrain her ight, her lat Words till reounding in her Ears, he came again into the Room where he left her with Don Antonio, jut as he reviv'd and call'd upon him, exclaiming on his Cruelty, in leaving her o oon. But when, turning her Eyes towards the Door, he aw him; Oh! with what eager hate he flew to him! then clap'd him round the Wat, obliging him, with all the tender Expreions that the Soul of a Lover, and a Woman's too, is capable of uttering, not to leave her in the poeion of Don Antonio. This o amaz'd her lighted Lover, that he knew not, at firt, how to proceed in this Tormenting Scene; but at lat, ummoning all his wonted Reolution, and Strength of Mind, he told her, He wou'd put her out of his power, if he wou'd conent to retreat for ome few hours to a Nunnery that was not above half a Mile ditant thence, till he had dicours'd his Friend, Don Henrique, omething more particularly than hitherto, about this Matter. To which he readily agreed, upon the Promie that Don Henrique
made her, of eeing her with the firt opportunity. They waited on her then to the Convent, where he was kindly and repectfully receiv'd by the Lady Abbes; but it was not long before that her Grief renewing with greater violence, and more afflicting circumtances, had oblig'd 'em to tay with her till it was almot dark, when they once more begg'd the liberty of an hour's abence; and the better to palliate their Deign, Henrique told her, that he wou'd make ue of her Father Don Richardo's Coach, in which they came to Don Antonio's, for o mall a time: Which they did, leaving only Eleanora her Attendant with her, without whom he had been at a los, among o many Fair Strangers; Strangers, I mean, to her unhappy Circumtances: whilt they were carry'd near a Mile farther, where, jut as 'twas dark, they 'lighted from the Coach, Don Henrique ordering the Servants not to tir thence till their return from their private Walk, which was about a Furlong, in a Field that belong'd to the Convent. Here Don Antonio told Don Henrique, That he had not acted Honourably; That he had Betray'd him and Robb'd him at once both of a Friend and Mitres. To which t'other return'd, That he undertood his meaning, when he propos'd a particular Dicoure about this Affair, which he now perceiv'd mut end in Blood: But you may remind your elf (continu'd he) that I have kept my Promie, in delivering her to you. Yes, (cry'd Antonio) after you had practis'd foully and baely with her. By Heavens! not at all, (return'd Henrique;) It was her Choice, or Fate, that
brought this michief on her; for I urg'd the Shame and Scandal of Incontancy, but all in vain, to her. But don't you Love her, Henrique? (t'other ask'd.) Too well; and cannot live without her, though I fear I may feel the cured Effects of the ame Incontancy: However, I had quitted her All to you, but you ee how he reents it. And you hall ee, Sir, (cry'd Antonio, drawing his Sword in a Rage) how I reent it. Here, without more Words, they fell to Action, to Bloody Action. (Ah! how wretched is our Sex, in being the unhappy Occaion of o many fatal Michiefs ev'n between the Dearet Friends!) They fought on each ide with the greatet Animoity of Rivals, forgetting all the Sacred Bonds of their former Friendhip; till Don Antonio fell, and aid, dying, Forgive me, Henrique! I was to blame; I cou'd not live without her:—I fear he will betray thy Life, which hate and preerve, for my ake!—Let me not die all at once!—Heav'n pardon both of us!—Farewell! Oh, Hate! Farewell! (return'd Don Henrique,) Farewell, thou Bravest, Truest Friend! Farewell, thou Noblet Part of me!—And, Farewell all the Quiet of my Soul. Then tooping, he kis'd his Cheek; but, riing, found he mut retire in time, or ele mut perih through los of Blood, for he had receiv'd two or three dangerous Wounds, beides others of les conequence: wherefore he made all the convenient hate he cou'd to the Coach, into which, by the help of the Foot-men, he got, and order'd 'em to drive directly to Don Richardo's with all imaginable peed; where he arriv'd in little more than
half an hour's time, and was receiv'd by Ardelia's Father with the greatet Confuion and Amazement that is expreible, eeing him return'd without his Daughter, and o deperately wounded. Before he thought it convenient to ask him any Quetions more than to enquire of his Daughter's afety, to which he receiv'd a hort but atisfactory Anwer, Don Richardo ent for an Eminent and Able Surgeon, who prob'd and dres'd Don Henrique's Wounds, who was immediately put to Bed, not without ome depondency of his Recovery; but (Thanks to his kind Stars, and kinder Contitution!) he reted pretty well for ome hours that Night; and early in the Morning, Ardelia's Father, who had carce taken any Ret all that Night, came to viit him, as oon as he undertood from the Servants who watch'd with him that he was in a condition to uffer a hort Dicoure; which, you may be ure, was to learn the Circumtances of the pat Night's Adventure; of which Don Henrique gave him a perfect and pleaant Account, ince he heard that Don Antonio, his mortal Enemy, was kill'd; the aurance of whoe Death was the more delightful to him, ince, by this Relation, he found that Antonio was the Man whom his care of his Daughter had o often frutrated. Don Henrique had hardly made an end of his Narration, e're a Servant came hatily to give Richardo notice, that the Officers were come to earch for his Son-in-Law that hou'd have been; whom the Old Gentleman's wie Precaution had ecur'd in a Room o unupected, that they might as reaonably have imagin'd the entire Walls
of his Houe had a Door made of Stones, as that there hou'd have been one to that cloe Apartment: He went therefore boldly to the Officers, and gave 'em all the Keys of his Houe, with free liberty to examine every Room and Chamber: Which they did, but to no purpoe; and Don Henrique lay there undicover'd till his Cure was perfected.

Don Sebatian, who till puru'd him with a mot implacable Hatred, had trac'd him even to Italy, and there narrowly miing him, poted after him to Toledo; o ure and ecret was his Intelligence! As oon as he arriv'd, he went directly to the Convent where his Siter Elvira had been one of the Profes'd, ever ince Don Henrique had foraken her, and where Ardelia had taken her Repented Vow. Elvira had all along conceal'd the Occaion of her coming thither from Ardelia; and though he was her only Confident, and knew the whole Story of her Misfortunes, and heard the Name of Don Henrique repeated an hundred times a day, whom till he Lov'd mot perfectly, yet never gave her Beautiful Rival any caue of upicion that he Lov'd him, either by Words or Looks: nay, more, when he undertood that Don Henrique came to the Convent with Ardelia and Antonio, and at other times with her Father, yet he had o great a command of her elf, as to refrain eeing him, or to be een by him; nor ever intended to have poken or writ to him, had not her Brother, Don Sebatian, put her upon the cruel neceity of doing the lat; who coming to viit his Siter (as I have aid before) found her with Donna Ardelia, whom he never remembred to have een, nor who ever had een him but twice, and that was about Six Years before, when he was but Ten Years of Age, when he fell paionately in Love
with him, and continu'd her Paion till about the Fourteenth Year of her Empire, when the unhappy Antonio firt began his Court to her Don Sebatian was really a very deirable Peron, being at that time very Beautiful, his Age not exceeding Six and twenty, of a weet Converation, very Brave, but Revengeful and Irreconcileable (like mot of his Countrey-men,) and of an Honourable Family. At the ight of him, Ardelia felt her former Paion renew; which proceeded and continu'd with uch Violence, that it utterly defac'd the Idea's of Antonio and Henrique. (No wonder that he who cou'd reolve to forake her God for Man, hou'd quit one Lover for another.) In hort, he then only wih'd that he might Love her equally, and then he doubted not of contriving the means of their Happines betwixt 'em. She had her Wih, and more, if poible; for he Lov'd her beyond the thought of any other preent or future Bleing, and fail'd not to let her know it, at the econd Interview; when he receiv'd the greatet Pleaure he cou'd have wih'd, next to the Joys of a Bridal Bed: For he confes'd her Love to him, and preently put him upon thinking on the means of her Ecape; but not finding his Deigns o likely to ucceed, as thoe Meaures he had ent to Don Henrique, he communicates the very ame to Don Sebatian, and agreed with him to make ue of 'em on that very Night wherein he had oblig'd Don Henrique to attempt her Deliverance; the Hour indeed was different, being determin'd to be at Eleven. Elvira, who was preent at the Conference, took the Hint; and
not being willing to dioblige a Brother who had o hazarded his Life in Vindication of her, either durt not or wou'd not eem to oppoe his Inclinations, at that time: However, when he retir'd with her to talk more particularly of his intended Revenge on Don Henrique, who, he told her, he knew lay omewhere abconded in Toledo, and whom he had reolv'd, as he aur'd her, to acrifice to her injur'd Honour, and his Reentments; he oppos'd that his vindictive Reolution with all the forcible Arguments in a Virtuous and Pious Lady's Capacity, but in vain; o that immediately, upon his retreat from the Convent, he took the opportunity of writing to Don Henrique as follows, the fatal Hour not being then Seven Nights ditant.

body.p: MY Brother is now in Town, in puruit of your Life; nay, more, of your Mitres, who has conented to make her Ecape from the Convent, at the ame Place of it, and by the ame Means on which he had agreed to give her elf entirely to you, but the Hour is Eleven. I know, Henrique, your Ardelia is dearer to you than your Life; but your Life, your dear Life is more deir'd than any thing in this World, by

div.p: This he deliver'd to Richardo's Servant, whom Henrique had gain'd that Night, as oon as he came to viit Ardelia, at her uual Hour, jut as he went out of the Cloiter.

Don Henrique was not a little urpriz'd with this Billette; however, he cou'd hardly reolve to forbear his accutom'd Viits to Ardelia, at firt; but upon more mature Conideration, he only choe to convere with her by Letters, which till pres'd her to be mindful of her Promie, and of the Hour, not taking notice of any Caution that he had receiv'd of her Treachery. To which he till return'd, in Words that might aure him of her Contancy.

The Dreadful Hour wanted not a Quarter of being perfect when Don Henrique came; and having fix'd his Rope-Ladder to that part of the Garden-Wall where he was expected, Ardelia, who had not tir'd from that very Place for a quarter of an hour before, prepar'd to acend by it; which he did, as oon as his Servant had turn'd and fix'd it on the inner ide of the Wall; on the top of which, at a little ditance, he found another faten'd, for her to decend on the out-ide; whilt Don Henrique eagerly waited to receive her. She came at lat and flew into his Arms; which made Henrique cry out in a Rapture, Am I atlat once more happy, in having my Ardelia in my poeion! She, who knew his Voice, and now found he was betray'd, but knew not by whom, hriek'd out, I am Ruin'd! Help! Help!—Looe me, I charge you, Henrique!
Looe me! At that very moment, and at thoe very words came Sebatian, attended only by one Servant, and hearing Henrique reply, Not all the Powers of Hell hall natch you from me; drawing his Sword, without one word, made a furious Pas at him; but his Rage and Hate miguided his Arm, for his Sword went quite through Ardelia's Body, who only aid, Ah, wretched Maid! and dropt from Henrique's Arms, who then was oblig'd to quit her, to preerve his own Life, if poible; however, he had not had o much time as to Draw, had not Sebatian been amaz'd at this dreadful mitake of his Sword: but preently recollecting himelf, he flew with redoubl'd Rage to attack Henrique; and his Servant had econded him, had not Henrique's, who was now decended, otherwie diverted him. They fought with the greatet Animoity on both ides, and with equal Advantage; for they both fell together. Ah, my Ardelia, I come to thee now, (Sebatian groan'd out;) 'Twas this unlucky Arm, which now embraces thee, that kill'd thee. Just Heaven! (he igh'd out;)—Oh, yet have mercy! [Here they both dy'd.] Amen, (cry'd Henrique, dying, I want it most:—Oh, Antonio! Oh, Elvira! Elvira! Ay, there's the Weight that inks me down:—And yet I wih Forgivenes: —Once more, Sweet Heaven have-mercy! He cou'd not out-live that lat word; which was Echo'd by Elvira, who all this while tood weeping, and calling out for Help, as he tood cloe to the Wall in the Garden.

This alarm'd the ret of the Siters, who riing, caus'd the Bell to be Rung-out, as upon dangerous Occaions it us'd to be; which rais'd the Neighbourhood, who came time enough to remove the dead Bodies of the two Rivals, and of the late Fallen Angel, Ardelia. The Injur'd and Neglected Elvira, whoe Piety deign'd quite contrary Effects, was immediately eiz'd with a violent Fever; which, as it was violent, did not lat long; for he dy'd within Four and twenty Hours, with all the happy Symptoms of a Departing Saint.
THE ADVENTURE OF THE Black Lady.
A NOVEL.
BY Mrs. A. BEHN.
LONDON, Printed for Samuel Bricoe, near Covent-Garden, 1697.

div.head: THE ADVENTURE OF THE Black Lady.
div.p:
When they were alone, Bellamora deired he might be permitted the Freedom to end for a Pint of Sack; which, with ome little Difficulty, was at lat allow'd her. They began then to chat for a matter of half an hour of things indifferent: And, at length the ancient Gentlewoman ask'd the Fair Innocent (I mut not ay Foolih) one, of what Country, and what her Name was: To both which he anwer'd very directly and truly; tho' it might have prov'd, not dicreetly. She then inquir'd of Bellamora if her Parents were living, and the Occaion of her coming to Town. The Fair Unthinking Creature replied, That her Father and Mother were both dead: And that he had ecap'd from her Uncle, under pretence of making a Viit to a young Lady, her Couin who was lately married, and liv'd above Twenty Miles from her Uncle's in the Road to London; and, that the Caue of her quitting the Country, was to avoid the hated Importunities of a Gentleman, whoe pretended Love to her he fear'd had been her eternal Ruine. At which he wept and igh'd mot extravagantly. The dicreet Gentlewoman endeavour'd to comfort her by all the oftet and mot powerful Argument in her Capacity; promiing her all the friendly Aitance that he cou'd expect from her, during Bellamora's tay in Town; which he did with o much Earnetnes and viible Integrity, that the pretty innocent Creature was going to make her a full and real Dicovery
of her imaginary, inupportable Misfortunes; and (doubtles) had done it; had he not been prevented by the Return of the Lady, whom he hop'd to have found her Couin Brightly. The Gentleman her Husband jut aw her within Doors, and order'd the Coach to drive to ome of his Bottle-Companions; which gave the Women the better Opportunity of entertaining one another, which happen'd to be with ome Surprize on all ides. As the Lady was going up to her Apartment, the Gentlewoman of the Houe told her there was a young Lady in the Parlour, who came out o' the Country that very Day on purpoe to viit her: The Lady tept immediately to ee who it was, and Bellamora approaching to receive her hop'd for Couin, topp'd on the the uddain jut as he came to her; and igh'd out aloud, Ah, Madam I am lot.—It is not your Ladyhip I eek. No, Madam (return'd t'other) I am apt to think you did not intend me this Honour. But you are as welcome to me, as you could be to the dearet of your Acquaintance: Have you forgot me, Madam Bellamora? (continued he) that Name tartled both the other: However, It was with a kind of Joy. Alas! Madam, (replied the young one) I now remember that I have been o happy to have een you: But where, and when, my Memory can't hew me. 'Tis indeed ome Years ince: (return'd the Lady) But of that another time.—Mean while, if you are unprovided of a Lodging, I dare undertake, you hall be welcome to this Gentlewoman. The Fair Unfortunate return'd her
Thanks; and whilt a Chamber was preparing for her, the Lady entertain'd her in her own. About Ten a Clock they parted, Bellamora being conducted to her new Lodging by the Mitres of the Houe, who then left her to take what Ret he cou'd amidt her o many eeming Misfortunes; returning to the other Lady, who deir'd her to earch into the Caue of Bellamora's Retreat to Town.

The next Morning the good Gentlewoman of the Houe coming up to her, found Bellamora almot drown'd in Tears, which by many kind and weet Words he at lat topp'd; and asking whence o great Signs of Sorrow hou'd proceed, vow'd a mot profound Secrecy if he wou'd dicover to her their Occaion; which, after ome little Reluctancy, he did, in this manner:

I was courted (aid he) above three Years ago, when my Mother was yet living, by one Mr. Fondlove, a Gentleman of a good Etate, and true Worth; and one who, I dare believe, did then really love me: He continu'd his Paion for me, with all the earnet and honet Sollicitations imaginable, till ome Month's before my Mother's Death; who at that time, was mot deirous to ee me dipos'd of in Marriage to another Gentleman, of a much better Etate than Mr. Fond-love: But one, whoe Peron and Humour did by no means hit with my Inclinations: And this gave Fondlove the unhappy Advantage over me. For, finding me one Day all alone in my Chamber, and lying on my Bed, in as mournful and wretched a Condition, to my then foolih Apprehenion,
as now I am; He urg'd his Paion with uch Violence and accured Succes for me, with reiterated Promies of Marriage, whenever I pleas'd to challenge 'em, which he bound with the mot acred Oaths and mot dreadful Execrations; that partly with my Averion to the other, and partly with my Inclinations to pity him, I ruin'd my elf.—Here he relaps'd into a greater Extravagance of Grief than before; which was o extreme, that it did not continue long. When therefore, he was pretty well come to her elf, the ancient Gentlewoman ask'd her, why he imagin'd her elf ruin'd? To which he anwer'd, I am great with Child by him (Madam) and wonder you did not perceive it lat Night. Alas! I have not a Month to go: I am ham'd, ruin'd, and damn'd, I fear, for ever lot. O, fie, Madam, think not o: (aid t'other) For the Gentleman may yet prove true, and marry you. Ay, Madam, (replied Bellamora) I doubt not that he wou'd marry me; for, oon after my Mother's Death, when I came to be at my own Dipoal, which happen'd about two Months after, he offer'd, nay, mot earnetly ollicited me to it, which till he pererveres to do. This is trange! (return'd 'tother) And it appears to me to be your own Fault, that you are yet mierable. Why did you not, or why will you not conent to your own Happines? Alas! alas! (cry'd Bellamora) 'Tis the only thing I dread in this World: For, I am certain he can never love me after: Beides, ever ince, I have abhorr'd the Sight of him: And
this is the only Caue that obliges me to forake my Uncle, and all my Friends and Relations in the Country, hoping this populous and publick Place to be mot private, epecially, (Madam) in your Houe, and in your Fidelity and Dicretion. Of the lat you may aure your elf, Madam, (aid t'other:) But what Proviion have you made for the Reception of the young Stranger that you carry about you. Ah, Madam! (cry'd Bellamora) you have brought to mind another Misfortune: Then he acquainted her with the uppos'd Los of her Money and Jewels, telling her withal, that he had but three Guinea's and ome Silver left, and the Rings he wore, in her preent Poeion. The good Gentlewoman of the Houe told her, he wou'd end to inquire at the Inn where he lay the firt Night he came to Town; for, (happily) they might give ome account of the Porter to whom he had intruted her Trunk; and withal repeated her Promie of all the Help in her Power, and for that time left her much more compos'd than he found her. The good Gentlewoman went directly to the other Lady, her Lodger, to whom he recounted Bellamora's mournful Confeion: At which the Lady appear'd mightily concern'd: And at lat, he told her Land-lady, that he wou'd take Care that Bellamora hould lie in according to her Quality: For, (added he) the Child (it eems) is my own Brothers.

Aoon as he had din'd, he went to the Exchange and bought Child-bed Linen; but deir'd that Bellamora might not have the leat Notice
of it: And at her Return dipatch'd a Letter to her Brother Fondlove in Hanthire, with an Account of every particular; which oon brought him up to Town, without atisfying any of his or her Friends with the Reaon of his udden Departure; mean while, the good Gentlewoman of the Houe had ent to the Star-Inn on Fih-treet-hill, to demand the Trunk; which he rightly uppos'd to have been carried back thither: For, by good Luck, it was a Fellow that plyed thereabouts who brought it to Bellamora's Lodgings that very Night, but unknown to her. Fondlove no ooner got to London, but he pots to his Siter's Lodgings, where he was advis'd not to be een of Bellamora till they had work'd farther upon her, which the Land-Lady began in this manner; he told her that her things were micarried, and he fear'd lot; that he had but little Money her elf, and if the Overeers of the poor (jutly o call'd from their over-looking 'em) hou'd have the leat Supicion of a trange and unmarried Peron, who was entertain'd in her Houe big with Child and o near her time as Bellamora was, he hou'd be troubled, if they cou'd not give Security to the Parih of twenty or thirty Pound that they hou'd not uffer by her, which he cou'd not; or otherwie, he mut be ent to the Houe of Correction, and her Child to a Parih-Nure. This Dicoure one may imagine, was very dreadful to a Peron of her Youth, Beauty, Education, Family and Etate: However, he reolutely proteted, that he had rather undergo all this, than be
expos'd to the Scorn of her Friends and Relations in the Country. The other told her then, that he mut write down to her Uncle a farewell Letter, as if he were jut going aboard to Pacquet-boat for Holland; that he might not end to inquire for her in Town, when he hou'd undertand he was not at her new-married Couin's in the Country, which accordingly he did, keeping her elf a cloe Prioner to her Chamber; where he was daily viited by Fondlove's Siter and the Land-Lady, but by no Soul ele, the firt diembling the Knowledge he had of her Misfortunes. Thus he continued for above three Weeks; not a Servant being uffer'd to enter her Chamber, o much as to make her Bed, let they hou'd take Notice of her great Belly: But for all this Caution, the Secret had taken Wind, by the means of an Attendant of the other Lady below, who had over-heard her peaking of it to her Husband. This oon got out 'o Doors and pread abroad, till it reach'd the long Ears of the Wolves of the Parih; who next day deign'd to give her an ungrateful Viit: But Fondlove, by good Providence, prevented it; who, the Night before, was uher'd into Bellamora's Chamber by his Siter, his Brother-in-Law, and the Land-Lady. At the ight of him he had like to have woon'd away: But he taking her in his Arms, began again, as he was wont to do, with Tears in his Eyes, to beg that he wou'd marry him e'er he was delivered; if not for his, nor her own, yet for the Child's ake, which he hourly expected; that it might not be born out of Wedlock,
and o be made uncapable of inheriting either of their Etates; with a great many more preing Arguments on all ides: To which at lat he conented; and an honet officious Gentleman, whom they had before provided, was call'd up, who made an end of the Dipute: So to Bed they went together that Night; and next Day to the Exchange, for everal pretty Buinees that Ladies in her Condition want. Whilt they were abroad, came the Vermin of the Parih, (I mean, the Overeers of the poor, who eat the Bread from 'em) to earch for a young Black-hair'd Lady (for o was Bellomora) who was either brought to bed, or jut ready to lie down. The Land-Lady hew'd 'em all the Rooms in her Houe, but no uch Lady cou'd be found. At lat he bethought her elf, and led 'em into her Parlour, where he open'd a little Cloet-door, and hew'd 'em her Black Cat that had jut kitten'd; auring 'em, that he hou'd never trouble the Parih as long as he had Rats or Mice in the Houe, and o dimis'd 'em like Logger-heads as they came.
